TALK.START.PARA: —I understand it is the wish of the House to consider the amendments together. There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Johns The Hon G.T.

TALKER.NAME: Mr JOHNS
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State, Assistant Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Public Service Matters)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the amendments be agreed to.

SPEECH.PARA: We are now considering a number of amendments that have been made in the Senate to the Australian Capital Territory Government Service (Consequential Provisions) Bill 1994. Nearly all of these amendments are government amendments. I remind the House that, during the process of negotiation with the ACT government and the trade union movement, I indicated that I would be available to make amendments to the bill, after any negotiations, as it passed through the chambers. That has occurred. We are pleased to propose some amendments to the bill as a result of the negotiations and, indeed, the opposition has proposed an amendment which we did not oppose in the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Let me refer to the amendments which are mainly of a minor and technical nature: firstly, we seek to insert a time frame of 18 months within which proclamation of the act must occur. This is to accommodate comments made on the bill by the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. Secondly, we seek to provide a mechanism for access back to the Australian Public Service for officers who are to become members of the separate service of the ACT on transfer day without the need for a merit test. This mechanism is currently available to officers of the service to enable them to move within the service through the operation of section 50 of the Public Service Act. I might add, in response to some of Senator Hill's comments on the radio this morning, that the opposition moved an amendment which extends access to this provision from 12 months to two years. I had suggested that we would accept the two years but Senator Hill insisted on moving that amendment, which is fine. However, I think it should be placed on the public record that both sides agree that a two-year transitional provision is a reasonable thing.

Thirdly, we seek to make provision for access by the ACT Government Service to the Merit Protection Review Agency on a user pays basis. We made two amendments to the Remuneration Tribunal Act 1973 to provide the capacity for the ACT Legislative Assembly to disallow determinations of the Remuneration Tribunal made in relation to ACT officers.

Fourthly, we wish to provide that the relevant provisions of the Australian Capital Territory Self-Government (Consequential Provisions) Act 1988 commence immediately after the commencement of this bill. This amendment avoids the need for separate proclamation action that would have to be coordinated with the proclamation of this bill. A further two amendments have been included which make provision for the transfer of recreation leave credits for officers appointed to the APS from the ACT service and for officers appointed to the ACT from the Australian Public Service.

Finally, the legislation has been amended to ensure that the mobility rights applying to ACT officers selected for positions in executive departments are applicable on the same basis to ACT officers selected for positions in the parliamentary departments.

We promised to deliver this legislation by 1 July, and we are about to deliver on that promise. I thank the ACT government, particularly its Chief Minister, Rosemary Follett, for its cooperation in a triangular debate between the two governments and the representatives of ACT public servants.

I reiterate that all the conditions held by workers are preserved as those workers move across to the new service. I wish the new ACT Government Service well. Whilst we exist in the same town and we will forever have a special relationship which has been built into this legislation, we are now going our separate ways, and I wish the ACT government and its public service well. I thank all of those officers in my office and the departments who have worked so hard to ensure the passage of this bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition will not be opposing any of these amendments, as they have been the subject of agreement, in most cases, and discussion in another place.I very briefly take the opportunity of joining the Special Minister of State (Mr Johns) in wishing the new public service establishment in the ACT good fortune and success.

PARA.TAB: There remains in this parliament a variety of views about what the appropriate method of management of the affairs of the ACT ought to be. I remain an unredeemed supporter of the municipality principle, but I accept that those who dictate these matters have other views. Those other views having prevailed, obviously the system has to be run properly. If you are going to have what you have now, having a separate public service makes a degree of sense.

I feel constrained to make two comments. I have not been able to find in any of the utterances of government ministers on the establishment of this public service anything to suggest that the odious practice which exists in the Commonwealth Public Service of giving preference to trade unionist will not be carried forward into the ACT public service. I would like some kind of guarantee from the minister that I am mistaken in that belief that there exists a significant degree of preference for trade unionists in the Commonwealth Public Service. That continues to be a source of criticism by the opposition and by many people in the Australian community.

In this context, I was very interested yesterday—or was it the day before?—to hear the minister for health proudly proclaiming that a public opinion survey said that 85 per cent of the Australian community supported Medicare. Members of the opposition were enjoined, on the basis of that, to sing hallelujah and praise to Medicare. I remind the House that public opinion surveys consistently show that over 80 per cent of Australians oppose compulsory unionism and preference for trade unionists, including an almost equal equivalent percentage of trade unionists themselves. If we apply the Medicare principle, I invite you to sing hallelujahs in favour of voluntary unionism and the end of preference in the Public Service.

But that point having been made, there will be another forum for discussion of such matters as the minister's Orwellian guidelines for workplace harassment which have been published recently. They really take the disease of political correctness in this country to demented lengths. The idea that a government bureaucracy should lay down the way in which you invade or not invade the work space of a colleague and, in effect, whom you should invite to your happy hour is quite an interesting proposition and one that in another environment I think the minister was showing very welcome signs of rejecting. Perhaps that debate will give him the opportunity of illuminating us a bit more on the statement he made which attracted so much publicity about a week ago. I thought he was getting very close to the mark with a lot of things, but that is for another debate.

TALKER.NAME: Mr JOHNS
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State, Assistant Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Public Service Matters)

TALK.START.PARA: —The beauty of separating the ACT Public Service from the Commonwealth is that the question of how it operates and controls its public servants will be a matter for it, gloriously, and we will not have to consider that any more.

PARA.TAB: The question of preference for trade unionists is a peculiar one because there is not a preference per se in the Commonwealth Public Service: what there is is an encouragement by the Commonwealth that people ought to be members of trade unions and there ought to be participants, because industrial democracy begs that people participate and there are well accepted forms in which they will. That is usually through trade unions. So I reject any notion that there is some sort of compulsion to operate through trade unions or that some preference is given by the Commonwealth to workers who are trade unionists. What there is is an encouragement. It is a sensible thing to join a trade union. If we are to have a happy hour later today to celebrate this separation of the ACT Public Service, I extend an invitation to the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard).

TALK.START.PARA: —With your indulgence, Mr Speaker: the point I make simply about unionism is that I do not have any quarrel with people being encouraged to join unions, but it is a fact, and it has been documented in this place, that advertisements are published by the Commonwealth Public Service inviting people to apply for jobs and those advertisements state quite openly that preference will be given to people who are members of unions. That is de facto, de jure—any way you want—forcing people. There is no greater compulsion to say to somebody, `If you do not join the union, you do not get the job.' I would be very happy to re-table those documents in this place.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB2.TITLE: Approval of Work: Further Development of HMAS Stirling and Garden Island, WA

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walker The Hon F.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to parliament: Further development of HMAS Stirling, Garden Island, Western Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: HMAS Stirling is located on Garden Island, Cockburn Sound and is 60 kilometres south of Perth in Western Australia. HMAS Stirling provides maintenance, supply and operational support for assigned and visiting warships as well as port berthing, shipside and administrative services.

PARA.TAB: The overall development of HMAS Stirling comprises three stages. This proposal continues the stage two development and will provide additional operational logistic maintenance and training support prior to the planned stage three development.

The public works committee tabled its report on 8 June 1994 recommending the project at an estimated cost of $40.54 million. In its report the committee made a number of recommendations to which the Department of Defence provides the following responses.

The Department of Defence will undertake an investigation into the possible use of a simulated firing range in conjunction with live firings on army ranges in the Perth area. Defence has undertaken to refer this aspect of the proposal back to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works on completion of the study. The Department of Defence will continue to liaise with the Commonwealth Fire Board and state fire authorities in respect of fire protection on projects including the HMAS Stirling development at Garden Island.

The Department of Defence has also agreed to carry out discussions with the National Trust of Australia, Western Australia and the Department of Aboriginal Sites of Western Australia regarding cultural heritage issues and continuing surveys for Aboriginal relics on Garden Island respectively.

In addition, the recommendation that a representative of the non-government environment conservation groups be appointed to the Garden Island Environmental Advisory Committee will be tabled before the state representative at the next meeting of the committee. I would like to thank the committee for its report and I commend the motion to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB2.TITLE: Approval of Work: Australian Embassy Complex, Hanoi, Socialist Republic of Vietnam

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walker The Hon F.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to Parliament: construction of an Australian Embassy complex in Hanoi, Socialist Republic of Vietnam.

SPEECH.PARA: This proposal was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works in two referrals, on 24 March 1994 and 11 May 1994. The committee has now duly reported back to parliament.

PARA.TAB: The main elements of the proposed work are a chancery building; an ambassador's residence; 12 apartments for embassy staff; recreation facilities, including a swimming pool, a multipurpose playing court and a squash court; and landscaping and car parking. The total estimated cost for the works at February 1994 prices is $A23.605 million. There will be no impact on the budget, as funds from the sale of properties in Singapore will cover the cost of the project. Four contracting companies with significant Australian association have been invited to tender for the managing contractor role for the works. Tenders will close on 27 July 1994 and, subject to parliamentary approval, a contractor will be appointed during August.

The Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works has made the following recommendations in its report. Firstly, a need exists to construct a new Australian embassy complex at Hanoi, Socialist Republic of Vietnam, to replace existing unsatisfactory working and living accommodation. Secondly, the committee agrees that the development should include appropriate recreational and sporting facilities. Thirdly, the committee agrees that the existing chancery should be converted to staff accommodation.

Fourthly, the committee accepts the advice from the Overseas Property Group, Department of Administrative Services, that the site when reclaimed will be suitable for the construction of the embassy complex. Fifthly, the committee recommends that the Overseas Property Group undertake a metal detector survey on the site before construction commences as a precaution against the possible presence of unexploded ordnance. The Overseas Property Group will arrange for this survey to be carried out.

Sixthly, the committee recommends that the Overseas Property Group develop a design philosophy for future overseas projects which would enable a sense of Australian identity to be expressed. The Overseas Property Group will state its design philosophy at the next public works committee hearing for an overseas project. Seventhly, the committee recommends that the Overseas Property Group install a solar water system in the residential accommodation. The Overseas Property Group agrees with this recommendation on the basis that the installation will be a showing of Australian technology, even though an economic assessment has not been carried out as yet. However, the Overseas Property Group will carry out an economic assessment of the solar water installation and will advise the public works committee accordingly.

Eighthly, the Overseas Property Group will provide a half-yearly report on the project cost to the public works committee at the same time as a similar report is provided to the Department of Finance. Ninthly, the committee recommends the construction of an Australian embassy complex in Hanoi, Socialist Republic of Vietnam, at an estimated costs of $23.605 million at March 1994 prices.
I thank the committee for its report and commend the motion to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB2.TITLE: Reference: Upgrade of Transonic Wind Tunnel at DSTO, Fishermens Bend, Vic.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: upgrade of transonic wind tunnel at DSTO Fishermens Bend, Vic.

The Defence Science and Technology Organisation's Aeronautical and Maritime Research Laboratory, the AMRL, is headquartered at Fishermens Bend, which is located about seven kilometres west of Melbourne in Victoria. This site accommodates most of the laboratory, whose primary mission is to develop, maintain and exploit, for the benefit of Australian defence, scientific and technological skills in areas central to military aircraft, air vehicles and relevant aspects of weapons.

The upgrade of the transonic wind tunnel at Fishermens Bend is required to more effectively meet, in combination with developing computational fluid dynamics capabilities, current and foreseen defence requirement for aerodynamic data in the transonic speed range. The demands for data to support the operation of high performance aircraft such as the FA18 and the F111 have outstripped the capability of existing wind tunnels, which are obsolete.

Given the increasing performance of modern aircraft and weapons systems, failure to address the shortcomings of the current facilities will jeopardise DSTO's ability to provide effective support to the ADF in the priority area of aerodynamic testing in the next century. The project proposes replacement or upgrade of a range of components, including compressor system, compressor drive, tunnel test section, installation of a new cooling system, a new plenum evacuation system and a new model support system. It is anticipated that construction will start in February of 1995 and continue until mid-1996. The estimated cost of the project is $12.7 million in December 1993 prices. I commend the motion to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB2.TITLE: Reference: New Laboratory Complex at DSTO Salisbury, SA

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walker The Hon F.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: New laboratory complex at DSTO Salisbury, SA.

SPEECH.PARA: DSTO Salisbury is located 22 kilometres north of Adelaide in South Australia. It accommodates DTSO's electronics and surveillance research laboratory, ESRL, which primarily undertakes research into electronic based defence systems. The present research facilities are spread over 1.39 hectares and about 650 buildings, many of which were constructed for the manufacture of explosives in 1940.

PARA.TAB: The proposal will concentrate ESRL activities in a 280 hectare site and provide a new laboratory complex which will accommodate 545 research and support staff. It is anticipated that construction will start in February 1995 and continue until mid-1997. The estimated outturn cost of the project is $50.714 million. I commend the motion to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB2.TITLE: Reference: Upgrading of Accommodation at HMAS Watson, NSW

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walker The Hon F.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Upgrading of accommodation at HMAS Watson, NSW.

SPEECH.PARA: HMAS Watson is located on a 15-hectare site at Watsons Bay, 13 kilometres east of Sydney in New South Wales. It is a major training establishment and carries out specialist warfare and navigational training for navy personnel. Defence infrastructure has been located at Watsons Bay since the 1870s but most of the buildings used by HMAS Watson were built in the 1950s and now need to be upgraded to meet current occupancy standards.

PARA.TAB: The proposal will provide new or upgraded living in accommodation for 346 service personnel, additional office space and classrooms, improved recreation facilities and additional parking space, accommodation for a total of 359 staff and 241 trainees is required. It is anticipated that construction will start in February of 1995 and continue until late 1996. The estimated outturn cost of the project is $18.81 million. I commend the motion to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB2.TITLE: Reference: Development of 2 Field Hospital at Enoggera, Qld

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walker The Hon F.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Development of 2 Field Hospital at Enoggera, Qld.

SPEECH.PARA: Enoggera is a suburb of Brisbane, and Gallipoli Barracks houses the army's largest concentration of units in south Queensland. It houses headquarters, 1st Division, 6th Brigade, consisting of integrated regular and reserve units, and a number of training, logistic and administrative units. The barracks area is approximately 200 hectares, with an adjoining close training area of a further 450 hectares. As a posting locality, Enoggera is one of the more popular for families and service personnel alike.

PARA.TAB: This proposal is to provide new facilities for 2 field hospital, which is an army land force unit. These new facilities will include accommodation for an operational army hospital with a 50-bed capacity and associated services. The proposal will also provide logistic, administrative, training and living-in accommodation facilities.

The field hospital provides deployable medical support to the field army while on training or operations. When not deployed, the unit provides limited health care to service personnel in the south east Queensland area. The existing substandard facilities at Kelvin Grove and Yeronga will be replaced as a result of this proposal. It is anticipated that construction will commence in early 1995 and be completed by early 1997. The estimated outturn cost for this proposal is $29.2 million. I commend the motion to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB2.TITLE: Reference: Stage 2 Redevelopment of Royal Military College, Duntroon, ACT

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walker The Hon F.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Stage 2 redevelopment of the Royal Military College, Duntroon, ACT.

SPEECH.PARA: The Royal Military College is the premier institution for the training of officers for the Australian Army. It trains both men and women in the skills required to lead the army into the next century. These skills include leadership, tactics, military law and administrative procedures. The existing facilities under consideration for redevelopment are in varying states of repair. This proposal will provide modern and functional facilities to support the training objectives of the college. It will be a continuation of the stage 1 redevelopment, which upgraded the cadet accommodation, messing facilities, training areas and engineering services.

PARA.TAB: This proposal will include a new logistics complex and headquarters building, along with extensions to the gymnasium, officers' mess, military instruction block and medical centre. The playing fields and ovals will be upgraded, along with the adjustments to the existing road network to provide safer and more efficient traffic circulation. It is anticipated that construction will commence in December 1994 and be completed by December 1997. The estimated outturn cost for this proposal is $28.7 million. I commend the motion to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB2.TITLE: Reference: Midlife Upgrade of Blamey Barracks, Kapooka, NSW

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walker The Hon F.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Midlife upgrade of Blamey Barracks, Kapooka, NSW.

SPEECH.PARA: The training of army recruits has been conducted at Kapooka since 1951 and the majority of the current facilities were constructed in 1965-66. The 1st recruit training battalion, which is located at Kapooka, is the only regular army recruit training institution and is also responsible for training recruits for the ready reserve. It is proposed to refurbish the existing facilities and construct minor extensions at an estimated outturn cost of $21.5 million. The upgrade will extend the life of the barracks for a further 25 years.

PARA.TAB: The objective of this proposal is to upgrade facilities at Kapooka to cater for improved instructional and learning concepts, the requirement to be more accountable for recruit's wellbeing, defined minimum standards of living accommodation, and an increase in the female to male ratios, both in staff and recruits. It is proposed to commence the works in January 1995 and to have the task completed by the end of 1996. The recruit training battalion will continue to be fully functional throughout the refurbishment. I commend the motion to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB2.TITLE: Reference: Chancery at Port Moresby, Papua New Guinea

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walker The Hon F.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Construction of a new chancery at Port Moresby, Papua New Guinea.

SPEECH.PARA: This proposal to be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works comprises a construction of a new five-level purpose built chancery; office spaces; display spaces; workshops; storage areas; staff amenities; external plant facilities and service building; a grassed playing area with associated facilities, including toilets, showers and change room; staff and visitor car parking; associated site works and services; and landscaping.

PARA.TAB: The present chancery was constructed in 1975-76 as a temporary building to the structural codes applicable then to Papua New Guinea. A structural evaluation conducted whilst examining the chancery building for rearrangements to accommodate increased AIDAB staffing to handle program aid to Papua New Guinea revealed that the structure does not conform to current design codes for seismic performance and could be damaged if the design earthquake occurred.

Apart from its structural problems, the existing chancery has become run-down and requires a major service upgrade. It does not meet the latest security requirements; office layouts are inefficient; and the building requires significant refurbishment. The temporary chancery was not planned to cater for present staffing levels and the current functions of the High Commission. The economic and life cycle analysis of options indicate clearly that a new building on a new site and selling the existing chancery is the most advantageous and economic course of action.

The building will be of a reinforced concrete framed structure with sheer walls. The structural system will ensure a high level of seismic resistance, with minimum damage to the internal partitioning and fittings. The new chancery is being planned to accord with current and future technology requirements of the user, and the layout will provide for future expansion. The climatic condition, utilities availability and commercial conditions in Port Moresby have been considered in the design of the building to minimise ongoing energy costs. Australian and New Zealand firms based in Port Moresby with the necessary expertise in the construction of this type will be given the opportunity to tender.

Generally, the design of the buildings will make the maximum use possible of Australian and New Zealand products and materials. The total cost of this project is estimated at $22.26 million, based on February 1994 prices. I table the plans of the proposed development. I commend this motion to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB2.TITLE: Reference: Housing Development, Bligh Park, NSW

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walker The Hon F.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Housing development, Bligh Park, NSW.

SPEECH.PARA: Bligh Park is situated about five kilometres south of Windsor. Subject to the approval of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works, the Defence Housing Authority proposes to acquire between 50 and 65 residential building allotments in a planned extension to the Bligh Park residential estate near Windsor.

PARA.TAB: The residential development is being carried out by a joint venture, involving Hawkesbury Council and Landcom. The joint venture has been in operation since the initial development of Bligh Park began in 1984. Landcom is the residential property development section of the Property Services Group of the New South Wales state government—created by one of the finest ministers for housing that New South Wales ever had. The Bligh Park estate will eventually comprise 2,225 dwellings. The Defence Housing Authority currently has 92 properties in the estate that services families. The authority considers the area to be an ideal location as it is located about seven kilometres from the Richmond RAAF base.

The residential allotments in precinct 29 of the development are expected to be available in about October 1994. The anticipated cost of acquiring 50 residential allotments is about $3.25 million. This expenditure is expected to be incurred in the financial year 1994-95. The combined project costs for 50 houses, including allotments, is estimated to be $8.5 million. I table the drawings and commend the motion to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Debate resumed from 28 June, on the following papers presented by Mr Keating:

PROCTEXT.PARA: Working Nation—ministerial statement and papers
and on motion by Mr Beazley:

PARA.TAB: That the House take note of the papers.

TALK.START.PARA: —This debate relates to the government's white paper on employment entitled Working Nation. I am reminded at the outset that yesterday in question time the Treasurer (Mr Willis) was in a Shakespearian mode and was quoting lines from Macbeth. At the time, I thought about what he had to say and about this paper. I thought there was a much more apt quotation from Shakespeare, one which summed up not only the comments of the Treasurer yesterday but also the whole approach of this government to the problem of unemployment and the entire approach of the so-called Working Nation document. The line I refer to is the one where Shakespeare talks about a great deal of sound and fury signifying nothing.

PARA.TAB: What we have in this document and in the approach which the government has taken is yet another illustration of government by illusion. This government issued a document some time ago entitled One Nation but it has done more than any other government in the history of this federation to create two nations. The gap between the rich and the poor in this country has grown considerably over the last decade. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) comes into this place at question time and seeks to blame the Fraser government, the Menzies government. If he were to go on for long enough, he would probably blame Lord Melbourne, Lord Bruce, Alfred Deakin or Governor Macquarie. No matter how often he comes in here and says, `They are not our problems; they are the problems of someone in past,' we know that the reality is that this situation has occurred as a result of this government's policies.

If there is one statistic that indicates the size of the problem that this government is faced with, it is that a decade ago the top one per cent of earners in Australia earned as much as the bottom 11 per cent. Today, the top one per cent earn as much as the bottom 21 per cent. The gap between the rich and the poor in this country under this government and under the Prime Minister who sits opposite has risen by that amount. Yet the Prime Minister has the cheek to come into this place and say to the Australian people, `This is one nation.' The reality is that Australia is two nations.

TALK.START.PARA: —So much for social justice.

—As my learned colleague says, `So much for the social justice.' When we look at this document we find that once again we have government by illusion. This document is entitled Working Nation. We are coming out of the worst recession this country has had in 60 years. When we are working for officially a million unemployed Australians and probably another million as well who are not officially recorded, the concept of working is once again an illusion. The government is led by an arrogant Prime Minister who says that this document is about a working nation. It is no more about a working nation than the previous document was about one nation. Once again it illustrates that the government at the present time is concerned about illusion and perception.

PARA.TAB: Honourable members will remember what the Prime Minister said on the eve of the last election in a secretly taped conversation with some of his staff members and close confidantes in a restaurant in Sydney. He said, `We've been weaving a giant tale', creating an illusion and a perception for the Australian people to believe that we are doing something to bring the nation together and put people back into work. The reality is that that is simply not happening.

The Working Nation document talks about expending $6.5 billion but, when we break that figure down and look at what is actually being spent each year, we find that in this first year about $1.3 billion is being spent, rising to about $1.5 billion in the second year. Whether the $6.5 billion is ever spent still remains to be seen. It could well be like the tax cuts that we were promised which have been put on the never-never. Honourable members will remember the second round of tax cuts which were, in the words of the Prime Minister, l-a-w, law. Of course, we are not going to see the second round of those tax cuts. They are on the never-never. Who knows what will happen with the expenditure under this so-called Working Nation document?

This morning I would like to briefly refer to two examples which illustrate this notion of a government which is concerned about pereception and illusion and which is not concerned about the real outcomes of policies. Let us take one simple example of its approach to family policy. The reality is that there is no comprehensive family policy in Australia that deals with enhancing families and that tries to affirm the commitment which the overwhelming majority of Australians aspire to and, even when they fail, seek out again.

I refer to the parenting allowance, which was much vaunted by the government and which is mentioned in the Working Nation document. The so-called parenting allowance is largely an illusion. In the white paper, the government announced that it will provide a parenting allowance of up to $132.65 per week for families with only one parent employed. It sounds fine; it sounds great. It sounds like the sort of policy that one would seek to support. From what we are told, it is fine. But what are we not told about it?

We are not told that it will apply to only 118,000 Australians, of about two million Australian households, most of whom will receive far less than $133 per week. We are not told that an unemployed married couple on either jobstart or newstart currently receives a maximum of $265.30 per week. Under these proposals, each person will receive $132.65 per week. Two times $132.65 adds up to $265.30, which is the same amount that they would have received before as a married couple.

So, on the surface, it sounds fine. It sounds like a great initiative which is doing something for parents and families in this country. But, when we add up the figures, we see that in reality it is not making much of a substantial change at all. It will certainly advantage some in cases where there is unemployment in families. But, if we were to believe the rhetoric about this, we would think that it would result in large-scale changes for Australian families across the nation, but it does nothing of the sort.

The same thing can be said about the whole area of training and employment. When the green paper was released, there was at last some hope that there was a recognition of the problems that had occurred in training over the last decade. For example, the committee stated that vocational training had been neglected, that existing arrangements had a number of shortcomings and that there were a number of deficiencies in the current system. But, when one looks at the response in the white paper, one sees that it fails in most of the major areas.

The white paper fails to provide anywhere near the number of apprenticeships necessary to replenish the skills of the Australian work force, particularly our Australian youth. What happened to apprenticeships over the last few years? In the three years between 1989-90 and 1991-92, the number of apprenticeships in this country fell from 62,000 to just over 38,000. That is an illustration of the lack of training being provided to the youth of this country.

The government says that it is doing something in the area of TAFE and vocational education and training which will improve the training standards. But when one looks closely at the figures for TAFE and for vocational education and training, no better picture is painted than this: participation rates in TAFE for students aged 17 to 24 years was the same in 1992 as it was in 1984. The total TAFE enrolments as a percentage of total enrolments by age actually declined in Australia between 1985 and 1991. As the federal government finally conceded last year, the number of 17- to 24-year-olds with trade qualifications had fallen by 11 per cent since 1983. So much for the great commitment to vocational education and training through TAFE.

If one looks at the Commonwealth's commitment to funding in this area, one sees that from 1983-84 onwards, funding dropped from over $400 million to just over $200 million. Yes, it has been increased in the last 12 months. But there was a period of some six or seven years where the Commonwealth neglected its commitment to vocational education and training, to the skills of our youth and to the opportunities of getting jobs, which is what this paper is meant to be about. The amount of funding went down, not up. Any efforts that are made now are basically trying to catch up on a situation which was allowed to deteriorate over that period of time.

The paper does nothing to address the high dropout rates from TAFE and the Australian traineeship system. It concedes, for example, that the government has no reliable information on the literacy standards of school children, largely because teacher unions around the country have successfully blocked testing of children up until now. What is the case if parents in this country want to know how their children are getting on at school? I can speak from experience as I have three primary school age children; one has just started secondary school. I have the greatest admiration for the teachers in the schools which they attend. How can we as parents get some objective assessment of how our children are going in schools across the country? How do we know whether our children are performing as well as others in the class, except from the say-so of the teachers, and how do we know that that class is performing as well as a class in the school down the road? In any event, how do we know that the standards across the country are as good as we might expect in a country which is told that it has to be and does need to be internationally competitive? How do we know if we do not ask the questions?

Until recently, the suggestion that we might have some form of objective assessment of primary school age children in this country has met with delirious cries of outrage, largely emanating from teacher unions. It is simply not good enough. It is not good enough for parents, it is not good enough for the country, and it is selling short Australian school children who want the best opportunity and the best chances to get on with their life and to obtain skills.

If honourable members want an example of an assessment that skills have gone backwards, last year the professors of mathematics at both Melbourne and Monash universities said that the standard of first year mathematics students at those universities had gone backwards by one year over the space of the last three years. If those universities got their students, at the end of the first year, to the same standard in mathematics as students three years previously had been when they came to university, they thought they were doing a good job. Just recently, one of the senior academics from Monash University suggested that we need a preliminary year to tertiary education so that students can be brought up to the standard which they might be expected to achieve at university. Is that not an indication of the problem that we are facing?

What we have in this document is once again government by illusion, government by deception, government of creating the giant tale that the Prime Minister talks about. It reminds me of my daughter who creates fantasies and talks to herself when she plays with dolls. The problem here though is that what the Prime Minister and this government are playing around with is not dolls but real people in Australia.

The government seems to have lost the plot. It thinks that this is just a matter of creating the perception that things will be all right and people will believe it. The Treasurer yesterday was wont to quote Shakespeare, and I reminded the House earlier that a lot of sound and fury signifying nothing was perhaps more appropriate. In the case of the Prime Minister, again, he is a man of illusion, and perhaps another Shakespearian quote is relevant: `A poor player, that who struts and frets his hour upon the stage. And then is heard no more.' The Australian people will rejoice when that day comes.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to add my comments to the discussion on the Working Nation statement, which was presented, I think, on 4 May. The paper provides a comprehensive program to boost jobs growth, increase the skills formation in the work force and ensure the long-term unemployed are not left behind during the economic recovery. The honourable member for Menzies (Mr Andrews) made much about alluding to the illusion in his discussion of what he saw as being policy outcomes from this government. Unfortunately, most of his spin was essentially quite negative. Even I would look forward to hearing some policies which might come from the opposition in a positive way.

PARA.TAB: The package is designed to meet both the social and economic needs of the nation, to get the whole community working towards that goal of securing jobs and to get the unemployed back to work. After all, it is the condition of the labour market which has driven the government to produce the white paper. I feel that there are imaginative policies and programs that are involved in this white paper. The paper builds on the information and the knowledge that the government already has through its previous and continued implementation of its labour market programs, which have been consistently attacked by the opposition.

As well, during the last election in my electorate the campaign very much focused on some of the labour market programs. I am delighted that the electorate was aware of the good work that the labour market programs do for the north coast. Hence, I and my colleague the honourable member for Page (Mr Harry Woods) were returned. I have no doubt that those labour market programs, and the way people perceive them, benefit not only those people who are in the programs but also those people who benefit indirectly from them and the initiatives in place—the employers and other members of the community.

Much has been said about the policy settings of the economy, and certainly they are in place for high economic and employment growth while maintaining low inflation. There has been much angst of late about interest rates, but I would suggest that we are capable of sustaining the high rates of economic growth—and the white paper certainly puts forward further reforms to achieve this.

There is no doubt that if we are to have an efficient economy, an efficient society, it is imperative that even the barefaced economists, or the red-necked economists—or whatever other term I might like to use to describe some of the pragmatists and hard-headed economists—recognise that efficient use must be made of the labour pool which is available, and having 10 per cent of people stay or remain in unemployment is not one of those efficiencies.

Working Nation is certainly about assisting the economy back into efficiency. It is more than being cool or cold and looking simply at the use of labour; it is about equity, it is about social justice and it is about assisting families and people to maintain their dignity and to contribute positively to society in their working life.

One of the major areas that I find commendable within Working Nation is, as I mentioned, the way that it has picked up the good information and good work that have already been put in place with our labour market programs and the work that has been done to assist regions of Australia. Various commentators have felt that we have not done enough. Some have felt that we have not gone in the right direction. But I feel that the key elements of regional development are addressed through the white paper. I feel that these key elements are certainly going to assist the north coast as a typical regional area. I will come to that very shortly in a more deliberate sense.

Some of the key points that will be of assistance to regions will be increasing financing options for business and regions. In other words, there will be the opening up of finance through the Commonwealth Development Bank and the reduction of the tax on PDFs from 25 to 15 per cent, which is very attractive to local investors. I will make more comments about the PDF scheme very shortly.

The work in facilitating infrastructure development through the regional infrastructure fund of $70 million is a great impetus to regions within Australia. I feel that the comments on an $80 million grant for the best practice program simply speak for themselves; nearly all of them have been quite positive.

The Austrade and the Ausindustry initiatives, which are designed to promote export activity, will be picked up. I know that they are already being picked up in my area. Austrade has already been of much assistance to a number of industries on the north coast. I look forward to assisting other industries in working with Ausindustry to expand the nature of their business. There are changes to the Department of Social Security system to improve program delivery so that looking for work, be it part-time or casual work, is attractive. Obviously, I will make further comments on the job compact very shortly.

The federal government has certainly created a framework that regional areas are able to adapt to their specific needs. I certainly have confidence in the ability, talent and skills that lie in the north coast and/or in any region. As a member of one or two government committees, including the House of Representatives Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts, I have had the pleasure of visiting quite a few regions on inspections and inquiries. I have picked up the feeling that there is the ability, talent and the skills in many parts of Australia to capitalise on the regional development ideas in the white paper. I certainly know that that is so in my area of the north coast.

The strong and committed leadership is there. It is continuing to strive forward. We have given assistance to these organisations to enable them to capitalise on what is available. Regional development does not come just from the top down. As I have mentioned, the skills are there so that it can come from the bottom up. If possible, other regions can model themselves on the examples of the two regions in Working Nation. They indicate that there has to be a bottom up approach. Working Nation makes that feasible.

Despite the structural unemployment problems, the far north coast region is growing. It is certainly one of the fastest growing regions in population terms in New South Wales and/or Australia. The region is very confident of its future. The best people to drive that regional development are certainly the local people and those investing locally and creating local jobs for the future of the region. Any notion of regional development involving vast amounts of government subsidies of one sort or other simply fall flat when those government subsidies are withdrawn. So it is imperative that the development come from within the region, recognising the strengths that are there and building on what is already in the region. That has already occurred in a number of regions.

Apart from the two that were mentioned in the Working Nation statement I pay tribute to the region of greater Taree, which has achieved that end on its own. It did not start just one or two years ago; it is one of those long-term plans which I think all regions have to take on board. It started 10 to 15 years ago, if not more, and from that slow, steady growth we now have a region which has quite a number of manufacturing jobs within that local economy. If there was ever an example I would point anyone to it is that area. I am also moving my own area towards that end very slowly.

These things do take a little time to put in place. It takes time for people to realise that they can make gains and where they can make gains. At times they go on the back foot a little when they find that they have made some mistakes, but you cannot go forward without making one or two mistakes. Nevertheless, I think the north coast area is quite capable of going forward. Moves are afoot, with a bit of assistance from me, to establish and ascertain local support for the establishment of a pooled development fund.

Some time ago, Bronwyn Anderson and the Chamber of Manufactures located at Ballina attempted to run a seminar on attracting finance to a region. They found that it was very difficult. Nevertheless, some positive feedback came from that early attempt. I understand that they will be having a second seminar, having learned some lessons, to try to push that forward again.

The pooled development idea for the north coast has already been raised with NOREDO, the Northern Region Economic Development Organisation, at a meeting in Grafton last week. It also raised the idea at its meeting. I feel that, with the support of NOREDO and other local organisations, with what the Chamber of Manufactures was trying to do some time ago and with what we can achieve by taking up some of the ideas in the Working Nation paper, we will go a long way towards achieving a positive outcome for the north coast. I feel that the north coast is certainly ready to take up the challenge.

I mentioned the positive feeling which is starting to develop amongst some of the regions, particularly the north coast. NOREDO was able to obtain a grant of some $40,000 for an area consultative committee to oversee some of the training and employment initiatives that are being put in place. As its name suggests, it is a diverse organisation. I commend the work of the chairman of that organisation, Dr Jim Gallagher. I also commend the good work of the north coast unions in supporting the employers and trainers in what they have to do to actually get people into these training positions.

I might digress a little and mention that the north coast is one of the first areas to get its jobskills programs under way. Essentially it was done with the cooperation of the employers and the unions in terms of what was required to ensure that training in those jobskills positions was real and that it was something which provided the people with skills. I also want to give some examples of where these jobskills positions are and how they have progressed.

I must also mention the work of people such as Mark Jackson, who was one of the first people involved in the jobskills position. He now works for Greening Australia and now it has started to take people through the regional environment employment program, REEP. Essentially, that program was devised by Greening Australia. The north coast is benefiting at the moment from some 250 places provided through the LEAP jobskills program. It is going a long way towards assisting worthy environmental projects both in the catchment areas of the rivers and along the coast, particularly dune care work.

I attended one of those dune care organisations just two or three weeks ago, at Shelly Beach near Ballina. The participants in the scheme were working with the local dune care group to improve the dunes along the coastline. That is not only improving their work skills but also assisting tourism growth around that area.

Another project which I recently had the pleasure of seeing completed was at North Tumbulgum near Murwillumbah and at Bray Park where students in the program were restoring historic grave sites in a cemetery. It probably does not sound like a very exciting program, but the fact is that when they finished that program some three quarters of those people had actually got themselves into employment within a month. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Working Nation white paper on employment and growth is really an indictment of this Labor government, which stands guilty both of ignoring the increasing national problem of structural long-term unemployment and of worsening it by its unintelligent, sectarian policy responses. One has to draw this conclusion because, by the government's own admission, it will be the business sector, in particular the small and medium sized business sector, that will drive this economy out of the recession.

PARA.TAB: Yet, when the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) set up the original working committee to produce the forerunner to the white paper, namely the green paper, we saw that the committee was formed of bureaucrats and academics. I recognise the tremendous input that academics and bureaucrats can have in looking at this nation's most serious problem; however, one would have thought that if, as the government stated, small business was going to play a very significant role in driving this country out of recession and driving the economic engine the government would have included in that working committee at least some people from industry and the commercial sector. But that was not the case. So I think this is a very cynical exercise. It is not about creating or providing jobs for people. It is simply about training or retraining people for jobs that simply do not exist.

Unemployment has become a massive national cost burden and a human tragedy. Despite the economic upturn since the beginning of last year, the official unemployment rate stands at just under 10 per cent, or around 900,000 Australians, of whom 350,000 have been unemployed for more than 12 months. A recovery rate at the current four per cent each year sustained for the remainder of the decade will cut the unemployment rate to only seven per cent at best. To reduce it to five per cent requires an annual growth of between five per cent and six per cent, and that is clearly beyond Australia's possibility while this government remains in office.

On 26 April, one of this government's own members, the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore), admitted that in addition to the almost one million people registered as jobless, another 750,000 Australians desire to work but stand outside the labour force. What is worrying more and more Australians and should worry this government is the fact that successive recessions punctuating periods of growth—perhaps we ought to be reversing this—leave Australia with a rising unemployment base. Should the policies of this government subject us to another recession, then we can anticipate a 14 per cent unemployment rate by the end of the century with more and more families in which no-one holds a full-time job.

It is necessary to look beyond the bald unemployment rate because during the years of growth from 1983 to 1989, although 1.6 million jobs were created, the number of unemployed fell by only 300,000. We had a situation where out of every five jobs created three were taken up by growth of the working population, one by a new entrant to the labour force and one by a previously unemployed person. The pattern is a repeating one since December 1992, with 211,000 new jobs but a fall of only 44,000 in the total number of unemployed.

In 1978, when unemployment exceeding seven per cent was seen as unacceptably high, the mean duration of unemployment was eight weeks. In 1993 it had risen to 33 weeks, and 40 per cent of the unemployed had been without a job for more than 12 months. It cannot be stressed enough that this is a tragedy not only for thousands of individuals who see themselves as permanently excluded from work and thereby socially marginalised, as well as materially deprived, but for Australian society, when a growing number of its citizens have no experience of the work ethic and can lack all sense of community.

It is alarming that of the three lowest income deciles in Australia very little income derives from wages or salaries. Among the poorest 20 per cent of Australians there are only 0.2 per cent employed people per household, compared with the national average of 1.2, and 2.5 among the richest 10 per cent. Even when we make allowance for aged pensioners, there are thousands of Australian children growing up in households where no-one in the household has a job. The extent of the problem can be seen in the attrition rates in some instances of subsidised employment with voluntary organisations, when applicants have been demoralised and the organisation finds that it has to act as a family support agency for these participants. More quantifiable is the total monetary cost of unemployment, estimated at between $16 billion and $25 billion by the committee on employment opportunities.

Unemployment benefits that cost 15 per cent of the federal education budget in 1974-75, then considered a very bad year for unemployment, compare with the equivalent of 82 per cent of the education budget in 1992-93. The only response that we get from this Labor government is more training and more subsidised jobs. The $1.3 billion spent on labour market programs and on a CES that in 1989 filled 30 per cent of job vacancies and now fills only 17 per cent is to be increased yet further. With spending up from $400 million in 1989, there are still 230,000 Australians who used labour market programs yet could not find work or training.

Throw money at the problem and it will go away; train the long-term unemployed and the unskilled school leaver for jobs that do not exist or that will be taken up by those whose more skilled occupations have disappeared—these are the kinds of solutions that we are seeing from this white paper. All that we will ultimately have are the best trained unemployed and low paid workers in the Asia-Pacific region. We may also look forward to tinkering with the statistics so that the replacement of jobsearch by Austudy for those under 18 could conveniently remove 37,000 people from the unemployment statistics.

TALK.START.PARA: —What a con.

—Exactly; we have been conned. Overseas experience shows that there is no ready excuse. Unemployment last year in the United States, despite a recession, was seven per cent, and it was only 2.5 per cent in Japan, which considers that it has serious problems. The productivity growth of Australia since 1983 has been the worst in the OECD, and investment is down to 19 per cent of GDP—the lowest figure for 40 years. The last people who should be blamed for this are either the wage earners of Australia, who have been working harder and longer for reduced real wages, or the wealth creators, who have been throttled by taxation and oncosts.

PARA.TAB: Low productivity is all about a government that does nothing to encourage fuller utilisation of capital equipment, not grasping that shift work is preferable to unemployment and takes pressure off the existing work force and that does not worry unduly that such near neighbours as Thailand, Malaysia and Indonesia take less than two per cent of their imports from us. It is also a government that brutally adds to labour oncosts by its taxation and industrial policies so that worldwide growth in employment becomes certain to pass Australia by.

Has this Labor government ever stopped to think that if Australia attracted a mere 1.5 per cent of the 60 million jobs created worldwide each year then we would smash our unemployment problem? This government brags about training for non-existent jobs but has dragged its feet on micro-economic reform so that in 1992 our waterfront was still moving only 18.7 containers an hour, compared with 20.7 in New Zealand and 26.7 in the United States. According to the Business Council of Australia, in the same year only 24 per cent of the potential gains from transport reform had been realised. The 1993 Industry Commission report cited only 11 reforms by this government, compared with 271 reforms at the state level.

This is a government that cheerfully presides over a national savings rate of 18 per cent of national income, compared with 33 per cent in east Asian economies. This is a government that has added $38.7 billion to national dissaving in three budget deficits since it abandoned surpluses after 1991 and, on its own projections of supposed fiscal responsibility, will add another $28.4 billion to national deficits over the next three years. This is a government that has now amassed a $56 billion public debt, which the government's own 1994-95 budget projects will lift to $95 billion within two years. This is a government that squeezes the states to improve its own financial situation at their expense, as has been highlighted by one of its own members, the honourable member for Fraser.

This Labor government is mocking the thousands of unemployed Australians by funding its vaunted training programs through a taxation regime that increases business costs and thus discourages job growth. It has been estimated by a study at Curtin University that 96 per cent of Australia's business enterprises spend more on compliance costs than they remit in taxation. This is clearly madness. Ninety per cent of employers paying the fringe benefits tax lose an additional 42 per cent in administration costs, and 64 per cent of such firms need to hire outside experts to administer the fringe benefits tax arrangements.

The superannuation guarantee charge costs the private sector more and more and is of scant benefit to low paid workers, despite the government's pathetic efforts, announced by the Treasurer (Mr Willis) yesterday, to redress the legislation that has not delivered the benefits to those it claims to assist. This government refuses to assist the states to abolish payroll tax, yet the honourable member for Fraser vindicates the coalition argument of the last election by saying that abolition of this tax would create an additional 100,000 jobs. The training guarantee levy has continued to harass private enterprise through the iniquitous practice of using the tax system to impose regulation. Despite the scheme's failure, the government is so paralysed it can only provide legislation to this House to suspend this measure rather than to repeal it.

The capacity of the private sector to create jobs is steadily thwarted by regulation, with the amount of deregulated legislation, rules and disallowable instruments increasing along with the growth in unemployment. In 1982-83, 703 such measures were promulgated. In 1991-92, it had increased to 1,543 pieces of regulation, legislation or whatever, all impeding the growth and development of this nation's business sector.

The past decade has seen an extra 30,000 pages of new statutes. Whereas the entirety of federal legislation prior to 1973 could be contained in a metre of bound volumes, another metre is now added every few years. So much of this increases the regulatory environment for the business sector. Above all, this Labor government relies on a healthy and developing economy to deliver job growth but at every stage it has been prepared to sacrifice growth when it conflicts with the supreme vested interests of the ACTU. No less a person than Anna Booth of the ACTU boasted on 20 April that, although private sector unionisation might well fall below 20 per cent, the ACTU would retain its position of dominance by imposing new work conditions on the private sector.

This government is an active partner in a process whereby a minority organisation has its ideology imposed upon the great majority of employees who choose not to support it, and draws its strength from a protected public sector. Small business that is 95 per cent non-unionised is the victim of this destructive process. This cosy partnership may have held down real wages since 1983 but it has only added to labour on-costs and hampered Australia's ability to increase its productivity. Centralised wage fixation continues to impose its dead hand, and the boast of this government as to 1,600 enterprise agreements looks hollow when we consider that there are 904,249 Australian business enterprises in the private sector.

The small businesses that now employ 54 per cent of private sector non-agricultural employees have, thanks to the subservience of this government to the ACTU, lost much of their legislative protection from secondary boycotts and are all the more vulnerable to anti-employment union pressure. This government has joined 17 nations, notably the subsistence economies of Malawi and Zaire, in adopting ILO conventions on the dismissal of workers and has used an international convention to impose upon Australian business and people a process whereby the dismissal of unproductive workers will become more difficult and more expensive.

Yet another ALP-ACTU sweetheart deal ignores the fact that fewer businesses will now be prepared to take the risk of hiring new permanent staff. The interests of the jobless are being sacrificed to those of existing and often less competent employees. Until we have a government prepared to uphold the interests of job creators and of jobless Australians against this selfish and increasingly unrepresentative power structure, all the training programs and subsidised employment schemes in the world will do nothing but plough the sands.

TALK.START.PARA: —This morning we are discussing the white paper entitled Working Nation which sets out the blueprint for this government's economic, industrial and investment policies for the next decade. In so many ways, what we do for the remainder of this decade will determine what we can do as a nation for the next century. The challenge for the government today is to put in place policies that will foster sustained growth and help create jobs for all Australians. In some instances, particularly with the long-term unemployed, that requires direct involvement by the government. The white paper Working Nation has set out specific measures to this end.

PARA.TAB: This government does not want to have two Australian societies—the haves and the have nots. We want one Australian community, we want one nation, working together for the same ends. Basically, it is the Australian people and the firms they work who hold the key to our future economic success and prosperity. The government can do many things to set up the economy for strong growth but, ultimately, it is the success of Australian firms that will determine our living standards in the 21st century. The success of Australian firms will determine whether we become two societies or remain one community. The government has a role to play, but in industry policy it is a facilitating role.

I would like to concentrate my comments this morning on the industry policy initiatives and investment policies contained in Working Nation. Industry policy is about building competitive firms and a competitive environment in which these firms can flourish. The two goals of the industry policy contained in Working Nation are: building competitive firms and building a competitive environment in which these firms can flourish.

We must lift performance in all areas of our economy. We need to focus on the factors critical to success in the global marketplace. We need to focus on innovation, uptake of new technology and business improvement, backed up with decisive leadership and a strong export push, particularly in the Asia-Pacific region. The emphasis in all of this is not on particular industries; it is on competitive enterprises in every sector of the economy. Innovation is the key to economic growth. At an enterprise level, innovation enhances a firm's competitiveness and its potential for growth. In the most successful firms, innovation touches upon every aspect of operations. For some firms, however, especially the smaller ones, there are impediments to innovation. Accordingly, the government will spend almost $120 million on promoting innovation.

The government will ease the eligibility requirements for the 150 per cent taxation concession for research and development. Thresholds will be reduced to allow greater access for small and medium sized companies. We will also provide a support scheme for specific early commercialisation in small, high technology firms. While research and development can deliver substantial returns, the benefits of technology diffusion can be twice as large. Yet most Australian firms are three to eight years behind their international competitors in technology uptake.

In the Working Nation statement, the government introduced a number of initiatives designed to boost enterprise competitiveness by accelerating the uptake of technology, particularly in small to medium sized companies. These initiatives include the formation of a national technology access and diffusion network—a network which will strengthen the links between business users, science agencies, and research and technology centres.

Australia's scientific base is a rich source of innovation for the development of new products and processes. The government will continue to nurture science conducted in the public interest. We want to see more of the nation's research dollar find its way into commercially viable outcomes. The government will increase the base funding for our three key scientific institutions and will establish a national research facilities program.

If Australia is to be a vital exporting nation, the relationships between firms, customers and suppliers must be strong. The past isolation of Australian industry behind the protectionist wall prevented many of these critical linkages developing. Accordingly, the government has announced in the Working Nation statement that it will provide additional funding through the National Industry Extension Service to support the creation of networks that improve competitiveness.

The successful transition to a global marketplace also required leadership from government and industry, and individual firms. Last year the McKinsey emerging exporters study found that corporate leadership was the most important determinant of export success. It has been the vision of firm leaders, and their strong commitment to realise that vision, that has generated much of our recent trade growth.

I am delighted that a number of companies in my electorate of Moreton were favourably mentioned in the McKinsey report. In particular, I mention three firms: Cigweld; Thompsons, Kelly and Lewis Ltd; and Tubemakers of Australia. Those three companies based in Coopers Plains in my electorate received a special mention in the report because they have been very active in driving to gain overseas export markets. They prove that, with vision, leadership and innovation, there are no boundaries Australian firms cannot explore. There are no limitations on where we can go to find new export markets and to earn valuable export dollars for the Australian economy.

One of the key points in the McKinsey report was that around 15,000 firms are potential exporters which have yet to get their act together. To encourage them on their export drive, the government will provide more than $100 million over four years to implement a major outreach program targeted at these potential exports. If firms are to innovate, take up new technology and explore new markets, they need access to finance on reasonable terms and conditions. The government is undertaking a wide range of initiatives to improve small business access to both debt and equity.

The concessional tax rate for pooled development funds will be reduced from 25 to 15 per cent for income derived from investments in small to medium size enterprises. The restrictions under which the funds operate will also be eased. The government will run a pilot business angels style scheme to match potential investors with small firms requiring equity finance.

The government will provide more working capital for small to medium sized exporters through the Export Finance and Insurance Corporation, EFIC. EFIC will also be able to provide increased working capital for a broader range of exports. There will be training for accountants and bankers and assistance to small to medium sized enterprises to obtain advice on export finance.

In total, these measures will lead to significant improvements in the availability of finance for small to medium sized enterprises. Government purchasing policy will be strengthened to stimulate Australian industry. Firms will be able to use their endorsed supplier status to break into new markets. The impact on Australian industry will be fully considered in all major government purchases.

In many ways, our future living standards will be determined by our export growth. The government is therefore committed to equipping Australian firms with an excellent export market intelligence network. The government will provide targeted financial assistance to new exporters and promote a growing export culture across Australian industry. The export market development grants scheme, the EMDG scheme, which has been a great success, will be expanded to include single service tourism operators.

The size of the infrastructure market in Asia is staggering. It will be worth around $600 billion over the remainder of this decade. The government will spend more than $12 million to assist consortia bidding for major infrastructure projects in Asia and it will also expand the trade and diplomatic network and provide additional funding for a stronger Austrade presence in the Asia-Pacific region.

At home, the government will establish new export centres and develop the exporter hotline service. Because the government wants to see greater export orientation across the whole of the Australian industry, we will strengthen the links between trade and industry at the government level. A new national board of industry, trade and investment will be established by the Minister for Trade (Senator McMullan) and the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook). This will work to develop agreed strategies for trade and investment promotion, export facilitation and industry development. It will ensure the better integration of policy, programs and services between the industry and trade portfolios.

One of its key tasks will be to spread the message that Australia is a very attractive investment destination. It is a message for both domestic and international investors. Investment has been the important ingredient missing from the recovery so far. I say so far because investment will come. When has the climate for investment in Australia ever been so good? The economy is growing strongly at over four per cent and Westpac is talking about growth of over five per cent.

This growth has been driven by low interest rates and the lowest inflation rate in this country for 30 years. Importantly, this growth is sustainable. The corporate profit share is at a near all time high level. Business confidence in manufacturing is also at a 30-year high and consumer confidence remains buoyant. This government is absolutely committed to a budget deficit of around one per cent of GDP by 1996-97. It is clear that the environment is right for investment.

The government is not going to leave it to those factors. Access to finance is frequently cited by business as a major constraint to new investment. In the Working Nation statement, the government has made it more attractive for business to invest in infrastructure development. Infrastructure bonds now cover a significantly wider range of activities and their tax treatment is now more generous.

The government has taken these measures to encourage Australian companies to invest in Australia. It is difficult to see what more the government could reasonably do. Now it is simply up to business. Business expects overall investment to grow by six per cent this financial year. This is the right sort of investment. It is not the type of investment we had in the mid-1980s which was speculative and tied up in property. We are now seeing productive investment coming into play. For example, manufacturers anticipate investment growth of 10 per cent. The simple fact is that investment is coming, it will be the right sort of investment and it will considerably boost Australia's economic performance.

We particularly want overseas firms to see Australia as a long-term location for strategic investment but there is fierce competition. The Asian countries are eagerly chasing investment to sustain their high growth rates. The government is going to provide special tax incentives and streamline immigration procedures so that more transnational firms establish their regional headquarters in Australia. When we look at all of the proposals and measures outlined in Working Nation and the subsequent measures that were contained in the budget, it is clear that this government is setting up a very strong environment for business growth, business investment and export development. (Time expired)
Debate (on motion by Mr Taylor) adjourned.

PARA.TAB: `(6) If the Council is asked under section 196Y to review a decision of the Repatriation Medical Authority under subsection 196C(4) not to carry out an investigation in respect of a particular kind of injury, disease or death, the Council must consider:

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Andrew)—I understand it is the wish of the House to consider the amendments together. There being no objection, I allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walker The Hon F.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the amendments be agreed to.
