SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Sciacca) is in Melbourne attending the annual congress of the Victorian RSL so I will speak on his behalf. The Veterans' Affairs (1994-95 Budget Measures) Legislation Amendment Bill contains important parts of this year's veterans' affairs budget package. It delivers major benefits to the ex-service community and has been developed following extensive consultation with ex-service community leaders. The initiatives respond in part to the recommendations of the Baume committee report entitled A fair go and concerns expressed by the Australian National Audit Office which the government was bound to address. There has been considerable misunderstanding concerning review rights following the introduction of this bill. Concerns have been expressed by certain ex-service leaders. As a result the government has worked closely with the ex-service community, the shadow minister for veterans' affairs, the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), and other non-government parties in the Senate and has agreed to the amendments which were moved by the opposition in the Senate last night. The bill establishes a repatriation medical authority, the role of which is to determine medical scientific issues of causation of injury, disease and death—matters appropriately left to experts—and make legislative instruments called statements of principles that set out the causal factors.

PARA.TAB: The amendments passed in the Senate last night will establish a specialist medical review council which will review determinations of the Repatriation Medical Authority in certain circumstances. The review council will be made up of a number of councillors selected from lists of names submitted to the minister by medical colleges. The selection of councillors to determine a particular application would be based on the field of specialist medical scientific knowledge relevant to the review.

In order to ensure that this is not an adversary process, legal submissions will not be able to be put to the review council. The review council will publish a notice in the Gazette, inviting submissions to it on the issue. The review council will have before it copies of all material that has been before the Repatriation Medical Authority. Persons who have made submissions to it may appear before it, if they so desire, and there will be no parties to a proceeding before the review council. However, the person who initiated the appeal will have the opportunity to make submissions and will be provided with a statement of reasons for the review council's decision.

In order to preserve parliament's oversight of statements of principles as disallowable instruments, the specialist medical review council will not be able to commence a review until after any disallowance period has expired. Because the statements are legislative instruments which are made by the Repatriation Medical Authority, its powers will be to require the authority to make any changes that the council directs of it.

On behalf of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, I would like to take this opportunity to thank the honourable member for O'Connor for the cooperative spirit in which he has approached the negotiations concerning this bill. I would like to thank the leaders of the ex-service organisations for the way that they have assisted both the government and the opposition in arriving at suitable amendments which will preserve the fundamental scheme of the original legislation and provide further review mechanisms. Finally, on behalf of the minister, I would like to thank his officers and staff whose work made this legislation possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise this morning to offer some comments on these amendments to the Veterans' Affairs (1994-95 Budget Measures) Legislation Amendment Bill. In particular, I would like to deal with the circumstances surrounding the proposal incorporated in the amendments before us now to establish a specialist medical review council. I do so on behalf of the shadow minister for veterans affairs and defence science and personnel, the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey). Unfortunately, the government has experienced difficulties with its timetable. The Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Sciacca) and the shadow minister are both stranded in Melbourne, even though they had made arrangements to be here to shepherd the legislation through the House for the last occasion this morning.

PARA.TAB: The shadow minister particularly wanted to be here. He has been very involved in the discussions and negotiations leading to the amendments before us now. I think this is his first bill since he has taken over as the shadow minister in the rearranged frontbench line-up for the opposition of the last month or so. He has unquestionably shown his mettle in his capacity to grapple with a very difficult issue and to negotiate in a constructive way with the government a preferred solution to the plan which was announced when the bill was first introduced.

As the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Walker) has rightly said, many matters within the government's proposed legislation will provide benefits to the veterans community. As concerned as we have been about one aspect of this bill, it was always our publicly declared intention to support the bill because those benefits should be made available to the veterans community. Confronted with an aspect of the bill with which we had grave concerns, we believed that the most appropriate way for us to proceed was to try to negotiate some amendment or compromise in respect of the proposed Repatriation Medical Authority.

In simple terms, the government's initial proposal was directed at clarifying the processes by which certain entitlements are determined for veterans. In very general terms—and I do not intend this to be a legal explanation of the current law—some entitlements are available only if the medical ailment of a veteran can be established to be causally related to war services. In criminal law, which many people would best understand, for a case to be successful the prosecution has to prove his or her case beyond reasonable doubt. That is a very high standard. In a civil case, which I think many people would also have had an association with in some way or another, the case has to be established only on the balance of probabilities. So that is a second general standard of which people might be aware.

For veterans, the standard of proof is even less, and rightly so. They have incurred their injuries, or in some cases they have died, as a result of their service to their country. So it is appropriate that the government, regardless of its political persuasion, should be very generous in the entitlements that it provides to veterans. The standard of proof under the Veterans' Entitlements Act has really ended up being—and I stress this in layman's terms—a standard of proof where the veteran has to establish only that there is a reasonable basis for a reasonable hypothesis and that there is a link between the ailment, or death in some cases, and the war service.

This standard of proof has been established by statute and High Court interpretation. The problem is that the definition has become so loose that inconsistencies have developed in various decisions of various bodies in awarding entitlements. That is basically unfair. I think most people would agree that, whatever the law is, it is a basic tenet of fairness and justice that that law be applied equally and consistently. The basis of the government's concern, which has led to this proposal, has been that, whatever the law is, regardless of whether veterans go to some tribunal here or in another state to establish their entitlement, they should get the same treatment. Regardless of whether veterans live in Sydney or Melbourne or whether they go to one tribunal or another, they ought to get the same deal. That basically has not been the case.

There have been various reviews. I think the Auditor-General had a look at the issue. Professor Peter Baume, a former senator and minister in the Fraser government, was appointed by the government to look at some of these issues. He basically said that we ought to revert to a civil standard; in other words, a higher standard of proof than currently applies. The government, under political pressure—and quite rightly so—rejected that suggestion. Instead, it came up with the bill currently before us today which has a scheme contained in it.

The idea of this bill is to try to predetermine what would be a reasonable hypothesis. It would be predetermined by an authority called the Repatriation Medical Authority. The government said that this will prevent the situation whereby speculative, fanciful and unsound opinions may determine a medical issue. Its objective is not unreasonable. When the honourable member for O'Connor first read the proposal, he said that there was an obvious problem with it. Ultimately, the bottom line of such a proposal was that it would stop veterans from lodging appeals on medical grounds. That is another unfairness. We started with a problem which was unfair, and the government's remedy also contained an unfairness. The honourable member for O'Connor alerted various organisations, particularly the RSL, to the real problem, which I understand was later confirmed by expert legal opinion. He then set out to try to maintain a sensible solution.

As I said, we obviously did not want to stop the bill, because it contained benefits for veterans. So we had to find a better way. We had to find a solution to the problems identified by the member for O'Connor. That has now been achieved. We appreciate the constructive way in which it has been dealt with. The government accepted the amendments moved on behalf of the coalition in the Senate, and those amendments have now been referred to us.

The amendments establish a specialist medical review council which, upon a veteran's appeal, can review the statements of principles created by the Repatriation Medical Authority. This is a major development, initiated by the honourable member for O'Connor, negotiated constructively with the support of the coalition and with the sensible support of the minister. We hope that it improves the bill. We believe it does. We also note the minister's second reading commitment to undertake a review of the operation of this new system after 12 months to ensure that the objectives are properly fulfilled by the legislative framework now set in place. Under all of those circumstances, the coalition is very pleased to commend the amendment to the House and to endorse the bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bradford Mr J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am disappointed that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Sciacca) is not here this morning. I wanted to hear his response to some of my points. Unfortunately, that is not going to occur. With the greatest respect, I am not sure that the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Walker), who is at the table, will be as far across the issue as he might need to be to respond. We will see whether that is the case in a few moments time.

PARA.TAB: There is no doubt, as has just been said by my colleague the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith), that the result we now have on the Veterans' Affairs (1994-95 Budget Measures) Legislation Amendment Bill is the best that we could get under the circumstances. I echo congratulations to the shadow minister for veterans affairs, the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), for the work that he did in a very short time. I commend the minister for being involved in joint consultations with us and the veterans community on this matter, but I make that commendation with some reservations. Whilst we appreciate the fact that the government has changed its mind on this issue and has accepted, to a very large extent, the opposition's position—it has effectively backed down—there is no doubt in my mind that the government, through this legislation, has sold out the veterans community. That can be clearly demonstrated. It will be clear to all veterans once this legislation filters down.

There has been very limited consultation on the establishment of the Repatriation Medical Authority. It is fine that there has been consultation with the heads of peak bodies, and I cast no aspersions on them whatsoever. The former minister made the point in the Senate last night—I watched last night's debate in the Senate because it was very revealing—that there were what amounted to secret negotiations behind closed doors on these matters, apparently with the excuse that they were related to the budget and that, therefore, there could not be widespread consultation. That might be a very convenient excuse, but it has amounted to a great deal of suspicion within the wider veterans community about the effect of this particular provision. When the news does filter down—it is slowly filtering down because members are starting to get input from constituents at large—there will be an outcry.

There will be an outcry because, as I said at the outset, the government has once again downgraded veterans benefits. There can be no doubt that that is what it has done. It is clearly evident in the legislation. It is evident in the dollars; we do not have to go past the government's estimate of the dollars. The Bushell case was favourable to veterans. The government rushed into the parliament within days of the High Court decision and attempted to reverse it in a ham-fisted way; it ended up being thrown out and it has never come back in that form. It did so ill-advised because at the time the department or the commission told the government that the High Court's decision in the Bushell case was going to cost billions of dollars. It has not, and it will not. The Baume committee said that it will not.

The government, which is forecasting savings from the implementation of the Repatriation Medical Authority in the order of $20 million over a period, obviously recognises that the Bushell decision was never going to open the floodgates in respect of claims. Through the establishment of the authority, the government has further attempted to circumvent or quarantine the Bushell decision. In that sense, the authority downgrades the status of veterans. It clearly represents—the dollars prove it—a diminution of benefits. It represents a reversal or change in the status quo. The situation that exists at the moment is different from what it will be once this legislation is passed and given assent. The result will be that it will be harder for veterans to prove causation. That is ultimately what this is all about. There are all sorts of other elements to veterans claims but, ultimately, the key issue for veterans is causation. The government cannot get around the fact that the introduction of the Repatriation Medical Authority is intended to make the proof of causation more difficult.

In the secret negotiations that occurred, the veterans community leaders were presented with an all or nothing proposition. They were forced into a deal. It is the same deal that has been given to us today. In other words, `If you don't take the bad with the many good things in this legislation for veterans, the whole lot will go out the window.' That is some sort of offer that has been put to us. That is the legislation we are faced with today. We are faced with voting for a bill which is favourable to veterans in a number of obvious respects but, in respect of the establishment of this Repatriation Medical Authority, is unfavourable to veterans.

As the minister said to honourable members on this side of the House and to the leaders of the veterans community, `It is all or nothing.' The government will bring these budget measures in only if the government ends up saving money. It will save money because, although there is a cost associated with the good things in this bill—the provision of benefits for maritime servicemen and so on—it anticipates saving money from the establishment of this authority.

It is true that in negotiations that have occurred in the interim there has been another layout of bureaucracy with the introduction of a Specialist Medical Review Council. There is no doubt in my mind that that has improved dramatically the situation that existed when the bill was first introduced. But we are still today faced with voting for legislation which, in its net effect—the bottom line—is disadvantageous to veterans.

The government cannot deny that this removes the basic right of veterans access to the courts on the issue of causation. Appeals on the matter of causation should go before proper courts, with medical specialists giving expert advice. That is not going to be the case. A medical star chamber is being introduced to determine matters of causation. I do not use those words terribly lightly. That is what it amounts to. Veterans rights have been abrogated. Every other Australian has the right to access courts and to proper determination. Veterans rights on this issue have been cut off.

I contrast, as I did when this matter first came up, the treatment that veterans are getting in respect of the High Court decision. I remind the government that when the High Court made a decision on Mabo, it did not come rushing in here the next day to try to change that decision because it was going to cost Australia billions of dollars; it came rushing in here the next day to widen the effects of that decision. The minister at the table knows all about that; perhaps he can address that issue. Let him deny that that was the case. Rather than saying, `The High Court has made a decision on Mabo that will cost us millions or billions of dollars; we had better do something about it,' the government extended it. The Native Title Act was more generous.

When it came to the Bushell decision—a decision that was going to cost the government money—because veterans were concerned, not Aboriginals, the government rushed in here within a week and wanted to change the law. I do not want to put too fine a point on that. Just the other day—I do not want to use this in disparaging terms—a veteran said to me, `Aboriginals run the department of Aboriginal affairs; why aren't veterans running the Department of Veterans Affairs?' I am not sure whether that was a light-hearted comment, but it seemed to me that there might have been a degree of sense or a degree of consistency in that.

Senator Faulkner in the Senate made it clear last night that all review and appeal mechanisms are intact, except on the issue of causation. I underline again that in most cases for veterans the question of causation is the key issue in relation to the determination ultimately of their claims. The end result of this legislaton today is that we have seen the government move relentlessly to quarantine the Bushell decision. It has had a couple of tries to do so and the end result today is that we are effectively blackmailed into supporting legislation which is generally of great benefit to veterans but, in respect of the establishment of this new process, is quite clearly and unarguably against the interests of veterans and is intended to save the government money. That is what this legislation is about: to save the government money. When you compare those savings, say, with the cost of the native title legislation, those few lousy million dollars is money that would otherwise go to veterans.

I want to make the point to the minister and to the parliament that we are not talking here about welfare for veterans, we need always to underline that we are talking about entitlements for veterans. Veterans are entitled to these benefits where they can establish that there is cause and effect between their war service and their state of health, which many of them experience as a result of that war service. So, in many respects, although the government is being generous in aspects of this bill, that generosity is hollow. It is clearly hollow because of the fact that the net effect of this legislation, when you read the detail, is a net saving of money to the government over a period of time.

In the Senate last night someone indicated—and I am not sure whether it was Senator Faulkner or one of the other speakers in the debate—that the Vietnam Veterans Association intended to pursue this matter through to the High Court. I am not sure whether that is the case, but I can assure the House that the input that I have had from Vietnam veterans has certainly been that they are not at all happy with this legislation. I do not cast aspersions on the RSL, and certainly not on its leadership for I have enormous respect for Major General James, but the fault is with the government.

This whole process has been one of limited consultation and limited time. We cannot blame the RSL, in a sense, when a proposition is presented with a fait accompli to take it or leave it. We cannot blame the RSL for wanting to have a civil and good working relationship with the government. It has to have that, and I understand that. It does not want to be up to its neck, necessarily, in the politics of the whole thing. So, ultimately, the RSL has been forced to accept a situation, I believe, the same way we are being forced to accept a bill today—through blackmail.

Down the line there has not been adequate consultation. My suggestion—and it was not an acceptable suggestion to the government—was that we ought to proceed, obviously, with the beneficial aspects of this bill and put aside the requirement for the establishment of the new process until there had been adequate consultation. In my view, it was quite reasonable to suggest that we get on with introducing on 1 July the changes that were of benefit and put aside this controversial change until it had been tested.

I am pleased at least that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs has acknowledged, or has given a commitment, that there will be a review of this procedure in 12 months time. I am inherently suspicious of those promises because reviews are promised and sometimes they never eventuate in quite the same way. I can assure him that I and others who, I suppose, on my own admission have a direct interest in veterans affairs will be watching very carefully to make sure that that review takes place.

The final point I would like to make—and I do not know whether the minister at the table is able to answer this—is that from my point of view it is important that we understand clearly what is happening here. The only standard to set for the construction of a statement of principles—and that is what we are about to get—is the standard already in existence: beyond a reasonable doubt. Therefore, the statement of principles which we are talking about establishing should be required to adhere to the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: In the development of a Statement of Principles the Repatriation Medical Authority or the Specialist Medical Review Council,—
which is going to look over its shoulder—

whichever shall be the case, shall determine that a reasonable hypothesis is raised of a causal relationship between the injury, disease or death of a veteran, as the case may be, unless it is satisfied beyond reasonable doubt, that there is no sufficient ground for making the determination.

My understanding of the statement of principles is that that will not be the case. I merely summarise by saying, and I mean what I say, that the government has sold out the veterans community once again on this. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to take up the House's time unnecessarily, but I do take the opportunity to make a few brief remarks to reiterate some of the comments that both my colleagues the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) and the honourable member for McPherson (Mr Bradford) have made. Firstly, I would like to add my thanks and congratulations to the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) for the work that he did in relation to this legislation with those of us on this side of the House, with those on the other side of the House who have more than a passing interest in veterans affairs and, indeed, with the government, in particular the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Sciacca).

PARA.TAB: I also want to congratulate the National President of the RSL, Major General Digger James, for his cooperation and large measure of assistance to the passage and improvement of this legislation. Finally, but by no means in the least, I would like to congratulate the responsible minister, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, for once again showing a very pragmatic and realistic approach to this legislation and to the improvement of the legislation that was initially tabled. In saying that, I want to reiterate to this House that, whilst this legislation is good legislation, it has been made better by the opposition and, indeed, by the shadow minister, the honourable member for O'Connor.

Through the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Walker), who is at the table, I leave two messages for the Minister for Veterans' Affairs for him to take up one or two of the points that the honourable member for McPherson made. I hope the member is wrong in relation to the star chamber approach. I think he is wrong, but I hope he is wrong. I also refer to the review after the 12-month period. I hope that the minister will take both of those points on board. He is the responsible minister, and at that 12-month point, or earlier if the occasion arises, I am sure that he will jump in and do what a responsible minister would do under the circumstances. I think that the legislation is good legislation. I have pleasure in supporting everything in it, including the amendments that have been put forward today.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been asked to respond by the honourable member for McPherson (Mr Bradford), and I will do so briefly. I must say I was bemused when I listened to his rather colourful language and hyperbole when he talked about star chambers,—
—Blackmail.

—blackmail, and the selling out of veterans. It is obvious that he is playing politics in the veterans community, and it is equally obvious that he is one out in his own party in this regard because today we are dealing with opposition amendments put forward in a cooperative spirit by the shadow minister, the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), who has worked with the government, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Sciacca) and the ex-service community, and this is the result. I think that sort of approach is not very constructive no matter how strongly he holds the views.

PARA.TAB: This talk about secret negotiations and a lack of consultation is wrong in this case. I am advised that the advisory council has been consulting with the minister for eight months on these issues. Admittedly, there are budget considerations, and some of those consultations have been in camera. But, nevertheless, it has been a lengthy period. In addition, there have been two sets of negotiations, because ex-service leaders have also in more recent times been negotiating about these things. So I think the exaggerative approach of the honourable member for McPherson is wrong in that regard.

The only other matter that I would like to briefly touch on is the question of the legal standard. I think he is wrong in his interpretation of the legal standard. The honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) endeavoured to some extent to set out the law there. It is not beyond reasonable doubt and it is not on the balance of probabilities. It is a reasonable hypothesis. The honourable member for McPherson will find that, as the standard is applied in practice, his fears in this regard will be unfounded.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Taylor Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will start my contribution to this debate by quoting in part what the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) said when introducing this documentation into the House on 4 May:

SPEECH.PARA: Unemployment is without question the greatest problem we face. Unemployment saps the confidence and self-esteem of our fellow Australians—which in turn saps the nation's. It damages the social fabric.
It has profound consequences for our social cohesion.
. . . unemployment threatens to create a permanent underclass.
It threatens to create the conditions for social decay.
He went on to say:
This government for one is determined to deal with the problem.

I say at the outset that the government fails its own test in relation to this Working Nation white paper documentation. That view has been, and continues to be, shared by many commentators across the country. For example, I will quote from two commentators who are at opposite ends of the ideological spectrum. One is the former Minister for Finance, Peter Walsh, and the other is Phil Ruthven, one of Australia's better economists. What did Peter Walsh say? I will quote from his article in the Australian Financial Review of 5 May, where he said in part:

Just over two years ago the One Nation statement set out a major program for infrastructure investment, two tranches of tax cuts costing $8 billion a year, and a commitment to a Federal Budget surplus by 1995-1996 which incorporated optimistic economic growth assumptions in the intervening period.
He went on to say:

PARA.TAB: Last year's Budget brought forward one tranche of tax cuts, deferred—probably forever—the second tranche, and set out a strategy for reducing the deficit to 1 per cent of GDP by 1996-1997. That bottom line was dependent on growth equalling the revised forecast, all of the new revenue measures clearing the Senate, and no net additions to outlays up to 1996-97.

SPEECH.PARA: He went on:

PARA.TAB: Growth so far seems to have exceeded the forecast but cannot be guaranteed for a further three years. The Government lost about $300 million of its enhanced revenue. And yesterday—

SPEECH.PARA: that is, 4 May—
the Government announced measures estimated to add $1.9 billion in outlays in 1996-97.

PARA.TAB: Unless major cuts in other programs are announced next week—

SPEECH.PARA: budget week, which they were not—
which is not likely—the no net additions to outlays component of the strategy has been blown away.

PARA.TAB: Fiscal policy targets which were probably too permissive in the first place have become more permissive. Moreover, the statement will continue to add almost $1.9 billion to outlays in 1997-98—the year beyond the target period—by which time if all goes well growth will be strong and unemployment will have fallen appreciably.

SPEECH.PARA: He went on:

PARA.TAB: For the foreseeable future, it seems that nearly $2 billion has been added, not as one or two-off recession related programs, but as structural additions to expenditure and, in the absence of higher taxes, to the Budget deficit. Whether the consequences of a higher deficit will detract more from employment than the other measures will add, is arguable.

SPEECH.PARA: He finished by saying:

PARA.TAB: Perhaps the best thing one could say about yesterday's statement is that it could have been much worse.

SPEECH.PARA: On the other hand, Phil Ruthven said:

Fifty years ago, the Chifley Government gave Australia a jobs blueprint that lasted two generations and pointed the way to many of the extra 2.5 million jobs that were created, even if it was to be Menzies and Gorton who did the bulk of the implementation. And it didn't take 227 pages.
In 1994, 8.7 million Australians (49 per cent) want jobs and 7.8 million have one.

PARA.TAB: In 2001, if 49 per cent of the then population also want jobs, we need 9.8 million. If we settle for 5 per cent unemployment (the average over the past 140 years), we need 9.3 million jobs.

We currently have 7.8 million, but around 700,000 of these will be lost over the next seven years as our businesses become more efficient. That means around 7.1 million of today's jobs in the new and old industries are more or less safe.

SPEECH.PARA: He went on to say:

PARA.TAB: We need the difference between 9.3 million and 7.1 million in new jobs in new industries for new consumer needs for new employees.
This is 2.2 million jobs in seven years—the equivalent of two whole manufacturing industries today.

SPEECH.PARA: He finished by saying:

PARA.TAB: But don't look for them in the White Paper. There is no guiding beacon for the unemployed—and new entrants in the future.

SPEECH.PARA: I agree with what John Stone said in the same edition of the Australian Financial Review on 5 May, when he said:

PARA.TAB: Yesterday's document was thus not about `jobs, jobs, jobs', but . . . about `politics, politics, politics'.

SPEECH.PARA: He went on to say:

PARA.TAB: As we shall see this year, or early next, it was about throwing up enough dust to obscure the terrible indictment which our unemployment level constitutes on 11 years of Labor rule.
At any rate, for long enough for Mr Keating to lie his way successfully through yet another federal election.
That, of course, is where the dollars come in; and in yesterday's statement, there were plenty of them.

SPEECH.PARA: He said:

PARA.TAB: True, the total `package' figure of $6.5 billion over the next four years is advanced principally as headline fodder, and for propaganda purposes in the now forthcoming election.

The immediately important figures are the $1.1 billion of extra spending which yesterday's statement will front-load into the 1994-95 Budget figuring, to be revealed next Tuesday, and the $1.9 billion on-going annual addition thereafter to the `structural deficit'.

SPEECH.PARA: That is the point that Peter Walsh made previously. The honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson), the then Leader of the Opposition, said this in relation to the white paper:

The Government's white paper on employment is yet another example of Labor's whole record on unemployment: they created it, they ignored it, they fudged it, they threw money at it, but they could not solve it.

PARA.TAB: The white paper is a recognition that Mr Keating's previous promises and policies in the area of unemployment have failed. In reality, the paper will not encourage businesses to generate new jobs. Moreover, it fails to address the root causes of the unemployment crisis which Labor's policies have created.

SPEECH.PARA: What did Ivan Deveson, the Chairman of the Business Council of Australia, say about it? He said:

The focus on long-term unemployment . . . will give hope to those who have been out of work for a long time. On the other hand, the white paper has not tackled the other key issues of labour costs and restrictive award provisions. Even more disappointing is the inadequate focus on the specifics of how faster micro-economic reform will be achieved.
What did Robert Fitzgerald, the President of ACOSS, one who is not reluctant to support a lot of what the present government says, say on this occasion? He said:

The failure to ensure an adequate, sustainable growth in the number of available jobs is of particular concern. The absence of any meaningful commitment to public and social infrastructure investment, or tax, trade and industry policy changes, is a glaring hole and will particularly disadvantage rural and regional unemployed Australians.

As someone who represents a rural, regional part of this nation, I agree with him entirely. This and the budget papers reveal that this government only intends to bash the bush once again. As far as the government is concerned, I do not think it could spell the word `rural'.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister's claims for his white paper are large. Regrettably, they are unlikely to be matched by results. In part, this is because the central problem being addressed, that of long-term unemployment, has an intractable element not amenable to government solutions. The brutal truth is that a significant proportion of the existing long-term unemployed are probably, for various reasons, unemployable, at least in the private sector. They are victims of past policies, notably protectionism, an inflexible labour market and long-term structural change and retraining, and job subsidies will probably not help them. The government has both a moral obligation and a political need to try to disprove this assertion and to at least ensure that those who are employable get job opportunities. What did the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello), now the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, have to say? He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Working Nation is nothing more than the inferior offspring of One Nation and Investing in the Nation.
It didn't work the first or the second time—and it won't work the third time.
The document does nothing more than churn previous failed policy statements with more taxpayers money.
Apparently the Government believes it can fix unemployment by re-naming and re-packaging the programs that have failed to make any significant impact on unemployment previously.
Rather than seek to provide genuine employment and jobs, the document seeks to hide the unemployed, by painting them with the invisible ink of a phoney job compact.

On that point, this white paper has the potential to hide more than 200,000 unemployed Australians from the unemployed figures. The possible figures are as follows: job compact, around 120,000; parenting allowance, around 60,000; CDEP, in the Aboriginal area, a little over 1,000; NEIS, about 1,000; in the ATS and entry level training area, perhaps as high as 17,000 or 18,000; partners allowance, about 3,000; and the mature allowance, around 30,000. The total figure comes to over 200,000 and that does not include the 15- to 17-year olds.

PARA.TAB: The coalition believes in effective and efficient labour market programs. We want to give as many unemployed people as possible a fair chance of standing on their own feet. This white paper gives no guarantee of this, nor does it take the hard steps to foster the climate of confidence that leads to the stronger economic growth investment necessary for employment growth and the creation of a genuine working nation. Training and retraining courses alone are certainly not the answer, notwithstanding that in my area skillshare is doing a very good job with a large degree of community support under very difficult circumstances.

The Prime Minister must not be allowed to dress up the unemployed wolf in sheep's clothing with yet another training schedule and get away with it. I am sure that the taxpayer will no longer sign a blank cheque. We need equity and balance, but not at the expense of generating more than equal treatment for minorities. Small businesses need genuine tax reform if jobs are to be generated, as well as modifications to the present training guarantee levy, the superannuation guarantee charge, fringe benefits tax and, very importantly, on the state scene, payroll tax. The government has done none of that or very little. I reiterate what I said when I started, that is, the government clearly fails its own test.

TALK.START.PARA: —The white paper on employment and growth is the culmination of a lengthy process of examination by the government of the changing nature of Australia's economic reality. The overwhelming task faced by the government when it came to office in 1983 was to undertake a wholesale restructuring of the Australian economy and to refocus its efforts to take advantage of the new emerging economic opportunities in our region and around the globe.

PARA.TAB: It has managed this change with a degree of compassion and without undue conflict and dislocation, maintaining a social cohesion which is the envy of other industrialised countries and developing countries in the region. As far as restructuring of the Australian economy is concerned, that process has gathered pace throughout the 1990s and will continue to do so beyond the year 2000. I think we need to understand fundamentally how the lives of Australians have changed in the short space of time since this government was elected. I refer here to the wholesale restructuring that has taken place within industry itself.

If we take the example of the banking system, some 10 or 15 years ago, as one walked around provincial cities like the one that I represent in this parliament, Geelong, there were more branches. When one walked into the banks there were more tellers and I would suspect that in the back rooms there were more bookkeepers than one could poke a stick at, to use some rural parlance. Now most of us do our banking through holes in the wall. The technological innovations in the banking system alone have seen the destruction of hundreds, perhaps thousands, of jobs in that industry.

Another particular important industry to Geelong is the automotive industry. In the last decade it has undergone massive restructuring. I can recall, barely five years ago, walking around the floors of Ford in Geelong and seeing many welders manufacturing cars. That welding task in the main is done by robots that have replaced the human capital that was previously engaged in that productive activity. The upshot of it all has been that the Ford Motor Co. in Geelong has restructured its operation and shed labour, along with a lot of other automotive companies around Australia.

There is another very simple example of the way in which the economic system has been restructured. Turning to the rural sector—and the previous speaker, the honourable member for Groom (Mr Taylor), in this debate seemed to have an affinity with things rural; I must say that I have an affinity with it myself, being the son of a dairy farmer, and I have worked the land myself—we have seen a massive reorganisation of the work task in dairy farming. We have seen herd sizes and productivity improve dramatically. We have seen the bulk handling of the output of the industry. We have seen changes to hay baling and carting. We have seen massive sheddings of labour where the task is now done by one or perhaps two operators. In the crop planting and harvesting that often accompany dairying, in the south-west of Victoria particularly, we have seen, likewise, the introduction of new technologies that have reduced the demand for labour.

What we have seen in the Australian economy in the last 10 years is not only a massive restructuring of the economy but also significant increases in overall productivity, which have been achieved without net additions to labour. As far as the refocusing of Australian industry is concerned, the government really did have a major task in 1983 when it came to power to change the business culture in Australia. We have succeeded, I think, in going a long way to achieving that. We see now that many of our major firms have reorganised themselves internally and are engaging in what could be called best practice management. As far as the labour force is concerned, we have noted an increase in the flexibility in the application of labour to the industrial task. Accompanying that we have seen significant increases in labour productivity.

I really am intrigued by the obsession that members opposite seem to have with the New Zealand experience. It is often quoted here in this parliament and held up to the nation as one that we should slavishly follow. I am unashamedly Australian and I believe unashamedly in Australian solutions to Australian problems. I think history will record that significant slabs of the great Fightback program that was put as the alternative economic blueprint for this nation were borrowed from the conservative government's economic program in New Zealand.

If indeed the New Zealand experience is one that we should emulate, I wonder why hundreds of thousands of New Zealanders are currently coming to Australia to work, gain employment and enjoy the fruits of our living standards. I do not mean to denigrate the nation across the water, but it is a significant fact that the New Zealand economy under the conservative government has not generated the jobs that would employ New Zealanders. Therefore, New Zealanders have come to Australia to be employed in an economic system that recognises their value to the productive process in material terms and ensures them a reasonable standard of living.

As far as refocusing the Australian economy is concerned, we have seen a massive orientation to export. Initially it was in the area of elaborately transformed manufactures, where we have seen a significant increase in exports, but now we note that it has moved into the services area, particularly tourism, education and health. To give the House an idea of how this change in culture has filtered down through the economy to regional cities and towns, I note with more than a degree of interest that Gordon TAFE and Deakin University in my electorate have got into the export ring and are establishing very strong links with Indonesia. They are very pleasing developments at the local level.

I think the economic base on which the Working Nation initiatives are built is both solid and sustainable over time. The white paper itself provides for a sustained period of economic growth and job creation. I think to understand the full import of this document it really must be viewed in its historical context and also we need an accurate snapshot of where Australia is today. We have entered a new economic era. We have gone through a significant period of restructuring which will continue beyond the year 2000. However, at this point in time we have achieved something that the opposition, which was so critical of this document, has been unable to achieve: sustainable low levels of inflation. We see that the current levels of inflation are the lowest for some 30 years.

We do have the lowest level of interest rates enjoyed for many years. The growth rate of the Australian economy is projected to be around four per cent to five per cent over the next four to five years. We have a massively expanded export base and low levels of industrial disputation, which were not able to be achieved by the opposition when it held the treasury bench. We have seen greater labour market flexibility and, of course, the profitability of industry is now at an all-time high.

One of the key factors in sustaining high levels of growth over the years ahead to the turn of the century is, of course, maintaining high levels of investment, both private and public. Since the budget was delivered we have seen considerable speculation about whether Australia can sustain the levels of investment that are projected in that particular document.

I think anybody who coolly analyses the investment platform has grounds for a degree of optimism in this area. As I mentioned before, we do have low inflation, a low level of interest rates, improved levels of business profitability, a raft of business incentives in place provided by the government to encourage firms to invest and we have seen a significant improvement in our competitive position, which is always a good incentive for entrepreneurs to enter international and domestic marketplaces with more aggression. That particular platform is a very solid one and I am very optimistic that the high levels of investment that are projected in the budget and which underpin the Working Nation document can be achieved and sustained over time.

We have had in recent days a fairly heavy debate in the public arena, and indeed in this House, on the level of interest rates. As those who have a basic understanding of economics would know, the level of interest rates at any one point in time is the product of many factors. It can relate to the way in which the government is managing its fiscal position. I do not think the markets of this country are all that perturbed about the way in which the government is handling its fiscal position. Overseas factors that we have seen quite recently have impacted on the level of expectation in Australia as to whether interest rates would rise. The overall demand for funds is another factor that must be taken into account in assessing the level of interest rates in this country.

As this government has achieved the lowest level of interest rates for many years, we can make comparisons with the years of the opposition. The coalition when it had hold of the treasury bench was not able to achieve the low levels of interest rates that this government has been able to achieve. So, inevitably, there will be an increased demand for funds in this economy and interest rates will tend to rise.

What really irks me is the way in which the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer) and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Costello) over the last couple of months have engaged in a premeditated attempt to talk up expectations in the marketplace about the level of interest rates. Of course, now that we have overseas factors impacting very seriously on markets here in Australia, I think we can honestly say that the irresponsible attitude of the Leader of the Opposition and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition is something we could have done without.

I am very impressed with the range of industry policy initiatives that have been announced in the white paper. The white paper itself provides for a very comprehensive range of assistance packages that are tailor made and targeted to industry. The initiatives that have been provided are consistent with our international trading obligations. I pay tribute to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook) and the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction (Senator Schacht) for their efforts in this regard.

We have finally broken out of the handout mentality of the past. We now have in place a meaningful and comprehensive range of supports for firms that match the overall objectives that the government is setting for small and medium firms as well as others; that is, they are export orientated, focused towards best practice, innovative and prepared to engage in research and development.

The key industry initiatives that have been provided in the white paper include better access for smaller firms to research and development incentives; the strategic networking of firms; expanded and improved industry, information and advisory services; small and medium sized enterprise training; benchmarking for bankers and business advisers; improved investment incentives for pooled development funds; better access for industry to the government purchasing market; and improved export marketing and promotion. Those are just some of the industry initiatives that have been provided by the government in this white paper.

I am very pleased with that package of initiatives because it is focused very much on the small and medium enterprises that are going to play such a crucial role in the economic recovery of this nation and the delivery of jobs. As far as the industry initiatives are concerned, I am very pleased to see that in the white paper the minister has taken up many of the government purchasing policy recommendations that were contained in the Bevis report, Buying our future. I pay tribute to the Chairman of the Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology, who did an excellent job in harnessing the expertise and the resources of the committee to produce such a significant and far-reaching report. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are talking about the need to create jobs in Australia. In that regard I pay tribute to a great Australian and his family, who are not only creating real jobs in this country but providing high quality services to Australians in need. I speak of Doug Moran, his wife, Greta, and his family, who founded the Moran Health Care Group in 1956. Today it is Australia's largest private health care provider.

PARA.TAB: I was privileged to be present last Saturday in Dubbo when the New South Wales Governor, Peter Sinclair, opened the new 60-bed Macquarie Private Hospital in that city. It is something that the people of that city can be very proud of. It was a great day for everyone concerned. There were 500 to 600 people present. After the opening ceremony, when they had a chance to inspect the new hospital, those who had not seen it were absolutely amazed at its facilities.

It is a very bright, modern hospital of the highest quality construction, containing state-of-the-art equipment. It has three of the most modern and best constructed operating theatres imaginable. These are probably not only the best in Australia but, as was said on the day, the best in the Southern Hemisphere. It is great to see such facilities not just in the capital cities of this country but also in country areas such as Dubbo in New South Wales. Country areas have often missed out on quality health facilities. We have only to look at Dubbo Base Hospital, the public hospital, which provides a magnificent standard of health care but is operating under difficult circumstances due to cutbacks in funds.

I was particularly impressed with the personal touches in the new hospital, particularly the art collection adorning the corridors of the hospital. Many of the paintings were done by Greta Moran herself. At a future date, the Moran Health Care Group will construct a retirement village nearby, which will complement the nursing home which it already has in that city. I would like to speak about the Moran Health Care Group because it has been so successful in doing things in this country, such as creating jobs, which we are desperately trying to do today. The Moran Health Care Group has a motto, `Don't predict the future; make it happen.' I think that is particularly apt. Mr Moran and his family have certainly carried that out.

Mr Moran and his family have built private hospitals, nursing homes, retirement villages, hostels, medical centres and related health care facilities, and serviced apartments for the frail aged throughout New South Wales and Queensland. They have 3,500 hospital and nursing home beds and employ 7,500 people, which is a magnificent achievement. The mind boggles. I guess the weekly wage bill must be of the order of $4 million or $5 million or more. In doing this, they have provided the highest standards of excellence and given an attention to detail unsurpassed in this industry in Australia.

Mr Moran and his family have a very great commitment to care for the people who use their facilities. In doing this, they have also been able to make a profit, which I think is very important. I remind the House that you cannot make a profit unless you are serving the consumer, and you do not get the opportunity to serve the consumer over the number of years that they have unless you are doing it very well. I am delighted to say that the profits they have made over the years have been channelled back into projects such as the new private hospital in Dubbo.

One might well ask, `What is their secret of success?' I think Doug and his family have shown great commonsense and a clear focus in what they have done. I was particularly impressed with Doug himself. He is very good in human relations. I do not think that is to be underestimated. He has never forgotten the very humble and hard background of his early years. You can see that in the way he treats his staff today.

His wife, Greta, is essential to the team. Their success in the health care area since their marriage in 1957 is due to the two of them. They are inseparable. She was a graduate nurse. In his early days he was a real estate and property developer in Sydney. The combination of his business skills, which were particularly lacking in the nursing home industry in the 1950s, and her health care skills has created an amazing dynasty in Australia. They started off in the health care industry when they had an aging relative who needed nursing home care. They leased a harbour side home at McMahons Point in Sydney and converted it into a 16-bed nursing home. They went from there. They have seven children. Most or all of them are involved in the Moran Health Care Group.

It is interesting to look at their family histories. Doug Moran's father was a coalminer who worked in the Newcastle area in the Depression. He later moved to Gympie, where Doug grew up. Doug went on to serve with distinction in the merchant navy in World War II. In 1946 he returned from England to Australia and served on the coastal and trans-Tasman shipping routes. Later he moved into real estate in Sydney, particularly specialising in the housing needs of the immigrants who were flooding into the country in those days.

His wife, Greta, has a fascinating family history. One of her ancestors was a fellow named Robert Cooper, a British distiller and businessman of prominence a century or more ago. He was caught smuggling cognac and ostrich feathers into England from France during the Napoleonic Wars. He was convicted and transported to New South Wales in the early 1800s.

He was pardoned by Governor Macquarie in 1818 and invited to develop a distillery for the colony. He sired 28 children, which I think is an absolutely remarkable achievement, and did many other things of note. For example, he built Juniper Hall, named after the berry used in the gin he was distilling, in Paddington. It was built in 1824 and is Australia's oldest surviving suburban villa. He was also instrumental in the construction of Sydney Grammar School.

Doug Moran has been very involved in the arts in this country. He is a fellow of the Royal Society of Arts in London, a vice-patron of the Royal Art Society of New South Wales and the patron of the Doug Moran national portrait prize. The shadow minister at the table, the honourable member for Mackellar (Mrs Bishop), will be opening the exhibition of the 30 finalists in the old Parliament House tonight. I urge every member to attend because it is going to be a great event. One hundred thousand dollars is put aside as first prize and $60,000 is to be divided up amongst the other contestants. Doug is also the President of the National Association of Nursing Homes and Private Hospitals Inc., and he founded the Moran Chair of Urology at the University of Sydney.

Doug's wife, Greta—I met her for the first time on Saturday and she struck me as a very gracious lady indeed—was schooled at Presbyterian Ladies College in Pymble; graduated in nursing from Sydney's Royal Prince Alfred Hospital; became a director of nursing; moved on to a hospital administration position; and is now the administrative director of the Moran Health Care Group. Greta is a quality artist in her own right. She studied at the Royal Arts Society under Henry Hanke and her art is displayed in private collections not only in Australia but also in the United Kingdom, the United States of America and Italy.

Their seven children are also absolutely remarkable. It is quite a family. Kerry, whom I met on Saturday and who spoke so eloquently after the function, has taken over the position of maintaining Australia's constitutional monarchy. She very much cherishes Australia's heritage.

I will also mention the achievements of one of their other children, Shane, whom I pick out at random. Shane is a bachelor of commerce, bachelor of laws, master of laws, executive director of the Moran Health Care Group, principal of a Sydney based firm of solicitors and attorneys, a fellow of the Taxation Institute of Australia, an associate of the Australian Society of Certified Practising Accountants, and a notary public. Shane's qualifications in law, including a masters degree in international business law, and in commerce, majoring in accounting, finance and systems, plus international experience in commercial law, chartered accounting, international business finance, taxation and general administration enable him to control the corporate, legal and administrative functions of the health care group. He has undertaken considerable studies and work outside Australia, and is fluent in German, Spanish, French, Chinese Mandarin, Italian and Japanese. He is a former Sydney first grade and representative rugby union player, and is an experienced pilot, holding a command instrument rating and jet endorsement on the corporate Beechcraft King Air.

It is easy to see the quality of Doug and Greta's children, and seeing that gives some insight into why they have been so successful. I am delighted that they have built many nursing homes and private hospitals in country areas, not just in Sydney, Brisbane and places like that. For example, there is an 80-bed nursing home in Bathurst; an 80-bed nursing home in Dubbo; the 60-bed Jessie Hunt Nursing Home—named after the mother of Ralph Hunt, a former member of this House—in Narrabri; the 80-bed Maitland Nursing Home in Rutherford; a 50-bed nursing home in Mudgee; a 100-bed nursing home in Murwillumbah; an 80-bed nursing home in Narrandera; 31 units in the Bathurst Gardens Retirement Village; and 220 units and 51 apartments in the Mountain View Retirement Village in Murwillumbah. Doug Moran has given great service to the country, for which I think he should be congratulated.

I salute Doug and Greta Moran and their family. They have made an enormous contribution to the aged and those in ill health in this country. When the history of Australia is written, theirs will be a very fine record that will stand out prominently. It is my delight to be able to pay tribute to them here today.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to have an opportunity to contribute to the discussion on the Working Nation document. The document is an important element in the broader economic recovery approach that has been fundamental to our policy direction over the last couple of years. I believe that the combination of the Working Nation document and this year's budget contributed to very real strides being made in consolidating the recovery.

PARA.TAB: It is worth noting a few of the statistics comparing Australia's position with that of other OECD countries. All too often, opposition members put to us that the recovery is not being sustained. There have been assertions that we were going to have double-dip recessions and other problems and that the recovery would not be a durable and enduring one. The last quarterly growth figures show that Australia is now growing at a rate of five per cent and that there is a real underlying growth rate of about 4.3 or 4.4 per cent. That very significant level of growth is the envy of other OECD countries.

Our inflation rate has stayed low throughout the recovery and the outlook is also for sustainable low inflation. For the first time in 20 to 25 years, we have been able to make the confident boast that we can have an economic recovery built upon the strong foundation of low inflation. All of the wages decisions taken by the government, in conjunction with the ACTU, are designed to reinforce the maintenance of that strong low inflation recovery.

Export growth, particularly in the manufacturing sector, has grown substantially in the last 18 months. That is an important part of the revitalisation of our economic performance, but also a recognition of our new capacity in international competitiveness. We now have an open economy, built upon the strengths of an international trading arrangement, in which our companies can compete. Our small and medium sized enterprises in particular are more inclined to look towards export market opportunities and are therefore playing their part in driving export growth in the manufactured goods sector.

For the past six to seven months there has also been strong growth in employment. All those who look at these issues in terms of economic cycles would say that employment—along with business investment, which is usually one of those lag elements in getting a recovery going—is going to be the last to show a significant improvement. Employment has started to move substantially. Last month's figures showed an unemployment rate of 9.8 per cent. This is still too high, and I would not argue otherwise, but we have had a growth in jobs in excess of 275,000 in the last seven months. This is a very significant turnaround in employment growth. It is also a recognition of what is occurring in the community at large and of the new economic and employment opportunities being created.

We can confidently predict that that growth will be continuing, despite the movement in the participation rate that will inevitably occur. It is interesting to look at international comparisons to see how strong the participation rate has remained in Australia over the last six to seven years. It will no doubt pick up again as in economic recoveries more people seek to move back into the work force. We have been able to have that strong participation rate while still having an overall improvement in the number of people in jobs and the percentage of people in employment. They are the sorts of background settings that are important when looking at what Working Nation seeks to do.

The fundamental thing that we sought to ensure through that process, which the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) made clear on election night, 13 March 1993, was that this economic recovery was one in which all Australians share. That is important. There is a tendency with international comparisons to see only economic changes that are occurring in some parts of the world. Because of structural adjustment considerations, and because regions might have particular industries that have been unable to meet the competitive pressures and the like, strong pockets of unemployment have developed in some regions that are, in a sense, intractable unless there is positive action on the part of government. We know that in many cases growth and economic change alone will not be sufficient to provide new jobs in many parts of Australia.

That has been true in areas like western Sydney and in industries like clothing, textile and footwear. That has equally been true in parts of regional Australia, where in the past particular industries employed a large number of people, often in limited or low skill areas. Those jobs are now being taken over as a result of restructuring in these industries—either through increased mechanisation or as a result of the different approaches that industries take when conducting marketing activities. The level of skill needed in the work place to match that adjustment process has displaced many people.

That means the government has had to constructively address ways of skilling our work force to ensure that all people are able to participate in employment opportunities as they come along. In recent times major efforts and resources have been put into our technical and further education sector. That will be an important part of providing the skill levels that people need. The range of labour market programs have also been an important part of that process. Clearly, the efforts that institutions put in to the transition arrangements from school to TAFE college and to work become important building blocks as well.

It was clear that the government had to do more to skill unemployed people, particularly those out of work for a significant period, 12 months or more, to a level which enabled them to take advantage of employment opportunities as they came along. That observation relates to unemployed people out of work for extended periods not just in Australia but in most developed countries. We need very significant, pro-active arrangements to get those people back into the employment market.

Comparisons can also be made with New Zealand. Its economy is now growing, even though the actual labour market has not grown significantly. New Zealand is starting to have skill shortages in some areas, despite the unemployment rate of over nine per cent. Many in New Zealand have expressed concern about that matter, and that is the sort of issue the Working Nation statement is designed to address in an effective way. It will ensure that something is done to provide a skills base so, as economic recovery gathers momentum, we get full value for all unemployed people who have been and are looking for work, irrespective of whether or not they have been out of the work force for a significant period. That is why the fundamental elements of the Working Nation statement are important. That is why the Prime Minister said that this recovery would be a recovery for all and that we would have policies enabling all unemployed people the opportunity to receive constructive, long-term training and job commitment on the part of the government in conjunction with the private sector. I think that is a very significant approach.

It is worth noting the fundamental elements of the job compact in the white paper. Amongst other things, it will provide more intensive case management; training and support to ensure that the unemployed person is job ready; a job for six to 12 months, primarily in the private sector; a training wage which combines employment with training, leading to recognised and transferable skills; new work opportunities which will encourage local proposals for employment generation, especially in regions where other employment opportunities are limited; and intensive jobsearch assistance. These are major concerns in most regions of Australia.

I had a discussion on Friday with the manager of DEET in my local area. About 25,000 people in the broader Parramatta DEET region have to be catered for. Clearly, it would have been abhorrent to the government to consider a proposition that did not do real and meaningful things to address the needs of those long-term unemployed people. If we multiply the 25,000 people in the region that I represent by all the regions across the nation, we see just what a commitment the government is giving in terms of that job compact—it is a real obligation. Equally, at the same time, we are asking for a real commitment on the part of unemployed people because of the resources and endeavours that we are requiring of the Department of Employment, Education and Training, other providers and the private sector.

I turn to the youth training initiative—another very important element of the Working Nation statement—and the opportunities that provides. It is clear that there needs to be a far greater focus on the transitional arrangements that apply to young people as they leave school and go into college. Indeed, the whole path from school to vocational training to the workplace and so on needs to be far more seriously addressed than has been the case in the past. So the youth training initiative is an important part of saying to young people, `We are determined to do something about the level of youth unemployment; this is a real, concerted way of ensuring that we give real commitment to you and we are expecting real obligation in return.' Working Nation is not just about the government taking the initiative but also about long-term unemployed people having opportunities and real obligations to take advantage of those chances.

I move now to other elements of the statement. There has been a big focus on a range of areas dealing with training in the regions of Australia. Again, I think that is part of ensuring that the skilled work force capacity across the nation is developed in the way it should be. Amongst other things, the regional development initiatives in this package include arrangements to fast-track the development of the international airport at Badgerys Creek. That is a very important initiative.

Numerous studies have identified the value of Badgerys Creek as not only an international airport but also an aviation facility for the broader Sydney region, as it will have a catalyst impact on regional development in western Sydney. It needs to be remembered that western Sydney is a very significant region of Australia—a region with over 1.5 million people, bigger than most of the capital cities of Australia. It is a distinct region and has particular characteristics.

The McKinsey report identified a series of companies in western Sydney that are very much a part of the export drive in manufacturing, which should be what Australia is all about. Often that is not understood by people when they talk about regions and what opportunities exist. The real opportunities to create employment in those industries in western Sydney are unequalled in any region of Australia. The employment growth and investment in manufactured exports that have occurred over the last five years in western Sydney are greater than in any region in Australia.

In developing a region like western Sydney there is a capacity to see how important the transport hubbing and the convenience of the region are. We should utilise targeted public sector investment to encourage that development to occur and we should encourage the facilitation of much greater private sector investment in the region as well. That is what the Working Nation initiatives propose for regional development. It is not expecting a large amount of public expenditure; rather it is expecting constructively targeted public expenditure that the private sector will build on.

McKinsey's work makes it clear that our economic future depends on small to medium sized companies that are innovative, outward looking and have an export focus. That is precisely the sort of thing that exists in western Sydney and that is precisely the sort of area that Working Nation encourages in the future. I believe the Working Nation document, along with the budget, provides real opportunities for all Australians to share in employment growth in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —The release of the government's Working Nation document was a cover-up by the government of the real reasons why we have a million unemployed people in Australia. In May 1994 more than 8,200 people in the Bendigo region were recipients of unemployment benefits from the Department of Social Security. The white paper, as the government called it—it has tried to title it Working Nation—highlighted the government's problems in this area.

PARA.TAB: The government has failed to recognise that most of the difficulties caused by unemployment relate back to the policies implemented by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) when he was Treasurer. He became federal Treasurer way back in 1983. Most of his economic policies, which were implemented then, resulted in massive interest rate increases and a steady rise in unemployment.

The Prime Minister became Treasurer in March 1983. At that time, the interest rate for housing loans was 12.5 per cent and it was 16 per cent for business loans. By December 1985—just two years after he became Treasurer; he had the opportunity to implement many of his policies—businesses were being hit with an interest bill of 21 per cent and more. Interest rates on business loans had moved from 16 per cent to 21 per cent in just two years and interest rates on housing loans subsequently rose to 17 per cent and more. It is not surprising that many thousands of small businesses went bankrupt under the Prime Minister's interest rate regime, which was quite tragic for rural and regional areas. I will mention some of them.

Many small businesses in the Bendigo federal electorate found that they were in extreme financial difficulty because of the massive increase in interest rates imposed on them by the Keating government. Due to the high interest payments, many farmers were forced off the land. They were forced to sell up—they left productive land which was contributing to Australia's export drive—take what they got for their properties and move into areas like Bendigo and Maryborough to try to find some form of work in another field.

It was quite obvious that it would not be possible for many farmers to be placed because of the difficulties small businesses in regional and country areas were having at that time with the massive increases in interest rates, which they were simply unable to cope with. Small businesses found that it was necessary to shed staff and reduce their work force. They incorporated members of their own family into the family business to try to help the business survive. The pressures on the family unit at that time were enormous. It is not surprising that many thousands of small businesses went bankrupt under that interest rate regime. In January 1993 the number of unemployed had grown to over one million.

Having created that problem, the Prime Minister now wants to spend about $5 billion of taxpayers' money to reduce the number of employed before the next federal election. Let us not have any doubts about the strategy. Working Nation is purely and simply designed to remove the long-term unemployed—approximately 300,000—from the unemployed figures prior to next the federal election. The Prime Minister is going to reduce those numbers by throwing $5 billion of taxpayers' money at the problem.

Any employment that is created through the Working Nation program will be short term. Employment under the job compact will last for only six or nine months. People who have been out of work for over 18 months will qualify for the job compact. They will be put into a short-term position for six or nine months and then, as a beneficiary under the job compact, they will be removed from the unemployment lists and the figures will start to look quite impressive. I can almost read the lips of the Prime Minister when he says to the press, `Here we go. The economy is coming good. We are reducing unemployment. The numbers of unemployed are decreasing month by month as we put people onto the job compact on a short-term basis.' It will all look very impressive to the unsuspecting Australian community.

One of things that has come out of Working Nation is the fact that the government has finally addressed the question of a training wage. Honourable members might remember that, in the lead-up to the last election in 1993, the coalition spelt out to the Australian community that there was a need for a training wage to encourage the employment of young people in industry and commerce. This would enable young people to at least get their foot in the door. They would have the opportunity to gain some meaningful employment through training, which is the key to their ultimate success and long-term employment prospects. To give a person a short-term employment prospect of six or nine months work and then take that person off the job compact and replace him or her with somebody else who has built up 18 months on the unemployed list is not the answer.

The government has finally admitted that the coalition had it right. It was correct to have a training wage which would encourage the employment of young people. They would get adequate training for a long-term career and not short-term employment for six or nine months.

Working Nation will not solve Australia's long-term unemployment. It will not make any improvements to unemployment because it has not made any improvements to the national economic strategies the government has in place. The government has gone off the rails in its regional development strategy. Regrettably, the government included the capital cities in its regional strategy. Instead of focusing on regional cities like Bendigo, Ballarat and rural areas, the regional policy, which was implemented by the government and which the government is focusing on, includes capital cities like Melbourne, Sydney, Adelaide, Brisbane and so on.

We all know of the political muscle of the capital cities when it comes to the distribution of funds.
