Any funds that the federal government has available for regions will be swallowed up by the capital cities. That has been evident with some of the proposals which the government has introduced. Obviously, this will continue even with programs such as the building better cities program where—

TALK.START.PARA: —Not under regional tourism development.

—I note that the Minister for Tourism, who is at the table, threw us a few crumbs, but he could always do better. I am grateful to the minister for what he provided to part of my electorate, but there is still much to be done by the government. Its focus is on the capital cities. Let us face it: the capital cities have much greater political muscle than regional areas such as Bendigo and Ballarat.

PARA.TAB: I would have thought the government's building better cities program would have concentrated on regional areas outside the capital cities of Australia and that the majority of money would have gone into building better cities outside the urban sprawl. The money could have gone into building better cities which would create job opportunities for young people throughout Australia. It would have been a very good way to stimulate economic growth in regional areas outside capital cities. But the Keating government decided that it would put most of the money into the capital cities. The real difficulty lies in trying to address the question of high unemployment in rural and regional areas of Australia, and the government certainly has not addressed that question.

The regional development strategy, which the Keating government has put in place, has focused very clearly on these capital cities. Most of the money spent on major projects—in fact, the ratio is more than 10 to one—has been distributed to the metropolitan cities of Australia. It is quite obvious that that pattern will continue and that regional areas outside capital cities will once again become the poor relation, even though they have some of the highest unemployment figures in the nation. At various times, some of these small regional areas in parts of my electorate have had unemployment levels of 39 per cent. That forces people to shift their place of residence to a capital city in search of work. Of course, that affects the whole rural community.

The regional development strategy that the government released some time ago contained some good recommendations. Surprisingly, the committee headed by Mr Bill Kelty of the ACTU made a very good recommendation with respect to the development of infrastructure in regional areas outside capital cities. But, strangely enough, the government did not take up that recommendation. That was one of the recommendations in the government's regional strategy document with which I agreed. Providing infrastructure to capital cities costs about 10 times more than providing it to some of these areas outside the capital cities. Even though the transportation and communications costs are slightly higher, the development of infrastructure in areas such as Bendigo would encourage metropolitan industries to relocate and new industries to establish themselves in those areas.

That recommendation was put forward by the Kelty committee, but it was not adopted by the government. The government still has scope to do something in that regard, but it has not taken the opportunity to do so. It has been focused simply on the prospect of removing the 300,000-plus people from the long-term unemployed list between now and the next election. It is simply a strategy to win at the next poll, and I do not think any member on the other side would deny that. They are very keenly aware of the problem that the high numbers of unemployed people is creating for them in their own electorates. They want to see that problem diminished before they have to face the voters at the next poll.

TALK.START.PARA: —They got it categorically wrong.

—That is not wrong. I have spoken to some government members in marginal seats and they understand the problem of high unemployment. They are terrified at the prospect of going back to the polls with the high unemployment figures they have now. They are terrified of the strategy which the government has implemented to provide short-term jobs. They know that, if the government is re-elected, that problem will still be there after the election. (Time expired)

—We have heard from government members, who have talked positively about the Working Nation package, and we have also heard from opposition members, who have not really talked negatively about the Working Nation paper. They continue to be at what IBIS Business Information calls stage three with respect to the progress that we should be making towards full employment. In other words, they are at the stage of asking what the government is doing about it and why the government has not done anything.

PARA.TAB: I believe that the government is moving into a reasonably positive phase. A lot more than what is specified in Working Nation needs to be done. But the government is moving into a phase where everyone is asking, `What can we'—not just the government—`do about it?' Let us hope that we can move into a phase where the unemployed are saying, `What can we do about it?' I think a lot of them are already doing that. We are certainly not at the same stage as the opposition, which is asking, `Why isn't the government doing more? Why did it not do something earlier?'

I believe that we have to look at what has happened in the past. If any mistake has been made by government, it has been because it has not looked at our history to see what has happened in the past. As a member of the House of Representatives Standing Committee for Long Term Strategies, I have been involved in considering the work force of the future. We have gathered some valuable information. We have received most of our information from business and academic organisations, political groups and other community groups. Quite a lot of national organisations have also given evidence to the committee. One of those groups is IBIS Business Information, which I mentioned before. It has clearly shown, through its submissions to the committee, that we are in danger of ignoring history, that some of the things that have happened in the past will happen again and that we ought to be working in recognition of those trends.

In a sense, IBIS Business Information is asking us to think about how people worked together before the Industrial Revolution. It has pointed out that, in a very real way, both unions and employers have what IBIS calls a subliminal gaoler's attitude. Employers believe that they have to keep people working in an area. Employees, some of whom descended from convicts, believe that they need to be regimented and they just want to make the conditions better. Big problems develop from that attitude, and we need to tackle those. For instance, at a time of recession or depression, there may be a need for people to move. I can remember a former minister for employment, Mick Young, telling me how much more mobile people were in the United States than in Australia.

Another problem is that we have had a tendency to put down our growing services sector. We have become blind to the reality that, in respect of world trade, our services sector, which was 10 per cent in 1950, is expected to increase to 50 per cent in the year 2000. Agricultural products, minerals and manufactured products are still important. We need to put a lot of effort into making sure that we add value here in Australia.

We also need to recognise the fact that the services sector is a legitimate sector. Unfortunately, just as a century or so ago people regarded mining as something that was done by the household or by the farmer and did not regard it as legitimate for firms to mine, we now tend to put down some of the service occupations. It is wrong for people to establish pecking orders and put down service occupations. That is quite offensive. It is the person who looks down on a waiter, or a doorperson, or a bouncer, or someone who is mowing lawns who has a problem, not the person doing the job. That attitude should not be allowed to infect the rest of society. Not only do these people have a legitimate occupation, but they may be developing towards another occupation through that job.

My son started as a film runner for a computer graphics firm that he wanted to work for in London. Just as your son, Mr Deputy Speaker Nehl, started at the bottom, my son progressed from that job as a film runner and gradually insinuated himself into the firm. He was co-winner of an advertising award, and now he is in the United States making movies for people like George Lucas and Steven Spielberg. That is what can happen with people who are prepared to see a job as legitimate, although they may even want to stay in that particular job.

Another point is the importance of outsourcing. It has happened continually. At the moment 51 per cent of an adult's work is unpaid housework, so housework provides an opportunity for outsourcing. If we can get work done by someone else in a fraction of the time and done more cheaply than we could do it ourselves, then surely it is worth trying. As well as that, business and farming people could profitably outsource. There are a whole range of opportunities which people can take through outsourcing.

For that reason, I believe that we ought to go beyond what is within the employment paper and look at the opportunities that are going to come up in Australia and that, in fact, will be available to the whole of the world. One of the opportunities for outsourcing in business would be computer software—and that is happening already.

In farming it could include harvesting and all sorts of jobs on the farm which are at present being done by the farmer, who very often has to buy expensive equipment, which he often holds on the property. For instance, in Sunraysia the government is putting in quite a substantial amount of funds for regional development. If the people there who lost their farms through the proposed mergers were to put their farms together, there would be occupations for those who wanted to take on contracting work, whether it be in harvesting, fencing, or any of the other sorts of jobs on farm.

Outsourcing provides particularly good opportunities for people in business. It is also a good opportunity for people in the provision of home services. Very often people would be glad to obtain a trusted and well-provided service. However, at the moment in families where both partners work, people come home and they have to get to work fixing the house up. If a trusted and well-presented service were available to people in the area of home duties, then it would fill a need. At the moment, potential users are inconvenienced by all sorts of things, such as washing dishes, looking after their swimming pool, helping their children with homework, minding aged relatives in the home, preparing meals, washing cars, cleaning house, minding children, assisting with study, and doing odd jobs and home maintenance. Very often they do not trust anyone to do this work, or else they cannot find a person of quality to do it.

I believe that it will not be very many years before firms which can do this are formed. Already there are firms in the larger cities, like Sydney and Melbourne, which make themselves available to do paid nursing, for instance. I believe that a need has been established for home services. There are plenty of examples of people who can do it. For instance, there is a firm in Sydney called Dial An Angel, which people can phone for assistance.

There are tremendous advantages, but the process will take quite a long time. What the government could do is encourage the process by providing a system of tax deductibility for outsourcing. This would take people out of the cash economy. At the moment they are asking for cash for work done and specifying that they do not want any reporting to the tax office. There would be an opportunity for an employing person to say, `I can get a tax deduction if I employ you, and I want to take advantage of that tax deduction.' Tax deductibility could be phased down from, say, 100 per cent in the first year to nothing in the 11th year. This would encourage employment, it would encourage industry to set up on a larger scale, and it would be of benefit for all involved—for those employed and for those employing.

At the same time, we could take the example of the job compact outlined in the Working Nation paper and we could specify, as the Commonwealth Employment Service does now, that people have to stick to the rule that there are no benefits if they do not take a job that is available. History shows that employment boosts have always come from the movement of services from home occupiers to outside providers—for instance, in the areas of tourism, catering, takeaways, restaurants and transport. When I was a child very few people went for holidays other than to the homes of relatives. Now people go for holidays to motels, to caravan parks, to all sorts of places, and a much smaller percentage go to relatives than previously. Laundry and dry cleaning is another area which has shown change.

The director of IBIS, Phil Ruthven, told of how he employed a firm called Jim's Lawnmowing. Jim would come around and mow lawns for him. Jim had four different lawn-mowers, so Phil asked, `Why do you have four different lawn-mowers?' He said, `There are at least four different types of lawn to mow, and I am much quicker and do a much better job if I use the right lawn-mower.' Now it is no longer Jim's Lawnmowing; it is a large enterprise which is doing work all over Melbourne. That is because those people are specialists, they do the job quicker than the householder himself or herself can do it, and they do a good job because they use the right equipment for the right service. We ought to be recognising the legitimacy of these services at the same time as we are adding value.

I will be supporting the Working Nation package right through my electorate, and I believe other members are taking advantage of the packages within Working Nation. What I have said before does not get away from the fact that we need to skill and that it is far better to skill people here in Australia than to bring people from overseas. It is far better to skill the unemployed, particularly if they have been unemployed for 18 months or more, and encourage people to employ them through the incentives that are mentioned in the Working Nation paper. It is far better to say to anyone below 18 years, as we are now going to say under the application of this paper, `You can't get unemployment benefits anymore. Either you are at school or you have a job or we will train you.' So I believe there will be great benefits, particularly in the area of tourism.

The minister at the table, the Minister for Tourism (Mr Lee), helped develop the recently announced $10 million package for the south-east forests of New South Wales that requires a local committee to be formed. There is great benefit in applying this package, along with the other packages that the government has made available. They include the tourism package which has been made available to the Jindabyne area, through which we are going to bring together the tourist information and national parks services to provide a great service to people going into the Kosciusko National Park. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today with somewhat of a heavy heart to address the government's document Working Nation: the white paper on employment and growth. It is for me a great disappointment that in 1994 a federal Labor government has given up on employing Australians. The Labor government no longer believes in a full employment policy, it has no prescription for rebuilding our industries that it has devastated, and it has no plan of action to put back to work all those Australians who not only want jobs but need jobs for their health and sanity. Here we are in mid-1994 with approximately 900,000 Australian men and women who desire paid work without jobs. In May of last year we had over 423,000 individuals classified as long-term recipients of income support for the unemployed.

PARA.TAB: It has been estimated that the unemployed, the underemployed, the discouraged job seekers and the dependent children of adults without work total in excess of two million Australians directly scarred by the lack of employment opportunity. Yet with this paper, entitled Working Nation, the government has addressed unemployment but not employment. It is not a vision for the future and how we will employ Australians but a series of packages and measures which will act to ameliorate the disastrous effects of unemployment on individuals' lives. In that respect, I find no great fault with the paper. I am not sure that all the programs will work the way they are intended to; I am not confident that the competition that is proposed for CES will be successful. However, essentially the problem is that the white paper is not a paper on employment; it is a paper on unemployment.
That Labor has given up on any goal of full employment is no more amply demonstrated than in a statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) when speaking to the white paper on 4 May. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The new provisions are tailored to meet the needs of the unemployed in the modern Australian economy. They will serve Australia for many years.

That says a lot, does it not? It says that the Prime Minister believes that this package of measures will serve the unemployed but not that it will find them useful, real employment. The Managing Director of BHP, Mr John Prescott, said of the white paper:

The resolution of unemployment will only come through fundamental growth and what would help growth is an idea of where we want to be in the future. Too much of the debate so far has been an economic debate.

John Prescott said what many in industry are saying: that we as a nation need a vision or a strategy—or a goal—for the future that recognises that full employment depends on economic growth, not programs; and that the economic debate over the past decade or so has concentrated on theoretical economics to the detriment of debate on the very practical opportunities and constraints faced by Australian producers of goods and services in both the domestic and international marketplaces. We in Australia need industry and we need jobs to fulfil the desires of Australians for products and services and useful work.

PARA.TAB: We went through a long period from the mid- to late-1940s until the early 1970s when Australia knew not what unemployment meant. We once reached the grand rate of 3.17 per cent unemployment, which was considered the limit beyond which a country could not sustain its people. Now we have lived with 11 and 12 per cent unemployment. We talk about considering five per cent unemployment to be the absolute minimum level that we have any chance of reaching. I do not know what the minimum level is, but I am confident that there must be many actions we can take to try to repair the problem in order to make employability and employment a reality for more and more Australians.
Back in 1945 the Curtin Labor government issued a white paper on full employment, which said:

SPEECH.PARA: The essential condition of full employment then is that Government spending should be high enough to stimulate private spending to the point where the two together will provide a demand for the total production of which the economy is capable when fully employed.

I am not sure that I really agree with the conclusions of the white paper, but it was written by the bright young economists of the time—when there was a great shortage of them, I might mention—and really introduced Keynes to Australia. Keynesianism is an economic policy which is very comfortable with socialism.

PARA.TAB: In 1994 the government has released another white paper on employment, but it is essentially a series of training programs and other labour market programs designed to ease the burdens of the long-term unemployed. The paper does not deal with the creation of employment opportunities in a positive sense. It is not an industry policy and there is not political agreement among the Labor Party, Liberal Party, the coalition of industry or even the community on how to reach full employment or even what it is. The white paper conveys no sense of urgency.

The long period when Australians were fully employed was a time when our agricultural products and the outputs of our mines were sold to the rest of the world at good prices and a time when we did not need to market them because the world was eager to purchase them. All we had to do was figure out how to grow them, produce them, process them or dig them out of the ground and transport them to other countries. The income from those commodities then provided us with one of the highest standards of living in the world.

With that income generated, we then built a manufacturing industry behind one of the highest tariff walls in the world. So Australia was in every sense an isolationist nation. We were an island nation continent in the South Pacific surrounding by a huge wall which was in many respects impenetrable. Behind that wall the manufacturing industry we built was, in many cases, inefficient, displayed poor quality and, in most cases, had no idea of commitment to service to the customer—because it was not necessary. The industry protected by tariffs, the competition was not available.

In the early 1970s when Whitlam came to power and we had the first of two major oil shocks that Australia felt the effects of during the 1970s, when Labor went riot and increases in the price of labour went through the roof, and when Whitlam in one fell swoop whacked 25 per cent off the tariff rates, our manufacturing industry went into spasm.

In 1962-63 manufacturing industry represented 26.2 per cent of the gross national product of Australia. However, by 1992-93 it represented only 14.7 per cent of the gross national product of Australia. All manufacturing nations in the Western world have experienced some decline in manufacturing as a percentage of their output. The telecommunications industry, the knowledge industry, the transport industry and the service industries have each increased in importance but no other nation has gone so far towards destroying its ability to make the products and supply the services that its citizens require for daily use as has Australia. We have destroyed in essence the very basis of what helps supply our needs.

We are faced with the problem now that every time Australia comes out of a recession, when people start to gain confidence, when people want to go to the stores and buy, they have to suck in imports at a great rate. So our spending on imports increases, not our spending on Australian produced products and services. Why? It is because too much of our manufacturing industry is gone. Too much of it has been blown away and too much of it is too small and too diverse to obtain any critical mass to be able to truly influence the world marketplace.

We really have only two significant world class companies that can structurally affect the market anywhere else in the world. The first of those is BHP. BHP today is not very happy with this government. It is not very happy with economic prospects in Australia and so it is investing offshore. That is because of the difficulties placed in its way in terms of resource development by the Mabo legislation and by the government's lack of commitment to reducing the current account deficit to enable us to survive after the recession without having an inflated economy. So the investment that BHP, a world-class player is making, is unfortunately not in Australia. It will ultimately benefit Australia but it certainly is not going to provide Australians with jobs.

The second world-class company that we have is Telecom, now called Telstra. Telecom, particularly now with competition from Optus, has become the second most significant provider of telecommunications services in this part of the world. It is second only to Japan. Telecom has a tremendous opportunity to take with it into South-East Asia all those small and medium sized companies that supply it with engineering services and supply it with products that it needs to build a telecommunications network. But this Labor government is now talking about selling Telecom.

I understand that if Telecom is to continue to be able to supply the infrastructure that we need in Australia for a modern, high speed telecommunications system, and if it is going to be able to compete in South-East Asia, then it needs capital. But the government has not got the capital to give it to enable it to grow at the rate at which it should.

I have two concerns about Telecom. I hope the government agrees to privatise it. But I will tell you what, if you do decide to privatise it by hiving off yellow pages or white pages or mobile net and leave us with the core but without enough critical mass to haul all the other bits and pieces with it into South-East Asia, then you will have done Australia a great disservice because we will have lost one of the jewels in the crown. We will have lost one of our only two significant world-class companies.

So, if you are going to sell it, sell it to Australians. Do not sell it to overseas interests, because overseas interests will not use Australia as the base to carry us into South-East Asia. The small and medium sized companies in my electorate that manufacture for Telecom, that surround it with world-class products and world-class services, will not get to South-East Asia because they will not have the vehicle to carry them there. By all means sell it to give it the capital to expand, but make sure that you sell it as an entity and you sell it to the moms and pops of Australia, not to the Yanks, not to AT&T, not to Bell Pacific, not to Bell Atlantic, and definitely not to the Poms either. Keep it in Australia for Australians. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the Working Nation paper, I think one has to recognise that this is a very good attempt by the government to address the problems that Australia finds itself immersed in. I have been listening to this debate with interest—to both sides, because I do not believe that wisdom resides solely on one side of the House. I particularly came in and listened to the member for La Trobe (Mr Charles) because I have some regard for him. I was hoping that he would spell out a vision—he tells us we are lacking in vision—but, alas, that was not the case.
—I ran out of time.

—I think the honourable member may be right. Time is running out for the honourable member. It seems to me that he does not understand the vision, does not understand where Australia must be going. I have a view that Australia's great challenge is yet to come. This nation has faced many great challenges in the past: the First World War, the recession, the Second World War and reconstruction after the war. I think the greatest challenge we face is the coming battle, a battle which must be fought, between the internationalists and the nationalists, for that is the battlefield on which the future of this nation will be decided. I make no bones about my position: I am firmly entrenched with the nationalists. The internationalists, however, have massive allies. They have the media, they seem to have both sides of this parliament and they have a lot of the vested interest bodies. The nationalists, however, have the numbers. They constitute the great mass of the men and women of Australia, who see the fraud of tying Australia into the international scene and see the dangers of it.

PARA.TAB: Let us look at history, for members here have said that we can learn from history—and I think we can. Too often we ignore history or, in the case of some of our leaders today, distort and lie about history. Let us look at the history of probably the greatest manufacturing entity that has ever existed in the world, the United States. How was the fortune of the United States of America built? It was built on protection, protection on a scale that Australia never conceived of. The average level of protection in manufacturing in the United States was between 50 and 60 per cent. What the Americans had was a policy of enormous competitive protectionism. There was enormous competition within their own community, and it was this competition that made them very capable of taking on the world, but their industry certainly was protected from international competition.

This occurred up until 1983, when the United States decided it would declare class war on its own people and adopted the policies of free trade. What this has bequeathed to America is enormous loss of prestige, enormous loss of economic power, debt out of control and a burgeoning underclass. The underclass in America, probably 20 per cent, is living a life which I would certainly not like to see in this country. I do not believe you can hold a country together when you deliberately set out to build such an underclass.

The United States says that its problems would be solved if only the wicked Japanese would lift all their tariff barriers and other sorts of barriers. The reality is that, if the Japanese did this tomorrow, which they are not going to do, the United States would probably sell another $10 billion worth of product into Japan. America has lost $300 billion in this mad cause of international trade.

I should add that average wages in the United States are now down to 1954 levels. That does not mean that everyone in the United States is getting less: some people are obviously getting a lot more, and some people are getting none at all. There has obviously been an enormous increase in the gap in the wealth and lifestyle that different people enjoy.

I fear that the same thing is starting to happen in Australia. Wages in this country are now down to 1974 levels, and yet we boast about it. We say, `What a good thing this is.' Once again, it does not mean that everyone is getting less: some people are getting a lot more, and some people are getting a lot less. How has this come about? It has come about quite simply. We have blitzkrieged blue-collar jobs and middle management jobs. That is where the trauma lies in Australia today. People talk about youth unemployment, but a far greater problem is middle-aged unemployment. For them there is less hope and less opportunity.

In the blue-collar culture—whether the feminists like it or not—it is seen as a requirement that the male be the breadwinner. What have we done? We have taken away the blue-collar worker's job and we have replaced it with jobs for his wife and jobs for his kids—part-time jobs, low paid jobs—but not jobs for him. This, of course, has led to a lack of self-esteem for such people.

We sometimes ask ourselves why we are faced with what might be described as `feral youth', kids who are out of control. How can we expect the head of the household to exercise control when he is unemployed and feels useless and inadequate? That is clearly an enormous social cost which has to be added to the total cost of the economic policies which we adopt.

It has been said—it was said by the member for La Trobe and it was said by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating)—that tariffs destroyed the Australian manufacturing industry. This is a fact which simply is not true, to use a contradictory expression. Take the example of the car industry. The car industry in Australia perished not because of tariff walls but because it was not Australian owned; it was always foreign owned.

The foreign masters would never allow us to develop a vehicle suited for our area, and they never allowed us to sell a vehicle where we wanted to sell it. We should have adopted the advice of the then general manager of General Motors—a great Australian, in my view—whose advice to the government of the time was, `You must develop your own car.'

However, then, as today, all economic decisions were made on one or two bases. Economic decisions are made either on the basis of fear of loss or on the basis of hope of gain. The idea was that by inviting in the nice Americans we could not fail. General Motors knew how to build cars. It could not fail. I think the firm was sustained by a $7 million loan from the Bank of Adelaide, guaranteed by the then federal government, and so we got a second-class American car—the Holden.

Had we designed a car for Australia, it would have been a car with unique properties. At that time, because we had large distances to cover, it probably would have been a six-cylinder car, with high ground clearance because of the condition of a lot of our roads. It would have been well sprung, and it would have had a big radiator and a big fuel tank, and we would have been the first in the field with airconditioning.

It would have been an ideal car for the Australia of the time, but it would also have been an ideal car for the whole of Africa, the Indian subcontinent and South America. We could have had the Volvo of the Southern Hemisphere, but instead we opted for a position where we did not even have a car that we could sell where the owners, our masters, did not want it sold.

That was why the car industry failed. The facts are these: in 1959 this country made more and better cars than Japan—many more cars and much better cars. Last year we made fewer than half a million cars, and the Japanese made more than 14 million very good quality cars. During that time, the Japanese have been hiding behind a protective regime the likes of which we have never dreamed of, and they have been highly successful with it.

The reality is that we must return Australia to the manufacturing industry. I have heard lots of talk about service industries, but it is the manufacturing industry that is the heart of this nation, and without it there is no future for South Australia or Victoria. We might just as well turn off the lights.

If you are going to have a manufacturing industry, I am not suggesting a return to complete tariff protection, although I do not resile from tariffs where they may be necessary. But you have to be intelligent about it; you have to decide what industries you want. There are clear categories. One category is those industries for which we have a strategic need, industries that we would need if the world were to catch fire tomorrow and leave us isolated. Those are the industries that may need some tariff protection. I note with interest that Israel has done this very well. It decided it needed those strategic industries; it protected them and now it leads the world in many of those technologies.

Other areas we should look at are industries where we have natural advantage. Sometimes these industries overlap. Industries where we have a natural advantage do not generally require any tariff protection, although it may be necessary as a start-up measure. I can tell members of this House that in a decade wool will be Australia's greatest export, not because we grow more wool—in fact, we will probably be growing less wool—but because we will be growing quality wool and marketing Australian merino wool, unlike the ubiquitous woolmark, which simply markets wool for the whole world.

It is interesting that the town of Biella in northern Italy, a town of some 50,000 people, makes more out of the sale of wool than Australia does. It does it by buying Australian wool and value adding it. We are moving in the right direction and, despite enormous opposition, the Australian company Austops, set up in Parkes, is doing very well. It is looking to expand because it has its order books full for two years. It is turning out a world-class product at better than world prices. We have leapfrogged the technology; we are now the best tops makers in the world. There was a very good article on Austops on page 2 of last Monday's Sydney Morning Herald—for those of you who read the provincial press. It is industries such as this that are going to make wool Australia's largest single export.

Another category that should be considered is industries employing what I call Australia's native genius, Australia's intellectual property. Something that is a world beater that has been developed by Australians should be kept in Australia. I was privileged recently to look at a company in Western Australia, Merlin Engineering, where two brothers, Daryl and Ra Wheeler, have developed a unique product. It is a hydraulic motor which embodies the attributes of two different sorts of hydraulic motors. At the moment you can have a vane type hydraulic motor that gives you high speed but very little torque—a characteristic of all vane type motors—or you can have a motor which gives you enormous torque but very little speed. If you could marry those two properties, you would have something which is saleable in the world. This is exactly what the Wheeler brothers have done; they have developed a motor that combines the properties of both types: they have a positive displacement, high-speed hydraulic motor.

The ramifications of this are just enormous. With this technology we could grab hold of world leadership in trucks. The car industry has gone; we cannot go back there; it is too late. But we are a big user of trucks by world standards, and we are a user of big trucks by world standards. With this type of motor you can revolutionise truck design; you can make a motor by putting these motors in each wheel; you can make trucks safer, more reliable and cheaper because you do away with expensive gear boxes and transmission systems. They are safer because they include dynamic braking.

In the mining industry, they would be an enormous leap forward in Haulpaks. The honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Charles) said that there are only two world-class players in Australia. Of course, that is not true. We are a world-class player in the mining industry generally. By world standards we are a big miner; we have the most efficient mines in the world.

What is needed to establish industries? Two factors are self-evident: a large customer and a state-of-the-art customer. In mining, of course we have both of those. Why then do we not have a manufacturing industry that services them? There is another imponderable but just as critical factor, which is government will. That is what is lacking in the establishment of a manufacturing industry to supply the mining industry in this nation. In fact, we are taking our management and our technology offshore; we are going to show Third World nations why we are the best miners. We are going to give them our knowledge—and then we will simply not be able to compete with their wages.

We talk of value adding, but you cannot value add our mineral product very much, because the market is Asia, and Asia does not want value adding. Asia knows that value adding means jobs and it wants to do it. Of course, a small niche is opening up for iron exports to China, where the demand for iron is so high that the Chinese would prefer to import iron. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wakelin Mr B.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pleasure to follow the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) in the debate on Working Nation and it is a pleasure to be able to agree with him. I will pick out three or four points that he made.

PARA.TAB: I have found myself very much in the mould of the nationalists rather than the internationalists, because I believe that Australia has too much to offer to allow itself to be submerged by any other philosophy. The honourable member for Kalgoorlie touched on the media. This debate on the white paper deals with very fundamental issues about the direction Australia should take, and I suppose it is appropriate for me to say here that my great disappointment during the 12 months I have been in this job is the trivialisation of the issues by the media. There are only two or three people who can come to grips with the issues in a thorough way. It is a difficult task, but to me too often the media are looking for the entertainment value and thereby trivialise serious issues.

The matter of the US underclass raised by the honourable member for Kalgoorlie has always been of concern to me. Although I have great respect for the Americans and they are our great allies, we are Australians and we must always remain so. We have much to protect and much that we should not borrow from our US allies.

The matter of unemployment of the middle-aged, particularly during this decade, is a very sad indictment of this country. Long-term unemployment is very much an issue that has to be grappled with, and the point about self-esteem and the ability of the leader of the household to give leadership to that household is a very important one.

There were another two points made by the honourable member for Kalgoorlie that I enjoyed listening to. One was the matter of the Japanese example and the quite astronomical protection in that country. It is pleasing to see removal of some of those barriers, but we must not underestimate or trivialise the way that the Japanese have protected their own economy. The second point he made that I enjoyed related to wool. It is wonderful to hear someone so confident about wool. As a wool producer I got quite a lift out of that. Even I have not been so bullish about the wool market as the honourable member for Kalgoorlie is, but it is a pleasure to hear.

In my contribution today to the debate on Working Nation, I want to talk about the ambitions of this country and the government's role in helping Australia to fulfil those ambitions. One of our most basic ambitions is to have a job, and we all know this is an ambition which for many is difficult to fulfil these days. The white paper purported to help us towards our ambitions for a job. However, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) sent a clear message to regional Australia that it should not hold such lofty ambitions.

In answering questions on the white paper, the Prime Minister said there would always be an unemployment problem in country towns. I must inform the Prime Minister that in my country town the unemployment rate is actually less than two per cent. Sadly, that is not the case in many others. He simply accepted that problem as a fact because the government cannot bear to extend any creative thinking towards regional Australia.

The Prime Minister also spoke of the aim to have 2,000 people to administer the new one-on-one case management system for the long-term unemployed. The Prime Minister said he felt that this was ambitious, and appropriately ambitious. I think it would be appropriately ambitious for the Prime Minister to say, `Yes, we can give more jobs to the regional centres. Yes, we can develop jobs outside of urban Australia.' However, this seems to be an ambition which the Prime Minister does not think is appropriate.

The Prime Minister also referred to Kelty's task force and its consultations with regional Australia. The task force recommended that the regions be encouraged to help themselves and specifically that regional economic development boards be established. This is a clear demonstration of how little the government knows about regional Australia. We have had development boards for years now. What does the government think regional Australia has been doing? Does it think we have been sitting on our backsides waiting for the government to help us attract industry and investment to the regions? If we had waited for the government's support and assistance, the unemployment problem in regional Australia would be even worse than it is now. The main thrust of Working Nation's ambition for regional Australia has already been up and running. The government had nothing new to offer regional Australia.

The Prime Minister also spoke of a need for regions to understand what they do best and focus on community objectives. Again, regions know very well what their focus should be, but their main problem is trying to get this government to take some notice.

I can cite two simple examples in my own electorate of Grey. The first is that Whyalla is competing to have a titanium dioxide pigment plant established in the town, and the council and the community have been running a petition for government support by way of tax incentives. The council and I attempted for some weeks to have the Minister for Housing and Regional Development (Mr Howe), our Deputy Prime Minister, personally accept that petition. It took many weeks for the minister to reply. When the reply came, he said that it was a matter best referred to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook). This is the kind of response that the regions find quite disappointing.

The second example relates to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Collins). Councils on Eyre Peninsula have been striving for some time to have the minister visit the area to look at the decline in their agricultural industries. Despite numerous representations—and I was assisted by my colleague Senator Ferguson in this matter—we have received no response at all.

This government regards regional Australia as a foreign country. The government cannot jump on a plane and visit regional Australia. It takes a special effort or a special task force. The government has to get people like Kelty to bravely step out of the city and talk to those strange regional people. Like a foreign country, regional Australia is left on its own to create jobs and growth. I believe regions have to take the lead and develop their industries and create jobs. However, government clearly must contribute towards this. The contribution from the government so far is half-hearted at best.

The white paper, which I have previously called `Training Nation' or `Stagnation', received its fair share of criticism, as you would expect in a vigorous democracy. Even before the release of the white paper, Richard Blandy of Melbourne University said that it would probably argue that restoring full employment was simply not feasible and that the term had even lost its meaning. This is true. Our standards and our ambitions for full employment are constantly falling.

It is a tragedy that the UN standard for measuring whether a person is in full-time employment is whether a person has worked for at least one hour—I repeat, one hour—the previous week. How on earth can one hour per week constitute full employment? The hole in the unemployment figures frustrates me and no doubt frustrates many others who are interested in the true number of unemployed.

Of course, it is getting more and more difficult to ascertain the number of unemployed as the government moves people into the different training schemes or onto welfare benefits. That was the true aim of the white paper: to muddle the unemployment numbers again, to move people into training schemes and temporary jobs which only add up to a bandaid on the huge problem of unemployment.

I recently spent time in the Pitjantjatjara lands in the north-west of my electorate. The similarities between the Aboriginal youth of those communities and the unemployed non-Aboriginal youth in the regional cities of my electorate were startling. Both groups are experiencing a kind of social dislocation. Both have all but given up looking for work. Both are involved in substance abuse. Both are involved in petty crime. They have similar habits: sleeping in and amusing themselves with recreational activities during the day, and roaming the streets or visiting pubs and clubs late into the night.

These groups have built up a kinship and reliance on their friends. When one does not have any money, he or she can rely on the rest of the group until the government cheque comes through. These groups do not have a lot of faith in the institutions of our society. Many of them do not have a clue about the so-called work ethic. It simply is not part of their culture. The development of this new culture in Australia is a crisis that we all need to be aware of. It is a culture which this government has very much helped to create.

The Prime Minister claims that a decade of Labor has created one of the most sophisticated social democracies in the world. I do not think we have become sophisticated, but rather we have become so bland and so afraid that we have no solutions to unemployment and, as a result, we have no work ethics or standards to hand down to our younger generation.

In this age of unemployment, how can we teach our youth what it means to have a job? In this age of reliance upon the government cheque, how can we teach our youth what independence means? Just look at their role models. Thousands of children are growing up in homes affected by unemployment. Countless children see their parents at home all day without work. This government says that it does not want two groups of Australians, the haves and the have-nots; however, there are clearly two groups at present, and these young people I spoke about represent one group.

To conclude, I want to turn to the matter of interest rates. There has been some discussion in the last week or so about rising interest rates. I took the trouble to get a few figures just before I came in here. The domestic debt—that is, the public, private and household debt—in Australia is about $600 billion. A one per cent interest rise on that comes out at about $6 billion. It is interesting that $6 billion is just the figure that the government has put into Working Nation over four years. The point I want to make there is the general point that the interest on our domestic debt, when it rises by one per cent, is $6 billion per annum. That staggered me and I was very surprised to see it.

The net foreign debt is $169 billion. Quite often we get a little lost in the hugeness of these numbers. I will never forget the headline some years ago when it was published on the front page of the Adelaide Advertiser. It made everyone just about turn off because it was too big a number to even contemplate. If we take a one per cent increase on this $169 billion net foreign debt—and we can talk about whether we take the loan long or short term, but most of this debt is short term and I think the numbers are still relevant—that would mean a $1.5 billion rise in costs to our domestic economy just through foreign debt. It is $6 billion to the domestic economy in terms of the domestic debt.

There are winners and losers in that, but who is the main winner? I would suggest that one of the main winners is the government through taxation and the generation of revenue. So the government spends this $1.5 billion, and there we have, with all the activity of the $6 billion rise in interest rates, the government being the beneficiary. To me that is one of the very cynical exercises of this reliance on debt. Debt is used not only to provide those consumption items that people need to have, but also to generate revenue and help the government balance its books.I will conclude with a quote about the unemployed from the Prime Minister. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: We are not going to leave them in the lurch. We are going to put out our hand and pull them up behind us.

This Prime Minister, when he was Treasurer and now as Prime Minister, has been reaching back, he would have us believe, for 11 years; he has been reaching back and pulling people up for 11 years. And we still have nearly one million people unemployed. I just wonder how long it will be before the Prime Minister acknowledges that he has contributed much to unemployment in this country by the sort of interest rate regime that he has put in place. He has gone through this nonsense of painting us as uncaring when he has done more damage by this whole business of his interest rate regime and at the same time claiming that he is reaching down to help pull people up. I find it most hypocritical and, as a parliamentarian, I find that it demeans this place.

TALK.START.PARA: —If Australia is to develop in the way which we all aspire for it, we must look at the regions to give us our strength. We will develop best when our development springs from the inspiration and commitment of the people who live in their sense of place. The goal is to put Australia to work. The aim of the Working Nation paper is to set those goals, give direction to them. These are policies for economic and social strength. By employing our people we are economically and socially stronger. We know what we would like to happen in our town, in our farm, in our suburb and in our environment. As the Kelty and the McKinsey reports both revealed, there is inspiration and commitment in abundance. The task now is to harness our local strengths and ideas in a strategy which will enable those regions to grow strong economies and create employment.

PARA.TAB: Firstly, we need to look inward to know who we are, what we can do, who has the skills and the best and the most efficient way of using them. Then we need to look beyond our regions and find niches in the mainstream markets in Australia and abroad. A lot of this has already been done and done at a local level. At the local government level in Tasmania, councils have been going through a dramatic reform process. Many have already been working on strategic plans, and changes in local government structures may have caused some upsets for traditional views. But they are honing down to this very important level to be much more efficient and effective organisations. We are beginning to participate in the modern Australia, to be part of the modern economy and thus reach out beyond our boundaries to the global economy. Each level must play a role. The Commonwealth is to provide strategic assistance of a kind that will enable the people of the regions to help themselves by investing in their own communities.

The strengths and weaknesses of the regions mirror the problems that face Australia as a whole. The consequences of recession and restructuring in different degrees are the same, along with the social problems, so the solutions must be similar. A regional development strategy must apply to the regions the same principles and programs as the national strategy applies. Industry and trade policy, export programs and the removal of impediments to finance and investment are policies for the regions. Labour market programs, training and education, and reforms to social security are also policies for the regions. The proper aim of a regional development strategy is that the people of the regions can, by their own efforts and ideas, share in and contribute to the nation's future growth.

My electorate of Lyons covers 61 per cent of the island state of Tasmania. Tasmania is seen as one region but is organised by various state and federal government policies as a series of subregions. Because of this, none of the regions functionally fits the Lyons electorate, making it difficult at times to assist in a strategic development. For example, most of the public servants live in the city, making it hard for many people to access them from remote country areas. Part of the federal government's assistance will be to ensure that those people can have the same advantages as the city people with access to programs and finance that can help them assist their region. It is aimed at helping people to think around problems, adopt new approaches and continue to develop promising old ideas.

Already there is evidence of Australians thinking smarter and across national boundaries. Remodelling old ideas, as mentioned in the Financial Review yesterday, is one such way. For example, Horizon Brewery has used the Mondragon cooperative model for its expansion process. The principles that the cooperative espoused have formed the basis of a successful 1990s style investment fund, where the investors have the final say in how the collective cash is managed and what types of investments are made.

One of the key regional development infrastructure changes identified in Working Nation is the ability to look at different ways of raising funds and assisting small investors to invest in their own future and that of their children. The Horizon Fund is one such approach.

In the same paper yesterday there was another story about a new $40 million wool plant to be established, marking an Australian company's first major move into upstream processing—a move long overdue, in my opinion. This tops processing company has estimated that the local tops making capacity will nearly double by the end of next year to about 60,000 tonnes, and this is still less than 10 per cent of the world volume—there is still a long way to go.

In Tasmania, new markets are being identified; we are thinking beyond our traditional boundaries. I have been looking at the possibility of putting Tasmanian fine foods on the plates of Saudi Arabia—I spoke about it this morning on radio in Tasmania. One of the world's richest areas, which has a culture of entertaining its friends and visitors very lavishly, should look no further than Tasmania for its delicacies, such as salmon or asparagus or a bowl of strawberries. If we can establish links with Saudi Arabia, it is an easy jump to the other Arab states around Saudi.

In order to think smarter and to help others to think beyond their state boundaries there is a need for the training that leads to developing new ideas. The Working Nation paper develops the theme of making sure our education and training are keeping up with all the other new developments; education and training are part of the overall strategic plan. Better skills promote better ways of doing things, and being more familiar with your region means new ideas.

Neither the government nor the public service must think that it is exempt from change. All must participate in the learning and the desire to assist others to learn. We are on the edge of a great `leap forward', as Chairman Mao might have said, except Australia is better placed to ensure that it is a democratic leap, with every Australian being involved in the process.

The necessary changes will not happen easily; a sustained effort will be required of us all. With such an effort our ambitions for Australia can be realised. Australia will enter the 21st century with a strong, dynamic economy, sustaining a society which offers more opportunities than ever before, more incentives and rewards for enterprise, and more security and cohesion. When we have the courage to do the job, then the satisfaction and the reward will certainly be ours.

We have a great opportunity to use the Working Nation paper, with all the work and effort that have gone into it, in the best interests of our nation. I spoke just now about getting regional focus and a lot of national programs certainly come in and assist our regions. There is a lot in this paper, and a lot of effort will be required to make the opportunities all work, especially in the regional areas, but we can do it. The paper gives us the opportunities, and I look forward to taking part in realising them.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been listening very carefully to the contributions by various members of the government on the subject of this very ironically entitled Working Nation paper. I am struck by the pious, self-serving, even smug set pieces which speakers have been delivering, in which each and every one of them has failed to address the fundamental structural problems of the economy and the way we work and produce goods in this country.

PARA.TAB: It is no good speaker after speaker burying his or her head in the sand and thinking that the problems afflicting the nation which are causing high employment—a huge foreign debt and month after month of balance of payment deficits—will go away. Quite the opposite. Whilst the economy is in something of a boom—although it is arguable as to what extent—and there may be a succession of economic statistics apparently favourable to the government, the fact is that the cycle will turn and turn much quicker than any of us who have the interest of the nation at heart would want. We are caught on a boom-bust cycle, and the government, by its very failure to address the long-term problems of the country, is condemning the country to a continuation of the cycle.

Let us look at some of the major issues that the government has squibbed on, to use a colloquialism. The first and most important, to my mind, is industrial relations. The cost of employing a person is prohibitive to small business and even medium-size business. And large business continues to shed labour, even in the face of improved economic data. The cost to business of employing people in this country is just too high, as high across the board as 40 per cent of the wage itself. For those 800,000 small businesses in Australia, the idea of employing a person, without a massive wage subsidy or under a training program as provided in some circumstances by the government, is fanciful.

The success of managers, both in the public and private sector today, is measured by how many people they can lay off, so as to improve, firstly, productivity and, secondly, costings. It is a terrible state of affairs when the laying off of people automatically results in improved cash flow, profit and performance. There is something disastrously wrong with the industrial relations system in this country if you get badges of honour and promotion in large companies according to how many people you have managed to let go—whether by voluntary or involuntary redundancies—and in small business by how few people you can avoid putting on in the first place. There is something very immoral about that concept of labour. It is something that has beset this country for a very long time and, despite the mass of industrial relations legislation presented by the government in the past few weeks, nothing will be done to alleviate the situation.

The cost of labour can only increase under this government's laughably termed `industrial relations reform'. The inflexibility and rigidness of both the wage fixing system and the influence of the trade union movement in the workplaces will continue, if not worsen, unabated. That is what is so terribly important to understand. I do not think workers have for one moment benefited from this government. Real wages have demonstratively deteriorated over its 11 years in office. Rather, it is the inflexibility, it is the work practices, it is the demarcation separations, which are the disincentive to employers.

The government does not represent the true and lasting interests of workers, as evidenced by the number of workers who have ended up in unemployment queues. The government also backs away from the hard questions of reform. We all remember, only a few days after the March 1993 election, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) announcing, with all of the boasting and bravado for which he is known, an industrial relations revolution which would see genuine workplace reforms leading to bargaining between employers and employees who were genuinely able to strike their own arrangements. In the absence of that trust or that line of communication, the relevant trade union would represent the worker. He quickly backed away from it and, some 12 months later, we saw presented to this parliament the hopelessly complex, detailed and unworkable legislation which killed off reform and was drafted largely by the ACTU.

Despite the many amendments and suggestions we made to improve the legislation, it went through largely unchanged, thanks, as always, to the Australian Democrats in the Senate, who are always willing to do the Labor Party's bidding in some sort of trade-off for one of their weirder and more wonderful individual pursuits. And, of course, the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton) has come back into the parliament seeking changes in an attempt to improve that initial legislation, which is an admission he got it wrong in the first place.

The power of the trade union movement to veto reform continues. Let me take as a very stark example the coal industry, for which I have responsibility as the opposition spokesman on resources and energy. The same Minister for Industrial Relations promised on 19 April 1994 that, once and for all, he would put an end to the renegade tactics of the United Mineworkers Union, which has conducted three strikes over the last nine months and has cost the coal industry—and, therefore, many ordinary Australians—hundreds of millions of dollars. He vowed to overcome, once and for all, the United Mineworkers Union's contempt—to use his words—for the decisions of the Coal Industry Tribunal, by bringing the Coal Industry Tribunal into the mainstream Industrial Relations Commission jurisdiction.

The Coal Industry Tribunal is a total anachronism. It is an antiquated body which is separate and apart from the Industrial Relations Commission. It sits out there all by itself, having been established in 1948, when there was just a domestic industry; and now of course it is largely an export industry. The minister promised legislation, but the House rises tomorrow and there is no legislation on the table. Many weeks after the minister's commitment, there is no legislation in sight. Round 1 has gone to the United Mineworkers Union. It would come as no surprise to anybody on this side of the House if the United Mineworkers Union and its acolytes within the Labor Party here in the House eventually succeed in forcing the minister to totally capitulate and preserve the Coal Industry Tribunal.

It is not in the interests of Australia, let alone of the workers whom the United Mineworkers Union seeks to represent, for the Coal Industry Tribunal to remain. It is hopelessly outdated and has the worst track record of any industry tribunal in the country. The industry has a mere 0.3 per cent of the nation's labour force, yet it accounts for 12 per cent of lost days because of industrial disputes. In 1993, when there was only the one national strike—there have been two national strikes in 1994; the Australian Bureau of Statistics has not yet caught up—the industry lost 3,288 days per 1,000 employees, because of industrial disruption. The all-industry average was 108 days.

The coal industry, with this industry specific industrial relations system, the Coal Industry Tribunal, lost 3,288 days when the all-industry average was only 108 days. That says it all. The strikes and the actions of the United Mineworkers have disrupted markets and cost jobs, yet the government is paralysed. The Minister for Industrial Relations promised legislation to reform the coal industry and abolish the Coal Industry Tribunal but we have not seen the colour of his money, and I do not think you should be holding your breath while you wait.

I have a couple of quick points before my time expires. Continuing this theme of resources, I turn now to uranium. The Labor Party has got itself economically and philosophically in a complete knot over this issue. How can uranium mined from Roxby Downs in South Australia or Ranger in the Northern Territory be somehow cleaner, more moral than the uranium that lies untouched in the earth waiting to be mined but prevented from being mined by the government's three-mine policy? It is breathtaking hypocrisy by government members.

They keep putting up this point that the market is saturated and that there is no economic return anyway. I do not accept that, looking at the economics of it, particularly as these proposed uranium mines need to come on stream to take advantage of the generally agreed upturn within two and three years from now.

But in any event, why should a government concern itself with the potential economics of the private sector? The principle is wrong. We do not make decisions in government to protect an industry from itself so long as, naturally, consumers or shareholders enjoy the protection of the law. There is no earthly reason, except for emotional and ideological obsessions, for this three-mine policy. It is disastrous for Australia's national interest and for many of the Aboriginal communities that want uranium mining to proceed. The left wing, together with segments of the trade union movement, is surely vetoing any rational assessment of this aspect of public policy.

I can continue with other examples of where the government has abysmally failed to address fundamental problems which affect Australians and stupidly hurt our capacity to provide jobs. The waterfront, cabotage and coastal shipping are all well-known areas. There has been inadequate reform across the board. The government can put up some initially impressive figures to show in various industries how there has been micro-economic reform, but they are hopelessly relative and meaningless as they are relative only to what has gone on before.

Also, in comparison to our international competitors we can never release the foot from the accelerator of reform. We must day in and day out drive forward with common purpose between employees and employers for greater and better efficiencies and productivity. We are all in this together. Despite this simple fact, extremists within the trade union movement have inordinate power to impede and in some cases completely stop the reform process.

There are many other areas of policy where the government can improve our economic performance and provide better jobs. However, we see the government unable to muster consensus within its own ranks on even the most simple and straightforward decisions, such as privatising ANL. That company is losing money hand over fist, particularly because of government indecision.

So on all those matters—industrial relations, the coal industry, the uranium industry, the ports, coastal shipping and privatisation—this government has failed the vital test. The vital test is simply whether it is acting in the interest of all Australians, with the end objective of providing jobs. Sadly, the answer is no.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not intend today to speak in detail on the fine points of the Working Nation white paper. This has already been done ably by my colleagues on this side on the House. What I intend to do is make some comment about the historical context of the white paper. I believe that Working Nation represents for the 21st century what the Chifley government's white paper of 1945 would have meant for postwar Australia if a Liberal government had not been elected in Australia in 1949.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is correct when he attributes much of Australia's economic problems of the 1990s to the sleepy 1950s. In that so-called postwar boom, a strategy, if you could call it a strategy, was implemented that in reality not only was disastrous relatively for the 1950s but laid the foundation for economic problems of the 1970s, 1980s and 1990s. The Chifley government had developed its white paper on employment in the mid-1940s as part of a plan for postwar reconstruction which, if implemented, would have laid the foundation for planned and sustainable economic growth for Australia in the postwar environment.

That white paper emphasised the need for trade unions and business to work together, as well as all levels of government, including state and local government. The 1940s white paper also argued for an efficient Australia-wide employment service, which was to ensure mobility of labour, to develop training and to provide vital information concerning the labour market for the formulation of economic policy. Instead, the Menzies government, with the particular complicity of the then Country Party, simply allowed the entry of foreign corporations into the manufacturing sector and then protected them with tariff barriers. There was no planning and no forecasting. The beginnings of Australian manufacturing in the 1940s were overtaken by the gradual foreign acquisition of Australian manufacturing industry.

Much attention has been paid to the lack of support for Australian research and development in that period. Whilst the rhetoric of the Liberals was anti-union, the government, through the period of McCarthyism and the red scare of the 1950s, was quite happy to assist tame-cat unions. Basically the deal was that they accepted the economic status quo and concentrated solely on wage determination. Unfortunately, the enthusiasm for strategic planning of the 1940s waned. But the chickens came home to roost in the early 1970s. The nature of the international system began to change and the Australian economy was not adjusted to change. Such was the Menzies legacy. The indicative planning mechanisms used in Europe were absent in Australia. For many reasons, capital at that time became much more footloose and internationalised. In Australia, for various social and economic reasons, the participation rate of women in the work force escalated.

Some, though not a majority by any means, of the former less developed countries began to develop strategies to attract manufacturing away from OECD countries like Australia. Japan, of course, was the first and best at this. But particularly in countries other than Japan low wages and non-unionism were always the keystone of these strategies. Slowly the focus of world manufacturing shifted from the OECD to Japan and later to the Asian tigers, Taiwan, Thailand and South Korea, for example. Even the United States felt the pinch, despite the overall strength of the US economy. The Australian labour movement and the ALP grappled in the 1970s to find policy solutions for these changes. Some, like Gough Whitlam, sensed that tariffs and protection were part of the problem, so they saw the answer in the reduction of tariffs.

But, of course, the Liberals could not make up their minds about tariffs either in the 1960s. It was a big issue for the Liberals. It cost Billy McMahon the prime ministership for some time. They still had no policy except for McEwenism, which was simple—an ad hoc example of the early Menzies no-policy solution. Unemployment began to grow as manufacturing in Australia declined. Then we had the Fraser government, which had no policy answers at all. Nothing like a plan or strategy was adopted by the Fraser government. Malcolm Fraser simply blamed the trade unions, maintained the Whitlam level of tariffs and did nothing else.

By 1983, something clearly had to be done. The ALP went to the election that year with the accord as one of its major policy promises. The accord contained the seeds of the white paper which we are debating today. It revived the concept of strategic planning for growth and employment, which had not been part of policy since the white paper of the 1940s. With the accord, the trade unions, revitalised by the demise of NCC influences in the 1950s and 1960s, took up the baton that would have been taken up in the 1950s if Menzies were not Prime Minister.

The unions turned their back on a simple focus on wages policy alone and focused on the role that they could play to improve Australia's industrial efficiency, not only to stave off the effects of de-industrialisation, but also to build up Australia's export capacity. However, the trade unions in Australia accepted the accord on the proviso that the Australian standard of living through the award system be maintained.

I noticed that the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran), who preceded me in this debate, made the completely hypocritical statement that somehow real wages have not risen. In the last 10 years, Mr Deputy Speaker, do you remember any office holder of the coalition, any shadow spokesman, any opposition member, supporting a wage increase for workers in this country? I cannot. Every time the ACTU made a wage claim, what did we hear, either from the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) or the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock)? They would say, `No, it is not the time,' and yet they have the hypocrisy to come into this place and talk about real wages.

Jobs were created in the early period of the Hawke government. The number of industrial disputes drastically declined. Though the accord process became more and more concerned with the wage fixation regime, the ACTU continued to call for a more strategic approach to industry planning. A document called Australia Reconstructed was produced by the officers of the ACTU. Again, that document contains some of the seeds of the white paper that is before the House today.

I would like to pay a tribute in particular here to someone who was vilified by the Fraser government, and that is Laurie Carmichael, who was one of the architects of that early policy. I do not think there is anyone in Australia who has the dedication that Laurie Carmichael has to the idea of the importance of training in Australia, and now what Laurie Carmichael is saying is orthodoxy, but when he was talking 10 years ago it was new and innovative.

Did the Liberal Party of Australia rethink its policies of the 1950s and develop some sort of policy mechanism that included planning that had been practised 20 years before by its equivalent parties in Europe? No. What it did was to begin to mimic the policies of Margaret Thatcher and Ronald Reagan. That is what it did. These policies were based simply on an attempt to destroy that earlier postwar compact I referred to between even tame-cat unions and the government over wages. It was an attempt to destroy the trade union movement, again merely mimicking the Asian tigers. However, that policy failed to halt industrial decline in those countries, and it may have even accelerated it.

Labor in government is faced with the reality of the continuing global restructuring of the world economy and with the problem of unemployment, which is faced by all comparable nations. The problem of long-term unemployment is acute in Australia, as it is in other OECD countries. Long-term unemployment is one of the major focuses of this white paper. I think it was the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) who highlighted the fact that long-term unemployment is faced by older people in the community—middle aged people. We always talk about youth unemployment, but middle aged people who lose their jobs quite often find it hard to adjust and to retrain.
The Australian people wanted a dramatic and visionary statement to provide the framework to face these challenges.

TALK.START.PARA: —They didn't get it.

—They rejected the low wage strategy, put up in the form of jobsback, at the 1993 election. They rejected the complete downgrading of government responsibility in Fightback. They elected the Keating Labor government. The 1993 industrial relations legislation, coupled with Working Nation is, thankfully, the nail in the coffin for a low wage strategy in Australia. Australia has to look towards developing high performance industries, whether we are talking about manufacturing, tourism—the major industry in my electorate—or retail. The harsh reality is that there are no other choices.

PARA.TAB: Education and training are the keys to developing high performance industries. Federal Labor has a proud record in funding primary, secondary and tertiary education. The white paper contains a $3 billion increase in funding over four years for labour market programs. That represents a massive commitment to education and training.
