The changes initiated by the Minister for Social Security (Mr Baldwin) and the essence of the jobs compact emphasise `security' in the concept of social security. Only with a secure social safety net, in both the benefit area and the labour market area, and only with the maintenance of an award system for those in work, can Australians be expected to agree to the changes that are necessary to take them into the next century. Reaganism and Thatcherism, still the policies of the coalition, have failed in their own terms in their own countries.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nonsense.

—The honourable member opposite disagrees. Look at the decline in Britain. What has Thatcherism brought Britain except further decline? What has Reaganism brought the United States? The United States is still going further down the manufacturing rung. It was once the world's greatest manufacturing nation. Reaganism has not delivered.

PARA.TAB: The white paper of the 1990s will provide the framework for the 21st century that the white paper of the 1940s promised, but which Robert Menzies and his government spoilt with their indifference to Australia's future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nugent Mr P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure whether it is a matter for humour or whether it is just sad, but so often in this chamber government members make speeches on critical current issues and devote nearly all of their time to talking about what Robert Menzies was doing 30 years ago or what happened in this country 40 years ago. Whilst, obviously, some components of their speeches may be relevant, we are here to talk about what is happening in this country today, particularly what has happened in this country in the past 10 or 11 years, since the government has been in office.

PARA.TAB: If we are talking about Menzies, there are a couple of points to be made. One is that during the Menzies time we were actually living in a different world, and the whole globe was living in a different world. Whilst there are some things you want to compare, the reality is that it was a different world. But if you want to compare, the facts are these: unemployment was low; inflation was low; the standard of living of Australians was better compared with the rest of the world than it ever has been since; we did not have the international debt that we have under this government. So if we want to talk about Menzies, we have to accept that they were pretty good times for the times that they were.

But, of course, that fact is always conveniently forgotten by those on the other side who, in the last 10 years, have managed to pretty well bankrupt this country. We now have an international debt of nearly $200 billion, and that is an absolutely phenomenal increase. We have seen a phenomenal rise in unemployment. In my electorate alone it has gone up by nearly 700 per cent in the lifetime of this Labor government. I think it is important that we recognise that there are lessons to be learned from history, but we can dwell too much on talking about what happened 30 years ago when we ought to be concentrating on what is happening now.

We are here to debate the government's document, Working Nation. It is a fairly thick tome but, of course, it largely tries to disguise the realities of the situation because the government is not able to actually fix the problem. It is something of a non-event, it seems to me. I want to talk about a couple of aspects of this document, in particular the matters concerning Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people—indigenous people. It is an area in which I have taken a particular interest in the four years since I have been here. I am also going to talk about the situation in my own electorate.

My electorate of Aston is an eastern suburbs seat in Melbourne, and it is an overwhelmingly young electorate. I have a lot of young people, and a lot of young people in this country today face the prospect of going through the school system, coming out of the education system at whatever stage and finding it very difficult to get jobs. This document offers more training by putting them on artificially contrived schemes and getting them off the unemployment lists for a few months, but it does not actually create jobs. That is really what, it seems to me, young people in my electorate are looking for. A lot of youngsters say to me, `What is the point of studying at school? What is the point of taking the HSC? What is the point of going to university because when I come out I cannot get a blooming job anyway?'

I have a young electorate. I also have more mortgage payers than any other electorate in this country. My electorate is the mortgage belt of Australia, and we are seeing what the markets think of this sort of document and the budget that followed it a few days later. Interest rates are starting to go up. It is interesting that in my electorate two or three years ago, when interest rates went through the roof under this government, there was massive hardship, massive social dislocation. What we need to see, and what the government has failed to deliver this year, is some sort of savings policy, some incentive to get people to save, so that we do not have to start going overseas cap in hand and borrowing overseas money.

People want to see, and the many hundreds—in fact, 6,000-odd small businesses in my electorate want to see—some investment incentives to give them some assistance in terms of updating their business and starting to let them be more efficient in the way they do things so they can compete with imports and compete successfully overseas. The 6,000-odd small businesses in my electorate want to see less paperwork for the government. At the moment most small businesses in this country spend an absolute fortune on government paper and regulations. That needs to be significantly reduced.

Most of the small businesses in my electorate want to see a reduction in taxes, particularly the taxes that are charged on business products and those products that are going to go overseas, so that they can be more successful. Most small businesses in my electorate want to see more flexibility in the industrial relations field, because if they can have the flexibility, then, of course, they are going to be able to employ more people.

If those sorts of incentives were provided for small businesses rather than artificially contrived job creation or training schemes, those small businesses would be better able to hire more people. There are about 800,000 small businesses in this country. If each one of those businesses took on one extra person there would not be an unemployment problem in this country.

What are young people being trained for? The disillusion is very real. What about the women who are increasingly looking for jobs these days? We have a whole new social revolution. That is not addressed in this document. I agree with the previous speaker's comments in regard to the mature aged unemployed. We often forget that the mature aged do not get the publicity in the current unemployment situation. A mature aged bread winner is often by definition the sole income earner of the family. For a man 45 to 50 years of age who has perhaps worked for the same company for 20, 25 or 30 years and is retrenched it is not easy to retrain. Often the sorts of jobs that he can go for are the jobs that are disappearing.

He goes home and he has the indignity of having to tell his children that he cannot get a job, that he cannot support them, that he has to go on the dole. His and his family's lifestyle have to be curtailed. There is the worry and stress that go with that and the prospect that perhaps he will never work again, even though he was promised an upturn in the economy a few years down the track.

In terms of the long-term unemployed it seems to me we are in severe danger of creating in this country, as has happened in other countries, an underclass and the social consequences that come with that of crime, substance abuse and so on.

So whether we are talking about the young, about women, about the mature aged unemployed or about the long-term unemployed, this document does not do the things that are necessary to actually create jobs. Working Nation does not address the issues. It hides the number of unemployed under other headings. It provides training but not the jobs. Let me quote the Australian Youth Policy in Action Coalition, which quite correctly says:

SPEECH.PARA: The white paper produces training but not jobs for young people. Labor can take the first step, money for training, but it does not know what to do after that.

The Labor government can always find more ways of increasing taxes, and it is increasing taxes. We have not had the promised tax cuts. We are raising more revenue from tax both directly and indirectly as a result of the current budget. It can always raise more money from the taxpayer but it cannot follow through with jobs for young people. It does not deal with the other issues affecting labour costs, such as the restrictive award provisions which will continue to inhibit the capacity of business to grow and provide more jobs.

PARA.TAB: Businesses, particularly those smaller enterprises that I was referring to, are also concerned about the new industrial relations regulations and provisions relating to termination which we have seen in this place in the last week or so. If a prospective employer is concerned that if he hires somebody he cannot get rid of them if they do not perform, that is obviously going to discourage that employer from hiring in the first place. So it has become a positive inhibitor to employment.

It is becoming more and more unattractive for employers to provide permanent full-time employment. We have seen that over the past 10 years. The percentage of casual employees in the workplace has risen from around 15 per cent to well over 20 per cent. The question has been asked: why does the `training wage' have to be subsidised by taxpayers rather than being able to be determined by negotiation between employers and employees, at no cost to the taxpayer?

For example, the accord protects the status quo. Rather than allowing some flexibility whereby the unemployed can negotiate directly with an employer, it takes away the bargaining power of the unemployed. It is this fundamental inflexibility in our working arrangements in this country which discriminates very specifically against those who are unemployed at the moment. But that is the accord; it protects those who already have jobs but does not look after those who do not have jobs. The government's attitude is to throw money at the problem but not fix it.

Another example of rhetoric is trying to improve employment for indigenous people but not actually succeeding. There has been a lot of big trumpeting around the country that the 1991 census showed a drop of 4.5 per cent in unemployment for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. However, we must recognise that those Aboriginal people are still almost three times as likely to be unemployed as a member of the broader community.

The government does not highlight the fact that up to 70 per cent of all unemployed indigenous Australians have been without a job for more than 12 months compared with 46 per cent of unemployed people in the broader community. Nor does the government highlight the fact that the average income for indigenous Australians has declined. Nor does the government draw attention to the fact that the overall employment situation for young indigenous men living in towns and cities has worsened. Nor does it admit that there is no evidence that there has been any reduction in the overall dependence of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people on the welfare system.

The major strategy to addressing the severe unemployment problem in the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander community is the community development employment program, or CDEP. This is a work for the dole scheme. I and the coalition support it as a concept. I believe that it could be extended to other parts of the community.

A major part of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission's funding—$234 million in 1992-93, or 26 per cent of its budget—is expended in the CDEP scheme. We should also acknowledge that a significant proportion of that money—over 60 per cent—is offset and clawed back by the government against social security payments, giving only a net cost to the government of about $93 million. So it is all a conjuring trick. We are spending this large amount of money here but we are taking it back there. What we are actually spending to try to deal with these issues is much less than what the government would have us believe.

Even more important is the wider context of addressing the tragedy of unemployment in the indigenous community. The government trumpets a success in employment for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. It talks about the 22,000 people who are employed under the CDEP. In reality, that hides the true level of unemployment, because they are not real jobs. It is a useful, constructive scheme, but it does not provide real jobs. It does not provide a long-term answer. Whilst we certainly support the CDEP, it has to be understood for what it is.

There is no forward path from the CDEP scheme. There is no method of getting further long-term sustainable economic jobs. This year, the government has cut back on the money that it has allocated to the Commercial Development Corporation in ATSIC to try to provide those jobs.

It is all there in the ATSIC review of the employment policy for indigenous Australians, which is called The review of the Aboriginal employment development policy. In fact, the government should have read that review before dreaming up its token section in the white paper in relation to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. In this document—time precludes me from reading it—there are four meagre dot points. The point is that over 90 per cent of the money it is offering will not be there this year. Over 80 per cent of it will not be there until after the next election. There is a net $28 million in it of which $3 million will be spent this year.

What the government is offering to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people is a con. The AEDP review lists 59 firm recommendations which could have been put into effect to create some real jobs. It seems to me that this document is a sham and a fraud. It will not do the job. The government ought to hang its head in shame. There is no question that at the next election the people will deliver their verdict with a thump.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to take part in this debate today on the white paper entitled Working Nation. Working Nation is a wide ranging policy document. It covers a whole policy agenda to make Australia competitive in the world and increase the standard of living for all Australians. It sets the scene and builds upon, as every program this government announces does, the environment for economic growth.

PARA.TAB: As the honourable member for Aston (Mr Nugent) is leaving the chamber, I would just like to take up one point that he made. I do not want to be too critical of him; I am going to save that for some of his colleagues. He made the point about overseas debt and we hear it constantly from the other side. What those opposite never say and what they are very quiet about is that this is mainly private debt. The way they are talking on the other side one would constantly think that the government is borrowing all the time. I think the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear) could show how long it has been since that occurred. We are talking about private debt, not public debt, and the sooner those opposite come clean on that—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is national debt and the country has to pay the bill. It is your regime that has caused it. There is no savings program in this country.

—I hear the honourable member going on about the fact that we have to pay the rate on it, but it is private debt not public debt. The way those opposite talk about it, one would think it was all government borrowing.
—That is because you do not have a savings regime that allows investment in this country. You are trying to distort the facts. You are uncomfortable with the truth.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Snow)—Order! The honourable member for Aston was heard in silence. I ask him to reciprocate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was remarkably restrained throughout his whole speech, as was the Assistant Treasurer. I want to turn to some comments that the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) made. I understand that the honourable member for Gippsland is now the opposition's resource spokesperson. Two weeks ago in this chamber he did not make a bad speech, especially for the honourable member for Gippsland, on the coal industry. After the speech I congratulated him on it. I rang a few of my friends in the miners federation and said, `He is learning a little and he did not make a bad speech. I think you should go and talk to him.'

PARA.TAB: Today he returned to the old National Party `kick a head' speech. He was talking about the Coal Industry Tribunal, which there is debate on at the moment, and he was talking about the number of days lost. I do not know where the honourable member for Gippsland gets his figures from. His figures are most certainly very different from mine. I would suggest—I do this in a spirit of friendship with the honourable member for Gippsland—that he goes and talks to the federation instead of just talking to the coal producers.

I represent a coalmining area. I will go down a coalmine with him in my area on the south coast. I will arrange for him to meet with the leadership of the miners federation. I think he would learn a little and it would save him the embarrassment of coming into this House and constantly trotting out this nonsense about the coalmining industry. He just displays his ignorance in this area. He is not an unintelligent person, although he tries to disguise it. I am sure that, if he came down and had a meeting with me and the miners federation, we would put him right on some of these areas. I know he is keen to learn, and we will do our best to assist in his education.

He then further compounded his ignorance and displayed his lack of knowledge to the House by bringing up the question of cabotage again. The issue of cabotage is very interesting. There are very few countries in the world that do not have cabotage. We will maintain cabotage in this country, as we should, and why should we not? I will tell honourable members why we will maintain cabotage. Two tankers have gone down off the South African coast in the last couple of days. The coast around Cape Town is being polluted with oil. We see it on the television every night.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ships of shame!

—My colleague the honourable member for Calare reminds me, not that I need much reminding, about Ships of shame. I am delighted that the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker) is now in the chamber because, if I have time, I have a few comments to make about his contribution the other day. The opposition wants to introduce to the Australian coast ships such as those which are polluting the South African coast at this very moment.

PARA.TAB: As I have said time and time again in this chamber, the shipping lane for most of our shipping is through our premier tourist resort, the Great Barrier Reef. The opposition, I am sure, will not be satisfied until it sees the Great Barrier Reef, our premier tourist resort, awash with oil. And it will be awash with oil unless we stop these ships of shame, these rust buckets that are trundling up and down the coast.

Mr Speaker, you of all people know this because you represent the Illawarra area, as I do. We see the ships that come into Port Kembla. You have been with me to inspect some of these ships which are in a disgraceful condition. They go up and down the Australian coast, mainly from our area, taking coal to Japan. If one of those ships were to go down—it is the bilge that would do the damage there—it would create irreparable damage to the Australian coastline.

I heard the honourable member for Gippsland talking about selling off ANL. As I said in this chamber on Monday, opposition members have those cheap flags, made in Taiwan, on each of their desks as some sort of nationalistic thing. If they are so keen to have the Australian flag fluttering, or rather limply sitting, on their desks, why are they so ashamed to see the Australian flag on Australian ships? That is the question they have to ask themselves. They come in here and talk about the Australian flag, wrap themselves in the Australian flag and display it on their desks, yet they do not want to see the Australian flag on Australian shipping. While ever I am in this chamber I will argue for Australian flagged and crewed shipping sailing under Australian conditions.

The honourable member for Wannon in his contribution made much of port charges. He very cleverly avoided saying that I had a briefing last week with representatives of the Australian shipping industry. I was not the only member there. Also there was the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Neville), the honourable member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur) and the honourable member for Sturt (Mr Pyne), who are all from the opposition side of the chamber. Representatives of the Australian shipping industry in Sydney raised with us the cost of Australian ports.

The major increase in costs at Australian ports over the last few years has been in port charges. Who imposes port charges? The honourable member for Hume (Mr Sharp) would know. It is not the federal government that imposes port charges. It is the state government. Of what political persuasion are those state governments? What happens to be the political persuasion of the state governments in New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia or Western Australia? If one wants to find the culprit for increasing port charges, one should not look to the federal government; one should look to the state governments, who actually impose the port charges. That is where the cost comes from. It does not come from us.

My own personal view is that we actually should take over the ports, but I doubt that I would get a lot of support in that line. So all I am asking is that when members of the opposition come in here and want to debate these things, especially as it refers to the Coal Industry Tribunal, as it refers to shipping or as it refers to cabotage, they have a little bit of honesty in what they are saying. When some of the claims that have been made are investigated, it is found that there is no substance there at all.

If the opposition has its way and cabotage is abolished in this country, and if the rust buckets of the world are permitted to go up and down the Australian coastline, eventually someone will pay a tremendous cost. It will probably be the taxpayers of Australia as it is in South Africa. A clean-up will now have to go on around Cape Town because these ships have gone down. The taxpayer there will have to pay for that, as indeed in Australia it will be the taxpayer who will have to pay when one of these rust buckets inevitably goes down, which it will.

TALK.START.PARA: —It being 3 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with standing order 101A. The debate may be resumed at a later hour.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Consumer Affairs. Does the minister agree that it is dishonest for baked beans made from beans imported from Hungary and tomatoes imported from Thailand, placed in cans made from imported tin plate, with labels printed in Singapore, to be described as `made in Australia'? What action does she propose to outlaw such a practice? What guarantee does she give, if any, in relation to that legislation?

—This legislation is before the House and currently going before a Senate committee. It has been before a House of Representatives committee where the only amendment asked for by the other side, after examining it very closely, was that we extend the time for industry to comply from 12 months to 18 months. Exactly the sort of thing that the Leader of the National Party describes will be outlawed by this bill.

PARA.TAB: I remind people that at the moment canned food, for instance, because of the National Food Authority requirements, has to have an address on it. That address could be in Brisbane or Sydney, and it could be the only identification on the can of the contents of it. Under the legislation that will be seen as an implied claim to being Australian. Therefore, the can will now have to have the very clear identification `canned in Australia from imported fruit'. Exactly the sort of thing that you are describing will be outlawed by our bill. We will have two major terms. Of course, I have talked about this very often in this House. For two years we have been looking at it.

TALK.START.PARA: —How about some legislation?

—You have asked for the legislation to go to two committees. It has been to one committee and is going to the other committee. The legislation was to begin being debated yesterday, but at the request of the opposition spokesperson, and in the spirit of cooperation which we have had throughout this, I withdrew and delayed it so that we could talk even longer and so that the very people you are talking about, the processors who are so concerned and who have been so misled, can sit down with me and the experts on this issue and tell me exactly what their concerns are to see whether those concerns are valid.

PARA.TAB: I tell the House that at this stage not one person—not one producer—with a concern has come to us and gone away still concerned. If people have been misled, we want to clear up that misleading information, and we will. That is why I plead again to anyone who has a concern that they have been misled on this legislation to come and sit down with me.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was on The Investigators last week.

—Had The Investigators program in all honesty broadcast the clear answers I gave to every misleading comment that was put on—they were not broadcast—then perhaps we would not be having these foolish and confusing questions now. I ask once more—I plead, and it was my condition on withdrawing the legislation for debate yesterday—that any producer or manufacturer who has a concern bring that to me and the experts in this issue so that we can get rid of those problems.

—I inform the House that we have present in the gallery this afternoon members of a parliamentary delegation from the Islamic Consultative Assembly of the Islamic Republic of Iran. On behalf of the House, I extend a very warm welcome to our visitors.

PARA.TAB: Honourable members—Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Can the minister inform the House of the Melbourne casino enterprise agreement lodged with the Australian Industrial Relations Commission? Why is this agreement being processed federally and not through the Victorian industrial relations legislation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brereton The Hon L.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Dunkley for his question. Last Friday, in what should have been a litmus test for the Victorian industrial relations system, the management of Melbourne's Crown Casinos went not to the Victorian system, but to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission to register its new industrial agreement. For the information of the House, the greenfields site agreement covers 2,000 workers and just happened to be negotiated between the Federated Liquor, Hospitality and Miscellaneous Workers Union.
—Are you going to have a high rollers table?
—I remind particularly the honourable member for Bennelong of the provisions of standing order 55.

—The honourable member for Bennelong will be pleased to know that this was negotiated between the Federated Liquor, Hospitality and Miscellaneous Workers Union and the chief negotiator for Crown Casinos, being none other than Mr Greg John, who just happened to be one of the architects of the Victorian industrial relations laws when he worked as a senior adviser to Premier Kennett. He is one of the architects of the system, and what is he doing? He is championing a federal industrial relations agreement. Obviously, he does not believe that Victorian laws are as good as ours when it comes to flexibility and agreement making.

PARA.TAB: In less than two years, the cries of dissent from Victoria have become one great chorus. Only last week, another 10,000 Victorian workers—this time the state's independent schoolteachers—gave up and joined the federal system. Even the minister concerned, Phil Gude, was proposing to change his legislation late last year. We know that and the press of Victoria know that. He would have changed it were it not for the fact that he was overruled by none other than Jeff Kennett at the very last moment. Now we have the head of Victoria's Employee Relations Commission—the body created by Greg John, Phil Gude and Premier Kennett—adding her voice to all the other voices in saying to the Victorian government that its laws are unjust.

In her annual report the commission president, the appointee of the Victorian government, Susan Zeitz, has told the government that its own legislation should be changed. She has pointed to federal and New South Wales industrial relations laws for inspiration. Mr Gude has admitted to the press that he has had that report on his desk for some weeks, but he is refusing to table it in the state parliament. He does not want us to know what is in it. That is the truth of it. I will give the House just a flavour of what is in the report; I quote one paragraph from page 5. President Zeitz said:

ANSWER.PARA: The absence of any provision for the independent scrutiny of individual and collective employment agreements, other than for the purpose of enforcement, is a matter of concern. It is appropriate that there be a mechanism for scrutiny of such agreements and for the ability to intervene and vary such agreements where it is established that they breach minimum requirements or that they are otherwise unfair.

Here is the creation of the Victorian government telling the Victorian government that the law does not work and saying it should be changed. How much more evidence does Victoria need? Already several hundred thousand Victorian workers, many of them with the full cooperation of their employers, have fled the Victorian IR system and now come under federal awards. Today it has been reported in the papers in Victoria that the Victorian government will challenge its own employee relations commission to overturn a decision brought down by that commission which reintroduced a limited form of compulsory arbitration. The Victorian government should cash in its chips and surrender now.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Consumer Affairs. How will Australian consumers benefit from the government's missed opportunity in not fully opening the superannuation market to banks and other financial institutions? Is it not a fact that the consumer interests of Australians with small superannuation accounts would be greatly enhanced by such an action? Is it not also a fact that the government's cop-out superannuation statement impacts most harshly on Australian women, whose superannuation accounts are more often small?

—I thank the honourable member for the question. I noticed the extraordinary interjections of the honourable member while the Treasurer yesterday described how the Australian government has moved to look after precisely the sorts of people that he was just describing, women in particular. Those people, whose superannuation contributions were being eroded by fees and charges, will be protected as a result of the Treasurer's statement yesterday. There were many ways in which this could have been done. The way that has been proposed will be extremely beneficial to those people. The statement has been welcomed by consumer groups.
—They won't get any interest on the money.

—Mr Speaker, I am hearing interjections from the Leader of the Opposition that there will not be interest. That is not a true statement. There could well be interest from the Australian Tax Office measures. I remind honourable members opposite that the success of superannuation funds of all kinds is what determines the amount of interest that goes to the contributors. What the government did yesterday was move to protect those people whose contributions have been eroded in the past by fees and charges.

—Has the Attorney-General's notice been drawn to the suggestion that the legal system fails to properly recognise the contribution made by women on family farms? Is this the case? If so, what does the Attorney-General propose to do about it?

—I thank the honourable member for her question. Honourable members may be aware that this weekend Melbourne University will host an important international conference of women in agriculture—the first conference of this type to be held. The organisers of this conference contacted my office about a fortnight ago concerning a particular problem they perceived where women, particularly women working on family farms, are disadvantaged in the way in which the law of compensation operates in terms of personal injuries.

PARA.TAB: It has long been the case that someone who suffers an injury at work can receive compensation, not only for the pain and suffering resulting from the negligence but also for specific economic loss. While the law has long recognised that someone experiencing the benefit of unpaid labour can be compensated for the loss of that unpaid labour, persons actually performing unpaid labour have not been so easily compensated by our legal system.

This is of particular interest to women working on farms, as often such women will not be partners in a formal legal sense. Nonetheless, they are making an enormous contribution to the maintenance of the property and the earning of income. Yet our legal system, it is claimed, does not properly recognise this contribution. In response to this request, I have referred the issue of compensation for unpaid labour, which applies in a broader set of circumstances than on Australian farms, to the Australian Law Reform Commission. The commission has told me that it will consider the issue in the second part of its important inquiry into equality before the law.

The first instalment of that report will be available to members and to the community shortly. I understand that the second stage of the report dealing with issues, such as the way in which the compensation and personal injury system operate and impact on Australian women, is expected to be available in September. I certainly wish the organisers of this important conference well in the work that they will do to raise the profile and understanding of the enormous contribution Australian women make in our rural communities.

TALK.START.PARA: —I endorse the last comments of the Attorney-General. My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. On Monday the member for Throsby said in this chamber that `to sell Australian National Line would be extreme economic folly'. He went on to say, `Instead of selling our heritage and our assets, we should be looking at the injection of funds to Australian National Line.' As Australian National Line is set to post a record loss of at least $20 million for the current financial year, and given that the minister is reported as saying last night that taxes and charges would have to increase if ANL's losses were continued to be absorbed, have the views of the member for Throsby now prevailed on caucus and which taxes and charges will be increased and when?

—Let me assure the House and the member for Throsby that his views and that of all members on the government side will be very carefully considered as part of the processes we have embarked upon. Let me again outline to the House the processes involved in the government's consideration of the future of ANL. These have been outlined in the past by me, the Minister for Finance and Senator McMullan.

PARA.TAB: In case there is any confusion, those opposite should understand this: we are undertaking a due diligence process in order that the full facts of ANL's performance can be carefully considered during the remainder of this year with a view to doing everything we can to achieve our objectives. Let me restate those objectives. They are to see a strong presence from ANL as an Australian owned and Australian flagged company operating with Australian crews under Australian award conditions. In order to do this, we have to guarantee that the company itself has a sound financial basis.

This government has never shirked its responsibilities in tackling the capital requirements of ANL. Let it not be forgotten that in 1983 we inherited the run-down shell of a company which was completely bankrupted. It was the Hawke Labor government that injected a total of $160.5 million into that company as a debt for equity swap and as a cash injection to prop up ANL.

It is no secret that it is a matter of concern that we want ANL to perform a lot better. Posting successive losses, as it has in its annual reports—audited by the Auditor-General and presented to this parliament since its incorporation in 1989—is of concern to the government, as is its performance this year. As the House should be aware that, rather than a $5 million loss for the whole year, as at the end of March it was projecting a loss of some $16 million; that is, a consolidated loss for the first nine months.

It is my intention to make sure that we do everything to put ANL on the firmest basis for Australia's shipping future. We understand and have always recognised the vitally important role that it plays. We would like to maintain and strengthen that presence. We want the structure that will best achieve that objective. The member for Wannon may be assured that, in all of our consideration on the future of ANL, we will be motivated by those very fine principles.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Social Security satisfied with the currently available methods of assessing poverty and inequality in Australia? Is he taking any steps to ensure the availability of more useful information on these matters?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baldwin The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for her question. The question of poverty and inequality is a very important one, about which we have seen some comment and debate in recent times. A variety of observations have been made by the opposition. We had an MPI debate a couple of weeks ago. As I said at the time, the issue is inherently complex. It is not sufficient to simply look at cash incomes when making judgments about people's material wellbeing. A range of factors, including cash earnings, have to be taken into account. You have to look at social security transfers and the provision of goods and services, such as medical services and education services, by government. You have to look at the asset holdings of various categories of people, the amount of benefit that they derive from holding those assets and so forth. It is a fairly complicated issue. Not many studies have tried to look at those various factors and bring them together in an overall evaluation of the circumstances of various people in this country.

PARA.TAB: However, I would like to draw the attention of the House to what is probably the best attempt to make this sort of judgment, taking into account the range of factors that I have referred to. It is a study done by Peter Travers and Sue Richardson, which has been published in book form and which is entitled Living decently: material wellbeing in Australia. To the best of my knowledge, this is the study which has most comprehensively tried to bring these various factors to bear. The conclusion of this book, which deals with the state of material wellbeing in this country, reads:
Our chief conclusion is that at the end of the 1980s most—

TALK.START.PARA: —The conclusion is at the end.
—It is summarised at the beginning. It reads:

PARA.TAB: Our chief conclusion is that at the end of the 1980s most Australians were indeed `living decently'. Material affluence was at an all-time high. Australia was not the world-leader in equality, but it still ranked around the middle of the dozen most equal countries in the world.

ANSWER.PARA: That is a bit of a contrast to the line that the opposition has been trying to push. It continues:

Australia is a world-leader when it comes to social mobility; that is, both privilege and disadvantage are less likely to be inherited in Australia than in any other country. There is disadvantage, of course, but one of our more positive findings is that disadvantage in one aspect of life is often offset by advantages elsewhere. For instance, the aged in Australia do not rank high in terms of income. However, they do rank high in terms of home-ownership, and in other material comforts.

PARA.TAB: Our positive picture of high levels of affluence and of relative equality is at variance with the `gloom and doom' that is typical of many editorial writers and political and social commentators. One reason for this is that we use rather more complex—
Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order.
—I am almost finished, Mr Speaker. It continues:

ANSWER.PARA: One reason for this is that we use rather more complex measuring-sticks of affluence and of material disadvantage than are common in Australia.

I think that puts into some sort of perspective the comments of the Leader of the Opposition and other opposition spokespersons. While professing tremendous patriotic fervour, they do their level best on every possible occasion to run down this country and portray it as the worst of all. Despite the difficulties of the recent recession, this remains one of the best and most equitable countries in which to live in the world. That fact has to be underlined.

PARA.TAB: The conclusion that I just quoted and the comments that I made earlier highlight the importance of getting more comprehensive and meaningful measures of material wellbeing. This is particularly important from the point of view of the social security portfolio, where we have to make judgments about the adequacy of payments and the relative priority that we give to improving different categories of payments. As a consequence of that, I have asked my department to embark on a substantial project to look at ways in which we can get more meaningful and conceptually sound indices of material wellbeing. I expect that that project will produce some very useful results in forming our efforts to further improve the adequacy of our social security safety net.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Consumer Affairs and follows similar concerns to those expressed by my colleague the honourable member for Mitchell. Yesterday your colleague the Treasurer advised that superannuation guarantee collections to an aggregate of $1,200 would be untaxed and administered by the ATO without cost to the investor. He went on to say that the contributions would be invested in government instruments with the interest being applied to offset the cost of collection operations. From a consumer affairs perspective, do not these two positions represent a contradiction in terms? Further, given the parlous state of the ATO's Child Support Agency operations and given the track record of the existing super funds in the treatment of consumers, can the government guarantee that the interest component will cover such collection operations? If not, do you agree that the small investor contributions in the ATO trust fund will at best stagnate—

PARA.TAB: Government members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The member for Leichhardt! The member for Burke!

—I wish Mark Antony over there would let me finish. If not, do you not agree that the small investor contributions in the ATO trust fund will at best stagnate or, at worst, be progressively eroded by inflation?

—I thank the honourable member for the question, which I think is mainly directed at the Treasurer. If the honourable member is asking me how consumers feel about what was announced yesterday, I can assure him that consumers are mightily relieved. I remind those opposite that when they were in power, most people on low incomes and most women did not have superannuation available to them at all. It is under this government that those on low incomes, those who have been in and out of the work force, who have an interrupted work pattern—such as women—are now at last able to have access to superannuation. Thanks to yesterday's announcement, the small contributions that they make will no longer be eroded by fees and charges.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. The proposed integration of the Heidelberg Repatriation Hospital into the Victorian state health system represents the largest asset transfer in history between the Commonwealth and Victorian state governments. Could the minister inform the House of the progress of this proposed integration and can he assure veterans in Victoria that their hospital needs will be fully catered for once this integration has been completed?
—Tell us about Greenslopes while you are on the job.
—I will tell you about Greenslopes another time.

—I did not hear the interjection; I will ignore it. I thank the honourable member for Jagajaga for his question. I am very pleased that on 10 June—along with the honourable member for Jagajaga, the honourable member for Scullin and the Victorian health minister, Marie Tehan—we announced an agreement in principle of the integration of the Heidelberg Repatriation Hospital with the state public hospital system. I am sure that members of the opposition, particularly those from Melbourne and other areas of Victoria, would be interested in this matter. It might save them a lot of stamps and it might save me a lot of time replying to them by mail.

PARA.TAB: The integration of the hospital with the state system should take place, all being well, on 1 January 1995. The agreement that has been negotiated with the state will guarantee the hospital's future as an acute care teaching hospital. At one stage, it was a bit touch and go as to whether the state would take it but, at the end of the day, after a lengthy period of negotiations and very constructive consultations, it represented a very positive outcome, not only for the 81,000 entitled veterans and dependants in Victoria, but also from the approximately 2,000 staff at that hospital.

I am pleased to say that we were able to obtain from the Victorian government a series of undertakings which safeguard the special needs and requirements of the veteran community, including the retention of some of their special services such as the rehabilitation work group, the psychiatric and psycho-geriatric service at the hospital, as well as representations from the veteran community on the hospital's board of management. There is also a preparedness to keep and maintain the chapel, the memorial rose garden and the Gallipoli garden, and to ensure that they remain accessible to veterans. Integration will ensure that the Heidelberg Repatriation Hospital can continue to serve veterans, war widows and their dependants.

The state health system will receive a payment from the Commonwealth government of more than $500 million over four years to guarantee the rights of veterans to access high quality services in Victorian hospitals—plus, of course, we have given them the hospital. It is not a bad deal for the people of Victoria. It is also a good deal for the veterans.

There are still a number of matters that have to be negotiated during this next six-month period. There are a few important, sensitive matters, such as industrial issues et cetera, but I think that they can all be overcome. We are aiming to secure arrangements for as many staff as possible so that they can be transferred into the employment of the state on 1 January 1995.

In conclusion, the bottom line is that the government will continue to be responsible for the health and wellbeing of the 81,000 or so Victorian veterans, war widows and other entitled people. I will personally take an interest in monitoring the transition arrangements once it happens on 1 January 1995.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you seen Bruce Ruxton today?
—I have been down with Bruce Ruxton today. Not a problem.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Williams Mr D.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. The minister will recall that, during the last week of sittings, I asked him about the draft Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples and, in particular, the provision which in effect provides for indigenous peoples to have the right to secede from sovereign states and to form independent nations. In his answer two days later the minister indicated:

QUESTION.PARA: the government supports the right of self-determination . . . consistent with national sovereignty.
However, the minister went on to say that given the stage reached in the drafting process:
. . . the government considers it premature to consider its final negotiating position in relation to this article and the declaration as a whole at this stage.
In view of this equivocation, does the government intend to preserve the integrity of Australia's territory, or does the government regard Australia's territory as negotiable?

TALK.START.PARA: —The member does not go on to ask: will the minister responsible cease beating his wife?

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! While some might be interested, I do not think that was in the question.

—If this is the standard of leading question that the honourable member used in the courts, it is no wonder that he abandoned the practice of the law for the back bench of the opposition. When the member asked the previous question, I referred it, as I shall this one, to the foreign minister. But I believe that the answer may well be the same.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Justice. Can the minister inform the House what is being done to ensure that disabled persons are able to exercise their rights under the Disability Discrimination Act?

—I thank the honourable member for Bass for her question. The Keating government is committed to stemming all forms of discrimination. To that effect, the Disability Discrimination Act is an important piece of legislation. The act, of course, is based upon the premise that much good can be done not simply by litigation but also by education and conciliation. When the act was brought into place, the government committed itself to a process of ensuring that there were appropriately funded bodies to enable people to have access to the remedies that the act provides.

PARA.TAB: To that effect, we entered into consultations with all the interested disability groups, including the HIV/AIDS peak organisations, the disability peak organisations and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. Their recommendation was that the best vehicle for providing this assistance was through the community legal centre movement, which is a very flexible community-based organisation, which would enable us to provide direct representation across the country in a most cost-efficient way. We have committed ourselves to providing $750,000 per annum to advocacy support services to make sure that the act is available to the community and is made effective.

As well as the direct representation that can be had through accessing community legal centres, we will be sponsoring the production of educational material firstly to ensure that those working in the sector have simple and accessible explanations of the act and how it can be best utilised and secondly so that those who wish to provide direct personal representation can have as clear information as to the act as possible. We will be making that information available in a variety of forms, including braille, sound recording, computer disk forms and the like, so that the disabled community can have access to the important information that will be provided. We will also over the next few months be bringing together those working in the sector to ensure that they provide an effective nationwide system for those with disabilities to be able to access the act.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Transport explain why federal road funding has fallen from a level of $1,788 million in 1992-93 to only $820 million today, especially as this cut has occurred at a time of significantly falling overall Commonwealth grants to the states? How can the minister justify a virtual halving of federal road funding at a time when many of our highways are in desperate need of repair and petrol tax increases are skyrocketing? Does this drastic reduction in road funding concur with the Parliamentary Secretary for Transport, Neil O'Keefe, who at the road transport forum conference at the Gold Coast recently said in a debate moderated by Paul Lyneham that he thought there was too much money being spent on roads by the federal government?
—The honourable member misrepresents—
—Does he?

—He does indeed. He grievously misrepresents the road funding position of this government. Rather than any halving of funds for roads, this government has maintained and indeed made a huge contribution to the national highway system whilst at the same time untying formerly tied grants to both the states and to local government. So to the honourable member's figure of $820 million for national highway construction must be added $350 million, which just happens to be the value of the now untied grants to the states, as well as an additional sum of $326 million which is being paid as untied grants to local government. So let us get the mathematics straight.

PARA.TAB: If the honourable member were serious, he would not be coming into this House trying to misrepresent this government's commitment to roads, which remains great and continuing; he would be taking his concerns to his state colleagues in New South Wales. Since we untied the road funds, the states have been siphoning off funds from roads and putting them into consolidated revenue. This year, $52 million of federal funds earmarked for roads have been siphoned off by the honourable member's political confreres in New South Wales. They are the people who have been robbing road construction in that state. They are the people who are responsible for his electorate not getting its fair share of road funding. So the honourable member ought to be a bit fair dinkum if he wants to talk about road funding. We have an impeccable record.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. State road funding has gone up 35 per cent in real terms and—
—Order! There is no point of order. Resume your seat. If members choose, under the guise of points of order, to perform in that way, they will be dealt with under the standing orders.
—Let me complete my response by assuring the House that the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport shares my absolute commitment to road funding.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister for Finance, is in regard to the government's attitude to interest rate changes. In light of the recent media reports, is the minister aware of any evidence which would indicate that Westpac is preparing to change agreements that it has already entered into for home loans at fixed interest rates?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —All honourable members will have watched the media over the weekend and throughout the earlier part of the week discussing the surging of interest rates on US bond markets. Immediately after initial reports on that, they will have seen people associated with the bond markets in Australia pointing out how changes to the interest rates in the long-term bond market here are a product entirely of movement elsewhere and not addressing the fundamentals in the Australian economy. They will then have seen as a coda to each of these stories, rather like a John Clarke interview, some spokesperson for the opposition—either the leader or deputy leader—effectively barracking for bond market interest rate rises against ordinary home owners and small business.

PARA.TAB: The oddity of that presentation, like a John Clarke interview, is matched only by the ignorance of the way in which their propositions are put. For the opposition leader, the Labor Party represents what he calls `funny money'. For the deputy opposition leader, the Liberal Party represents what he calls `sound money'. They fundamentally conduct the economic debate between themselves in the lingo of 1930s economic debate.

I noticed recently that their quaint nomenclature in the economic debate is now exceeded only by their ignorance of movements in interest rates domestically. For example, today the opposition leader earned himself the ire of Westpac by totally misrepresenting the position of Westpac on fixed interest loans. He was invited by a journalist to speculate on the impact of the change in Westpac's fixed interest rate on home owners. He replied thus:

ANSWER.PARA: Well, if you had a loan with Westpac and you were—in particular, if you had a fixed interest loan with Westpac, you would worry. I mean, the Treasurer—this is typical of the Labor attitude—the money, it just does not matter, it just does not matter. It matters a lot to people who have to pay more for their mortgages. A lot of new home buyers take out fixed interest loans and those are the people who are ending up paying more for their mortgages.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't do it nearly as well as he does.
—I will not do it, because I do not want to engage in that type of mockery and raillery with you. But I am sufficiently attuned to his particular presentation to be able to do it if I need to.

PARA.TAB: The point about this exercise, and why it has sent Westpac troppo, is quite obviously that he is wrong. There is not a proposition coming forward from Westpac that the fixed interest loans it has out—many of them involve people who are new home buyers—will now be overthrown by a decision by Westpac to have its rates increased.

So the statement to them that they ought to worry is a mischievous statement. A mischievous statement implies motive. I am sure the Leader of the Opposition's motive was not that people should necessarily take to the trenches as a result of what he had to say; in this case, his defence on motive has to be ignorance. It can be only that, because he has intervened in economic discussion in this country on this basis since he took over the position of leader. It is a case of all once over lightly. It is all inaccuracy. It is having a presentation based on a quote of somebody else and then saying at the end of the day, `No, I do not really believe that.'

The Leader of the Opposition has now finally trapped himself at a point where he is obviously causing concern to not only Westpac—which will have to handle, no doubt, a number of worried inquiries in this matter—but also a large number of Australians who have no need to worry. From our point of view, it is simply further evidence that he has very great difficulty rising to the great heights to which he has been elevated by his people.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Attorney-General. The Australian Securities Commission, for which you have ministerial responsibility, revealed in Senate estimates hearings last week that it had imposed 13 penalties on a Mr Achilles Constantinidis, the relevant company officer in each case, for breaches of the Corporations Law. All those penalties relate to the 1991 accounts of the piggery group, of which the Prime Minister was half owner at the time. Apart from doing something about the general inefficiency of your operation of this process, would you try to persuade your irresponsible Prime Minister to do something about this matter because up until last week the penalties had not been paid?

—We have been subjected over recent times to attacks by the honourable member for Barker and friends in the Senate on the Prime Minister and his investments. Those have been comprehensively answered by the Prime Minister in terms of his involvement in these particular companies. Certainly, the Australian people see through these sorts of attacks for what they are—fairly grubby and designed for mud slinging and nothing more. You asked me about the inefficiency of the Australian Securities Commission and fines for late lodgments of returns and matters of that kind. If the honourable member were actually interested in the affairs of the Australian Securities Commission he would have noticed in the most recent federal budget that there are changes to the penalty system for the late lodgment of returns by Australian companies and significant increases to fines imposed for late payments so as to increase the compliance rate by Australian companies. Something like 16 per cent of all financial returns have been lodged late.

PARA.TAB: Mr Howard interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I warn the honourable member for Bennelong.

—So it is hardly one unique example when something like 16 per cent of all companies in this country have lodged late returns. If he were interested in this area, he might have noticed the simplification proposals which would, for the vast majority of Australian companies, take away the need for the lodgment of financial returns. If you had a genuine interest in the management of the Corporations Law and company management in this matter, you would address your question to those substance matters rather than this grubby little exercise that you are engaged in at the moment.
—Can the Minister for Transport advise the House of steps being taken by the government to accelerate a ban on smoking on international flights to and from Australia?

—I know that this will be of particular interest to the opposition's own smoking gun, the member for Mackellar. I am very pleased to have this timely question from the honourable member for Fowler. Only last week I again experienced first-hand the discomfort caused by smoking on international flights. We all know that that discomfort is greatly accentuated by the enclosed environment of an aircraft cabin.

PARA.TAB: I inform the House today that I am pressing the management of both Qantas and Ansett for the extension of smoking bans to their international flights. I am sure that this will be a move welcomed by the travelling public and, indeed, warmly welcomed by the airline staff of both Qantas and Ansett. The government has acted and shown leadership in the past on the question of smoking bans. We banned smoking on all domestic flights within Australia in 1987 and we extended those bans to all services operated by international carriers between airports within Australia from October 1990.

Australia has continued to be at the forefront of focusing international attention on this very issue. At the 1992 International Civil Aviation Organisation assembly it was Australia that took a leading role as sponsor of the motion urging member countries to progressively restrict smoking on aircraft and to implement a complete ban by 1 July 1996. That motion was, of course, passed. Australia, New Zealand, Canada and the US are now in the very final stages of concluding an agreement to ban smoking on non-stop flights between these four countries.

Australia supports these agreements being open to adoption by other countries. This will be the very first multilateral response to the ICAO resolution. In approaching Australian international carriers I look forward to further cooperation from the airlines in this very important area of public health.

—I think the honourable member for Chisholm raises some very valid points in his question to me. I will look at the substance of the matter and give him a full response.
