INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Chisholm (Dr Wooldridge) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

PARA.TAB: The Government's procrastination and inactivity in addressing problems in aged care.

INTERJECT.PARA: I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

TAB.EMPHASIS: More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wooldridge Dr M.R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter of public importance is about aged care. For the benefit of honourable members, let me paint the picture. Everyone knows that our aged population is increasing. Today 11.1 per cent of Australia's population are over 65 years of age. That is over 1.8 million Australians. Twenty years ago that figure was 7.8 per cent of the population. In the year 2021, the year I turn 65, our aged population will peak at 15.6 per cent of the population. Of those 1.8 million Australians, 90 per cent still live at home, 84 per cent are independent and six per cent need formal care in their homes. Of the other 10 per cent, three per cent live in supported housing, 2 1/2 per cent in hostels and 4 1/2 per cent in nursing homes. That means that 75,000 Australians are living in 1,400 nursing homes. That is about 10 for every honourable member's electorate. Of the nursing homes, half are private, three-eighths are voluntary and one-eighth are run by state government.

PARA.TAB: In this matter of public importance I will be talking about the problems that nursing homes are facing and why they are facing those problems. I will also talk about dementia. I raised a question to the Speaker earlier about a report tabled yesterday. This is a major report by Professor Bob Gregory into the funding requirements of nursing homes. It was not released in the normal way. It was not tabled in this House, let alone subject to a ministerial statement or the opportunity for debate. It was released from the office of the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence). When we look at the report we can understand why the government tried to sneak it out without much attention. It is a damning indictment of a lack of care of Australia's frail and vulnerable aged. I will read verbatim from the report. It found:

SPEECH.PARA: There is a need for substantial improvement in nursing home buildings around Australia.
Because of the Government's funding formula, there is a complete lack of any incentive to maintain good quality nursing home stock.

Professor Gregory got the Australian Valuations Office to do a survey of structural and design faults in nursing homes. The biggest single fault he found was that for people with wheelchairs or frames—and that is a lot of our frail elderly—the toilets were too small for them to be helped. Of the 75,000 Australians in nursing homes, 12 per cent—or about 10,000—live in rooms with five or more beds.

PARA.TAB: Professor Gregory found that the present funding system is not providing sufficient funds and is not attracting applications necessary for the placement and upgrading of nursing homes. He also found that, across the whole of the voluntary sector, if we are going to replace our nursing homes every 40 years—and many people would consider that far too long—we will have to find 670 new beds every year. Professor Gregory found that in the last eight years not once has that number of beds been found. In fact, we have come within cooee of it only once in eight years.

Why is it happening? Nursing home funding is not easy to understand. You have to understand CAM, SAM and OCRE. CAM—the care aggregated module—is what they pay for care. It looks after nursing staff and the physical help that a patient gets. SAM is the structural component of it and includes knives, forks, tables, power, buildings and carpets. OCRE is other costs. CAM works okay and OCRE work okay, but there are serious problems with the structural component of nursing home funding that have consistently been acknowledged and consistently failed to have been acted on.

Bob Gregory found that, in the calculations the government uses to pay for its nursing homes, there is no provision for replacement of those nursing homes. That is why they are literally falling down. Bob Gregory found that, if you wanted to bring our nursing homes up to the standard required of current design and safety standards, you would need $540 million to $1 billion. Also in the calculations there is no provision for return on investment. Three years ago, a report showed that you would require $1.56 per patient per day to bring that structural component up to a reasonable level. That was acknowledged by the former minister, the honourable member for Batman (Mr Howe), and it has not been acted on. Instead we have had delaying tactics—Gregory No. 1, Gregory No. 2 and now a round of consultations just to do what everyone knows needs to be done.

The next thing that has not been acted on is the differences between states. Victoria has the lowest number of nursing homes as a percentage when you look at the ratio of its elderly population to that of any other state of Australia. It is not surprising because Victoria has the highest cost structure of any state in Australia. In fact, you would need $1.11 per patient per day just to compensate Victoria for the average of the whole of Australia. Power and water costs more and there is a different structure of ownership of nursing homes—there is far more rented accommodation. Again, the former minister acknowledges this. Bob Gregory talks about this and nothing has been done.

One dollar and fifty-six cents a day or $1.11 a day does not sound like much, but $1.11 per patient per day works out to $22,000 every year for the average nursing home in Victoria. That is why people are looking to quit the industry, that is why the buildings are falling down and that is why the standard of the structures needs to be dramatically improved. As well, the government has changed the funding formula for replacing nursing homes. It used to be that the government would fund two-thirds of replacement costs and the industry would replace one-third. That worked. In 1991 the government changed it so that it provided one-third of the cost. The net effect of that has been that replacement has not occurred. Bob Gregory said that of 210 applications last year—15 per cent of nursing homes wanted to upgrade—seven went ahead. Not seven per cent—seven nursing homes in Australia. People want to do it but they cannot afford to do it. They are completely unable to do it. I will read to honourable members a letter from Ashleigh Lodge in Brighton, which is in the electorate of the honourable member for Goldstein (Dr Kemp). The proprietors refer to what they cannot afford to do and to their patients. The proprietors of Ashleigh Lodge were thinking of quitting the industry. They say:

SPEECH.PARA: We cannot afford the following:
*hi-lo beds to replace old stock
*replacement of old commodes
*replace awful old pillows
*ongoing replacement of:
—floor coverings
—curtains
—bed screens
—painting and general refurbishing
*upgrading to ensuites—impossible even with the capital grants which we could not afford
*replacement/upgrading of wheelchairs and shower chairs
. . . only able to afford the very basic linen, crockery, cutlery . . . what else can one do when the national allowance . . . is $3.94 a day?

The second matter I want to raise in this matter of public importance is dementia. Of the 1.8 million Australians who are over 65 years of age, four to five per cent will have serious dementia. Brian Burdekin looked at this in his report on human rights and mental illness. I will read some of his findings. Approximately 3,000 Australians with dementia are still confined to psychiatric wards. I will talk about one of those in a moment. He found that inadequate support services in the community are forcing older people unnecessarily into institutional care. He found that outdated, inappropriate design and funding arrangements for nursing homes result in some residents with dementia being chemically constrained.

PARA.TAB: There are eight dementia specific units in Australia. One of them, Strathdon Community Lodge, is in my electorate. Strathdon lodge, which is run by the Uniting Church, is likely to close within the next two months. It is the standard setter for Australia. Next month, a delegation from Russia will visit the lodge to see the best in the country. The Uniting Church can no longer afford the drain on resources to keep it open.

Let me tell you about two people I met last week at Strathdon lodge. The first person is called Gertie. She is 80 years of age. She has been at the lodge since April 1983. Prior to that, she lived in a large psychiatric hospital. She had been there for 53 years. Her life was spent in a dormitory style ward, with up to 20 beds. She had not spoken for years. She shared communal facilities with very disturbed people. Her family would often find her curled up in the foetal position on a chair. She was completely resistant to approaches from staff or family. Her only emotion was aggression when anyone tried to help her with personal care or hygiene. She had worn communal clothes and had not worn underwear since she was 26 years old. She was being medicated twice a day to sedate her.

Today Gertie is a dignified lady, wearing her own clothes and taking pride in herself. She has started to speak again. She takes part in the activities of the lodge. She loves music and dancing. The point is that she was being cared for in far more expensive and completely inappropriate facilities. Her care today is much cheaper. That is the change in her. Where will she go when Strathdon closes? I imagine she will go back to the psychiatric hospital. Do not be shocked. Brian Burdekin tells us that there are 3,000 others with her.

Last week I met another lady named Toni. She is 88 years of age. Previously she was in a nursing home, costing the government $102 a day. In the nursing home she was frequently found weeping. She frequently wandered aimlessly looking for something to do. She followed the nursing staff round, asking for her belongings and wanting to go home. Overnight she would not settle. She was sedated every night because she was constantly up and down. She would rummage through other people's rooms, which caused confrontation and fights the whole time. The staff coped only by drugging her. She has been in Strathdon three months. She no longer walks aimlessly. She no longer has outbursts of anger. She is a keen participant in daily activities. She helps with household chores. She is happy to sit up late at night. She goes to bed tired and is on no medication.

The point is that these people are being cared for in less expensive facilities. It is far cheaper to look after them in dementia specific facilities. However, time and again the government has failed to address the issue of dementia. Dementia cannot be funded as a specific unit. Two dementia specific hostels exist in Victoria. The government's idea of dementia is to get a nursing home, mainstream people, stick a piano in the corner and call that a dementia ward. It is nothing of the sort.

People with dementia are physically well but hard to care for. They need specialised facilities. Those facilities need not cost more; they can save money. Because of some bizarre, bent, presumably ideological move to the mainstream, rather than recognising the specific needs of people with dementia, people like Toni and Gertie—my constituents—are likely to be back in nursing homes or psychiatric facilities.

There are many other areas of aged care, and my colleague the honourable member for Adelaide (Ms Worth) will touch on some of those as the second speaker for the opposition. This is the International Year of the Family. Families provide the majority of care for elderly Australians yet what assistance or encouragement do the carers themselves get? Very little.

What happens to rural families that do not have access to aged care facilities? Is the government prepared to be innovative and look at shared, multipurpose facilities to replace country hospitals that state governments are closing down? No. It is being dragged to the table kicking and screaming.

There is a plethora of programs in the area of respite care which desperately need rationalisation. What is happening to the home and community care program? There are three levels of government involved in that program. There is massive duplication, it reaches only half its target population and everyone involved in the program says something has to be done about it.

What happens to people from non-English speaking backgrounds when they need age care? We had a wave of migration from South-East Asia from 1975 to 1985. Where is the planning for when those people reach retirement age, dement and lose the ability to speak English? The planning is not there. What about people from Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander backgrounds who require nursing home assistance earlier because of their health status? There is no planning whatsoever in that regard.

What I have detailed shows a failure of duty, a failure of responsibility and a lack of care. I will finish my speech by going back to the Gregory report and the findings of the Australian Valuation Office. The findings show nursing homes with small or insufficient bathroom and toilet facilities; inadequate ramps and a lack of wheelchair access; inadequate heating, cooling or ventilation arrangements; and chutes being used for both food and soiled linen. This is 1994. This is not something from the 1960s; this is happening today. The fact that aged care facilities have inadequate heating and insufficient bathroom facilities warrants explanation. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous The Hon A.C.

TALKER.NAME: Dr THEOPHANOUS
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Human Services and Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is good to finally have a discussion in this House on social justice issues. The government welcomes the idea that there should be more debate in this parliament on social policy. This debate has been a long time coming. It is interesting that the honourable member for Chisholm (Dr Wooldridge) has put forward these propositions at a time when it is quite clear that the main opposition spokespersons, the main actors in determining opposition policy, all disagree with his general approach.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member has not only lost the position of Deputy Leader of the Opposition but also been put out of the shadow cabinet altogether. Taking his place in the new shadow ministry are a range of dry people, including the new shadow finance minister, the honourable member for Forrest (Mr Prosser), who does not give a damn about social justice. The new shadow finance minister not only does not give a damn about social justice, aged care and social policy but also gives press conferences every day or every second day calling for more cuts in the budget.

How can there be more cuts in the budget and more money given to social policy? That is a contradiction. It is interesting to note that when the member was speaking the shadow finance minister and the other great champion of dry economics—the man who has built his whole reputation on supporting the New Right and attacking social problems, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard)—fell asleep. That is how much interest they have in social justice.

If the honourable member can get the opposition to address these social justice issues then all the better. But we need to get a real financial commitment from the opposition. We have the hypocrisy of the opposition on the one hand saying that more should be done in certain areas such as aged care but on the other hand pressing the government to cut the budget. They cannot have both propositions.

This government has a record of massive spending in the area of aged care. Before the election of the current Labor government, aged care in this country was a disgrace. If it were not for the federal Labor government taking control of aged care and providing massive increases in spending in aged care, the aged of our community would have nowhere to go and no programs to support them. The overwhelming proportion of the funding for aged care in this country does not come from state governments; it comes from the federal government. The federal government which has put this into place is the federal Labor government, which has a record of very significant spending.

This year alone, $1.7 billion will be spent on nursing home care, which is just one aspect of aged care. But the honourable member for Chisholm says that that is not enough or that not enough is done with the money. That is an absurdity. Of course, there are problems, and I will come back to those in a moment. But, as I said, if the opposition is serious about doing something about the problems, it should support financial spending in those areas instead of crying crocodile tears about its concern for the aged. If those opposite had won the election, they would have cut out of the federal budget more than $10 billion in spending on social programs.

The heart of the honourable member for Chisholm is in the right place but, unfortunately, he is of a tiny minority within the Liberal and National parties that is concerned with social policies. As was clearly reported in the Australian the day after the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) became the Leader of the Opposition, instead of moving to a more moderate position, the opposition put many people in the shadow cabinet who were from the dry side of economics and who were on the record as calling for cuts in spending on social programs, including those in the area of aged care.

The honourable member for Chisholm asked how the funding has progressed over the years. Let me say this: funding in nursing home care has continued to grow each year. This means that the government is addressing actively the increasing dependency of the nursing home population. Since we came to office, funds for frail, older Australians have increased dramatically and are well above increases in the cost of living.

In this budget, the government has increased even further funding to aged care. This budget has a strong focus on special needs groups. Not only is this government increasing funding, but it is also contributing to the better quality of life for older Australians in a range of important areas, and the opposition knows that. We have a major initiative which targets frail, older people who have insecure housing. This means that flexible services will be available to rural and remote communities that could not otherwise support a stand-alone nursing home or hostel. The government also announced a major initiative for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities. This is a most important breakthrough which is based on the views of the communities themselves.

The government also made a commitment to the needs of people with dementia. The honourable member for Chisholm mentioned dementia in his contribution. The government has spent more money on dementia and, contrary to what the honourable member for Chisholm said, it has special programs in the area of dementia care. This is the first government, state or federal, to introduce programs directed towards dementia care. So for the honourable member to get up and say that our idea of dementia is to put people to one side and give them a piano is a misrepresentation. We are funding a whole range of programs in the area of dementia, including research.

The Gregory report is important. The first report was important, as was the second one. When the report was released, what did the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) say? Did she reject the report? The minister said that the report obviously found certain shortcomings and that the government would examine the best possible way to address those shortcomings raised by Professor Gregory. She did not say that we were going to run away from the issues.

I again say to honourable members that if we are going to spend additional moneys on nursing homes, as Professor Gregory says, we have to bite the bullet. There are several ways of doing that. One is to increase spending on nursing homes in the federal budget. Will the opposition support that or will it get up and say, `You are spending too much money in social policy areas,' as it has been saying over a number of years? Will the opposition support us if we put into place such a scheme? Does the opposition support increasing charges—another option mentioned by Professor Gregory—for people in nursing homes?

The situation with aged care is very clear. There has been a massive increase in the Commonwealth's responsibility in this area. We face spending even more in the future because we have an ageing population. If we on both sides of the House are to be responsible in the area of aged care, we have to adopt a bipartisan approach to making a long-term commitment towards it. It is a question of getting agreement with the opposition parties that aged care is an area of social justice where we can make a commitment to spending. There is no doubt that there will be a need for even more increases in spending on aged care.

The honourable member for Chisholm mentioned that there are some specific areas of need in aged care, such as people from non-English speaking backgrounds. Since being given responsibility for the access and equity agenda in relation to this matter earlier this year, I have been discussing with the minister and the Department of Human Services and Health what we can do about aged care for people of non-English speaking backgrounds. In the next six to eight weeks, I will be announcing a series of new initiatives in this area—a series of initiatives which have been carefully thought out and which will be targeted at achieving outcomes for people of non-English speaking backgrounds. There is no doubt that the honourable member for Chisholm is right: we have to address this question. But he did not come up with any constructive suggestions. All he came up with was, `Here is a problem for you.' This problem has been around for some time. It is only today that we heard from the honourable member—from anybody from the opposition parties, for that matter—about the need for something to be done in this regard.

The reality is that we will be addressing this question in a series of projects, not only through ethnic specific nursing homes and hostels but also by a substantial extension of the concept of clusters in nursing homes and hostels, which are directed towards ensuring the formation of particular cultural and linguistic groupings in homes and hostels and ensuring that they are serviced by people who speak the appropriate language and who are familiar with the particular cultural background.

I turn to the Gregory report. The government has been waiting for this report for some time; it has not procrastinated. There were some delays associated with the report that the honourable member did not mention—the report by Sir William Keys—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is dated May. Friday is July. You have been sitting on it.
—We have not been sitting on this report. That is an unfair allega

SPEECH.PARA: tion. The honourable member has no right to make that allegation. The report by Sir William Keys was supposed to be finished but we had a problem with the industry, which wanted more time for consultation. How are we to get action in the area of capital development and new investment in nursing homes? The honourable member talks about nursing home proprietors and hostel proprietors wanting to get out of the industry. That is the case only in some sections of the industry; he has exaggerated the problem. We have to consult with industry groups and with the organisations representing those groups to make sure that we put in place systems, practices and approaches which they consider suitable, and on the basis of which they will be investing in nursing homes and hostels in the future.

PARA.TAB: Let us have a constructive response to the report based on what we need to do rather than trying to score political points from what is a very serious social justice area. The reality is that, in the area of social justice, this government's record in recent history, both state and federal, is second to none. In recent history there has been no government committed to more programs in the area of social justice, including aged care, than this federal Labor government.

Look at the spending and look at the record of the federal opposition. What has the record of the federal opposition been? It has been time and again to say, `Don't spend that money, that's too much money. We would cut spending.' What did the honourable gentleman to whom you were deputy, the former leader, want to do in his Fightback package? He wanted to cut out $7 billion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not cut aged care. We gave a commitment to dementia care, which was funded, unlike you.

—You say that he did not want to cut aged care. What nonsense. Where was he going to cut the $7 billion? All of the community organisations condemn the federal opposition because of its positions on social justice, because of its positions on health, because of its positions on Medicare and because of its positions on aged care. At this very late stage you have suddenly developed a concern for the aged—but, as I say, better late than never. We welcome your concern, but when you back your concern up with some actual serious policy development, some serious programs in the area of aged care, I can assure you that the minister and I will listen to any constructive suggestion and put it into place. But it is a mistake for you to simply score political points. (Time expired)

—I am pleased to support the honourable member for Chisholm (Dr Wooldridge) today in raising his concerns, first of all about the fact that this report was released not in the parliament but elsewhere. I say again, as I have had to say before, that I feel somewhat sorry for the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Theophanous) because again he is left to hold the fort and the minister, the honourable member for Fremantle (Dr Lawrence), is not here. I do not criticise him at all. He does very well to defend her, but she should be here not only to defend the government's position but also to listen to what others in this place have to say.

PARA.TAB: This report by Professor Bob Gregory, which has been sat on despite the parliamentary secretary's denials, reveals the crisis facing Australia's nursing homes and the industry. It prompts us to think of the whole area of aged care. In nursing homes, though, which look predominantly after the frail aged, Professor Gregory relates this crisis directly to the 1988 introduction by the government of a new funding formula and then the 1991 budget decision to halve the level of funding provided for upgrading nursing homes. He estimates that upgrading the existing stock may cost as much as $520 million.

Professor Gregory raises other points. There is a need for a substantial improvement in nursing home buildings, but because of the government funding formula there is a lack of incentive to maintain a good quality of nursing home stock. Eighteen per cent of residents live in rooms with five or more beds, and toilets are not large enough to allow carers or walking frames in with the residents. The present funding system does not provide sufficient funds, and does not attract the applications necessary for placements and upgrading of nursing homes in the voluntary sector.

I could go on and on, but it is probably just necessary to look at the fact that Australia does have an ageing population. The member for Chisholm has given us some vital statistics on this fact. We are all growing old, therefore this matter is relevant to all of us. Whichever side of the House we sit on, no-one can say we should be disinterested.

The EPAC report states that the percentage of people over 80 by the year 2051 is going to be extraordinarily high. Many Australians, of course, do remain fit. I am happy to say longevity runs in my family. My father, who is 81, has been on the tractor recently trying to beat the rain and my mother, who is in her 70s, helps him. That is a good sign.

I am looking forward to my own old age, and hope to remain active. A great number of people do the same. There are aged Australians caring for other aged Australians. There are women nursing their husbands who are dying in their late eighties, and then where do they go? There are women and men who came here as migrants in the 1940s and 1950s, and while the men went out to work and learned English the women stayed at home and still do not know how to speak English. These people are now being cared for in aged hostels and nursing homes.

When we think of aged care, we have to think of those who are not as independent as they once were receiving home care from the HACC program. Then there is the community care package, the hostels and the nursing homes. There are criteria for assessment under which people will be judged as to what they will have. That is fair enough, but it gets a little complex. For instance, the government has been a little tardy about talking to people working in the industry. It may not have been necessary to have so many reports if there had been more consultation.

The director of one nursing home to whom I recently spoke claims that the authorities are not prepared or unable to acknowledge the level of care required for dementia sufferers. Their needs are quite different from the needs of those with obvious physical frailties or disabilities. There is general agreement that there must be some measure of assessment. The emphasis, though, is on physical rather than mental health. There are 14 questions which must be answered, and they go something like this: Is the patient incontinent? What about the skin integrity? What special nursing is required? Is there physical aggression, verbal disruption, behaviour problems, vision, hearing, speech comprehension? What is their mobility? What are their toilet requirements? What are their washing and dressing requirements, eating requirements and their level of independence?

This classification for nursing homes residents equals nursing hours which, in turn, equals dollars. This assessment is a funding tool and does not equate to care given. It gives little recognition for dementia. There is no classification, either, for palliative care, but palliative care is being given in nursing homes. This equals many hours of specialised care. One nursing home has a patient on a ventilator. He is not incontinent, he is not physically aggressive, he is not verbally disruptive. Therefore he scores few points and therefore few nursing hours and few dollars but in fact requires one-to-one care from between three to six hours per day. Prior to his admission to the nursing home he received 24-hour care which was HACC funded and therefore cost the community.

Problems for carers are becoming more complex. Once people did not live so long and when they were particularly ill they were cared for in more acute settings. These are the problems to be looked at. The government from time to time jokes about the fact that we have been on the opposition benches for too long. I wish that we had not. Having been in government for that degree of time, the government has had responsibility. There has been neglect. The nursing home industry has been waiting since 1991, when a departmental review recommended that there should be an immediate $1.56 per resident per day increase as a component of federal government funding for changes to make the industry viable. The industry says, `We look forward to the consultative process, but we have been waiting for ages and it does not seem to happen.'

I accept the fact that finding government funding for a whole lot of different programs is difficult. I am not saying money grows on trees, but there should be more flexible arrangements. Those people who fear—like I fear—that in their old age they will not have adequate care and who are prepared to put money away should be given the opportunity to perhaps pay for a standard of care or contribute on top of that government funding. When we have that mix of financial arrangements there will be more money to go around. There will be more money for capital expenditure on those homes, which will benefit those who come from a poorer sector.

A safety net will exist so that the environment in which they are being cared for will not have the same chute used for rubbish and linen. Dementia sufferers will not be rescued off the streets in their dressing gowns, or perhaps having discarded some portion of their clothing, causing embarrassment to their carers and their families. There should be proper facilities for them. This situation will only get worse as we live longer because, the longer we live, the more dementia sufferers there will be.

I have concentrated largely on the nursing home problems because the report prompts me to do so today. But the home and community care program has come under the microscope recently with the public inquiry held by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Community Affairs. It has been most interesting. There has been a bipartisan approach to many of the areas we have been following up. But unofficial rationing has been taking place in the HACC program because there have not been enough funds to go around; evidence has been given to that effect. Evidence has been given that the young disabled are fighting for the same HACC dollar that the frail aged are fighting for. Evidence has been given that people who have been assessed as needing hostel accommodation are being cared for in their homes. Certainly in my own electorate I have found people in hostels on the 4 or 5 level who really should be moving into nursing homes as they rapidly change up to the 2 or 3 level.

My office was recently instrumental in finding a nursing home bed for one of my constituents who had nowhere to go and who was suffering badly from dementia. While investigating that I found that there were 75 people in public hospital beds awaiting admission to nursing home beds and that there was nowhere else for them to go. So I would like to draw to the attention of this parliament the fact that we need to be thinking about our aged and planning for them very carefully. It is no good trying to do everything once the real crisis of the situation is upon us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Deahm Ms M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It gives me great pleasure to speak to this issue. As the convener of the caucus aged care task force, I have taken a keen interest in this topic. It is interesting that both the opposition speakers have criticised the government's commissioning of reports. They say, `We do not want reports; we want action.' They say, `Not enough consultation has occurred.' Those reports precisely involve consultation. Professor Gregory was at great pains to consult all the players in those issues. While saying, `We do not want reports' they have also accused of us of dragging the chain and not responding to those reports. The most recent Gregory report has only just been released. There has been no dragging of the chain on that. One of the first things this new minister did when she came to office was to agree to the recommendations of the Keys report.

PARA.TAB: Both speakers from the opposition have outlined a situation in our aged care system, particularly in nursing homes, with which I do not think anybody on this side would disagree. That is precisely why this government has commissioned the reports that we have alluded to and why it is now acting on them; it has taken action. When this government came to office it found aged care in a very poor state: aged Australians were over-dependent in nursing home care, they lacked alternatives and they had no choices. People without choice often found themselves in nursing homes because there was simply no alternative support for them.

In 1981 the Auditor-General concluded that there was inadequate financial accountability for nursing home funding and no guarantee of quality for residents. A few years later, Senator Giles chaired a Senate select inquiry into private nursing homes and concluded that quality was very mixed, despite the good efforts of some providers, and that there was insufficient government regulation. That report says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . poor treatment of the patient, unsanitary conditions, poor food, inadequate control of drugs, improper use of restraints (both physical and medicinal), assaults on human dignity and reprisals against those who complain.

That was the situation when this government came to office in the early 1980s. The government has taken considerable action in that time to rectify that situation but, as all speakers have noted, it is not an easy one; it does not happen overnight.

PARA.TAB: However, the government has taken great action as far as spending money is concerned. Expenditure on aged care in 1992-93 was 170 per cent more than in 1983-84. Adjusting for inflation, the 1992-93 expenditure was 61 per cent higher than for 1983-84 compared to an estimated increase of 32 per cent in the target population over the same period. So to accuse us of inaction and procrastination is utter rubbish.

Expenditure on community care services, which obviously involve the aged, has risen even more dramatically. Expenditure on community care services in 1938-84 was $61.5 million, while in 1992-93 it had risen to $342 million. This represents an increase of over 450 per cent over this period, or a real increase in funding of over 230 per cent. So please do not tell us that we are not spending enough money on this problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —I didn't say that.

—The opposition has certainly accused us of not taking action when we certainly have. There have been considerable achievements in that time. Since 1986, the government has been implementing a strategy of aged care reform. This has taken a number of different angles. This is comprised principally of changing the balance of care away from nursing homes towards support for people living in their own homes and in hostels.

PARA.TAB: The home and community care program has been alluded to. As the honourable member for Adelaide (Ms Worth) has mentioned, the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Community Affairs has been undertaking an inquiry. Certainly there has been duplication. Certainly there needs to be streamlining. I am glad that she admits there has been bipartisan agreement on it. The government has also introduced what are known as community aged care packages, which provide the equivalent of hostel accommodation in a person's own home. The opposition will agree that those choices are very important.

Assessment for people going into nursing homes and hostels has also been streamlined. Gone are the days when we put granny in a nursing home because she was in the way. Aged care assessment teams assess a person's eligibility for a hostel or nursing home, and that is extremely important. Standards of care have also improved. We no longer have what we call regulations—the big policeman looking at us and saying that we can or cannot do something. Standards monitoring, which looks at outcome standards, is much more important. I will quote again from the Giles report in the pre-1980s:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . regulations . . . generally assess whether a facility is capable of delivering required services, not whether these services have been implemented or whether quality care has actually been received.
Quality care is what is important. That is what this government is about.

PARA.TAB: Support for carers has also been an important plank of this government's policy. The honourable member for Adelaide alluded to the fact that we often find aged people looking after aged people. Sons and daughters of ageing people are often left at home to care for them. Support for carers is an important part of our policy, and it is an important part of the HACC program.

One issue that has taken a great deal of time in this debate is dementia. It is not an easy issue. There are no easy answers when people find themselves in a demented state, be it mild, severe or somewhere in between. It is not easy for the people around them, be it their family, carers or the people who look after them in institutions. I have had the privilege of visiting some dementia specific facilities. I am sorry that the honourable member for Adelaide has left the chamber, because one of the most impressive ones was in her electorate, where a facility was built specifically to care for people with dementia.

The national action plan for dementia care is again an important plank of this government's policy. Unfortunately, when Brian Burdekin put together his report, many of the actions and plans by the government were not in front of him. So many of his criticisms have become invalid because of that time lapse. The most startling thing is the people on the other side criticising this government for not taking sufficient action on dementia. Fightback said that the opposition would spend $10 million on dementia care. The national action plan spends $30 million, and we have now included an extra $12 million in this year's budget. So please do not call that inaction or procrastination.

As I have said, dementia care is extremely important. The $30 million in the national action plan includes demonstration programs, which I alluded to in an earlier speech in this place; funding to aged care assessment teams to better assess people with dementia and improve knowledge and expertise in the area of dementia; and more services for people suffering from dementia. An extra $12.3 million in this budget has been allocated for aged care assessment teams to set up psycho-geriatric units, which are extremely important. I have a psycho-geriatric nursing home in my electorate which I know is in need of improvement. What do we do with people who are a danger to themselves and sometimes to others? It is very difficult. As the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Theophanous) has said, politicising these issues is totally inappropriate.
The honourable member for Adelaide talked about her growing old. I know that I am older than the honourable member for Adelaide.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, no!
—Absolutely. I am terribly sorry to say so, but it is true. I will be needing aged care long before she does.

PARA.TAB: I refer to a program in this year's budget called new homes for old. This government takes an holistic view of aged care. We are not just saying, `They are sick, put them away,' or `They are going a bit dotty, put them away.' We look at their health care needs, their quality of life needs and their housing needs. New homes for old, to which $610,000 has been allocated in this budget, is looking at ways of providing better housing for people as they age. Many people do not want to stay in a house that has become too big for them. This initiative is a step forward.

The government is also conducting surveys to look at what the needs of younger people—people even younger than me—might be when they get to that stage of dependence. If that is not long-term planning, what is? When we look at the results of those sort of surveys—

TALK.START.PARA: —How old are you?

—The honourable member for Chisholm can find out how old I am by looking up the Parliamentary Handbook. These surveys will give us a better idea of the needs of people, not just what somebody in the medical profession thinks they need. One of the main things this government has provided over the last 10 years is a choice for people so that they do not go into the sausage machine that they previously would have found themselves in. Finally, the accusation of procrastination and inactivity is utter rubbish.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works, I present the 57th general report of the committee.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—The committee's 57th general report deals with the committee's activities during 1993 and covers the work of the 30th and 31st committees. During the year the committee met on 33 occasions and presented nine reports. The estimated cost of public works on which the committee reported was just over $252 million. Projects ranged from the construction of a new transmission tower on the top of Mount Wellington to improve and enhance the scope of television and radio reception to southern Tasmania, to the refurbishment of historic Victoria Barracks in Melbourne to provide modern office accommodation, to the redevelopment of CSIRO facilities at Prospect near Sydney. The projects were varied in extent and function. All were recommended for approval by the committee.

PARA.TAB: As in previous years, the committee takes the opportunity to highlight a number of important matters in its general reports. A feature of the past year was the number of briefings from senior officials of departments, agencies and industry. Officers from the Department of Defence, the Defence Housing Authority, the Civil Aviation Authority, the Australian National Audit Office, Overseas Property Group, Commonwealth Fire Board, and Kelstrom Pty Ltd briefed the committee on a wide variety of matters relevant to inquiries and public works in general.

Another highlight of the year was the second public works committee conference, which was held here at Parliament House. Members of public works committees or their equivalents from the parliaments of Tasmania, Queensland, South Australia and the Australian Capital Territory and the New South Wales public accounts committee, because of its interest in the private funding of public infrastructure, and representatives of the Commonwealth attended the conference. The conference addressed a variety of statutory and operational matters which are common to, or have significant ramifications for, inquiries involving the proposed expenditure of considerable public funds.

Matters discussed at the conference included: the use of consultants; the use of value management techniques to assess public works; follow-up procedures on works in progress; the private funding of infrastructure; and the impact of the untying of Commonwealth departments and agencies from a central government design and construction authority. It is planned to hold these conferences every year if the calendars of the various parliaments permit. The next conference will be held in Hobart later this year and we hope to see each state and territory represented, perhaps even Papua New Guinea.

A number of significant issues emerged during the year and these are described in the report. These relate to the provision of earth leakage circuit breakers and smoke detectors in Defence Housing Authority dwellings, the provision in all Commonwealth buildings of facilities for people with disabilities to ensure that right of equal access is maintained, and energy conservation.

The Public Works Committee Act precludes the committee from meeting overseas, although the committee is required to inquire into and report on overseas works such as embassies and high commissions. When members of the public works committee are on delegations or are overseas in a private capacity, they always inspect any work that is being considered by the committee. This anomaly has caused problems. The committee is unable to inspect existing buildings and sites proposed for work and to hold informal discussions with local staff and officials responsible for the design and construction of what are, after all, buildings which in some way should reflect Australia.

The committee therefore believes that the Public Works Committee Act should be amended to enable the committee or a sectional committee to undertake inspections overseas and for the resources to be available for it to do so. We have put this up before, but it has always fallen on deaf ears. As the Minister for Finance (Mr Beazley) is at the table, it may get a better reception this time. I have said before that it is much more prudent and effective if local inspections and discussions are held before committee inquiries, as is the case with other projects.

This has been brought home to us with a recent project, the Hanoi Embassy complex. Although we have the handicap that by the time it reaches us a project is essentially a fait accompli, at the design stage, I doubt very much that had we inspected this site we would have recommended the Hanoi project. We would also save the government considerable amounts of money with overseas inspections, as it would be much cheaper than flying bureaucrats and models to Canberra.

In conclusion I would like to make special mention of a number of former committee members who retired from the committee, and the parliament for that matter, during the report period. Mr Lloyd O'Neil, the former member for Grey, and Mr Ewen Cameron, the former member for Indi, served on the committee from May 1990 to February 1993. I would like to thank them both for the contributions they have made to the committee and to the parliament. I should also mention the former Vice-Chairman, the honourable member for Groom (Mr Taylor), and another former committee member, the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Bruce Scott), for their contributions. I thank the committee members for the support they have given me during the year, especially the Vice-Chairman, Senator Paul Calvert.

The committee, because of the nature of the work and the pressures we are increasingly under, makes tremendous demands on the membership and I thank the committee members for their hard work during the past year. The committee also thanks the staff for the friendly and efficient way in which they respond to the many demands members place on them. It is not always easy dealing with the committee members, but the staff carry out that work in a most efficient and friendly manner. I commend the report to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Customs Tariff Proposal No. 3 (1994); and
Excise Tariff Proposals Nos 3 and 4 (1994)

Customs Tariff Proposal No. 3 of 1994 and Excise Tariff Proposal No. 3 of 1994, which I have just tabled, contain alterations to the Customs Tariff Act 1987 and the Excise Tariff Act 1921 which arise from measures announced in the 1994-95 budget and additional measures connected with the Civil Aviation Authority's charges for 1994-95.

PARA.TAB: These alterations operate on and from 1 July 1994. The Treasurer announced on budget night 10 May an increase in customs and excise duties on aviation gasoline and kerosene for use in aircraft of 1.194c per litre. These increases are a further part of the process announced by the government in the 1992-93 budget of the phased introduction of full recovery of the costs incurred in implementing aviation safety standards and 50 per cent of the costs of safety standards setting and compliance. The rates of duty applicable to avgas are subject to further variation in respect to the duty collected and paid to the CAA to recover airways costs attributable to avgas powered aircraft.

The proposed reduction of 7.521c per litre follows the adoption by the CAA of a marginal cost basis for the pricing of services provided to operators of avgas powered aircraft. This approach has been adopted in recognition of the fact that a large proportion of CAA facilities are put in place because they are required for regular public transport operations mostly undertaken by aviation kerosene powered aircraft.

The alteration contained in Excise Tariff Proposal No. 4 of 1994 operates on and from 1 April 1994. This is the date on which the amendments contained in the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Act 1993 and the Excise Tariff Amendment Act (No. 2) 1993 relating to the government's decision to combat fuel substitution came into operation. The alteration provides exemption from excise duty for crude oil and condensate for all uses other than as fuels, and where they are used as fuels, in the recovery, production, transportation or refining of crude oil or condensate. Summaries of the alterations contained in these proposals have been prepared and are being circulated for the information of honourable members. I commend the proposals to the House.

DEBATE.TITLE: FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT AND ACCOUNTABILITY BILL 1994COMMONWEALTH AUTHORITIES AND COMPANIES BILL 1994AUDITOR-GENERAL BILL 1994

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)That:

(a)subsequent to the presentation and first reading of the Financial Management and Accountability Bill 1994, the Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Bill 1994 and the Auditor-General Bill 1994 and associated memoranda, the Bills be referred to the Joint Committee of Public Accounts for consideration and an advisory report to the House by 23 August 1994; and
(b)the terms of this resolution, so far as they are inconsistent with the standing and sessional orders, have effect notwithstanding anything contained in the standing and sessional orders.
(2)That a message be sent to the Senate acquainting it of this reference to the committee.

In moving that the package of bills be referred to the Joint Committee of Public Accounts for examination and report by the fourth week of the spring sittings, I need to point out that in accordance with standing orders the second readings of this package of bills will take place in the next week of sittings; that is, in the first week of the spring sittings. These bills, like few others, will ultimately have an impact on the entire field of government activity, simply because almost every action of the government has a financial implication.

PARA.TAB: The JCPA was the body which initiated action to replace the Audit Act and the government believes that it should be the body to formally examine, in the first instance and on behalf of the parliament, the proposed outcome of this action. The government believes that with these bills having a large technical content input from the JCPA, it will assist the debate, which, as I have previously announced, is intended to take place in the spring sittings.

The government sees the referral of bills to the JCPA as akin to issuing them as an exposure draft. Members wishing to contribute to the consideration of the package should feel encouraged to do so, either through the proceedings of the JCPA or direct to the government. Either way, their views will be taken into account. Further consideration of this package will also occur in the government's own committee process. Our committees will be giving more detailed consideration to this package and any amendments forthcoming from the other channels that I referred to.

This is a most important set of changes to the Audit Act, which I do not think has been much altered since it was first put in place in 1901. I think it behoves us to give this process a leg along, which means that we have to proceed with a reasonable degree of expedition. Otherwise it will get bogged down and then nothing will be achieved. I should point out that the committee that gave this consideration did so some years ago. It has taken a long time to get to this point because there has had to be an infinite variety of consultation through departments, through government business enterprises and, of course, with the Auditor-General's office and other aspects more informal of the political process.

Cabinet has had a look at the matter and I think we are now in a situation where some structure has to be put into those considerations. These bills do put that structure into the further consideration. The Joint Committee of Public Accounts has done a fine job in this area thus far, so I think it is totally appropriate that we and the Senate should have its advice on how it thinks we have measured up to the sorts of things it thinks are important in this area.

I might say that members of my own party will want a bit of a further look at these things—I am sure members of the opposition parties also will want a bit of a look at these things—but the way in which we have ordered business in this place, which I think is very much for the better, means that if we are actually going to have this package through by Christmas there needs to be a formal introduction effectively right now.

A whole series of purposes is served by this process. The way in which we are doing it effectively creates something of the nature of an exposure draft without actually formally entitling it as such. From the arrangements we have informally with colleagues on all sides of the Senate, the passage of this by Christmas will be comfortable, provided that at the end of the day they like the product. The way in which attention has been paid these matters by all the people that I have referred to, I think, amply justifies decent handling of it by the parliament.

As I have indicated, virtually by implication in the things that I have been saying, the government is not so proud of its authorship in this regard that it is going to take umbrage at getting additional advice from any sources and we look forward to the consultative processes yet in hand.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
