SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Dr D.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first thing that one must say about the white paper is that it is not about creating jobs; it is about training. As Professor Helen Hughes has said, it is not about getting rid of unemployment but about making unemployment palatable. The white paper is about training and other schemes designed to reduce the statistical levels of unemployment to conceal unemployment.

PARA.TAB: The schemes, training and otherwise, within the white paper have the potential to hide over 200,000 unemployed people from the unemployment figures. On a conservative estimate, when fully operational the jobs compact within the white paper could hide some 120,000 unemployed people, the parenting allowance could hide some 59,000, and the mature age allowance could hide some 30,000. The white paper is designed to make it appear to the community that these policies are providing jobs to fix the unemployment problem created by the choice of high unemployment policies by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) to bring the 1980s boom to a halt, when in fact those people who have been the victims of those policies are to be put through yet more training schemes.

Training without job prospects is demoralising. The success of the white paper, in the end, will depend on whether or not the government policies that are currently in place will actually bring about economic growth. The figures that the government has put into the budget—figures derived from the Treasury estimates of growth over the remainder of this decade—lead to the inevitable and sad conclusion that by the end of this decade unemployment is likely to still be of the order of seven per cent, even if there is no further downturn in the economy. That means that many of those who are currently finding it impossible to get employment face the prospect of continuing and prolonged unemployment.

In the short time available to me today I want to comment particularly on the training proposals in the white paper. At the centre of the white paper's job compact is the training wage. It must be made quite clear that the concept of a training wage is one which the coalition has advocated for quite some time. Indeed, it advocated it before the election.

The concept of the training wage recognises that unemployed people excluded from the work force can obtain jobs if there is sufficient incentive for employers to take them on. These are training jobs. Whether they will obtain sustainable jobs will depend entirely on the growth in the economy and on whether enterprises find it appropriate to take on people to meet the growing demand. But let us focus for a moment on the prospect of giving unemployed people at least a temporary job, in many cases to gain the first work experience that they will have had.

In the last election the coalition put forward a proposal which we called the Austrain scheme, combined with a taxpayer funded user-buys scheme for young and older unemployed persons. The great strength of the scheme which the coalition put forward was that it combined a major financial incentive to employers, which increased the longer a person had been unemployed, with a commitment by the Commonwealth to fund training in a very flexible way that met the needs of employers and unemployed people. It was a system which provided genuine choice as to the kind of training which would be undertaken by the employee, thus ensuring that it was the best possible training for the future opportunities for the formerly unemployed person and that it was training which met the demand from enterprises and from trainees.

At long last the government has recognised that a training wage has a role to play. It has taken a long time to get the ACTU even to that recognition. Unfortunately, the government has already run into significant problems with the scheme that it has tried to put in place—a scheme which has some significantly different features from those which the coalition advocated. The problems that the government has faced with this scheme are self-inflicted problems. They have occurred because the government has allowed the training agenda to be dominated by the needs and demands of the trade union movement for a training system which can be used to expand the scope and influence of the power holders in the government's centralised industrial relations system.

These problems have occurred for the same reasons that the government has run into difficulties with its superannuation policies—noted this morning by the press who commented adversely on yesterday's statement of the Treasurer (Mr Willis)—its education policies, its tax policies and its industrial relations policies. It is a relentlessly sectional government. Every major policy decision must be forced through the ACTU approval process and be subject to an ACTU veto.

The government has defined the training wage in a way which meets the requirements of the ACTU. It is to be based on a single national award. The training element is to incorporate the Carmichael training agenda, with its unsatisfactory implementation of competency based training and its bureaucratic and costly accreditation arrangements. The training wages proposed and approved by the ACTU are higher in some cases than the minimum rates currently payable under existing awards. The problem with this approach is that it means the government has had to present the employers—that is, the people who are going to have to offer the jobs—with a fait accompli. There has been no satisfactory discussion with those who are going to have to employ people under the training wage. They have been told by the ACTU and by the minister on behalf of the ACTU, `Take it or leave it.'

The employers who have been placed in this very difficult position have acted with goodwill. They want a workable training wage system. They have expressed a range of concerns: the level of wage rates for young unemployed people, the role of trade unions in the accreditation of training schemes, and the extent of costly and bureaucratic accreditation processes which may apply. Despite these concerns the employer representatives have gone along, hoping that their members will find the arrangements workable but knowing all the time that, if they do not, the training wage scheme as proposed by the government in the white paper simply will not work.

The employers have to take on trust the fact that the state tribunals, which generally provide coverage of employees in clerical and retail occupations—two of the key areas which have to be expected to play a role in the implementation of the scheme—will provide a flow-on of the conditions embodied in the single national award. As usual, the states too have simply been left out of the consultation process in setting up the scheme.

Such was the level of concern expressed by the employer organisations over the ACTU approved training scheme that the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Crean) was forced to cut five days off his overseas trip last week and fly home to attempt to stitch up a deal with the employer representatives and ease their concerns. In the end, whether a deal is struck or not in itself means little. The only thing that matters is whether the terms in which the training wage are finally implemented are terms on which small businesses throughout Australia will be prepared to employ unemployed people. If the scheme is not attractive to Australian small business, it will fail. No amount of behind the scenes dealing, threatening and bludgeoning employers, is going to achieve that objective. In the end, those employment decisions are going to be made by individual small businesses themselves.

By around November or December this year, we will get an indication of whether the deal which has been stitched up is going to lead to an effective training wage system, but it will be quite some time before we know this. I make the point very clearly that this scheme—the job compact—offers no hope in the near future to the great majority of the long-term unemployed, who are the victims of the deliberate high unemployment policy of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). Even though the proposals are to be implemented formally in July this year, it will be literally years before many unemployed people will be offered jobs under the job compact. The compact is to be phased in over four years, and I do not think that people who have been unemployed for over 12 months are going to take much comfort from the fine print in the white paper which spells out clearly that people who have been receiving benefits for over 18 months `will have received a job compact offer by the end of 1997-98'. Under these proposals, that is how long some people are going to have to wait to get some benefit.

Since the white paper was presented, a report of great significance on the training arrangements the government has established has been published. This report is entitled Successful reform: competitive skills for Australians and Australian enterprises, and was prepared by the Allen Consulting Group. I will refer to it in my remarks as the Fitzgerald report, after the executive director who handled the report, Dr Vince Fitzgerald.

This report has been presented since the white paper with the white paper proposals in mind. It is quite plain that, in the view of the consultants, the white paper has not remedied the very serious problems in the government's existing training arrangements, which under the training wage are intended to provide the foundations for training. While framed in the forward-looking language that one expects of a consultant's report, the report is a damning indictment of the training arrangements the government already has in place, and it recommends a major change of direction in the nature of those arrangements.

Perhaps the single most damning statement in the Fitzgerald report is the conclusion, which states that the government's training reforms `do not appear to have had a demonstrable effect on enterprises' decisions or productivity'. That is, they have failed for some six years now—since these training reforms were put in place—to contribute to lifting productivity or affecting the decisions of Australian enterprises about training. They have failed by one of the central criteria by which they have to be assessed.

The change of direction that the report recommends is towards arrangements oriented to the needs of enterprises rather than industries, which are responsive to the directly expressed needs of employers and those seeking training. In short, the report recommends the creation of a national training market based on user-buys principles—the very principles which the coalition advocated before the last election and which the government and its accord partners have been so reluctant to put into effect in the training area. The Fitzgerald report is quite clear. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the current approach to reform will not, without change, bring about the fundamental outcomes desired on a satisfactory scale.

The report recommends that immediate action should be initiated and completed by the end of this year to put in place the machinery needed to measure the actual outcomes in skill formation and enterprises and the links to enterprise productivity, together with employment outcome measures for individuals and a range of other tasks which the government must set about implementing if, according to the report, there is going to be any successful outcome to the training initiatives in the white paper and the broader national training agenda. Unfortunately, we have a government whose training agenda, like so many of its other agendas, has been motivated entirely by the politics of policy making within this government. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to have the opportunity to speak on the Working Nation statement, which is a major initiative of this government. It is the first white paper on employment for 49 years. We only have to listen to some of the debate in here, particularly the contributions from those in opposition, to once again be reminded on how good it is—and how fortunate I am—to be on this side of the House as part of the Labor government.
—Fortunate indeed—you are very fortunate, my friend.

—I am a lot more fortunate than the honourable member for Ballarat, given the fact that I chose to be a member of the Australian Labor Party, that is for sure. Unemployment was the major issue at the last federal election and it remains a major political and social issue in this country.

PARA.TAB: During 1992, when in a recession, unemployment was unacceptably high—over 11 per cent. I recall the glee and the smiles at the time on the faces of the opposition leader and the frontbench opposition members. They loved the high levels of unemployment that existed in 1992, for two reasons. Those opposite see unemployment as desirable. As friends of the bosses, they want to drive the price of labour down. Consistent with the theory of supply and demand, the bigger the pool of unemployed, the bigger the supply of labour. In that way they can keep the price of labour down. That is the cynical way the opposition views unemployment in this country.

The other reason opposition members relished high unemployment was that they saw it as an electoral winner. Given that we were in government and that we had unacceptably high levels of unemployment during a recession, the opposition thought that was the way to win the federal election in 1993. So for those two reasons our opponents—the Liberal-National Party coalition—relished the fact that there was high unemployment. They did not care about the unemployed, the ordinary people, and the social and human tragedy that ensues from unemployment; they were just looking forward to their electoral prospects. I guess they thought that the higher unemployment was, the lower they could force wages down. That was quite obvious from the policies they took to the election in 1993.

We have heard a lot today from previous speakers on the other side, particularly from the last speaker, the honourable member for Goldstein (Dr Kemp), about how similar the government's initiatives in the white paper are to their Austrain proposal. Nothing could be further from the truth as far as I am concerned. We dubbed the opposition's Austrain proposal `Aus-slave' because it was really about forcing people's wages down to slave wages. There was no training in the Austrain proposal. That is the big difference between our proposal and their proposal. Our training wage is about providing training.

Our whole emphasis in this area, since the Carmichael report, has been on skilling and training the work force, whether unemployed or not. We have had some great successes in that area. I will talk about them later. The opposition's policy was to reduce people's wages—I believe it was by $3 or $3.50 an hour—depending on age. Those opposite wanted to bring in Austrain and a youth wage of around $3 a hour. They wanted to sell off the CES and cut people off the dole after eight months—the unemployed that they are so concerned about! The Jobsback policy, which the opposition took to the election, is the younger sibling of Fightback. That is one of the reasons it was resoundingly defeated in the 1993 election.

Following our election victory, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and this government set about addressing unemployment head on. We recognised that unemployment was the major political issue that faced us in 1993 and faces us for the next three ensuing years. The Prime Minister and the then employment minister made a number of statements to address unemployment. A task force was set up within the caucus. I was privileged to be a member of that caucus employment task force. We set about addressing the problem of unemployment, particularly long-term unemployment. There was about a million unemployed people when we came out of the recession. The statistics showed that, of those million or so, at least 300,000—it is probably more like 400,000—were long-term unemployed; that is, they were unemployed for over 12 months. That was a serious problem that we saw with the cycle.

In the early 1980s, when unemployment was high as a result of the recession, long-term unemployment went up. When employment grew throughout the 1980s in the period of the Hawke government, unemployment came down, but long-term unemployment did not come down by that much. It then went up further during the recession in the 1990s. Statistics and graphs presented by experts, such as Dr Bruce Chapman, showed that long-term unemployment was becoming entrenched and a real problem. The caucus task force looked at that issue and consulted widely with people in the community. We received hundreds of submissions. Everyone had an idea about what to do on unemployment. Many worthwhile submissions were received by that task force. As I said, we received very significant advice from experts.

Members of the task force also talked a lot amongst themselves about the real causes of unemployment. I think we need to go back and look at unemployment over the last couple of decades. Quite apart from the fact that we were in a recession, there were some structural reasons for the unemployment figures. There are more women seeking employment—which is a positive thing—since the great equal pay cases were fought and won in the early 1970s as a result of the efforts of the trade union movement, the same union movement that is vilified and harassed by the opposition. So trade unions were the ones responsible for equal pay for women. Following the revolution in women's issues, more women quite rightly sought to participate in the workplace. Even though it was a very positive social development, in terms of overall participation, it increased the size of the labour market. So, naturally, there were pressures.

That was offset to some extent by the fact that, since 1983, the number of students staying at school until year 12 has increased from about 30 per cent to about 80 per cent. That means considerably fewer young people attempt to enter the work force before the age of around 18. As I said, 80 per cent of students stay at school until year 12, whereas 10 years ago only 30 per cent stayed at school.

I do not need to elaborate on technological change except to say that, with computers, automation and info-technology, work that was formerly done manually is now done by computers. That means fewer jobs are required, particularly in the case of unskilled and routine types of jobs. So fewer jobs are available.

Micro-economic reform has been very positive in the 1980s, but a by-product has been more unemployment because fewer people are required to do the same amount of work. We have debated tariffs, the lowering of tariffs and the removal of protection. The reality is that that has cost jobs in some industries. So in the short term that is a problem which has added to unemployment.

In addition to all those long-term structural problems which are a feature of the 1990s, we were in a recession from 1990 to 1992. Now we are in a very strong economic recovery. We have come out of a recession. We have very high levels of growth and are in a recovery. The opposition does not like that. Just as it enjoyed having high unemployment before the last election, it is now very concerned about growth. We hear a lot of platitudes from the opposition about how it is a low quality recovery and that we had better watch out because interest rates will rise.

We also had this nonsense last week about interest rates rising in the near future. What intrigues me is comments from the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer) and the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) about the boom-bust cycle. They said, `It is no good having all this growth and economic recovery because we are only in a boom-bust cycle. We will have recovery, then a boom and go bust again. It is dreadful. The sky will fall in.' I find that intriguing because I thought that booms and busts in economic cycles were an essential feature of a capitalist economy. I thought that the coalition was a party of private enterprise and market capitalism. What are we seeing here? Are we seeing the Leader of the Opposition becoming a new socialist in Australian politics?

The only guarantee—if there is one, and I am not sure that there is—that we will never have a boom-bust cycle is by having a totally planned command economy, such as that in the Soviet Union. So what does the opposition want? Is it saying that we should not have boom-bust cycles, that we should not have economic cycles but have a planned economy? That just goes to show how much nonsense we get from this desperate opposition. It is absolutely desperate to know what to do, given that the government has won the so-called unwinnable election. The opposition missed its chance at government when unemployment was high and when economic circumstances suggested that there could be a change of government. There was no change of government. Those opposite missed their chance. They now find that there is an economic recovery, unemployment levels are reducing, jobs are increasing and that this government has presented a magnificent white paper. The opposition has to resort to negative tactics like having stupid little flags on its benches.

The caucus task force took a number of submissions and produced a report entitled Growth plus. The task force identified that, while we need market driven economic growth to create jobs and sustain the recovery, we need more than that: we need a social side; a human side, if you like. That is where initiatives such as the job compact come in.

As well as recommending that the government develop a job compact, the task force recommended that there be greater flexibility in hours of work, more opportunities for part-time work and a case management approach taken to unemployment. That initiative has now been adopted in the white paper. In addition, we recommended that the CES be revitalised. This initiative has also been incorporated in the white paper. The task force report was subsequently presented to the expert committee which in turn produced a green paper. After further community consultation this led to the Working Nation document which was presented to the House on 4 May.

The white paper contains the very important job compact initiative which will apply to all those who have been in receipt of jobsearch or newstart allowances for over 18 months. The job compact will include more intensive case management, training and support to ensure that unemployed people are ready for jobs when they become available and a training wage, which has been criticised today. I think the comments on that matter speak for themselves.

The training wage was embraced and agreed to by the ACTU, the representatives of the trade union movement, which, after all, is the legitimate representative of workers—the people of Australia. I make no apology for the fact that the government thinks it is very important to get the union movement to support initiatives in the labour market. I believe case management will be very important and widely available. The one-on-one case management model will apply to all recipients of the youth training allowance and the newstart allowance, the short-term unemployed who are considered to be at high risk of becoming long-term employed, people who are not on the job compact and all recipients of the job compact.

The other feature of case management is competition. Case management will be provided by the CES and the CES will receive a boost in resources and get more and better trained staff to implement the initiatives contained in the white paper. There will also be the opportunity for community organisations such as Skillshare and private sector organisations to provide this case management. ESRA, the Employment Services Regulation Agency, will oversee the whole process. It will have an important role in ensuring that these very important initiatives in the labour market are implemented successfully.

I wish to stress the importance of the regional development initiatives contained in the white paper. One of the keys to better employment is to provide jobs close to where people live in the growing regions of Australia. In terms of growth, there is no region more important than the Macarthur region in south-west Sydney which is the area I represent. I have been working closely with the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Latham), the honourable member for Fowler (Mr Grace) and the honourable member for Prospect (Mrs Crosio) in order to develop a regional organisation in the area. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hall The Hon R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The member of the Australian Labor Party who has just resumed his seat, the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Haviland), is following the traditional path that speakers from that side of the House have followed for a number of years, the years which encompassed the beginnings of the recession. What those opposite cannot understand is that the recession was caused by the government's mismanagement of Australia. From time to time, there is public discussion about the ambitious 1980s and the way this government fostered the wheeler-dealers, the paper managers, across Australia.

PARA.TAB: In recent days, we have been regaled by tales of the Holmes a Court attack on BHP. I have said in this House before—and the member for Macarthur who is leaving the House will remember it—that it was his government that encouraged Holmes a Court's attack on BHP. Had the attack been successful, this government would have been responsible for the dismemberment of Australia's greatest national asset in relation to the economy and private industry.

That attack and the mismanagement of government finances by the three Labor administrations in Western Australia, South Australia and Victoria are the factors behind the recession in this country. They have set this country back years in its recovery. The honourable member referred to the recovery, but the opposition knows what caused the recession that is behind the recovery that is now occurring.

What is the basis of the recovery? We all support the increase in sales and look forward to the promise the government has made in relation to capital investment and industry, which is yet to be fulfilled, but we know that so far the recovery has been based on debt. I pose this question to anyone who wants to discuss the issue: if we took the $13 1/2 billion deficit out of the budget, would we have a recovery? Of course we would not.

The government may well say that the deficit is its instrument for bringing about the recovery. That might be so in the short term. However, the government is not just loading up the economy for our children; it is also loading up the economy in the immediate future. From here on, year after year we have to meet the increasing debt repayment. This will be a drag on the national budget for many years.

The white paper and the One Nation statement, which was presented to the House a year ago, are spurred on by the government's guilty conscience about the recession and the need to do something for the Australian people. The government might be successful here and there and, when it is successful, I support it, as any Australian would. We have to do what we can to get out of this enormous recession. Its after-effects will live on not just in an economic sense but in the psychology of Australians. I say to the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Mr Lindsay), who is at the table, that the Australian people will not forgive the Labor Party.
We have before the House the Working Nation white paper. Page 3 states:

This is a White Paper on employment and growth. We take the view that the two are inseparable; success in one will complement the other. The Paper might even be taken to mark the end of the old debate about economic and social goals. The policies in this White Paper derive from the premise that those goals are indivisible.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course they are indivisible. If we are going to have success in producing long-term jobs for those middle age people and youths now out of work, we will have to have growth. What does the white paper say about growth? We find many references in the white paper to training, the job compact and the creation of employment. But we need to look at the basis upon which employment is to grow in the future—and I do not mean the debt to which I have already referred.

PARA.TAB: The white paper gets thin when it refers to the matter of growth. The references to regional development start on page 17 of the white paper and run out at page 21. Then there is another page and a half on industry development. That is all the information there is on the development of Australia upon which all these jobs have to depend. Where will these people go when they have been trained? What will their future hold if this government does not produce the growth that provides employment?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is all done with mirrors.

—As my colleague at the table says, it is all done with mirrors in the economic sense. Let us look at some of these structural matters. If we are to create more jobs, I would have thought the government would have come out with some physical program which would assist the development of Australia. I would have thought we would be looking to the four corners of this great land and its natural resources. I would have thought we would be saying, `We'll get ahead of the time here. We'll put a railroad here. We'll support a port here. We'll work with state governments to provide the infrastructure for the future jobs of Australia. We'll encourage private enterprise through the taxation system and be deeply involved in those matters.' But, no. All we get is the sort of throwaway statement that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) made when questioned about Working Nation on a radio program. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: You've got to see this, not in terms of the way you help regional areas as by just throwing a bucket of money at them. That's proven not to work. I think what works is regional communities who know what they're doing for themselves.

That is a half-truth. Of course, regional communities have to know what they are doing for themselves. In most instances, they know what suits their region. What they need is assistance in order to complement their own work and activities in regional development. But do they get it?

PARA.TAB: I refer to the road program. I do not refer to part of the programs. I refer to all the identified road grants for roads in Australia that are given out by the Commonwealth. I wish to make an interesting comparison. The aggregate of road spending in the years 1983-85 was equal to that of road spending in the years 1991-94. No progress was made in that decade. There was no increase. In fact, in the intervening years, there was a very real reduction in road funding in Australia from the Commonwealth government.

In 1992-93, over $2,000 million was spent on road funding, and $1,600 million or $1,700 million was spent the year before. This figure was increased because, in his One Nation program, the Prime Minister promised $600 million more to increase the quality of Australian roads. But, as soon as that year was over, he reduced the amount of funding to the roads of Australia by some several hundred million dollars. It was a fraud. The Prime Minister increased the road funding one year, but he is making up for it by reducing road funding in subsequent years. This year, about $10 million—a nominal figure perhaps—is being spent on road funding, which shows the direction of government thinking in relation to the Working Nation document, which is seeking to provide jobs for hundreds of thousands of Australians. Yet, in a comparable document which refers to road funding, the government has decreased the amount of road funding this year in comparison with last year. What a lot of nonsense! Nothing could be more important to Australian development than jobs and a proper transport system, and the government has failed.

Let us not neglect the question of excise. The government might say, `We're short of funds. We don't have the funding for roads that we would like.' However, the government's excise collections have increased from just over $7,000 million last year to $8,000 million this year. So the government has made an increase of $1 billion from the motorists of Australia, but it has decreased the amount being spent on roads by $10 million. It is a fraud. The road programs of Australia have been fraudulent for a long period, and never more so than under this Keating government.

As we all know, there have been proposals to increase infrastructure. A former premier of New South Wales and a political colleague of the Prime Minister, Mr Neville Wran, is chairing a committee which is looking at the development of the Northern Territory. The economic round-up put out by Treasury just recently contains a report which shows some of the pros and cons of the Northern Territory, which has a great influence on the thinking of my state of South Australia because of the desire to complete the rail link between Alice Springs and Darwin. The report is worth reading. It deals with Darwin as a transport hub. It refers to freight rates, the development approach, the effect on defence and so on. But the government simply ignores this question. It has commissioned a study, which everyone knows is a way for the government to defer for as long as it wants the required facility.

We have yet more prevarication in the face of enormous growth in Asia. The same economic round-up document shows a growth figure for China of just under 14 per cent for the year 1993. Korea shows a figure of over five per cent and Singapore shows a figure of about 10 per cent. We are looking at having a transport link from Adelaide to Darwin. This would be one more connection with one of the most fascinating growth areas of the world—Asia and South-East Asia. Yet the government has produced this white paper document which ignores all of the major physical development of this country.

The problem is that we have an enormous amount of debt. An article in the Australian Financial Review of 15 June was headed `Managing Australia's magic pudding'. It was written by Dr David Clark, Director of Community and Business Education. It is a non-politically written article. I am sure Dr Clark wrote it totally apolitically but, as much as he might have done so, the political message is there. Australia's debt has just gone ahead to a degree which no-one would have credited a few years ago. In relation to public debt interests, he writes:

SPEECH.PARA: Outlays on public debt interest . . . by the Commonwealth are estimated to increase over $1.89 billion over 1994-95 to $7.4 billion. Such outlays will total 7 per cent of total Budget outlays—only slightly less than what we spend on education and defence and almost half what we spend on health.
That is what the debt structure that this government has created is costing with respect to the capacity of the country to produce services for its citizens. In another excerpt, Dr Clark writes:

Between 1991-92 and the end of the fiscal year 1994-95, the Commonwealth will have created $51 billion of debt. Further deficits over the next two years will add at least another $15 billion. Assuming an average financing cost of 6.5 per cent—an underestimate if interest rates rise—interest payments will add an average $4.25 billion to the Budget deficit bottom line.

I repeat what I said when I began this dissertation: we welcome any attempt to solve the worst problem facing Australia, and that is unemployment. We acknowledge that a great deal of that unemployment can be sheeted home to the action of this government in this Working Nation paper. The recovery, so far as it has proceeded before the investment in plant and equipment has occurred, is based on debt. I think it is fair to say that this government is as deficient now in its management of Australia's physical resources as it has been in the past. Unless it can produce a plan in that direction, it will fail. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek leave to make a short statement regarding the matter of privilege raised on Monday.

—If this relates to the matter raised by the honourable member for Tangney, has the honourable member for Tangney been informed that the honourable member for Chifley wishes to speak? Would it not be appropriate to give the honourable member for Tangney the opportunity to be present while the honourable member for Chifley makes a statement on this matter?

—I have not contacted the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Williams), but the secretary of the committee is contacting all members of the House of Representatives who are members of that committee, two of whom you see in attendance at the moment.
—I am not disposed to give leave until the honourable member for Tangney is present.

PARA.TAB: Leave not granted.
Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the initiatives of the government contained in Working Nation: Policies and Programs. I know it is a cliche, but it has been called an historic document. It is historic in the sense that it is the first white paper on employment in 50 years. Australian industries have gone through an incredible amount of restructuring and there has been turmoil in many aspects of community life.

PARA.TAB: We are now at a point where we have learnt from the successes and, indeed, the mistakes of the past 10 or 20 years. It is apparent, except to many of those opposite, that Australia had to go through that restructuring. Had those opposite paid more attention to the realities of the economy when they were in government—as they encourage the government to pay attention to what they see as the realities of the economy today—Australia would not have had to undergo radical changes in such a short space of time to bring it into this part of the 20th century. We are dealing with the effects of that restructure, which had to occur, as well as a world recession of an incredible magnitude.

The white paper on employment and growth is one of this government's greatest achievements. It will be recognised around the world as a model of mechanisms for dealing with unemployment. All countries in the OECD face these same dilemmas, particularly the Western countries. This white paper is critical not only to Australia's economic development but also to our social and community development. For the first time it gives all Australians—in a clear, constructive, comprehensive way—an opportunity to begin to understand the workings of government and the way government programs can interact across the areas of employment, social security and industrial relations policy. It gives incentives—imperatives—to individuals, businesses, state and federal governments and industries to achieve what must be achieved if Australia is to progress.

The opposition talks a lot about growth—as well it might. It is being recognised—by the community if not by the opposition—that Australia's rate of economic growth is now considerable; it is certainly ahead of that of many other countries we would normally compare ourselves with. Over the last few weeks we have seen the new Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer) attempt to talk down the economy yet again. It seems to be a feature of political life in Australia that those in opposition seek to make the worst of something rather than look at the reality of the economic development that is occurring. We have seen the media take the same approach. The media in this country has a lot to answer for. The approach it takes to, say, news, is an almost dog in the manger approach when compared with the approach of other countries. That same approach comes through with the opposition. Whether it be hares running or whatever the case may be, the media and the opposition continually try to make the worst of the situation rather than focus on some of the positives.

Confidence is a key factor in investment and growth. It continues to amaze me when I read newspapers from other countries—particularly the United States, where the economic situation is in many ways worse than it is here—to find that the media is constantly looking not only at balanced reporting and discussion, but at ways in which to stimulate the economy. If we in this country had been in such a position, many of the impacts of the recession—let alone the time we waited to overcome the recession—would have been eliminated.

We have to look at the white paper in the context of all the work the government has done in the past 10 years. Business, whether it be industries or banks, or whatever the case may be, has never had a more productive opportunity to put its money where the mouth of capitalism is. We now have high rates of growth, a much more skilled labour market, drastically changed workplaces, reductions in tariff and quota protections and restructured industries. Capital market regulations have been relaxed; we have low inflation; we have tax reform to encourage productive investments; and there are more measures contained in this white paper.

The industry development policies contained in the white paper build upon an environment which is already competitive through not only stable macro-economic and micro-economic policies and competition policies but also through the work that has been done to build competitive firms. It is important for business, particularly at a time when there seems to be some induced destabilisation or panic operating in some of the financial markets, that we focus upon what has been achieved and the strategies that are very clearly espoused within this document.

In terms of building a competitive environment, the white paper points to the macro-economic stability of Australia today, the micro-economic reform that has been carried out, the export market access programs which have been developed over the past 10 years and which are even further enhanced and refined within this paper, the change in education and training, and the changes in tariff and dumping policies, where both government and business are becoming far more able to deal with some of the more minute differences and changes that occur. This white paper is full of initiatives which go to those lengths.

Labour market skills and the diversity of the labour market, which are very important in building a competitive environment, are enhanced through measures contained in the white paper. Another key element of the white paper's industry strategies is to build competitive firms. This white paper contains measures on innovation, science and technology, information, networking, the development and focus on leadership and management skills—one of the greatest weaknesses for many years in Australian business, better access to finance. I congratulate the honourable member for Brisbane (Mr Bevis) for his efforts in regard to changes made to government purchasing arrangements.

The white paper contains measures to encourage exports and the focus on Asia. We have only to look at the incredible intensity of effort going into the markets to our north, particularly, as we speak, around Indonesia. We have only to look at the drastic changes which have occurred in this country and the way in which many businesses have responded to that initiative.

If we look at the industry based strategies and the regional economic development strategies which are in this white paper, we realise that, if we are serious, if we are looking to Australia in a positive sense, so much is before us in this white paper. The opposition talks about growth, and yet continually, as it has over the years before, it fails to accurately or comprehensively describe how it would achieve growth without adding extra taxes on people at lower incomes and without causing even further disruption to people. The opposition has not produced its own white paper. The best we ever got out of it was Fightback, and all that did was create further tax increases.

TALK.START.PARA: —A great document!

—The former Leader of the Opposition wants it brought back. Do I hear any advances on that? It was a good idea at the time and, you never know, somebody else might bring it back. But in this white paper, the job compact is a very important initiative. It is something which I do not think Australia has seen before, and it has concepts which Australian business, individuals and government can work to define and be very different from the way in which many other countries would deal with it.

PARA.TAB: It allows for better delivery of labour market programs, the early identification of people at high risk of long-term unemployment and the case managed approach linked with new work opportunities. The ever important growth in the economy, I believe, will be one of the things which the government will have to look at and monitor very carefully. It will be a tremendous advance with the cooperation of all involved.

In the minutes I have left, I want to concentrate on regional and economic development because it is a key to unemployment. Governments, treasuries and newspapers from time to time tend to deal with the economy as one great big aggregate. It is not. The Australian economy, like most economies in a large diverse country like ours, is made up of a series of economies. The Kelty-Fox task force went a long way to broadening our understanding of those regional economies and how they contribute to the aggregate.

We all come from different parts of the country. Different parts of the country have greater strengths and weaknesses, and different parts of the country have been more or less affected by the recession and, indeed, the restructuring that has gone on. The northern areas of Melbourne that you and I represent, Mr Deputy Speaker Jenkins, are the most important manufacturing areas in this country. They have many great strengths. They have a skilled work force. They have good opportunities for growth in industrial areas. They are close to quite efficient infrastructure as well as areas of infrastructure which need even greater development. They have many of the things which have driven Australia for many, many decades.

There are people in other states who like to gloat at times and think of Victoria as the rust bucket state, but that could never be further from the truth. It is in Victoria that Australians drive around in Australian cars, wear Australian clothes and eat Australian food. It is one of the great manufacturing areas, but there are also many opportunities for changes and growth in different industries, which can be taken up, I believe, by sensible regional and economic development policies.

The white paper talks about regional and economic development organisations—the Office of Labour Market Adjustment and area consultative committees. I believe, as I know you do, Mr Deputy Speaker, in the importance of making those processes work to help bring finance, business and industry together and to bring the government training facilities and the community together to make those strengths work for us. This area has been not only one of Australia's most productive manufacturing areas but also one of its central manufacturing area for decades, as it will continue to be and grow even further. It has now undergone incredible restructuring, and the people in this area need many opportunities, such as presented in this white paper, to make it strong again.

I remind the House that if there is to be economic development, we should not be looking at just simply the aggregate of economic development. More and more government policies, like those in the white paper, need to focus on the micro-economic development in the various regions of Australia, particularly those that have been our manufacturing base for so long.
