SPEECH.SPEAKER: Price The Hon L.R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Mr Deputy Speaker, you will recall that on Monday, 27 June the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Williams) raised with you a possible breach of privilege. I refer you to page 1921 of the Hansard. I had no prior knowledge that the matter was going to be raised, but I did advise the Speaker and all honourable members that, at the request of the deputy chairman of the committee, this matter was already listed for discussion at Tuesday's scheduled meeting.

PARA.TAB: The committee met on Tuesday. I vacated the chair in order that the matter be discussed, and clearly indicated to the committee that I would not vote on any subsequent resolution of the committee about this matter. The committee, for the purposes of the item, was chaired by the deputy chairman. The matter was not resolved and a further meeting was held on Wednesday morning and again on Wednesday evening. I am pleased to report to the House that the committee, with me not participating, unanimously resolved as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: The Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues—
(a)notes—

(i)that the chairman of the committee had discussions with Cheryl Critchley on or about 9 June 1994 and with Sue Dunlevy on or about 21 June 1994 on the subject of the committee's inquiry into the Child Support Scheme.

PARA.TAB: (ii)that the discussions resulted respectively in the publication on 11 June 1994 of an article by Cheryl Critchley in the Melbourne Herald Sun and on 22 June 1994 of an article by Sue Dunlevy in the Sydney Daily Telegraph Mirror.
(iii)that the articles refer to what are said to be or appear to be recommendations in the draft report under consideration by the committee.
(iv)that the chairman of the Committee denies canvassing the recommendations of the draft report with the journalists.

SPEECH.PARA: (b)expresses the opinion that neither any disclosure of any part of the draft report that may have resulted in the publication of the articles nor the publication of the articles actually caused substantial interference with the work of the Committee.
(c)expresses concern that the chairman has provided the occasion for aspects of the draft report under consideration by the committee to be referred to or speculated upon publicly.
(d)recommends that, except for this resolution being reported to the House and to the Senate, no further action be taken.

Mr Deputy Speaker, the committee was also very much of a mind to ensure that the goodwill necessary to complete the consideration of the report was not jeopardised by this matter. That is certainly my wish as chairman of the committee.

PARA.TAB: I want to make it clear to the House that I accept the decision of the committee. But as the accused I want to assure the House that I protested my innocence at the charge of breach of privilege. The committee was unable to establish that I had conveyed any one specific recommendation, let alone the 150 recommendations of the chairman's draft report, nor any of the papers or proceedings of the committee. I do freely and frankly acknowledge that I did state, or so-called leaked, the fact that the report was of some 600 pages in length and contained some 150 recommendations.

Again, to be frank, it did not seem to me that I was committing such a terrible crime at the time. According to the guidelines laid down, the committee was unable to find that there had been substantial interference with its work. So the committee has effectively concluded that there was no breach of privilege. The committee has found that none of the persons mentioned on Monday, including myself, has a case to answer.

Sue Dunleavy and Cheryl Critchley are both guilty—guilty of being genuinely concerned at the very real plight of so many victims of the scheme. They are guilty of seeking justice and equity on their behalf, and they are guilty of taking a genuine interest in the work and future report of the committee. Together with so many of their colleagues in the print, radio and television media, I sincerely thank them, as do countless numbers of our fellow Australians. The committee would never have been able to organise the hotline or the record number of submissions without them. They have set themselves a very simple but absolutely vital task, that is, to inform the people of Australia—who in my opinion have every right to be informed.

The House of Representatives Standing Committee of Privileges, in its report concerning the Public Accounts Committee, acknowledges that not all members or observers share the view that the present rules of privilege should be maintained. I firmly believe that these rules are more appropriate to an age of morse code, but in today's environment unduly restrict the public's access and right to be informed. I invite and urge the Committee of Privileges, having discerned the dissatisfaction with, and the inappropriateness of, the present rules as far as they apply to committees, to review and revise them to reflect contemporary standards and needs and have at the forefront of their deliberations the right of ordinary Australians to have the ability to be informed.

Mr Deputy Speaker, during this inquiry I have, as chairman, encountered what might loosely be described as unintended or intended obstacles to this inquiry. This may very well have been another. But I pledge to you and to all honourable members that I will not be deflected from the task of tabling the committee's report no later than August this year. I will not betray the trust placed in me and my committee by so many of our fellow Australians and, I might say, a Child Support Agency keen to change but looking for additional guidelines for change.

Last but not least, this matter has caused the fulsome attendance of members at meetings of my committee. Is it unfair of me to hope that this enthusiasm may spill over to the committee's deliberation of the report? I thank the House.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)—Order! Whilst the honourable member's statement appears to conclude the matter that was raised with the Speaker earlier this week, I will ensure that the Speaker is made aware of the honourable member's statement.

TALKER.NAME: Mr LINDSAY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That Mrs Moylan be discharged from attendance on the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, and that, in her place, Mr Beale be appointed a member of the committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Speaker has received advice from the chief opposition whip that he has nominated Mr Ronaldson to be a member of the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training in place of Mrs Sullivan, Mr Beale to be a member of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities in place of Mr Moore, Mr Cameron to be a member of the Joint Standing Committee on the National Capital and External Territories in place of Mr Halverson and Mrs Gallus to be a member of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Native Title in place of Mr Reith.

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Interestingly, today the parliament has gained the opportunity to discuss the white paper on employment and growth, Working Nation, a document that may or may not achieve its objectives but certainly one that is extremely important. I have argued strongly that the parliament have more time to look closely at reports and white papers of this nature. I am extremely hopeful that when we return in August we will see the second chamber used much more consistently in this regard.

PARA.TAB: The other great coincidence is that today we are considering this white paper on employment and growth—and having a look at some of the subheadings as to how this government proposes to proceed with a financial commitment over four years of $6.5 billion and how it plans to assist small business, social security and many other areas—and yesterday the Minister for the Environment, Senator Faulkner, refloated the concept of a carbon tax. We are talking in this paper most particularly about addressing the problems of and creating employment for the 900,000 unemployed and, I think it is, the 350,000 of those who are now categorised as long-term unemployed.

In that context we still have people saying we should tax energy. I could not think of a worse possible tax. I might have raised in this parliament before the hypothetical case of our Prime Minister (Mr Keating) as a youth being spirited off to Russia to be brainwashed by the KGB for the purpose of sending him back to Australia to enter the political system with the intention of destroying our economy. We now know that the trip was not necessary. But on the other hand, had it happened, I am sure the Prime Minister's advisers and brainwashers in Russia would have told him, `When you get back there, tax fuel, tax transport, tax energy.' Probably no country is more reliant on transport than Australia. We are a very large country that has the huge benefit of having these resources to hand along with other raw materials, which gives us a huge advantage in being competitive in world trade.

Just to make sure that the government dumps another tonne of lead in the saddlebags of our employers—the people who have the best potential to fix this job—Senator Faulkner gets up and says, `Let's tax energy. Let's have a carbon tax'. I pointed out to the House the other day that there are some great initiatives in Australia in our export effort. I do not know how big it is today, but down in Tasmania there is a major exporter manufacturing wheels for motor cars. This manufacturer has had the good sense to locate its manufacturing facility right alongside the aluminium smelter. It takes liquid aluminium, as I understand it, off the smelter and turns it into mag wheels instead of—which is so common in Australia—letting the whole process solidify, shifting it somewhere else, and then remelting it and going through a manufacturing process.

Senator Faulkner should have got up and said, `We will give tax incentives to people who do those sorts of things'. I do not know why—the people of Victoria might want to give me some good explanation—we create steel at BHP in Port Kembla and then cart it all the way down to Melbourne to turn it into engine blocks. It seems to make a lot of sense to me to do it while it is still running. I have been in a major steelworks in Taiwan where they had huge liquid iron carriers that they shifted around the place. It is technologically feasible while it is still running hot to take it over to a plant that creates engine blocks and, instead of delivering billets down to Fishermens Bend or wherever they go in Victoria, make them straight away. We should give tax incentives to people who do that. That is preventing extra greenhouses gases; it is positive.

But no, this government's mentality is about imposing more taxes. It wants to use the environment as a revenue raising measure. It has done it with fuel taxes, contrary to its promises in the last election—in a country where everything has to move on wheels, where there are huge distances between our resources and our manufacturing industries.

This white paper deals with a regional strategy. It quite correctly identifies our regions as being areas for development where there is a higher percentage of long-term unemployed people. How do we improve their lot by taxing everything that comes into their area?

In Western Australia, a company went to the regional town of Bunbury to make some batteries. It could not stay because all its customers were back in Perth and it was having to freight very heavy commodities back there. It was a good idea, and probably one that would have survived if we did not tax fuel. Why tax fuel in a country the size of Australia? It is silly, but it is revenue.

I have heard the Prime Minister, in his days as Treasurer, admit that the government was hooked on fuel taxes. There has been criticism of the Fightback proposals of the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson), our past leader, which sought to remove the tax on fuel. I do not think that was a silly measure. I thought it was an outstanding measure to recognise that, in Australia, it is downright foolish to tax fuel.

We are here discussing a paper. We recognise that there cannot be jobs if business is going to be taxed, because business will always be the only creator of real jobs. We can have as many jobs in the public sector as we like—and there is an obvious need for many—but they do not produce the things that balance the books. They have to be paid for by the prosperity of the private sector. It is downright foolish on that first account to think that we are even contemplating a carbon tax. We signed a convention to commit ourselves to practices that will be debilitating to any outcomes written in One Nation. It is time that ministers who have given support to this document stopped dreaming up revenue measures that hurt.

I reminded the parliament the other day that $800 of lead in the saddlebag of every car manufactured in Australia is applied through our present indirect tax system. That is not my figure; it is a Treasury figure. Yet we tell people to compete. We are a nation of raw materials, such as bauxite, steel, energy and coal. Why not give our exporters the advantage they need to compete even at home? I have reminded people time and again of people in your electorate, Mr Deputy Speaker Andrew, who have to pay $2,000 per week tax on every semitrailer they use to get their product into Melbourne and Sydney while their Brazilian manufacturing competitors bring their product in on the cheapest transport available in the world—namely, international sea transport.

I have probably said enough about that, because there are so many other aspects of this white paper that I want to touch upon. We were promised case management. Case management would be an excellent idea in terms of the operations of the CES. My family associated businesses employ about 40 people. I am very conscious of the problems of the unemployed. Not that long ago I instructed my son, who manages those businesses, that we needed a handyman and that we should try to get somebody over 40, who preferably would have been long-term unemployed. There would be a training period in the sort of work that we would want that person to undertake. We were going to teach the successful applicant MIG welding, amongst other things. We thought that the subsidy available would be helpful during that training period.

We went to the CES and wrote a specification which, to my mind, met the greatest need for the unemployed. Four weeks later, we had not had an applicant. I must admit that we had two or three, but they all had jobs. What did the CES do? It typed out a little card and put it in a rack. We thought someone of that age would be better for us in that type of work. In the end, I had to ring up the state director and say, `I don't want to complain, but would you please reconfirm what I hear in the parliament, which is that there are all these people in this older age bracket looking for work.'

We had our first applicant the following Monday. He is still with us. He went off the subsidy the other day, and we are satisfied with him. He has a good job. But how can people get jobs when those in the system are not ringing them up and saying, `We have a job for you, Smith'? Why does a member of parliament have to ring the state director? When we looked into the white paper and saw the funding allocated for this program, it became a joke. I worked out that the funding was probably $16.4 million. The Prime Minister said that the government was going to case manage 500,000 unemployed people. I worked that out to be $16 per head per annum. I just cannot see how it is going to work. It is silly.

But, since then, we have seen ex-Premier Kirner being given a job on a special committee that will bring the private sector into case management. That is a good idea. I have reminded this House before that, some years ago, I attended a briefing from two outstanding Americans whom this government brought to this place for the purpose of advising it on placing single parents into employment. They were a very interesting couple who came from the state of Massachusetts. One was the director of social security; the other, his wife, was the director of the American equivalent of our CES.

They identified heaps of single parents with qualifications. The husband, who was paying the pensions, called upon his wife and the private sector to get these people back into the workplace. But fundamental to the American bureaucratic approach was putting a price on getting those people back into the work force. They were not paid a weekly amount or a pension. He said to his wife's bureaucratic department and to the private sector, `We will pay you $10,000 if you can train these people and put them back into a permanent job.'

It was working, so the government brought these people here to advise it. But did the government pick up on the fundamental strategy? The fundamental strategy is that an incentive be given to the private sector to get these people back into the workplace. The private sector would also take the loss if it failed; that is private enterprise. No; the government sent them home, having paid a lot to get some very good advice, and ignored it. I do not know whether that is what Mrs Kirner is proposing. On the other hand, it would be a mammoth task if she were to get a job for all those whose jobs she destroyed in Victoria. We should be bringing in the private sector. Of course, $16.4 million for the proper case management of 500,000 people is laughable.

Some other aspects of the white paper worry me. I missed the opportunity the other day to speak about the pooled development funds. Both the Commonwealth Development Bank and the pooled development funds will be given opportunities and encouragement to invest in small business. It is a noble intention, but a look at the people who need that money will show that it will not work for two reasons.

Let us first look at the very small businesses. The Commonwealth Development Bank cannot take an equity position in a family business if it is not incorporated. There is a notion called joint and several liability. The Commonwealth Bank, by investing as a partner in those businesses, would be liable for those businesses' entire debt. It would be totally impractical. The government said, `Let them form a proprietary limited company.' After this wonderful statement, we put up the fees for that arrangement in the budget. It is far too complex and difficult for small business. They just will not get into it, so they cannot get the money off the Commonwealth Development Bank.

Pooled development funds involve medium enterprise. Medium enterprise needs a second board of the stock market. That is the sort of thing that governments need to be initiating. I know that that proposal was a disaster last time. That should not deter us from making it good and creating a market so that investors can invest in medium-sized enterprises, which is where the investment has to be. That is where this whole thing fails. It is all about spending money, but not about addressing the fundamentals or doing what the parliament is about, which is writing laws that allow business to get on with what it does best—employing people. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Henzell Ms M.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It always seems to be my lot in life to follow the member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey).
—A hard act to follow.

—It is an incredible act to follow. It is delightful to see the member for Wentworth on the opposition's side of the table. I am fascinated that we have a new twist to the personal vilification of our Prime Minister (Mr Keating), and the fairytale that is being floated by the member for O'Connor is that our Prime Minister spent his formative years in Russia with the aim of coming back to disturb the economy of this country. This is absolutely outrageous. I am afraid that it is all of a one with the sort of strategy that would appear to be part of the opposition's response, unfortunately, to matters such as the white paper.

PARA.TAB: Bereft of a policy initiative and in the transition to the opposition's new lean team, or whatever it is called, it has reverted to some initiatives that are probably very relevant to the member for O'Connor and his age—they go back to the 1950s. There is a call for patriotism. I take note that the Australian flag is still very evident on the opposition benches. I have no problem with the Australian flag and patriotism, but I want to remind the House of what Samuel Johnson said about patriotism in Boswell's Life, volume one at page 545:

SPEECH.PARA: Patriotism is the last refuge of a scoundrel.

We should always be mindful of this because I believe that there is patriotism and patriotism. There is the cheap xenophobic ethnocentric form of patriotism, which I must say is the sort of thing the opposition has been floating—suggestions that our Prime Minister is less than patriotic because he wants to encourage a reasonable, mature, responsible debate about our constitutional arrangements, about how we as a country face the future.

PARA.TAB: It concerns me greatly that this sort of cheap performance may well encourage the lowest common denominator attitude in our community; it will hardly forward our national concerns and commitment. There ought to be a debate on the flag and there ought to be a debate on our constitutional arrangements. Part of real patriotism is how we forward this country's future. I believe that the white paper is very much a patriotic document.

Let us look at what is stated in the white paper, because I think it is a visionary document. It is a result of widespread consultation with not only the community but also some of the most significant minds in this country and it used the expertise and skills of a broad range of people within the government, in private enterprise and across this country. The white paper states:

If we are to develop the strength to compete in the world and maintain and increase our standard of living, we must make the most of all our resources. Greatest of all these are the talents and energies of the Australian people. When we waste them, we are weakened. When we employ them, we are made stronger. The policies described in this statement are policies for economic and social strength. The two go hand in hand, and with them go more opportunity, more fairness, more confidence and faith in our country and ourselves, more cooperation and cohesion in communities and across the nation.

SPEECH.PARA: This is indeed a patriotic statement of how this country ought to run. I also want to indicate that this is the position of not only the white paper but also one of the chief employer groups of this country, the Business Council of Australia. In its bulletin of April 1994 it reports on a national business summit held in March of this year entitled `Investing in Australia's future: achieving the Australia 2010 vision', which has been an initiative of the Business Council. I quote from a paper given by Mr Ian Salmon, the Managing Director of the Australian Mutual Provident Society and Chairman of the Australia 2010 Action Committee for the Business Council of Australia. On page 16, he said:

PARA.TAB: The Australia 2010 program proposes a series of strategic directions . . . under the following headings.

SPEECH.PARA: National Management—which involves improvements in the performance of government and business, government business enterprises, and economic management;
World Competitive Practice—in areas such as education and training, employee relations, innovation and corporate governance and accountability;
Saving & Investment—which involves improvements in our national saving and investment performance, taxation policy and our foreign debt position;
Internationalisation—involving the development of better overseas links particularly in our Asian region and Australia's place in the global environment.
This document further states:

PARA.TAB: It seeks to encourage all Australians to work smarter, together, to help bring the country back into the top ten ranking as one of the world's most prosperous countries.
It is about remaining a fair, caring and free society.

SPEECH.PARA: I am interested in the remarkable coincidence between the sorts of statements in the 2010 vision, as outlined by Mr Salmon, and statements in the white paper. Page 3 of the white paper summary document states:

PARA.TAB: With the White Paper we have set new national goals: new goals of economic efficiency, new goals for education and training, for our income support arrangements, for industry and for the regions of Australia. We have committed ourselves to a path by which Australia will enter the 21st century with one of the world's most sophisticated and efficient economies underpinning one of the world's most equitable and cohesive societies.

SPEECH.PARA: The key to this, which is made very clear in the white paper and in the Australia 2010 vision, is economic sustainability. I quote, once again, from the white paper. Page 3 of the summary document states:

PARA.TAB: While economic growth is the key, growth alone will not suffice. The experience of the 1980s tells us that growth will deliver jobs to the new entrants to the labour market, and to some of those temporarily unemployed; but the long-term unemployed and the truly disadvantaged will frequently miss out. In this White Paper—the first White Paper on unemployment in 50 years—the Commonwealth announces sweeping changes to the Social Security system and landmark new labour market programs.

SPEECH.PARA: This has been a great initiative and the outcome of the consultations. In reviewing, as the green paper did, what has happened through the economic cycles of the 1980s, it was quite clear that the long-term unemployed, approximately 500,000 Australians, were not going to be picked up with the new investment opportunities that have obviously presented themselves in more recent times. Therefore, it was of absolute necessity that the government deal with this as a matter of not only social justice but also economic efficiency. That is what many of the initiatives in the white paper are about. That is why over the next four years we are going to spend approximately $6.5 billion—because just as the government had to kick-start the economic recovery, it has to take responsibility for providing effective training and job opportunities for those people who will not be normally picked up as the economic recovery improves.

PARA.TAB: I also want to make some comments about the opposition's response to the economic good news. It is very disappointing to see the sorts of statements we have from the new Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer) and his deputy, the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello), in relation to talking down the economy at a time when it is very important that we work together. A basic commitment of the white paper is the importance of government working together with the private sector, the trade union movement and communities right across this country. Here we have the opposition using cheap, political responses instead of basic policy development. I think the opposition leader's petulant performance on Lateline last night is all of a piece with this. I think it will become clear very soon that unless the opposition is prepared to develop some policies that will work it will be left behind.

I will comment further on just how closely aligned business is with the government's direction. As I said previously, Working Nation is truly a patriotic document, a document that has vision that will take us into the next century and fit us for our position in the Asia-Pacific region.

As Mr Salmon says in his article, economic security will be elusive unless we as a nation improve the functioning of our economy and increase investment to generate employment. This is one of the most difficult options the government is facing and it was referred to in the National Bank publication Decisions of June 1994. An article by Alan Oster, the chief economist for the National Bank of Australia, states:

There are clear signs that the economy has moved up a gear and appears set to kick-up further in the next financial year. The Statistician's latest National Accounts suggest that Australian output/income growth picked up to around the 4% mark in the latter part of 1993 and into early 1994. That growth momentum has in turn reached a stage where hours worked have picked up, and employment is now growing by more than 2% per annum.

SPEECH.PARA: He further states:

PARA.TAB: The main missing domestic ingredient in this rosy outlook is business investment—both the statistician's and the National's surveys point to relatively subdued expectations. Of course, the external outlook is also a vital ingredient. In that regard, 1994/95 growth among the major industrialised economies is expected to pick up to around 2.25%, and in the developing Asian economies to remain around 7%.

With business confidence relatively high, private sector expectations improving and a moderate improvement in world economic conditions, we expect that Australian growth could be 4.2% in 1994/95—slightly lower than government's forecast of 4.5% released in the recent Commonwealth Budget. In composition terms, there are also few differences between the National's and the Budget projections for 1993/94 and 1994/95.

SPEECH.PARA: Later in the article he states:

Our latest findings point to both improving business conditions and confidence, together with an important pick-up in capacity utilisation. On balance then, our projections are for business investment to rise by around 15% in 1994/95, much the same as the government's forecasts.

It is therefore unclear where the federal opposition is coming from. I suspect that its only position is to attempt to talk down the economy in a very unhelpful way. In the short time left to me, I want to congratulate the government on having the vision and commitment to put together a sweeping document that covers income support arrangements and training, which is a vital component. I will conclude by quoting the Chairman of McDonald's:

Although the Australian workforce is expensive and definitely over-regulated, it is possible to make up for those things . . . This is I suppose my biggest emphasis word I want to leave with you . . . it is simply a matter of training, training, training and training.
He continues:

About 7 or 8 years ago, I sort of woke up, I suppose. I realised I was getting nowhere and I said to my people—hey, if we're to address this problem we have to come around it from another direction—we have to look at productivity side. If we're faced with those high labour costs, then we've got to get productivity to balance it.

Now, and in fact for the last two years, we are on top of the world. We are the best country, the most productive country in the world. 20% better—20% better than West Germany, the second most productive staff in the world.If McDonald's can do it, then I believe all companies can do it. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slipper Mr P.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was interested, as always, to listen to the contribution made by the honourable member for Capricornia (Ms Henzell). In my view, and I think in the view of most people in the electorate, there is absolutely nothing patriotic about a Prime Minister who bags our flag in Indonesia, who bags our constitution in France and who bags our nation in discussions with his predecessor about who is going to be Prime Minister of Australia.

PARA.TAB: There is also nothing visionary about the white paper. The previous speaker, the honourable member for Capricornia, mentioned that many things were included in the white paper. She might have been right to that extent, but, unfortunately, there was one major missing ingredient: the paper failed to provide for long-term real jobs for so many people who have been out of work during Labor's 11 years in office.

The Working Nation package will cost the Australian taxpayer approximately $6.5 billion. Unfortunately, it is not going to achieve what the government claims. The fact that the government has allocated $6.5 billion in a program which is going to be such a failure is clear recognition that the government's policies in the past have been unsuccessful. It is clear when we look at the white paper that that failure is going to continue.

One only has to look at the statistics which the government publishes each month to see an indication of Australia's unemployment crisis. Unfortunately, those statistics do not reveal the true picture. The unemployment statistics we receive each month do not include all the people who are seeking work but merely that proportion of them who receive newstart or jobstart allowances. What about the tens of thousands, perhaps hundreds of thousands, of people who do not receive unemployment benefits, people who are seeking work, people who are registered with the Commonwealth Employment Service but who do not receive any form of government benefit, certainly those who do not receive newstart or jobstart or maybe those people who are supported by their families? On the Sunshine Coast alone, there are some 6,000 people in that position.

Our official monthly unemployment figures tell us that there are about 14,000 people out of work on the coast, yet 20,000 people are registered with Sunshine Coast Commonwealth Employment Service offices as looking for work. In other words, about 30 per cent of the coast's jobless escape the official statistics. This is one example of how this government fudges figures and, of course, the white paper is yet another. The Sunshine Coast has the most rapid population growth of any region in the country and, unfortunately, we have one of the highest levels of unemployment, estimated at about 15 per cent.

This government really should come clean. It should admit the gravity of the unemployment problem in Australia. It claims that there are almost one million people out of work. The reality is that the number out of work would be between one million and two million. This government is being dishonest. I think that is a tragedy and the government stands condemned for that.

Unemployment, though, is much more than a statistical problem. It is a social problem of the greatest magnitude. Loss of a job means much more than a person not going to work. It changes life for the whole family and often causes collapse of the family unit, which is the basic unit in our society. The situation is so grave in my own local area of the Sunshine Coast that the local Sunshine Coast Sunday newspaper recently ran a large feature on unemployment. Among the articles was a letter from a middle-aged woman—a desperate plea to the community to find work for her husband. It read in part:

SPEECH.PARA: The last three years have been horrendous. We lost a child and three other family members, our home, car, his job and many other disasters. Finally after his being out of work for almost 12 months, we separated due to continual stress and he went south to find work. We want to reconcile but unless he can obtain work here it is almost impossible . . . We are not looking for pity or charity. We are both hard workers and believe in honest work for honest pay and we know we are only one family of the many victims of Australia's problems.

She is so right. Thousands of Australian families are going through similar disasters. Just as unemployment means more than a job loss, employment means much more than a job and a pay cheque. It promotes a sense of worth, self-esteem and pride. Over the last 11 years, more and more Australians have lost their self-respect, along with their jobs. They do not want government handouts, short-term training and retraining schemes; they want jobs—real jobs—and the opportunity to put one foot on the ladder of employment, the ladder of opportunity. This is the fundamental flaw in Working Nation. It has no strategy to create real long-term jobs.

PARA.TAB: To reduce unemployment and to create sustainable long-term jobs, we must create a conducive investment climate. We must free-up the labour market, not have the fiddling at the edges we have seen in this parliament recently. We need to encourage the expansion of the small business sector, the most important generator of jobs in Australia. In all of these areas, this white paper fails dismally. It is a fact that if every small business in Australia could be encouraged to employ just one person then we would not have an unemployment rate. This white paper does nothing to encourage those people to take the risk and to spend the money to put people on the payroll and give them an opportunity.

The coalition is not opposed to all of the white paper initiatives. For example, we support the parenting allowance, the introduction of training wages, the shake-up of the Commonwealth Employment Service and the suspension of the training guarantee levy. However, with respect to the latter, we very strongly would seek the total abolition of the training guarantee levy. I believe that in due course the government will be forced to join us in that position. We do not—and cannot—support a policy document which seeks to hide more of the nation's unemployed from the official statistics. We cannot support a policy document that seeks to shuffle our jobless from the dole queue to a training queue and then back again.

I receive many phone calls at my electorate office—I dare say that you do, Mr Deputy Speaker, and I dare say that even government members do—from people who have been sent to many training schemes. I recall one particularly tragic case in which one gentleman had been sent to eight training schemes. He says that he has this ticket and that ticket but, unfortunately, he still has no job. When

SPEECH.PARA: he is sent to those training schemes, he is taken off the unemployment list.

PARA.TAB: By sending people to training scheme after training scheme, the government is artificially and temporarily reducing the jobless queues. The government is continuing to stack the training queues and fudge the jobless figures. I imagine that in due course we will find that the government will seek to call an election. Government underestimates the Australian public. Labor in government is particularly guilty of this offence.

Under the government's training schemes, more than 200,000 people a year who are classified as unemployed will be dropped from the unemployment statistics as they move into new training programs. They will be on the jobless queue, they will be on the dole queue, then they will be on the unemployment lists for one month—and then off and then on and then off. Unfortunately, this white paper is not about creating jobs; it is about solving the government's political difficulties.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where do they go?

—They go on the list and then off the list. Unfortunately, this government has no vision. This white paper is an expensive document which will not in any way achieve what it seeks to achieve. This white paper is about training; it is not about dealing with unemployment, and it is not about creating real jobs. It is an expensive document which is doomed to failure, in line with this government's earlier unemployment policies. On 5 May, the day after the government announced Working Nation, the Advertiser newspaper published an appropriate editorial. It said:

SPEECH.PARA: There is a problem. It is a political problem. Solution: throw money at it. This has been the governmental reflex down the ages. It sums up the Keating government's response to the hideous political embarrassment and vast human tragedy of unemployment.

Everyone, on both sides of the House, agrees that unemployment is a tragedy. The vast majority of Australians now, following the `recession we had to have', are affected by it in some way. Most people have a friend, a family member or an acquaintance who has been jobless. We all know someone who has been on the dole and out of work. Many people have had personal experiences with unemployment. These people know that training schemes without the creation of real jobs are an expensive waste of time.

PARA.TAB: Working Nation tells us nothing about how the government plans to encourage employment growth. Everything seems to be resting on the inflated growth and business investment figures the Treasurer (Mr Willis) forecast in the budget. Economists have already said that the government's growth projections are too high. The point should be made that if investment is going to happen then much of it will be overseas. Of course, that will do nothing for Australian jobs. It really is time that the government stopped gambling and introduced policies which will address unemployment. Better still, let the coalition take over government, because we have policies which will give hope to Australia's jobless.

It is clear that history will record the white paper as yet another tragic Labor failure. It is important, though, to give industry the incentive to develop, expand and become more productive; to encourage industry to take on new employees; and to create a more flexible labour market by introducing real labour market reform. The government claims to be reforming industrial relations in this country. Of course, that is laughable. We are actually going backwards.

I believe that the industrial relations legislation the government has brought in is simply designed to give the unions more time. All this government has done is to make it more complicated, more difficult and more expensive for employers to take on new staff. Last year's Industrial Relations Reform Act saw to that. The government's industrial relations policies are not getting people back into the work force. We will now have higher labour costs, more bureaucracy, and more rules and regulations. If employers could possibly avoid getting caught up in the industrial relations web that Labor has woven, they will do so. Who would not? In other words, the government's policies will discourage employers from taking the risk; they will discourage employers from putting on people.

Working Nation is not the solution to Australia's unemployment crisis. It is the Labor Party's response to its own failure. The Labor Party has presided over high unemployment for 11 years. It simply has no idea of how to solve the problem. The Labor Party deliberately engineered a recession and put hundreds of thousands of Australians out of work. Now Labor plans to put them into training queues. Labor masquerades as the political party of the underprivileged. In a sense, it is that—in so far as the Labor Party has created an underclass in our nation that has never been here before. The gap between rich and poor in Australia has never been wider. In fact, the gap is greater here than in any other OECD nation. Members would recall that I was suspended from the House for asking the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) a question about this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —You weren't suspended for that, my friend.

—The government is prepared to do anything to muzzle opposition members who are prepared to stand up and be counted, to point out the major problems and to point out what a disastrous effect 11 years of Labor government have had. The gap between rich and poor in this nation is now wider than in any other OECD nation. Labor talks about care and compassion, yet there are still between one million and two million people unemployed. The government tells us there are slightly under one million, but when we look at the true statistics we see that in reality there are closer to two million people unemployed. In addition, over a million people are unable to find adequate employment, and hundreds of thousands of people have simply lost faith in this government.

PARA.TAB: Working Nation might be spotted with some reasonably good initiatives, but they are not strategies to create real jobs. The big aim of Working Nation is to have unemployment of half a million by the year 2000. It is unbelievable that a political party considers a goal of half a million people out of work an achievement. This government has no idea about how to create jobs. It does not understand the needs of business or the importance of small business in the process of job creation. Working Nation is yet another Labor employment policy doomed to failure.

It is time that this government at last confronted the problem. The problem is that we have between one million and two million people out of work. We have some families in which two or three generations of people have not had a job. Government ministers come in here and claim that they are introducing policies which are going to help people. The reality is that those policies will simply send them to the training queues or temporarily take them off the dole lists and then send them back. It is criminal—it is a tragedy—that after 11 years of government the Labor Party treats Australia's unemployed people with such monumental and gross contempt.
Debate (on motion by Mr Lavarch) adjourned.
Bill returned from the Senate with amendments.
Ordered that the amendments be taken into consideration forthwith.

No. 1—Clause 2, page 2, subclause (4), line 7, omit "Schedules 2, 4, 7 and 8", substitute "Schedules 2, 7 and 8".
No. 2—Clause 2, page 2, after subclause (4), insert the following subclause:

PARA.TAB: "(4A) Schedule 4 commences on a day to be fixed by Proclamation, being a day after each House of the Parliament has, by resolution, approved of regulations referred to in subsection 195(1) of the ASC Act, as amended by Schedule 4 of this Act.".

PROCTEXT.PARA: No. 3—Schedule 4, page 35, item 19, omit the item, substitute the following item:
"19. Subsection 194(4):

TAB.TAB: Omit the subsection, substitute:

PARA.TAB: `(4) A person who appears at an inquiry is entitled to have another person present to assist the person and a person who so assists is entitled to address the Panel.'.".

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I would like to indicate to the House that the government proposes that amendments Nos 1 and 2 be disagreed to and an amendment be made in place thereof, and that No. 3 be agreed to. I suggest, therefore, that it may suit the convenience of the House to first consider amendments Nos 1 and 2 and, when those amendments have been disposed of, consider amendment No. 3.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. J.D.M. Dobie)—Is there any objection?

TALK.START.PARA: —I had not seen these amendments until now. I had not been advised that the government was going to disagree with the amendments that were made in the other place. Furthermore, the shambles that has erupted around this seemingly small measure that the Senate had a firm view on and passed had to be seen to be believed. Some of us do have responsibilities in this place. We want to attend when we can. I have come in here four times today to deal with this matter, and it has been continually deferred. God knows what the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) has been doing. At no stage on the occasions I came in to deal with this matter, despite notification that it would be dealt with, was I informed by the government that it was going to disagree with what happened in the other place.

PARA.TAB: In circumstances where measures come down from another place there is an understanding, which the public might not comprehend, that the government and the opposition talk about these matters. We have to deal with them sensibly in the legislative framework and the intent that the government has in mind, as well as administratively. I come in at this late hour and find that the matters that have been agreed to in the other place are being disagreed to here in two instances. Perhaps the minister might explain and I might be given the call, but at this juncture we are batting zero.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night in the Senate the shadow Attorney-General, Senator Vanstone, moved an amendment, which was also advanced without any notice whatsoever to the government; in fact, it was quite contrary to an agreement which had been reached by my office and that of the shadow Attorney-General on how a particular amendment would proceed. Notwithstanding that agreement, and then without notice, a further amendment was put to the Senate and that amendment was agreed to.

PARA.TAB: Today there have been attempts to come to a position as to how we should now handle this further amendment agreed to by the Senate. I inform the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) that my office has been in contact with the office of the shadow Attorney-General, although I do not know what communication has then flowed from that office to the honourable member's office. We discussed a few matters and then finally came to this particular amendment, which the government will move.

In fairness to the House, this matter has been put on and put off on a number of occasions to try to reach an agreement. At this point, I am not aware of what Senator Vanstone's view is on this matter, although it was devised in a way as to resolve the conflict between us. I hope that it will do that. While I apologise to the honourable member for his lack of understanding about this matter and lack of notice, I assure him that the office of the shadow Attorney-General has been told of this matter and has been given a copy of the amendment. I regret any inconvenience caused to members of this House, but they are the background circumstances.

TALK.START.PARA: —I accept what the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) says, and I thank him for his apology in regard to the inconvenience. It was good of him to put that forward. I regret that the government is not going to accept the amendments that were moved in the Senate. As I understand it, the purpose of amendments Nos 1 and 2 was to ensure that the regulations equated with the rules of natural justice, as section 195(1) indicates is the government's intention. If it lives up to its intention it has nothing to worry about but, if the regulations fail—in the opinion of either house of parliament but, I suppose practically speaking, the Senate—to properly equate with the rules of natural justice, then the regulations not receiving a positive endorsement would stop schedule 4 coming into operation.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. J.D.M. Dobie)—Perhaps the honourable member would prefer to make this speech when the motion has been moved.

TALK.START.PARA: —No. Having indicated my regret about the course the government foreshadowed—I suppose in essence I have foreshadowed my response—I now indicate that I will be one of the voices at least voting against the government's motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lavarch The Hon M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That Senate amendments Nos 1 and 2 be disagreed to and that the following amendment be made in place thereof:

SPEECH.PARA: Schedule 4, page 35, item 20, omit proposed new subsection 195(3).

I will very briefly talk about the circumstances explained by the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock). The particular regulations did relate to the proceedings of the companies and securities panel, which is the takeover panel and a form of peer review on corporations' manners. Without going into detail, a dispute arose in the amendment bill about the application or otherwise of the rules of natural justice. The proposal in the bill originally was amended by agreement after discussion with the shadow Attorney-General, and there I thought—to my ignorance—the matter rested.

PARA.TAB: As it turned out the Senate, on instigation of the shadow Attorney-General, then went this further step and said that it wanted these particular regulations to come forward and be agreed upon before these changes to the law would come into being. Rather than go through another round of reconsidering regulations and so forth, we are all directed as to whether the rules this panel followed complied with the rules of natural justice and whether they would be challengeable in a court.

The proposal I am now putting to the House is that we simply delete from the section the point of disagreement—the original provision dealing with how far the rules of natural justice apply to the proceedings of this panel. All we are proposing is that that provision limiting the rules of natural justice simply be deleted so there would be no restriction whatsoever on the procedures the panel might decide upon of its own volition.

More importantly for the concerns opposition members have been expressing in this debate would be the ability to challenge those decisions in the court. The need now for the regulations, and hence this subsequent amendment, is removed by what the government is proposing. I accept that the honourable member for Kooyong is probably in a somewhat difficult position. He has not been involved in this matter or in the negotiations of it and, as a result, is at a disadvantage. I accept what he says about voting for it. Hopefully it will now finally be resolved in the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lavarch The Hon M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That Senate amendment No. 3 be agreed to.

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment, which was put forward by Senator Vanstone, relates to certain procedures before the corporations and securities panel. The government is not overly enamoured with this amendment. However, given that we are in a great spirit of compromise, and being a cooperative chap, the government will accede to this particular amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, amendment No. 3 will insert into the bill proposed new section 194(4), which will entitle a person to have another person speak on his or her behalf before the corporations and securities panel. That seems reasonable to us. This amendment derives from the shadow Attorney-General who moved it in the Senate. I am pleased that the government will accept it.
