Motion (by Mr Lavarch) proposed:
That the House do now adjourn.

TALK.START.PARA: —Over the past several years in Australia, ever-increasing pressure seems to have been placed on the family unit, particularly the traditional family unit—the representative one that most people still belong to, or aspire to belong to, despite some people wanting us to believe otherwise. The pressures on these families, and on non-traditional families, have increased because of the recession that created one million unemployed—hopefully, we are coming out of it now—and because of the policies of the present federal government which have resulted in the rich getting richer and the poor getting poorer, with a gradual disappearance of the so-called middle Australia.

PARA.TAB: New sexual freedom, the creation of a new value system and many other influences are adding to pressure that is causing the break-up of families. I have heard many people speak of the amount of money spent by the federal government on helping to sort out the `spoils' when families fall apart through institutions like the Family Law Court. In the year 1992-93, $74 million was spent in this area. Keep in mind that this is only the amount spent by the government. If we add the amount spent on the legal profession by former marriage partners, the total cost would be difficult to calculate.

The Child Support Agency, operating within the Australian Taxation Office and with an expenditure of $56 million in 1992-93, collected $200 million from liable parents. We can see therefore that just in the areas of the family law court and the Child Support Agency, the federal government spent over $130 million in 1992-93.

It appears to me that we are doing things back to front if we want stable families in Australia. We are closing the stable doors after the horse has bolted. Recently I inquired into the level of funding provided by the federal government to assist families with counselling before reaching the point of no return. We, who are married, or who have been married, realise that both partners have to work at the relationship and must continue to communicate. Sometimes when this communication breaks down, a mediator or counsellor can be of great assistance. That is where family and marriage counselling can assist.

I was made aware of the real need for this service when I came into contact with the Riverina marriage and family counselling service. That service, like many of these services throughout Australia, is underfunded for the work that confronts it. Despite the best intentions of the Wagga Wagga branch, the average waiting time is 2 1/2 weeks. When busy, this can increase to five weeks. When a family faces crisis, these waits may be too long to save the situation.

There are other counselling services in the Riverina, such as the Catholic Centacare service. This operates out of Wagga Wagga and Griffith, with a visiting service provided to Leeton. These services operate largely on government money, with some money being provided by Centacare and the Catholic Church. Not so long ago the waiting time in Griffith was three months. Thankfully, it is now down to three or four weeks, although that is still too long. The good news is that a service will soon be available in West Wyalong.

Apart from federal funding, each client is also charged on a sliding scale according to income. In 1992-93, the family counselling service was provided with an amount of $19 million by the Attorney-General's Department. While this is a substantial amount, it pales into insignificance when compared with the $130 million spent by the government after the family unit has already broken apart.

I am pleased to see that an increasing amount is being spent on marriage education, but this is reflected in the lowering of the amount spent on family counselling. It is obvious from investigation in my own area of the Riverina that not enough emphasis is placed on family and marriage counselling. I strongly support the work of those people in this area, even though they are grossly underfunded and, in some cases, work beyond their allocated time without pay.

There is a great deal more I would like to say on the subject of marriage counselling, family skills training, marriage education and family mediation, but time does not permit me to do so. I hope to bring the matter to the attention of the House in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to express concern tonight about a proposal by the people who currently control the National Roads and Motorists Association in New South Wales to float the NRMA, have it listed and to issue shares to NRMA members. The NRMA was established in 1920 as a mutual organisation for motorists. In 1925 it extended its functions to include insurance. As a mutual organisation, the NRMA currently belongs to the members. So when directors claim that the NRMA will share $2 billion with its 1.8 million members, I emphasise that the 1.8 million members already own the NRMA. They need to be very careful about the implications of this matter.

PARA.TAB: At the present time, as a mutual organisation, any benefits which accrue to the NRMA must be distributed to members in one way or another. The way in which they have been distributed is by making sure that the road service is subsidised—it operates at less than cost—and that any profits made by the insurance arm of the NRMA are returned to NRMA insurance policyholders by way of untaxed rebates.

Members of the NRMA who may be encouraged or tempted to accept the $500 worth of shares should keep in mind that a number of possible dangers are involved. The dividends that would accrue to them in the future as a result of their share ownership would be taxed, unlike the rebates and the other benefits which they get from their current ownership of the NRMA as a mutual organisation.

There is also a very strong possibility that that $500 worth of shares will be subject to capital gains tax. It is certain that, whatever arrangements are made for the $500 worth of shares, any appreciation in the value of those shares will be taxed in the form of a capital gains tax when, and if, those shares are sold.

I think a lot of people may be tempted to vote for that change in the expectation that they will then be able to sell their $500 worth of shares and finish up with $500 in their pockets. That may well not happen. If a capital gain applies to those shares, they will receive less than $500. In addition, if those shares are disposed of, there is no question that a concentration of ownership of the shares in the NRMA will become a reality.

The NRMA may fall into the hands of major institutional investors, such as insurance funds and other types of commercial and overseas investors. If, then, under those circumstances, the operation of the NRMA becomes profit driven rather than service driven—as it presently is as a mutual organisation—the roadside service will be required not only to pay for itself but also to pay in excess of the cost. This means that the subsidised service will disappear. It also means that the insurance arm of the NRMA will be required to pay as large a dividend as possible to the shareholders, in which case the rebates which have been made available to NRMA insurance policyholders up to the present time will disappear. Those policyholders will have to pay substantially more.

The NRMA itself has put out material which acknowledges that over the past two years policyholders have shared $180 million in rebates. Those rebates will disappear, and that $180 million will go into the pockets of the shareholders.

It is important that, if the NRMA is spending at least $2 million to promote its preference for the floating of the NRMA, an equal amount of funds should be applied to promote the `no' side of the case so that members of the NRMA are given fair, balanced, objective and adequate information to make it possible for them to make their decision later this year. I appeal to the people not to be hoodwinked and not to be fooled. They should vote very strongly against the proposal, which is simply designed to entrench the present controllers of the NRMA through the arrangements under that corporate structure. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to place on record my support for the International Year of the Family and to discuss some of the issues which face families today. It is immensely important that we have a year specifically set aside for the family because society is changing rapidly and we really do need to take a breather and consider what the family means. We have to consider what the family is. There has been heated debate about what constitutes a family and what support government should provide.

PARA.TAB: But what it all boils down to is choice. We want more choices in child care, job structures, the way we live and so on. Men and women want more choices today than they traditionally have had. More women want to participate in the work force and men are also beginning to re-examine their traditional role. We now have paternity leave as well as maternity leave. The greater availability of contraception is also providing people with more choices. We also have growing choices in child care—although many would say not enough choices.

These choices have an impact on today's families as people try to decide what is best for their family. The government needs to respond to our rapidly changing society and the new choices which society is demanding us to make. We need to support the family as an unit of love, care and support. After all, the family is a highly tuned and effective operation—the smallest democracy, as they say. The family is responsible not only for the upbringing and care of children and the care of aged family members but also for the support between partners. It is the place where we learn our values, develop our characters and what is important in life—respect for each other.

Government also needs to recognise the different environments that families live in and apply policies which seek to treat all families fairly. I believe that families in regional Australia have less choices than families living elsewhere. If we live in a city we have a wider choice of schools and child-care facilities and we would probably also have more job choices. Our regional families, especially farming families, are suffering because of the choice they made to live in regional Australia.

Many of our farming families are living well below the poverty line. There have been a number of reports into rural poverty. One of them was carried out by the Country Women's Association. The CWA has also been distributing food baskets to rural families. I have heard of a case where three food baskets were gratefully divided between 10 families.

The rural decline is having extremely distressing effects on these families. Imagine the kind of stress it is creating and imagine how farmers feel when they cannot put food on the table for their children. Imagine how farmers feel when they have to ask their young children to work on the farm with them, often working long hours on top of their school work. Imagine how they feel when family members have to leave the farm to find work elsewhere and the feeling of dislocation this brings to the family unit.

Similar circumstances are experienced by city families living below the poverty line. However, the effect on regional families is compounded by the fact that government support is less easy to access. The farming family cannot hop on to the local bus and visit a government department or a counselling agency. We have rural counsellors who are doing a marvellous job but they are running themselves into the ground to help farming families in need.

I therefore place on the record my strong hope that the special needs of families in regional Australia are a focus in this International Year of the Family. The government must look at some equitable policies which recognise the specific difficulties of such families. In this, the International Year of the Family, we should be striving to ensure that no family working so hard and for so many days a year should be waiting for donations of food baskets.

I would like to end by highlighting some of the encouraging information gathered by my colleague the honourable member for Menzies (Mr Andrews), who carries out an immense amount of work on the issue of the family. He points out that 82 per cent of children are growing up in two-parent families, 65 of all marriages will last a lifetime, 72 per cent of households are couple households and over 80 per cent of young people say they do want to marry one day and expect their marriage to last a lifetime.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I want to pay tribute to the Surf Life Saving Association of Australia and in particular its Far North Queensland branch. In an era when volunteering seems to be dying, thousands of young men and women give their time on weekends and holidays to patrol and save lives on Australia's beaches. In 1992-93 there were 256 surf life saving clubs throughout Australia with 71,654 members, including some, I am sure, in your electorate, Mr Speaker.

PARA.TAB: Their record is impressive. Since 1930 they have clocked up a cumulative total of 58,468 recorded lives saved in my home state of Queensland alone. In the nippers, young people are taught life saving and water skills from an early age and enjoy themselves at the same time. Dedicated parents and surf life saving club members are always there behind the scenes giving up their time.

Honourable members may be surprised to know that the Cairns Surf Life Saving Club, which is located at Palm Cove, is celebrating its 70th anniversary this year, making it one of the oldest clubs in Australia. In Cairns we do not have to contend so much with the surf, but—

TALK.START.PARA: —The stingers.
—We have to contend with the marine stingers. The honourable member does not have to remind me of that.
—We don't have those in Cowper.

—They certainly do not. The stingers are the problem and that is where lives have to be saved in Far North Queensland. I recently had the pleasure of attending the Cairns Surf Life Saving Club's annual presentation night. I thank the new president, Brian Coates, and the secretary, Wayne Allen, and his enthusiastic new committee for the hospitality extended to me. I also recently attended the presentation night of the Port Douglas surf club, which is one of the youngest surf clubs in Australia. I thank the president, John Goodman, for an excellent evening.

PARA.TAB: Other clubs in the Far North Queensland branch are Ellis Beach, which is in my electorate, and Etty Bay and Mission Beach in the electorate of the honourable member for Kennedy (Mr Katter). I again pay tribute to all these clubs and their dedicated members and to John Bromley, the president of the Far North Queensland branch.

This parliament and the people of Australia should thank the surf life saving movement because without it, local government and the tourist industry would have to pay millions of dollars for beach patrols, as occurs overseas. Community education is another important function of the surf life saving movement. This is a unique Australian institution which we should do everything we can to preserve.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nehl Mr G.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I want to speak on behalf of one of my constituents, a Mr Georges Deane. He is not only an Australian citizen but also a French Polynesian from Tahiti, a French citizen and an ex-member of the French army. He served with some distinction in Vietnam. Mr Deane had the opportunity of visiting his family last year but became ill while he was in Papeete. I am concerned about the treatment he received there.

PARA.TAB: In a letter to the public prosecutor at the Papeete court house in Tahiti he says that on Thursday 26, November 1993 it was very hot at his daughter's house, where he had been staying since he arrived from Australia. He went to bed at about 11.20 p.m., and at 12 p.m., he says:

SPEECH.PARA: I felt the thumping of a fist in my chest and I was out of breath, being able to breath only with difficulty.

He got his son-in-law to call an ambulance to take him to hospital. I know that ambulance services in Australia would respond more quickly than they do there. An ambulance arrived at 2.15 a.m. and gave him oxygen and injections and took him to Papeete in their vehicle.

PARA.TAB: During the trip the attending doctor asked which hospital he wanted to go to. He said, `To the veterans' hospital at Mamao Territorial Hospital'. But that was full, so the doctor then decided to take him to Paofai Clinic and asked whether that suited him. He was suffering from a thumping pain in his chest, so he said, `Yes, I'll go anywhere.'

When he arrived at the clinic he was carried in on a stretcher and placed in a room where he was given oxygen. During the night he got no other treatment whatsoever. He was visited at 8.00 a.m. on 27 November by a clinic employee who demanded 100,000 French Pacific francs by way of a deposit. He had just arrived at the hospital by ambulance. He replied that he did not have that amount of money with him but he was covered by private health insurance in Australia.

That employee stated that the clinic's management would not accept any insurance from outside the territory. Mr Deane said that he was an ex-French army veteran and was affiliated to the veteran fund, but the employee replied that, even with his veteran card, he still had to pay 100,000 French Polynesian francs on the spot or he would not be treated. So the employee called his daughter and told her to come and collect him. She arrived a few minutes later.

It is a long story, and I will not go into all of it. The important point is that Georges was not just concerned about his treatment. At least he had family there. He was a French Polynesian. He was a native of Tahiti. He spoke fluently not only in Polynesian but also in French. He was also concerned about the position of other Australian citizens who might fall ill in French Polynesia and be placed in the situation where, unless they can immediately produce 100,000 francs as a deposit, they may be tossed out.

I have had correspondence with Monsieur Gaston Flosse, who is the President of French Polynesia, and the prosecutor. I have also had correspondence with Senator Gareth Evans on the question of assistance to Mr Deane but, unfortunately, nothing can be done. My major concern was that, at that time, we did not have an honorary consul in French Polynesia. I am pleased that, following my letter to the foreign minister, he advised me that there had been an Australian consul in French Polynesia since April 1990 and that the Qantas manager was appointed honorary consul at that time. I had suggested that that would be a good way to go.

Unfortunately, there was a delay with a change of Qantas manager. Even though the foreign minister agreed in April this year to the appointment of a new one, the French have still not approved that appointment. I make the point that, if Australian citizens are going to travel to an area such as French Polynesia, they should not get ill. They will be up for big dollars and many francs. I hope the French do agree to the appointment of the honorary consul as quickly as possible because it is a vital part of the safety of Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chynoweth Mr R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —An article in the Australian caught my eye recently. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The new-look Liberal Party under Alexander Downer is delving back to the future, modelling itself increasingly on the golden era of Liberalism—the Menzies years.

I was curious to see what new policies the people of Australia could expect from the new leader of the Liberal Party. So I delved back to the records of the past—the records of the Menzies years. I refer to some of the policies which the people of Australia can expect the new leader of the Liberal Party to recycle. In his `forgotten people' broadcast in May 1942, Menzies said:
The great vice of democracy . . . is that for a generation we have been busy getting ourselves on the list of beneficiaries and removing ourselves from the list of contributors . . .

The people of Australia should be warned: Menzies wanted to slash welfare assistance and increase taxes. This means that the new leader of the Liberal Party also wants to. Menzies put out a booklet called We believe, which set out the principles of the Liberal Party. It reads:

We believe in the crown as the enduring embodiment of our national unity and as the symbol of that other unity which exists between all the nations of the British Commonwealth. We believe in Australia . . .

Australia only came second behind the British Empire. The people of Australia should be warned again: Menzies wanted to create Australia in the image of Great Britain, and the present leader of the Liberal Party also wants to. He does not just want to keep Australia as a monarchy. He wants to bring back knighthoods, such as the one that his father had.

PARA.TAB: Please do not think that this is just my imagination running away with me. There is plenty of evidence which indicates that it is not a Downer-Costello ticket, but that it is a Menzies-Downer ticket. The current leader of the Liberal Party went to Geelong Grammar and Menzies went to Wesley College. Both of these schools are part of what the old boys' network calls the `sacred six' of the establishment schools.

The first ever leader of the Liberal Party, Menzies, went to Wesley. The next leader, Harold Holt, went to Wesley. The next leader, Sir John Gorton, went to Geelong Grammar. The next leader was that well-known establishment outsider, Sir William McMahon. Not only did he not go to the right school, but he actually came from the wrong state. This is probably why Sir John McEwen at first refused to have him as the leader of the Liberal Party. Following McMahon, the next Liberal Party leader was that well-known son of the establishment, Malcolm Fraser, who went to Melbourne Grammar, another one of the sacred six.

But it is not just the schooling; it is also the clubs. The only former Liberal Prime Ministers still alive, Gorton and Fraser, are members of the Melbourne Club. So is Tony Staley, who played hangman for the former leader of the Liberal Party, the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson). Sir Percy Joske authored a biography of Menzies. In his book, he writes:

SPEECH.PARA: Menzies has been criticised for failure to provide for talented leadership when he retired from the Parliament . . . however, if Menzies had not appointed A. R. Downer as High Commissioner for Australia in the United Kingdom, the party would, on Holt's tragic death, have had a Leader in the House of Representatives who could have inspired it to future success and prevented the political troubles which proceeded to harass it.
Was Sir Percy a futurist? Sir Percy was saying that the Menzies mantle would have gone from Menzies to Holt to Downer—that is Downer Sr, and not Downer Jr.

PARA.TAB: We now have a situation where Downer Jr strives to fill the shoes of Menzies. Should Junior fill these shoes, Australians can expect a part-time Prime Minister, just like Menzies, who was overseas for months at a time, attending tea parties at Buck House, watching cricket or dining with the House of Lords. The people of Australia should hope that Downer Jr never becomes Prime Minister. I can assure them that one Ming dynasty was more than enough.

TALK.START.PARA: —Harvesting of Australia's biggest ever cane crop, with well over 30 million tonnes of cane in the field, began in many centres along the Queensland coast over the last few days. Sugar production in Australia is set to exceed last season's record 4.3 million tonnes, which is worth more than one $1.4 billion. Some 80 per cent of that will come from export earnings. The Queensland industry, which produces 90 per cent of the nation's crop, has 6,300 growers and directly employs 20,000 people.

PARA.TAB: Colourful were the days when the canecutters came to town, creating a robust, if not sometimes fluctuating, economy. The boom and bust cycle of Summer of the Seventeenth Doll was very much a part of daily life. But in the mid-1960s there was a sea change. Critical to this change in the growth of the sugar industry was the cane harvester. The swinging cane knife was fast becoming history, and my electorate was the cradle of this new harvesting technology.

Leading the revolution has been one Bundaberg company whose founders pioneered the design and manufacture of cane harvesting equipment. Established in Bundaberg in 1947, the Toft family company, of which Colin and Harold Toft were the foremost members, led to the formation over time of Austoft Holdings, which today is Australia's largest agricultural machinery manufacturer. This company is recognised as a world leader in this specialist area of engineering and hydraulic technology.

Recently, Austoft Holdings celebrated a significant milestone with the company's 100th Allrounder cane harvester, 7,000 series, rolling off the production line in Bundaberg. The 7,000 series was produced in 1984 and sales for the company have topped more than $200 million, with approximately 64 per cent of the cane harvesters produced being exported to 30 countries.

This chopper-style harvester is the Rolls Royce of cane harvesters, with its large capacity and ability to harvest both burnt and green cane in almost all weather conditions. It is a leading item of technology. Last year in Texas in the United States the company claimed a new world record for chopped cane from a single machine in one season when the Austoft Allrounder harvested 125,785 tonnes of cane. Such has been the success and popularity of this series 7,000 machine that Austoft has been able to capture 70 per cent of the world market in cane harvesters.

There is enormous potential for future growth in the global harvester market, particularly in the Asian region where much of the crop is still harvested by hand. As these economies grow, so too will the demand for capital and Australia, through companies like Austoft, will be in the box seat to take advantage of such opportunities. We have all heard the catchcry that Australia must become a more clever country. Here in regional Australia is an innovative agricultural machinery company which has been doing just that.

Austoft is not just about cane harvesters. While the core of its business remains the design, manufacture and marketing of mechanical harvesters, the company has diversified into a number of areas. Austoft also manufactures self-propelled and tractor trailed infield transporters, plus hydraulic trench digging equipment, notably the Trencheroo and the Diggeroo, which are used extensively by Telecom, electricity authorities and the building industry.

In conclusion, this latest success for Austoft Holdings, with the production of its 1000th Allrounder 7000 series cane harvester in Bundaberg is in large part a tribute to the skills and commitment of the company's 370 employees and to its hard working management team of John McGrath, Les Lester, Mal Baker, Greg Weir, Mike Hochen and Noel Searl, to whom I extend my heartiest congratulations and wishes for the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mrs Silvia

TALK.START.PARA: —I stand in this House during the adjournment debate to once again bring to the attention of this House the incidence of suicide in our nation. On 18 June this year, I was invited to speak at a suicide seminar in the north-east of Tasmania at a place called Scottsdale. Scottsdale and the surrounding area has a very small population of some 3,000. Imagine my amazement when I walked into the room, sat down at the head of the room and then counted the number of people there. There were 107 people representing some thoughts on suicide at that seminar, which seemed to me a very large number. They were a very interested group of people. The seminar was organised by the North East Health Forum, the North East Community House and the North East Task Force. It was funded by the Scottsdale Lions Club, the North East Lions Club, Apex, Rotary and the Leo Club, plus the community house and the task force.

PARA.TAB: People in the north-east of Tasmania were particularly keen to talk about this subject—a subject that a lot of people do not wish to talk about. Those who spoke at the seminar included Pat Igoe, who is the mainstay in the Launceston Lifelink; Mollie Campbell-Smith, a coordinator of community forums; Barry Johnson, who has been a youth worker for 23 years, including 10 years as an adolescent counsellor; and also many local interested people whom I will not name.

Some very interesting information came from the local policeman. He indicated to me some figures that I find rather astounding for such a small community. He said that in this year alone in the north-east of Tasmania there were five definite suicides and two possibles—the actual cause of death was not identified. In the 5 1/2 months of this year alone, there had been 17 identified cases of suicide in the 003 area of Tasmania. When I stood up to talk to those people at the seminar, I identified my own foster brother as being one of those statistics.

The people at the seminar were absolutely stunned by the incidence of suicide. It is an incidence that I have been trying to draw to the attention of people in this place. I hope that they will become aware of it. This morning at the hearing of the Standing Committee on Community Affairs, I offered some possible terms of reference for this particular issue. I quote part of an article written by Clea Hincks which appeared in The Examiner on the Monday following the seminar. These statements are quite accurate:
Tasmanian males aged between 10 and 19 are almost twice as likely to commit suicide than their interstate counterparts.

SPEECH.PARA: That is astounding. The article continues:

PARA.TAB: Researchers based at the University of Tasmania are baffled at the findings that are set out in the latest Medical Journal of Australia, which is published by the Australian Medical Association.
The suicide rate among Tasmanian boys aged 10 to 14 was 1.7 deaths per 100,000, compared with 0.9 deaths per 100,000 on the mainland.

SPEECH.PARA: An eminent Tasmanian at the university, Dr Andrew Tulloch, was quoted in the article as saying:
. . . it was not understood why the rate was higher in Tasmania than on the mainland.
He was further quoted as saying:

PARA.TAB: "There are said a lot of things that need further study."

SPEECH.PARA: The article went on to state:
In the same age bracket, mainland and Tasmanian females were less likely to commit suicide than boys, but the study found no significant difference between Tasmanian and mainland girls.
Dr Tulloch recommended that support teams be formed to provide immediate assessment and backup for self-harming adolescents and their parents.

Those things are included in the terms of reference that I offered today. We need to look at what role we can play as a federal government, and what support we can give, not only to those potential suiciders, but also to the families and the survivors of suicide, of which I stand here in this House as one.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miles Mr C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to talk about the family and the International Year of the Family. On 30 May this year, we had a private members debate in the parliament. The honourable member for Deakin (Mr Aldred) called upon the political parties in this House to develop policies that:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)aim to weld the family together and sustain it through adverse circumstances;
(b)in the taxation area positively discriminate in favour of the family; and
(c)in the operation of the Family Law Act emphasise reconciliation where possible.
Listening to that debate, I was interested in a comment made by the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Latham), who said:
There is no role in our society for a government to impose on people its good image of what a good family life is.

I believe that comment is saying that the government is happy to abdicate in regard to encouraging people to live in certain ways. Empirical evidence is coming from the Western world—Great Britain, the United States and Western Europe—which indicates that certain family groupings are much more effective for a healthy society than others. It is not a matter of opinion. It is not a matter of persuasion of any political party. It is evidence that is coming through to us that says that children have a much better opportunity in life if they live in certain families. We as members of parliament have to affirm that.

PARA.TAB: During this, the International Year of the Family, a lot of statistics have been mentioned. I want to refer to one or two which very rarely get mentioned. We talk a lot about divorce and say that family life is breaking up. The statistics also show that 87 per cent of all first marriages in Australia are still intact. Yet we get the impression from the media and sometimes from government spokesmen that very few families are left intact. It is very important for us to understand that, even though there are difficulties in regard to family breakdown, the overwhelming majority of Australians live in intact families. The benefits which come from living in intact families are numerous.

Research from a study in the United States shows beyond doubt that kids need both parents. The study found that children nurtured in two-parent families receive benefits, such as being six times more likely to live in financially adequate circumstances. The overwhelming majority of children in our country who live in poverty do so because of family breakdown and single parenting. This is not to say that the task of single parents is easy; it is not. We as a society must underpin the needs of those people. But at the same time, we must encourage Australians—particularly parents—to stick together, because it is that framework in which children are nurtured and our society will benefit.

We also find that children in two-parent families are two to three times less likely to have emotional and behavioural problems. They are less likely to drop out of high school, less likely to get pregnant as teenagers, less likely to abuse drugs and less likely to be in trouble with the law.

So there is a need during this International Year of the Family for us to encourage all Australians to try to live together in families in which two parents are available for the nurturing of children. Far be it from us to say that there is a great diversity of family groupings that are all the same and children will grow up no matter what those groups are because that is just not the case. The empirical evidence coming through from the social scientists right around the world is that children do better in two-parent families. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PARA.TAB: The DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins) took the chair at 10.00 a.m.

DEBATE.TITLE: INDUSTRY, SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 9 June, on motion by Mr Lindsay:

PROCTEXT.PARA: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prosser Mr G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —This bill was originally to include provision for a further downscaling of the government's holding in the Australian Industry Development Corporation Ltd. In a press release dated 24 March this year, the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development, Senator Cook, noted that the legislation had been introduced to allow for the government's sell-down in AIDC Ltd from 81 per cent to 51 per cent. But on 26 April, Senator Cook, in conjunction with the Minister for Finance (Mr Beazley) announced that the government would sell the whole thing instead.

PARA.TAB: So it appears that, at some point between March 24 and April 26, the government has got into the coalition policy book to find out what a sensible policy the sale of the AIDC might be.Either that or, when they were calculating the budget numbers, they came up a bit short and thought they had better sell something off to make up the difference. What is left of the Industry, Technology and Regional Development Legislation Amendment Bill is an assortment of bits and pieces.

The amendments to the National Measurement Act 1960 stem largely from an external program evaluation of the National Standards Commission that was undertaken by Dr Kevin Foley in 1992. The review found that the commission was orientated more towards short-term objectives and was unable to provide a comprehensive strategic response to requirements of the national measurements system.

Dr Foley made nine recommendations, and the amendments proposed in this bill are largely a response to the recommendations and general thrust of the program evaluation. This bill also includes provisions to amend the Pooled Development Funds Act. Pooled development funds, as the members of this chamber would be aware, were an initiative that came from the One Nation economic statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). The One Nation document said:

SPEECH.PARA: The government has been concerned for some time about the difficulties small and medium sized enterprises can experience in obtaining equity capital. This concern was reinforced during the Ministerial discussions with industry . . .
The availability of equity can be a critical element for the success of small and medium sized firms. Small firms, however, often have difficulty in obtaining this form of finance because:

PARA.TAB: they do not have access to the same range of sources of capital as larger firms, particularly as there is no reliable and easily accessible market for trading equity in small businesses, such as the Stock Exchange

SPEECH.PARA: and

PARA.TAB: adverse economic conditions have encouraged investors to concentrate on established larger and safer enterprises.

SPEECH.PARA: The government's response to this problem was to introduce the pooled development funds program. The program was designed to help small and medium sized Australian firms to obtain patent equity capital. The Department of Industry, Technology and Regional Development's 1992-93 annual report explained the nature of the pooled development fund program in the following manner:

PDFs provide patent equity capital for eligibility activities in companies with total assets not greater than $30 million, in return for concessional tax treatment. Investors in PDFs can elect to receive either tax exempt dividends or dividends with attached imputation credits.
The PDFs never worked. The industry department's annual report went on to say:
To date seven firms have been registered as PDFs. Of these, none has raised any capital although two are currently looking to the market for support.

The tax rate on pooled development funds was originally set at 30 per cent, but at this rate the pooled development funds attracted next to no interest so the government lowered the rate to 25 per cent. This bill before the House currently proposes that the concessional rate be now reduced to 15 per cent, half the original rate.Pooled development funds have been an abject failure but they are only one of many examples of bad policy that we have seen in recent years from the government.

PARA.TAB: One Nation, the statement that announced the introduction of pooled development funds, is held up as a model of ill-conceived economic policy. Investing in the nation was, if anything, worse, and the most recent attempt, Working Nation, is the most foolish of the lot, in my view. The changes to the pooled development fund scheme that we are discussing here today were of course announced in the industry statement part of the Working Nation document.

In many ways the failure of the pooled development fund scheme is symptomatic of the failure of industry policy over recent years. Pooled development funds were a rushed and poorly researched policy initiative, and that is why they did not work. Industry policy in general suffers the same disease. It is rushed and ill conceived and, at the end of the day, it does not produce the results we should achieve. That is why the Australian newspaper described the industry statement as `industrial strength waffle'.

I could list a dozen examples of ill-conceived policy announcement from the industry statement, but today I will spare this government the embarrassment. The actual initiatives announced in the white paper were, for the most part, a hodgepodge of program adjustments and changes that had been building up in the industry department since Alan Griffiths, the former minister, announced the statement.

Honourable members present today might be interested to hear a story I was told the other day by an insider. Apparently, Mr Griffiths' announcement of the industry statement was a mistake. We all know that it was a mistake, but apparently he did not mean to announce the actual statement—it just slipped out one day. So it is no wonder the statement was so full of rhetoric and twaddle.

On the rhetoric side of the matter, all we heard in the industry statement is that industry policy, in a post-protectionist environment, is all about building a competitive business environment and building competitive firms. This is hardly the visionary policy breakthrough that Senator Cook would have us believe it is, and a definition of industry policy is hardly what business was looking for from the statement. Business wanted to know what the government was going to do to create a competitive business environment and what it was going to do to create competitive firms. The answers to these questions are, respectively: nothing to do and not enough. But that is the way the government works—everything is done on the cheap.

The policy announcements in the industry statement do not match the rhetoric. On balance, the statement is going to accomplish nothing towards building a more competitive industry and more competitive industry base in this country. It is unfortunate that the government did not take the opportunity when the statement was announced to say, `Sorry, we've got industry policy wrong and it is about time we started again.' As Steve Burrell, from the Australian Financial Review, said in a column earlier this year, someone setting out to create a new public service would not create a monster called an industry department and charge it with responsibility for developing industry policy. It is a shame that the industry department was unable to spot the vital issues that it should now have ownership of—issues like micro-economic reform, competition policy and regulation reform. These issues desperately need a home in the bureaucracy and business needs an area in government to drive these issues along and keep them on the agenda.

In conclusion, it is a real shame that we are here today debating the changes to the pooled development funds, when we could be debating legislation that actually achieved something positive towards industrial development in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —As this is my first speech in the Main Committee, I would like first to congratulate the officers and the staff of the parliament for their efficient and admirable work in bringing this innovation to fruition. I believe that this committee has great potential to help parliament to expedite its workload. Despite what some people outside parliament might think, we know that there is a great deal of bipartisan, uncontentious legislation brought forward. It is most appropriate that these matters are dealt with smoothly and without partisanship. I am very happy to cooperate with this approach. My congratulations and thanks to all involved.

PARA.TAB: The Industry, Science and Technology Legislation Amendment Bill has two parts: to allow a reduction in the Australian Industry Development Corporation shareholding in its principal subsidiary, Australian Industry Development Corporation Ltd, and to increase the number of members of the National Standards Commission.

The AIDC is a statutory corporation established in 1970. Its function is to foster greater Australian equity involvement in the manufacturing, processing or transportation of goods and natural resources. It is also involved in internationally competitive service industries. Australia has had a generation of economic change. This change is continuing, and AIDC is a major factor in keeping these changes going.

The three areas of major activity for AIDC are the promotion of greater efficiency and competitiveness in Australian industry, the reconstruction of Australian industry to achieve long-term viability and competitiveness, and the promotion of new industries or companies that have good growth prospects. Efficiency and competitiveness are the centre and core of any economic policy which can hope to succeed, and productivity is based on these.

Productivity is the source of real and lasting high wages and high profits. Economic soundness is really all about pursuit of productivity. Our competitors and markets in Asia especially are very soundly based on productivity. Australia can do it. Our rural sector is extraordinarily productive per hectare. Many of our service industries have made great leaps in productivity in the last decade. Industry as a whole can do the same.

This amendment bill adds to the government's decision made in 1988. In that year, AIDC faced a capital shortage and went to the capital market by the agency of a subsidiary company, AIDC Ltd. In 1989 AIDC Ltd was partially privatised to raise capital for the parent corporation. However, the government retained 81 per cent of AIDC Ltd. This amendment bill today seeks to lower the government holding to 51 per cent. However, this is not a fire sale. The corporation will hold its shares until it receives a price that reflects the underlying value of the corporation assets.

The corporation is well run and quite profitable. In 1992-93 AIDC reported an operating profit after tax of $35.9 million. As at June 1993 the Commonwealth's interest in AIDC's consolidated capital and retained profits was $165.5 million. The sale of AIDC Ltd shares transferred to the Commonwealth under the amendments proposed by this bill are estimated to raise approximately $100 million.

The proposed new part IVB in clause 5 of the amendment bill will prevent the AIDC holding less than 51 per cent of the subsidiary company AIDC Ltd. The role of AIDC in helping Australian industry is largely unknown outside of specialist circles. However, its work is valuable and the corporation has a good reputation internationally. This is due to good management and the underlying value of investments in Australia and, of course, the underlying wealth of Australia as an economic unit. Commonwealth government guarantees extend to all the corporation's borrowings and other obligations of the AIDC group.

In 1993 the corporation launched a 10-year, $125 million Eurobond issue at 9.25 per cent. This was targeted at traditional European investment houses and it was well received and fully taken up. The AIDC is currently engaged in a review of its clients' requirements to see how it can best expand its range of services and products to meet their demands. Small and medium enterprises—the real engines of growth and prosperity—are the principal clients of AIDC.

In this year's budget and the white paper, the government showed its seriousness about initiatives to help small and medium enterprises by raising industry assistance spending by almost 13 per cent; a rise of $409 million to a total of $3.59 billion. These initiatives are aimed at helping the development of internationally competitive firms and overcoming market weaknesses.

In my dealing with the owners and the operators of small and medium businesses, particularly in my own electorate of Lowe, I have heard the constant refrain about access to investment capital. These complaints I accept as valid. Of course, not all businesses have difficulty in accessing finance. However, given the importance for small business of access to finance, the government is adopting a strategy of helping to improve the interaction between banks and small businesses.

The increased competition in financial services has delivered some considerable benefits. However, the increasing complexities of the banking sector and the rapid changes in banking practices have led to some customer discontent. The health and the growth of the economy do depend on the proper financing of our small and medium enterprises. I am glad to see that the Australian Bankers Association has already developed a code of banking practice which relates to personal customers.

The next stage is to examine the concerns of small business with a view to improving that relationship. The government will play a facilitating role in this process. AIDC Ltd is a key element in this government's and private investment's drive to improve our industrial performance. One of the major achievements over the past few years has been the building of a market driven, flexible, responsive, corporate culture to underpin the new strategy of AIDC Ltd. A further significant technological development has been the introduction of the new risk policy approval procedures, in order to ensure that AIDC Ltd can offer its clients the responsiveness to which they are entitled and, at the same time, limit AIDC Ltd's risk.

The placement of all problem loans and investments in a separate risk policy and procedure division has proved to be a crucial step in ensuring that AIDC Ltd exercises maximum control over its investment portfolios. A great deal has been achieved in containing risk, and this has meant that the rest of the company has been able to concentrate on developing and implementing its new business strategy. These amendments are useful to AIDC. They give it greater flexibility and a more market oriented approach, and both of these characteristics are desirable.

AIDC plans to take an even more pro-active approach to its responsibilities. This is excellent news for the small and medium business community, which provides more than half of all private sector employment, and I am happy to commend this amendment bill to the committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was a fascinating speech we have just heard. It was completely unrelated to the matter of standards, which is the main subject contained in the legislation before this chamber today: the Industry, Science and Technology Legislation Amendment Bill 1994. This legislation deals with changes to the way in which the Australian standards will operate and the way in which the main body which administers standards, the National Standards Commission, will operate in Australia. It relates to borrowing powers and to all areas of the performance of the commission.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Standards Commission has a twofold purpose. It has the purpose of setting standards for Australian businesses, and it has a process to enforce the observance of Australian standards by Australian manufacturers and producers.On one hand, the government has a responsibility to see that standards are set at a sufficiently high level in our produce and in our manufacture such that they will maintain the proper reputation and reliability of our product. On the other hand, the government has a responsibility to ensure that the conditions and standards which are set are not so onerous as to be a cost impost on the Australian consumer.

The proposals before the House do not go to the nub of compliance, nor to the nub of unnecessary regulation and the paper war which is imposed upon small business, mentioned by the previous speaker, the honourable member for Lowe (Mrs Easson) in her erudite—but irrelevant, in terms of this legislation—speech. So I acknowledge that she has inadvertently opened up the whole debate to let us explore the way in which small business has been dealt with by this government.

The One Nation statement purports to make life more productive and more profitable for small business but, as we have seen, practically none of that statement has been implemented. The government has basically walked away from it and has imposed cost upon cost on small business. If this legislation is abused, the National Standards Commission can make life unbearable for Australian manufacturers and producers by imposing on them precise and detailed requirements which are a cost burden and which are really a process of control and compliance unrelated to the market-worthiness of products.

I want to deal with the whole range of compliance with standards in Australia, because I believe it is time that we reassessed this situation. In too many instances, Australian manufacturers and producers are required to observe standards which are in fact unrelated to the needs of the community; yet those who produce overseas need not observe the same standards. The way the process works is this: unless a product is notified to the National Standards Commission or to a state consumer body as being below Australian required standards, those products continue their unimpeded entry into Australia.

Let me recount to the House the situation two years ago when some dried apricots were imported from Turkey. Nobody complained about the quality, but they were far below the quality required of Australian producers. Having got these apricots into Australia, the importer found that there was no market for them. Being a shrewd importer, he then tried to export them and found that he could not because the apricots did not meet Australian export standards.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was shameful.

—It is a shameful waste of bureaucracy and an imposition on Australian manufacturers to require them to observe a standard that we do not impose on importers. Where is that level playing field that the Labor party is so fond of talking about? I believe that, in legislation connected with industry, science and technology, we ought to have a mandatory requirement that all imported goods into Australia meet the same standards that Australian manufactured and produced goods need to meet.

PARA.TAB: We should undertake a process whereby low quality products are blocked at the front gate: they should not get through customs. The Australian Labor Party for all its carry on, for all its talk about support for small business, is not prepared to impose on importers the same standards that it is imposing on Australian manufacturers with this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Fightback?

—The honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland) can protest. But the fact of the matter is that, unless notified by state authorities or consumer groups, under consumer legislation, and then by a strange and long-handled process through Australian customs, there is no requirement for importers and imported goods to meet the standards laid down by the National Standards Commission.

PARA.TAB: I think it is time that we moved as a nation and had blanket legislation requiring all importers to gain a certificate which indicates that the standard of their import is equivalent to the requirement placed on Australian manufacturers or producers. Until we do this, it is a completely unfair process.

I believe that we should reduce tariffs, but let us reduce tariffs in such a way that like competes with like. We are not prepared to do that. The government has played with this matter for years. I have heard ministers and parliamentary secretaries speak on this matter from time to time. I refer the House to the joint industry policy of the Liberal and National parties that was issued as far back as 1989. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: International competitiveness depends not only on price, but also on quality, service, design and reliability of supply. In the final analysis competitiveness, and therefore standards and quality of Australian goods and services, must be determined by the market.
The next Liberal and National Party Government will actively promote a greater understanding of the importance of quality, especially for export purposes.
I think that most Australians would support that statement. This is where the National Standards Commission comes into the picture. The policy goes on to say:

To ensure that Australian manufacturers are not prevented from meeting the ever-changing needs of Australian consumers or overseas markets, we will remove unnecessary and inflexible, mandatory product standards.

That is where the government should be paying attention to the needs of small business. If the government was serious about trying to break down the cost impositions that its bureaucracy imposes on small business, it could start to deal with these things.

PARA.TAB: However, the government is not going to do that: it is going to let the National Standards Commission go into a brand new world of investment, of freedom from parliamentary and ministerial scrutiny. That is what the legislation says: the government is going to let the National Standards Commission have its head. But instead of the government putting on the check that should rightly be put on the commission by asking it, `Are you being obtrusive? Are you nitpicking? Are you imposing too much on business?' the government is saying, `We are going to free this up and let the commission run its own course.' I think that is a coward's way through this process. It speaks poorly of the minister, and of his understanding of the need for small business to have unnecessary and inflexible mandatory product standards removed.
The policy of the Liberal and National parties, as far back as 1989, goes on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: We will also work to minimise non-uniformity of standards across states to achieve consistency with international standards applied by our trading partners.

I give credit to the previous Prime Minister, Bob Hawke, in so far as that was an area where he applied major pressure. He and Nick Greiner, the Premier of New South Wales at that time, worked together to advance far beyond the position of previous governments in the matter of mutual recognition of standards and mutual recognition of service provided by governments. It was a good move, but I think it has faltered now. I do not think the current Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is interested in anything much but French clocks and his appearance on the front page and how he gets on the front page each day. I have not heard a statement from him or a commitment from him that he is prepared to advance this cause. Bob Hawke was prepared to. He raised it at a number of premiers conferences and had working parties going on in order to achieve a common recognition across the states of Australia on standards and, of course, a common recognition which is consistent with international standards.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister does not have standards when he is overseas.

—That is a statement that can be given a wide interpretation, and many in Australia would want to give it that wide interpretation. I will finish reading this short passage from the Liberal-National Party policy statement of 1989. The final statement is:

SPEECH.PARA: Imports will be required to meet mandatory standards imposed on local products.

That is what I am on about today, that imports should be required to meet the mandatory standards imposed on local products. There is not one patriot amongst the mob over there that is prepared to get up and say that they believe that should happen and that the government is going to do it. What is wrong with them? They know they have got the power, they have got the committees. Are they just going to let the machine of government roll on, as it does here in this chamber and the other chamber, where to anything the executive says we just tug the forelock and away we go? I have seen no real effort by backbench members of the Australian Labor Party to have their government look at these issues.

PARA.TAB: We used to get Andrew Theophanous occasionally uttering a bleat of protest on behalf of the left against something that the government was doing. Theophanous would get up and have a bit of a go—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member will refer to the member by his title.

—I can refer to this next gentlemen without his electorate. When Gerry Hand was on the back bench, he would get up and have a go, but now nobody will have a go on the other side. Honourable members opposite ought to be taking this up. As real Australians none of them will have a go on this issue that imports will be required to meet mandatory standards imposed on local products, and that is the matter under discussion today. I want to hear from the members of the Australian Labor Party that they are serious about their support for small business, that they are serious about the support for primary producers.

PARA.TAB: One of the biggest stumbling blocks that they face, a great part of the lead in the saddlebags, is to have an unexpected load of a competing product lobbed into Australia, which is of a lower standard and is not required to meet the standards that are imposed on Australians, either by Commonwealth or state legislation. This matter is legislated. Australian producers cannot avoid their responsibility. They will be fined and go to jail if they try to put onto the market a product of a lower quality. The amount of zinc on tin plate, the thickness of tin plate, the strength of welds—all sorts of standards are imposed for safety and other reasons on Australian manufacturers. We do it every day by legislation and state parliaments do it every day. Then we have got the inconsistency between one state and another. All our manufacturers have to build to what is the highest common denominator of these standards, and that imposes an additional cost.

Let me give honourable members an example. If a company is manufacturing cans for the containing of tinned food in Australia it must look around the states of Australia to find which state has the highest standard. The company must then manufacture the tins to meet that requirement so that they will readily flow into the markets of each state. That is a simple proposition. But that procedure, which may be above the safety and health requirements—they are just commonsense—imposes an additional cost on that product and on the Australian consumer for the Australian product—honourable members know the logic of this. However, the importer, unless he is picked up by some alert consumer group or some opposing manufacturer within Australia, can import into Australia scot-free of the standards. It is only if he is picked up by the department of consumer affairs or a consumer group in a state and then notification goes through to the Australian customs department that the customs department can block the product at the front gate as it comes in.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you admit that the law does exist.

—The law does exist, but look at the delay process. Look at the orange juice situation in Australia. So much can be unloaded as to wreck completely the Australian market and the rights of the Australian producer in a short time. Forget about the law; it is dilatory, it is cumbersome, it is slow. That process depends on the initial identification by an Australian group and then notification through the appropriate state departments—their testing, compliance and understanding—and, finally, notification to Customs. Can you imagine the time involved? It could take anything from three months, six months or a year to go through, by which time the Australian producer or manufacturer has had his market destroyed.

PARA.TAB: It is time that the government did something. Why cannot a simple amendment be made to these processes to have all imports meet the same standards that Australian producers have placed on them by Australian laws? It is a simple thing. Why should foreigners not observe the laws that we impose on ourselves? Is the government prepared to say it is going to give foreigners a better run than it gives to Australian producers and manufacturers? In fact, that is what the government is doing through the law. It is not prepared to make a law across the board that says that every import will comply with Australian standards.

Since 1989 that has been the policy of the coalition. We are going to stick with that because we think that is a fair law for Australian producers. Tariffs and fancy protections are not needed. All you need is to have commonsense law that makes foreigners comply with Australian law. I say to the government: do it. Where is your patriotism? Where is your sense of support for Australia? Honourable members opposite parade themselves as being strong patriots, as does the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), when it suits him. But the next minute, in private conversation or in the quiet of the parliamentary process, you prove that you are not committed to the best interests of Australia. The Prime Minister can make an aside remark to the previous Prime Minister and think that that is smart. Here in this chamber none of you will get up and say that it is sensible to impose on foreigners the same conditions that we impose on—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I advise the honourable member to address his remarks through the chair. His use of the second person causes the chair a little disquiet.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, given freedom away from that chair, I know you would agree with the proposition that I am putting, and I know that the honourable member for Banks (Mr Melham), who has just entered the chamber, is a man of discernment and fairness. He probably belongs to the same faction of the Labor Party as you do yourself—
—You are trying to finish me off, aren't you?

—I should add that the honourable member for Banks has been courageous in some of his statements over the last few weeks. He matches the comments that Dr Theophanous has made and that the former minister, Mr Gerry Hand, used to make, but nowhere else in the Australian Labor Party is there the courage to have the government make laws that are in the best interests of Australian manufacturers. In this regard, I need to draw to the attention of the House the work that has been done by Harry Wallace, the President of the Australian Owned Companies Association. I do not agree with everything that Harry Wallace has done or said, but he has endeavoured, with his organisation, to promote the benefits to Australians of supporting their own companies.

PARA.TAB: There have been a number of publications and honourable members will be familiar with the Aus Buy reports listing the companies that they need to buy from in order to support Australian companies. But we do not need to go to that extent. What we need to do is just have a fair situation where the Australian manufacturer or producer competes on the same grounds that apply to the importer.

I know that there are honourable members of long experience in the chamber. I signify the presence of the honourable member for Cook (Mr Dobie). I know he was supportive of the policy of the coalition in 1989, a continuing policy that recognised our need for fairness and consistency. The government has not done that. Under this legislation, as we change the operations of the standards association and we make the amendments to the industry, science and technology legislation, there was a first-class opportunity to impose across-the-board sanctions to imports. That would then be implemented by Customs and every importer would have to produce a certificate saying, `This product that I am importing fulfils the Australian standards.' Nothing could be simpler. It is a simple administrative process and the government chooses to ignore it. Shameful!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Griffin Mr A.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I rise for the first time in the Main Committee and, to use football parlance in relation to the World Cup at the moment, I am not sure whether it is quite like playing away from home or playing at a different time of day but, nonetheless, we will see how we go. Today, we are here to debate the Industry, Science and Technology Legislation Amendment Bill 1994, which is a omnibus bill which amends the Australian Industry Development Corporation Act, the National Measurement Act, the Patents Act and the Pooled Development Funds Act. I do not wish to speak on the Australian Industry Development Corporation Act today. I will concentrate my comments on the other three acts.

PARA.TAB: Regarding the amendments to the National Measurement Act 1960, the National Standards Commission is a Commonwealth statutory authority established in 1950 and operates under the National Measurement Act 1960. The commission has a responsibility for advising the government on the scientific, technical and legislative requirements of the Australian national measurement system and has specific responsibilities for coordinating the national measurement system, for legal metrology, for trade measurement and for the completion of metrification.

These amendments are to put in place the recommendations of Dr Kevin Foley following a program evaluation of the National Standards Commission. The amendments will expand the expertise available to the commission and bring its administrative functions in line with similar authorities. In particular, the amendments will provide for, firstly, an increase in the number of members of the National Standards Commission from eight to 10, and secondly, for an increase in the limit on contracts which the National Standards Commission may make without ministerial approval from $100,000 to $250,000. Thirdly, the National Standards Commission will be vested with power to invest its money and, fourthly, the National Standards Commission will be vested with power to make grants and provide other financial assistance.

With regard to these amendments, I say the following: the increase in commission members was a recommendation from the report of a program evaluation of the National Standards Commission conducted by Dr Kevin Foley in 1991-92. The increase in membership will allow the commission to expand its skills, perspective and experience into increasingly important areas such as the quality assurance movement and measurements in analytical chemistry.

The dollar ceiling on contracts has not been amended since 1987 and now corresponds with the minor capital items limit which is included under the running cost arrangements. Contracts entered into in the past by the commission related to the provision of testing equipment which is funded over a number of years to meet the commission's responsibilities to maintain a testing capability to the international standard.

The commission, which is under scrutiny from industry, and which is expected to pay for the operation of the laboratory, must follow best business practice in the management of funds. The facility to invest funds will ensure funds earned through the patent examination process are maximised, so reducing the need to increase fees. This investment power is in line with similar authorities.

Turning to the Patents Act 1990, the amendments to the Patents Act 1990 are extremely minor. When the definition of the Australian continental shelf was amended in the Seas and Submerged Lands Act 1973 by the Maritime Legislation Amendment Act 1994, there were a number of consequential amendments necessary to bring other pieces of Commonwealth legislation into accordance with that definition. The Patents Act was inadvertently omitted from that list of acts. The proposed amendment seeks to rectify that omission.

I now turn to the act that has probably attracted the most interest in the debate today and that is the amendments to the Pooled Development Funds Act 1992. The PDF program introduced by the government in 1992 is designed to encourage the provision of patent equity capital to small and medium sized Australian businesses whose primary activities are not retail operations or property development. The Pooled Development Funds Act 1992 enables the registration of companies that will provide long-term patent equity capital to small and medium sized Australian companies. The PDFs and their shareholders receive concessional taxation treatment. The program gave effect to the initiative announced in the One Nation statement designed to alleviate the problems experienced by small and medium sized Australian firms in obtaining patent equity capital.

It has become necessary to increase the time period in section 24(5)(b) of the Pooled Development Funds Act during which audited statements are applicable. The purpose of specifying audited statements under section 24 is to establish a mechanism for a PDF to verify the size of the potential investee company. This is important because a PDF may not invest in a business having total assets exceeding the limits specified in the PDF Act.

The problem with the existing wording of section 24(5)(b) of the PDF Act is that it prevents all registered PDFs from investing in established businesses during the period from 1 July until about the end of October each year. During this period current audited statements that are less than 12 months old generally are not available to be used to determine the size of the investee company. Section 24(4) requires that the last audited accounts of the investee company are to be used to determine the size of that company before a PDF can invest and section 24(5)(b) requires that the last audited accounts must relate to a period that is less than 12 months before the investment is made.

The PDF Act does not provide the board with any discretion in this situation to approve investments that do not satisfy this timing constraint. Therefore a change in the legislation is the only practical solution. For example, if a PDF wishes to invest today in an established business, the business would have audited accounts for the financial year that ended on 30 June 1993. These accounts are acceptable as they relate to a period that ended less than 12 months before the investment. However, on 1 July 1994—in only a couple of days—these same audited accounts are no longer acceptable under section 24(5)(b) as they relate to a period more than 12 months before the date of the investment.

For some four to six months from 1 July the investee companies will not have available audited accounts covering the year ended 30 June 1994. Therefore, during this period PDFs cannot invest in such companies. It is commercially impractical and would be expensive to require a potential investee company to undertake a mid-term audit just so a PDF can invest in this time period.

Extending the time period under section 24(5)(b) from 12 months to 18 months solves the problem. Companies under the Corporations Law are required to produce annual audited accounts for the most recent financial year within six months of the end of that year. Implementing this change will have the result that current audited accounts will always be available at the time of a PDF making an investment. This is not tinkering at the edges, as the opposition suggested in the Senate when the bill was debated there in May. It is correcting an unforeseen administrative consequence of the original act.

The initial response of investors to the PDF program was disappointing. However, the government has remained committed to the objectives of the program and has reviewed the program after consultation with industry groups. The government identified a gap in the market supply of patent equity capital for SMEs and set out to address that problem. However, it takes some time from the introduction of a new program until the private sector responds and commences operations. Also, it is difficult to determine the correct balance of incentive required to encourage investors without being overly generous. The government, in announcing the further changes in the white paper, is acknowledging that there is a need to be more generous than originally thought necessary.

Eleven PDFs are now registered. Three PDFs have raised $35 million between them and two of the PDFs have either invested in or committed all of their available capital to eligible businesses. The other PDFs are positioned to respond quickly to the white paper changes once they are enacted.Since the announced changes new PDF registration applications are being received by the PDF Registration Board.

As a result of a review, the Prime Minister announced in the white paper a number of changes to finetune the program. The main features of the changes are a reduction in the rate of company tax from 25 to 15 per cent on the profits a PDF derives from investing in businesses and a relaxation of the PDF operational rules.

Other initiatives include improving the flexibility of the PDF rules by increasing from $30 million to $50 million the total asset limit of companies in which a PDF may invest; increasing from 20 per cent to 30 per cent the proportion of raised capital that a PDF may invest in any one business; giving the PDF Registration Board a discretion to allow PDFs to invest in excess of the prescribed 30 per cent limit in any one SME investment, so long as it can be established that this is not intended to avoid tax provisions and the PDF agrees to meet the prescribed limit within an agreed time frame; removing the restriction that PDFs may not invest more than five per cent of their capital in start-up enterprises; and raising the limit on ownership in a PDF by investors, other than banks and life offices, from 20 to 30 per cent while maintaining the board's discretionary power to vary this restriction. Bank and life offices may own up to 100 per cent. The revised arrangements will improve the access to capital by small and medium sized Australian companies and address imperfections in the capital markets.

I speak in general terms now on the subject of industry policy, which the previous speaker, the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) entered into. Industry policy is essentially a balancing act. It is about setting parameters and encouraging investment but also about certainty and security being in place so that the private sector, which must be the basis for this investment, knows what it is dealing with, what the projections are for the future and how it can understand clearly when the government will and will not provide assistance.

From this government's point of view we have tried over the years to adjust our policy to the needs of business. We have not always been successful but we have always tried to do that in a way that provides certainty, in a way in which the system is designed so that that assistance that we are able to provide is structured to affect those industries which can use it and whereby we maximise the advantage to the country. I really stress that question of certainty and continuity.

The danger that we see in the opposition at the moment is that we have a situation of no policy whatsoever and, quite often, differing views are announced. As we all know, this Committee and the main House are forums where members of all sides can raise issues of concern to them and can expand the dimensions of policy debate and be in a situation where a range of issues can be covered.

The views within the opposition are often quite markedly different. The former opposition leader (Dr Hewson) and the honourable member for Barker (Mr McLachlan) both have a view that tariffs must be cut.
