They have stated that view many times and of course it was a major part of the Fightback program.

TALK.START.PARA: —They advocated zero tariffs.

—That is right. Then, only recently, the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Charles) was saying that we need to increase tariffs; tariff increases are what we should be promoting. Probably the best example at the moment of that is the new opposition leader, the man for all seasons, Alexander Downer. The media commentators and honourable members on this side of the House have picked up that he is trying to be all things to all people at all times. A recent article in the Melbourne Age by Geoffrey Barker was headed `True-blue talk, but no flesh':

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Downer was critical of increases in foreign ownership of Australian businesses since 1983. Yet he said he was not supporting formal limits on foreign investment and that foreign investment had been "very much the foundation of Australian economic history".

Mr Downer also criticised the movement of Australian businesses offshore. Yet he said he was not opposed to it, and acknowledged that economic internationalisation was "inevitable". He also indicated support for government financial deregulation and rejected any return to greater tariff protection.

Mr Downer criticised the Government's use of international treaties to undermine Australia's political sovereignty. Yet he conceded that a future coalition government would have to live with decisions made by previous governments—although it would ensure wider inputs into whether future treaties should be signed.

Mr Downer said the solution to increasing foreign ownership of Australian assets was an increase in national savings, but has not revealed his policy for boosting savings. He said the solution to Australian business moving offshore was more competitive tax regimes, infrastructure and (presumably) labor markets. He has yet to reveal his policies to achieve these ends.
Criticising Mr Keating, Mr Downer reminded his audience yesterday of William Randolph Hearst's aphorism: "A politician will do anything to keep his job—even become a patriot".
With yesterday's speech, Mr Downer joined the ranks of the patriots.
I think that is true and I think we saw it last night, too, on Lateline with Kerry O'Brien, another very disturbing characteristic of a new opposition leader.

TALK.START.PARA: —You should see whose payroll he is on.

—Again, I am quite encouraged by the fact that the opposition leader is resorting to that sort of tactic, because it was a similar tactic which actually brought down the previous Leader of the Opposition. It is, `If you are not with me, if you are not a card-carrier, you must be against me'—
—You are talking about the Prime Minister now.

—`Therefore, if you criticise something I say, by definition you must be the enemy.' This is what is coming through. The honourable member for Lyne (Mr Vaile) should take this back to his coalition colleagues with some concern, because I think he knows—
—Don't give them tips.

PARA.TAB: The DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. J.D.M. Dobie)—Order! Order!

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a high opinion of the honourable member for Lyne. We are on many committees together.
—The honourable member will cease speaking when I am calling order. I am just pointing out to him that remarks should be placed through the chair, not across the chamber—particularly in this chamber.

—My apologies, Mr Deputy Speaker. As I said at the start of my speech, I am still getting used to the environment in this place. I find the informality unusual. As I was saying, the actions of the opposition and the new leadership of the opposition have to be a concern to all of us. The comments that have been made, and were raised last night with Kerry O'Brien, about the question of interest rate policy and that question about certainty and continuity in policy are an issue for the country as a whole. The actions of the Leader of the Opposition and his deputy, the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello), in terms of continually talking the Australian economy down really do produce a dilemma for Australian industry and for the economy as a whole.

PARA.TAB: We have seen comments from many people who are not card-carrying associates of the Labor Party—for example, industry people such as the head of the MTIA—who are saying that these comments are damaging the economy. These comments are affecting the perceptions that those overseas have of Australia and the perceptions Australians have about themselves and about their country. It is that negative sort of approach that will continually affect this recovery as it goes on. It does the opposition no good, no justice and no credit at all to be engaging in these sorts of tactics at a time when we should be working together to ensure that this country moves through into recovery, and to a situation of jobs growth, on the firm policy base this government has provided.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is my maiden speech in this chamber, and I guess—
—First speech.

—First speech, not maiden speech. Certainly, I think we all wait and watch with great interest to see how this chamber will work to the benefit of the processes of parliament and democracy in this country.

PARA.TAB: The Industry, Science and Technology Legislation Amendment Bill contains a range of relatively insignificant changes to the Australian Industry Development Corporation Act, the National Measurement Act, the Patents Act and the Pooled Development Funds Act. The coalition will be supporting this legislation. I would, however, like to take the provisions of this bill slightly further and consider the government's general approach to Australian industry. I intend raising only a couple of points and I will keep my contribution relatively short.

Given the government's almost complete reliance on Australian industry to underwrite the cost of its `hide the dole queues' scheme, it would seem likely that it would be doing everything possible to assist business in whatever way that it could. One would expect a reduction in the burden of taxes, charges and regulations which are imposed on businesses and industry. One would expect certain incentives to be offered to business to grow and expand. One might even expect a stable policy environment to allow long-term planning by business and industry in this country.

With the exception of the temporary suspension of the training guarantee levy, this government fails on all three counts. It is interesting to note that the government has temporarily suspended the training guarantee levy. If people look at our policy at the last federal election they will find that it has actually picked up on a policy initiative of ours on this side of the House—

TALK.START.PARA: —Stolen, stolen!

—Well, it has stolen it but, unfortunately, it does not have the guts to go all the way and abolish it totally. Of course, that is the tragedy of this government. It has not got the guts to bite the bullet on many of these issues. One of the great impediments out in regional Australia is the fact that many businesses out there pay higher salaries to attract skilled workers to the area. So they have a greater commitment—a tax liability, one might say—in the area of training guarantee levy, workers compensation, superannuation, payroll tax, all those taxes which are taxes that this government seems to think business can pay and still survive and make a profit.

PARA.TAB: Industry in Australia is still overburdened with the payroll tax, albeit it is a state tax; the superannuation `tax', because it effectively becomes a tax on businesses; and wholesale sales tax. We know that in the budget of last year wholesale tax rose one per cent across the board, and it is going to rise again this year. It is yet another tax on businesses. Day after day, government members come into the House and say that they have achieved this year's budget without any increases in taxes. They fail to remind their constituents and the Australian consumer generally that they put up massive increases in taxes in the 1993 federal budget, and those increases are still impacting on and still having implications for industry this year.

Industry is lumped not only with the cost of these taxes, but also with the administrative headache of meeting pedantic, inflexible and unrealistic guidelines and regulations. On the subject of incentives, the federal government has in the past offered a very useful and effective incentive to invest—and we acknowledge that—in the form of the general investment allowance.

This allowance of 10 per cent was taken up by many of my constituents in the electorate of Maranoa, and I am sure it was taken up in many electorates around Australia. I have heard many good reports from other parts of the country where the allowance has been particularly useful to small and medium sized enterprises in regional cities and towns.

On the downside, the allowance was plagued with bizarre and confusing regulations which prevented many genuine investors from accessing the benefits to which they were entitled. I would like to refer to two particular cases in my own electorate, and I am sure there are many members on the other side of the House who have had these pedantic regulations brought to their attention.

One case involved a motel operator who sought to upgrade the airconditioning facility in his establishment. Generally speaking, that would have entitled him to the 10 per cent investment allowance. However, because he runs a motel and not a factory, the new airconditioning systems were required to be installed as a number of separate units. Unfortunately, each of these units cost less than the threshold $3,000 at which the 10 per cent investment allowance would apply. So even though his investment outlay came to well over $50,000 to aircondition the motel, because each individual unit cost less than $3,000 he was not entitled to the 10 per cent investment allowance.

I am sure members on the other side of the House would have to say that that is a clear anomaly in terms of the intent of that investment allowance. Had that airconditioning consisted of a single unit worth $50,000 then that motel operator would have been entitled to the 10 per cent investment allowance. I do not think that was the original intent or the spirit of the legislation; however it is what investors out there have had to live with. It is another one of those pedantic rules that perhaps have been drawn up by Treasury or the bureaucracy. That rule has meant that many potential claims on that investment allowance have been disallowed because they simply did not fit within the black-and-white regulations applied by this government.

The second case involved another genuine investor who was discouraged by inappropriate excessive regulations. It relates to the purchase of a crop-dusting plane. A number of cotton growers in my electorate have struck the same problem. Despite their wishing to upgrade their equipment and, in so doing, contribute to a multimillion dollar export industry and create jobs in country and regional Australia—and also in the cities because many of these flowthrough effects come through to the cities—the government is simply not interested.

According to the investment allowance guidelines, aircraft are excluded without exception. One would have to ask oneself: why without exception? There is no special consideration for those used predominantly, or even exclusively, in industry. Yet a plane such as a crop duster is not a plane in the sense that many of us would use planes and know the use of aeroplanes. It is a piece of machinery; it is equipment or plant. It just so happens that it is used in the sky, rather than on the land or built into a factory. Crop dusters are expensive, and especially designed for that purpose. They are not pleasure craft. The decision to purchase is driven by commercial considerations only. Yet, for reasons unknown to this government, they do not count as a genuine investment in terms of the spirit of the investment allowance.

I would strongly encourage the government not to wind up this 10 per cent investment allowance on 30 June. I know, looking at the date today, that we have one day left to change this; and I guess we are not going to see this occur. But the scheme should clearly continue if we are to encourage investment in industry and encourage industry to upgrade its plant and equipment. It would assist Australian businesses to become more competitive and more able to cope with an international, globalised economy.

There is another good reason why this investment allowance should continue, and I will relate that issue to my electorate of Maranoa. For the last four years unprecedented drought has plagued my electorate and many parts of Queensland. Many of those people who would dearly love to upgrade their plant and equipment have been unable to do so because of the effect of drought and the lack of cash flow. Those people are going to have to wait for a real break in the season to get some cash flow and confidence to go out and invest in new plant and equipment.

As we speak in this chamber today, the drought is still with us in Queensland; it is spreading through New South Wales. But I refer particularly to the situation in Queensland, where these people, and many of the agricultural industries which would have liked to have upgraded in the last three or four years, more particularly since the introduction of this 10 per cent of investment allowance, have not had the cash flow in their business because of the drought, and certainly have not had the confidence to go out and invest whilst the drought continues.

That would have been a very good reason to extend this 10 per cent investment allowance to those areas which have been plagued by drought and have been prevented, because of drought, from considering the upgrading of their plant and equipment and obtaining this 10 per cent investment allowance. They have been particularly disadvantaged by climatic conditions which are totally beyond their control, but I think that would have been something that the government could have at least considered in the preparation of the budget this year.

Quite simply, this issue is about being flexible. We must stick to the spirit of the legislation and not to the infinite degree displayed in the past. I do not advocate a flexible approach at the expense of accountability. Schemes such as this obviously need to be administered and monitored with transparent and thorough scrutiny. However, if that scrutiny is provided through explicit and inflexible regulations, as I have described, that strangle the purpose of the scheme, the potential benefits to industry and Australia generally will be neutralised.

There is room for both scrutiny and flexibility. If Australian industry is to be resuscitated, the government will need to find that happy medium. Unfortunately, I know that we have only a day left for any changes and that we are not going to see those changes. It is very sad that the government has not considered some of the requests that have come from the business groups around Australia and addressed some of the anomalies that I and we on this side of the chamber see as clear anomalies in the spirit of that 10 per cent investment allowance.

I also refer those anomalies to the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Mr Lindsay). Perhaps at some time in the planning for next year's budget there will be a reconsideration of the investment allowance. The government will only have one more chance to do so, as there will only be one more budget before the next federal election, and that will be the last budget that we will see from the Labor Party for many years. They ought to address this in the spirit of trying to resuscitate business investment in Australia, and I hope that the parliamentary secretary ensures that in his discussions he does take up that issue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cunningham Mr B.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the legislation before the chamber, which is the Industry, Science and Technology Legislation Amendment Bill 1994. As we have been having a fairly wide ranging debate, there are a couple of issues that I want to raise in relation to this, because the bill itself deals with national standards, the national standards of companies and industry, and with pooled development funds. It is on those areas that I would like to make a few comments.

PARA.TAB: One of the industries in Australia that has performed very well when it comes to national standards is the pulp and paper industry, which is probably one of the most maligned industries in some of the debate that has gone on in Australia. The pulp and paper industry had to undertake the restructuring and economic reform necessary to achieve international competitiveness and to achieve world standards. To this end, I must commend the employers and the union movement. The CFMEU, as a union, voluntarily entered into negotiations with Australian Paper Manufacturers back in 1988 and worked with that company to introduce major structural reform in the workplace.

That reform has not been without some penalty. In the short term, there have been job losses caused by reduced manning levels resulting from such changes, and this has impacted on many industries across Australia. For example, at Maryvale in my electorate, the APM company—Amcor, as it is known today; the largest pulp and paper mill—shed 330 jobs in the period between 1988 and 1993. While voluntary retirement packages and natural wastage factors were of initial concern to members, greater employment security, increased skill application and resultant job satisfaction have all contributed to real productivity gains and a more competitive workplace.

Prior to the restructuring commencing, the mill produced about 600,000 tonnes of pulp and paper and had 1,260 employees. As of 1 July last year, 800,000 tonnes were produced—which is an increase of 200,000 tonnes—by just 930 people. Improving productivity generally means producing more with the same number of people or producing the same amount with fewer people. At Maryvale, cooperation between the union and the company has resulted in the mill producing more with fewer people—which is a common occurrence in Australia today, particularly since about 1988. The cost of production at that mill is now four per cent below that of three years ago. Taking the consumer price index into account, that is an effective reduction of 11 per cent.

It has not all been good news, however; there is a downside to this. State government charges increased by 11 per cent and took some $5 million of the savings that had been achieved by the changes. The state government, of course, is responsible for the supply of gas, electricity, crown wood, rail transport and various taxes. It is in that area that I think we are still to see, in our region, the real changes that are required to make the restructure effective for the community, and to replace or do something about those 350 jobs that went from that one workplace.

We have not yet seen the flow-on from the state government for those gas and electricity prices. The savings have not been made available to industry as they should have been if we are going to get investment back into Australia. However, improving international competitiveness by restructuring workplace reform is not just about reducing employment numbers. It is also about management practices, training and retraining, multiskilling and continuous improvement; and occupational health and safety practices are very important. The CFMEU has been very much to the fore in this regard, and the union and the company are to be commended for their approach, which has enabled change to be understood by the members and employees, who consequently have been capable of effective implementation of that change.

We always hear from the opposition that these things are not happening in Australia and that there is no labour reform; but the opposition just refuses to look and see that it has been taking place. I refer in particular to an area that I represent. I will admit that the Latrobe Valley probably has had in the past one of the worst reputations in Australia for industrial relations. Today, we are a shining light of change. We have industrial agreements in place and we intend to publicise them as much as we can. Hence, at every chance I get in the parliament, I will be raising these matters.

Other than the original occupational health and safety agreement which was negotiated with the industry back in 1984, the three most important agreements negotiated in the period since 1988 are the restructuring, training and enterprise agreements. Those are major items for Australia today. The restructuring agreement had the effect of reducing manning levels, as I have said. However, it also provided for retraining, transfer to other duties and acceptance of greater responsibilities. As a result, there is now wide acceptance and practice of multiskilling throughout the mill and, in the production area, employees are now responsible for the production process in crews of each of the mill's 13 operating units.

In the occupational health and safety area, the major employers in that industry signed an agreement on occupational health and safety in 1984. However, it was not until the establishment of a special occupational health and safety unit in 1990 that there was any dramatic improvement in health and safety of the workplace and resultant reduction in lost time through injury. The agreement by APM to participate in the funding of the OH&S unit contributed significantly to the participating companies' efforts to be internationally competitive and to raise their standards. There is evidence now that the union's intervention at that time resulted in improvements in health and safety. From 1984 to 1990 lost time injury rates at the Maryvale mill have fallen significantly.

In the area of training, the overall object of the training agreement at the mill is to improve operating effectiveness of the mill and thereby increase productivity, increase competitiveness and improve job scope, responsibility and security. As mentioned previously, training and retraining was a major component of the restructuring. It remains an essential component in all further efforts to increase productivity. The agreement has been the vehicle for multiskilling and acceptance of greater responsibility in the workplace.

There are three key factors in the agreement's general approach. First, it is acknowledged that training is a long-term investment and not a cost. The return on that investment will be through improved operating effectiveness. Secondly, the effective development and implementation of training proposals require a consultative approach by all parties, and we have that. Thirdly, employees will be paid for skills attained and used by an employee within the mill according to agreement, and the parties have agreed to remove barriers to the utilisation of skills acquired. Fourthly, all employees accept that they have a responsibility for teaching others as part of their normal duties according to past practice. While it is acknowledged that training is a long-term investment, productivity gains at Maryvale have already demonstrated its worth in the short term. This is further evidence that the policies being put in place by this government are working and will continue to work.

Let me move on now to the enterprise agreement. In an effort to improve this country's overall competitive trading position, the federal government has encouraged industry and unions to enter into enterprise agreements which recognise the need for industry in this country to bring its costs more closely in line with overseas competitors. Given the restructuring experience of APM and the CFMEU and the union's involvement in councils, studies and inquiries, this challenge was taken up readily and negotiations entered into for the first enterprise agreement in the pulp and paper industry. This agreement, now signed by both company and union, commits the parties to a range of measures leading to real gains in productivity, efficiency, competitiveness and attainment of world standards.

The key objectives of the agreements are, firstly, to align the company's cost structures more closely with those of the company's major competitors. In particular, the unions and employees commit to the objective of reducing the cost of labour over the two years of the agreement by 10 per cent. Such reductions may occur by several processes, namely, improved operational efficiency through improved skills and dedicated work teams; improved work flexibility; improved manning productivity; improved commitment and adherence to quality management principles; and other productivity; quality and service measures as appropriate to the objective. They are also to become more flexible and responsive to the requirements of the company's customers.

The union and the company have agreed to adopt the broad approach to productive performance and incorporate management and labour efficiency, quality training and equity issues. Individual mill agreements will detail specific measures for such key issues as working to the full range of skills, removal of demarcation barriers and the acquisition of vertical and broad skills. In addition, consequential agreements on training and occupational health and safety are recognised as key elements and measures to enhance productivity.
In commenting on the success of this cooperative union and company approach on micro-economic reform, Commissioner Merriman of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission stated:

SPEECH.PARA: What has been occurring at APM Maryvale is a substantial development in cross-skilling and a development which a short time ago would have been placed in the too hard basket as being an impossibility. What is occurring is a significant example of award restructuring, work place consultation culminating in the removal of previously high impregnable barriers. The training and development program now in place, following constructive negotiations, demonstrates Australian ingenuity and a dedication to productivity improvement.
As can be seen from this statement, both the CFMEU and the APM have invested considerable time and effort in a range of measures to improve productivity and overall competitiveness.

PARA.TAB: It is somewhat of a tragedy to come into this parliament, both this place and the main chamber, and hear so many members opposite saying that nothing is happening in labour reform. If there is to be a judgment made of our opponents at the next election, it will be that they continue to be out of date, out of time and out of step with the Australian people.

What is occurring at APM Maryvale is also occurring right across the Latrobe Valley region in my electorate. The industrial agreements are all signed. As I said in the other chamber last night, within six weeks we hope to be demonstrating to the world, and to Australia in particular, that this region has turned the corner on the dark days, as we used to talk about them, of the environmental and industrial relations problems of the Latrobe Valley.

We need to get out and demonstrate that. We need to get out and start talking about pooled development funds. What we need in Australia, more than anything else, is confidence. As my colleague the honourable member for Corinella (Mr Griffin) said, `Talking down the economy is not the way to get Australia into the world market.' I do not think it is doing much for the opposition to continually talk down against the facts—to keep saying that labour reform is not taking place and that nothing is happening. All that the opposition is saying to many investors, who probably do not know any different at this stage, is that things are not occurring. Members opposite are not doing any good for themselves or for Australia.

Pooled development funds and the measures that have been introduced by this government to make them attractive will not work of their own. It certainly will not work if the message that is going to the people who make these decisions is that things are not right in Australia. Let me give honourable members an example of this. Three months ago Mission Energy invested $1.4 million in the Loy Yang B Power Station in the Latrobe Valley, which is in my electorate. There are 52 banks involved in the funding of this proposal.

At the Mission Energy opening there were people from all over the world. I sat next to a person who had worked in the Latrobe Valley 15 years ago. He is now the leading person in that organisation in Singapore. His knowledge of what was happening in the Latrobe Valley was 15 years old. He still believed we were uncompetitive and that we had not changed. We were talking about Mission Energy's ability to go into East Java and build a similar power station. He was looking for contract workers and skilled people to assist in that development in Indonesia, but he said to me that Australia would not be in it because we were not competitive.

We had to very quickly get to work on him and inform him of the change that has occurred in Australia and of what is now taking place in Australia. The people in the public arena, and in this parliament in particular, who keep reporting that things are not changing are doing a great disservice to Australia. We realise that we have a problem and that we have to get out and correct it. We have to make the changes that are needed to change the world's perception of what is happening in Australia.

There are many people in Australia prepared to do that. People on this side, certainly, are out there doing their very best. Our Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is in Indonesia this week continually working towards this. The plea that I would make is for the opposition to come on board and to be part of Australia. Opposition members should acknowledge what is occurring in Australia. They should acknowledge the benefits of the pooled development arrangements that are there for investors in Australia. They should acknowledge the reform. The evidence is quite clear. It is available for them to see. They should get on to some constructive thinking and some constructive policies that may help Australia in the future.

Their leader was on television last night saying that all will be made available in the next election campaign. That will be much too late. The Australian people have never, ever—in my experience—got it terribly wrong when it comes to making the judgments in relation to who should govern them. They have got it right now, they have for the last 13 years and they will continue to get it right, I believe, in the future.

It gives me great pleasure to support the legislation that is going through the parliament. I believe that national standards are very important. I believe that the development funds act is extremely important but the whole lot must be seen in context. When it is seen in context, not only by the members of the opposition but by a lot of the people that they talk and deal with, a little more confidence coming from them and a little more reality could have a great impact upon how investors think about investing in Australia.

I believe it is certainly well on the way now but investors still need encouragement. They still need the confidence that things are in place and are working. I believe that, if we keep working at it and keep a solid program going that brings this information out to the people and if everybody takes every opportunity they can in this chamber and other parts of the parliament to notify this, our investors will start to realise. I believe they are realising now but they will move much more quickly to put in place the funds that are required to generate the opportunities that Australia has.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vaile Mr M.A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are certainly having a broad ranging debate on the Industry, Science and Technology Legislation Amendment Bill 1994 this morning. We listened to one of the government speakers a while ago talking about the Australian Industry Development Corporation. I would have liked to have come in and spent 20 minutes talking about it as well. We are reducing the public ownership of the subsidiary company which I am sure is going to bring to light some interesting outcomes down the track with its ownership, or part ownership, of the Australian Submarine Corporation. That is not what we are talking about here this morning, Mr Deputy Speaker. As I say, we are having a broad ranging debate.

PARA.TAB: We have listened to the honourable member for Corinella (Mr Griffin) talk about business investment and foreign investment in Australia and the comments from the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer). We have also listened to the honourable member for McMillan (Mr Cunningham) talking about training as a part of what I understood to be an enterprise agreement with APM. That reinforces the comments that the opposition was making yesterday in the main House on the debate on the Training Guarantee (Suspension) Bill.

I will get back to the bill that is before this Main Committee this morning. The Industry, Science and Technology Legislation Amendment Bill 1994 has a number of measures. It amends the National Measurement Act; it amends the Patents Act and, most importantly, it is another amendment to the Pooled Development Funds Act. Yesterday we debated the Pooled Development Funds Act in the main House of Representatives chamber. The parliamentary secretary's speech on the second reading—I presume that is who made the second reading speech—referred to the pooled development funds and the size of the investee companies. That was amended yesterday but I presume it has still got to go through the Senate. I will come to that in a minute.

This bill that is before the Main Committee today amends the National Measurement Act by providing for the following: there will be an increase in the number of members of the National Standards Commission from eight to 10; there will be an increase in the limit on contracts the National Standards Commission may make without ministerial approval from $100,000 to $250,000—and we just presume they are not going to be using the Australian government credit card in those areas; the National Standards Commission will be vested with power to invest its money; and the National Standards Commission will be vested with power to make grants and provide other financial assistance.

The Patents Act 1990 is amended to make minor technical amendments which are consequent to the amendments made to the Seas and Submerged Lands Act 1973 by the Maritime Legislation Amendment Act 1994 (No. 20 of 1994). The Seas and Submerged Lands Act 1973 now contains an express definition of the Australian continental shelf; thus reference to the continental shelf convention and the Patents Act 1990 are no longer appropriate.

That is following on from our commitment to another international convention. As you know, Mr Deputy Speaker, the coalition is very concerned about the number of international conventions that Australia is becoming a signatory to without any reference to the Parliament of Australia. The fact is that the governments of Australia—not just this government, but consecutive governments over a period of time—have signed in excess of 2,000 international conventions. At the same time, the United States of America, which the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton) was holding up as a great role model and was tugging his forelock to the other day, has signed somewhere in the vicinity of only 300 or 400 international conventions.

We have been suggesting to the government that those conventions should be subject to the scrutiny of this parliament, and they should be debated in this parliament before the government signs them. That has resulted in the amendments to the Patents Act. The amendment to the Pooled Development Funds Act is probably one of the more important aspects of this bill that we are debating this morning, and it is certainly one that has drawn the most attention of speakers from both sides of the chamber this morning. It is terribly important, because we are talking about the future of this country, and about incentives and encouragement for small to medium enterprises and large enterprises—but mainly small and medium enterprises—to go on, develop, invest and generate more employment.

As was set out in the main House yesterday, we are not opposing the measures that the government is making. We are not talking things down as the member for McMillan implied a while ago. We are purely doing what any professional opposition would do. I am sure that the members of the Labor Party, when they return to opposition—and they will one day—will do the same thing, because an important element of government in Australia is a strong opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —But basically you are a professional opposition or a permanent opposition.
—Order!

—The honourable member objects, but it is an opposition's job to highlight areas where the government could improve its performance, and the government has proven to the people of Australia with the Training Guarantee (Suspension) Bill last night that it can improve what it is doing in Australia by taking note of policies that the opposition has put forward. We were going to abolish the whole thing, but we will come to that later on.

PARA.TAB: So it is important that an opposition highlights to a government areas in which the opposition believes the government can improve its performance. If that means talking about changing fiscal strategies and talking about interest rates and what the downstream effects of current policy may be, so be it. But it is not a case of talking the economy down or talking interest rates up; it is about highlighting to the government some of the inadequacies that we believe it has in policy areas, and it is done in a positive spirit, not a negative spirit. I refute the arguments put forward by the member for Corinella and the member for McMillan who implied that that was actually the case.

The Pooled Development Funds Act 1992 is amended to extend from 12 to 18 months the period to which the most recent audited accounts of an investee company must relate for the purpose of determining the value of the total assets of the company before a pooled development fund invests in the company. This change reflects the fact that audited accounts for the previous financial year are generally not available for up to six months into the current financial year.

Again, if the government had done a little more research when establishing the pooled development funds out of the white paper which was produced back in 1992, a lot of these things might have surfaced, and it might have been structured better in the first place, instead of having to keep coming back to the parliament with amending legislation, as we saw yesterday and as we are seeing today, to try to fix up these things. I would just like to quote from some comments that were made by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) on 27 January 1994.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can you believe them?

—Not really. However, almost two years after the launch of the now infamous One Nation statement, the Prime Minister, when interviewed on the ABC's AM program, faced the following question from Maxine McKew:

SPEECH.PARA: Why not give more assistance to specific industries to help promote value added production?
As is the norm with the Prime Minister, he did not answer that question; he answered another one, saying:

Well, we have got a number of quite innovative tax measures here. We have got pooled, we have got pooled development funds to provide funds for small to medium businesses that can't get equity on the stock markets, and they just can't get equity privately.

He then went on to enunciate other One Nation proposals that have largely been unsuccessful or even less successful than the PDFs to date. When addressing the House during the second reading speech for the Pooled Development Funds Bill in 1992 the then Minister for Science and Technology said:
This program is an important element in the government's overall strategy of removing impediments to the growth of Australian industry and improving employment prospects of all Australians.
He went on to say:
The government is aware that this program will not meet all the needs for channelling capital to small and medium-sized firms.

We agree with him because it has not done that; it has been shown not to have done that. In the debate yesterday the figure that was mentioned was about $35 million. That is all that has flowed into it, and it is going nowhere near helping the people that it was to try and assist.

PARA.TAB: I would like to draw a few analogies, as previous speakers have done, on a parochial basis from my electorate. They cut across a couple of comments of government members with regard to the business investment that we are trying to address with pooled development funds. In Wingham—and the honourable member for Hunter (Mr Fitzgibbon) knows the area fairly well—we have an employer of in excess of 350 people, the local one of the few remaining high-tech abattoirs in New South Wales that still have an export licence. It was a cooperative that, going back quite a few years, went into liquidation. It was bought by a consortium of local graziers and local business people, kept going not because of the input of the unions involved but because the workers wanted to keep their jobs. They worked three days a week; they had a de facto type of enterprise agreement going for many years there.

It was privately owned until just recently. The owners had to expand and spend millions of dollars on high-tech gear for the boning room, packaging and freezing to send beef to Japan and Korea, but they could not afford to do it and they could not get the money within Australia. They could not get the finance, although they turned this country upside down to try to find funding to maintain the ownership of that. They did not sell the business, the abattoir, because they wanted to get out of the industry or because they were not making a profit; it was just the enormity of the investment they had to make to maintain their world competitiveness and to maintain their market share overseas.

Do you know who owns that now? It is the Nippon Meat Packaging Company, because nobody else would invest in it. There were no Australian investors who were prepared to buy that business, to buy that abattoir. The four owners wanted to maintain their ownership but they could not get the funding to do what they wanted to do so they would not have been in business. So what happened? It is now Japanese owned. The Wingham tannery, a small enterprise, a small business by anybody's standards, employs about 25 people and is striking the exact same problems. The owner cannot get finance because he is moving into an expanding market. He wants to export into South-East Asia. He cannot arrange the capital to buy the stock and to retool. He is not highly geared by any standards as far as his equity is concerned with his loans but he cannot find finance. He is turning the place upside down.
I have been going through the Commonwealth departments and the Commonwealth offices to try to find assistance through the office in Sydney, through the Minister for Small Business

SPEECH.PARA: in New South Wales, because he is struggling to maintain a business. If he cannot get that finance, if he cannot get that capital, he is going to end up closing it down or it might end up being sold to a South-East Asian owner.

PARA.TAB: That is the problem we are facing. The point that we are trying to make is that we still do not believe, even with the amendments made yesterday and today to the pooled development funds, that it is helping such people. Why is it not helping these people? Why will the commercial financial institutions not underwrite and finance some of these operations? It is because there is more cream elsewhere; there is too much competition in the marketplace.

The honourable member for Corinella was talking about some of the comments that the Leader of the Opposition has made about interest rates, fiscal policy and so on. Right at the nub of that is the competition that the Commonwealth government is placing on the marketplace for finance. The money that you are borrowing is placing too much competition in the marketplace and you are competing with these people. One of the speakers in the House of Representatives talking about the Pooled Development Funds Amendment Bill yesterday told the great example of one of his constituents trying to borrow some money for an expansion in the business. The bank would not lend it but, for the same amount of money, one of his staff borrowed money for a car because there is more profit in it for the banks.

The fact of the matter is that there is more room for the Commonwealth government to play in this area to ensure that there is adequate finance on an equitable basis, on a sustainable basis, for small and medium businesses in Australia. If the Commonwealth government does not ensure that there is finance available for expansion, for stock, for promotion and for retooling into the future, we are not going to have a manufacturing base; we are not going to have anything to value add to; we are not going to have those industries here. Do the honourable members opposite know how many industries have headed off to South-East Asia to operate over the years? They are well and truly documented.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are coming back this way.
—We have not seen too many of them and I think—

PARA.TAB: The DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. J.D.M. Dobie)—Order! Remarks should be made through the chair, not to each other.

TALK.START.PARA: —More incentive has to be provided. We agree that we are heading in the right direction on the pooled development funds. In the second reading speech, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Mr Lindsay) mentioned the changes to the threshold for the investee company—changes that were made in this bill yesterday, but which had not gone through the House of Representatives then.

PARA.TAB: Until we provide more incentive and until we recognise the problems that business faces in this country, we are not going to see those changes. I would like to see some of the companies coming back onshore. We desperately need them. That is the only way that we are going to generate some fair dinkum employment in this country.

Finally, it has been a broad-ranging debate. The honourable member for Corinella mentioned a few important elements for business investment: incentive, certainty, stability, equity of treatment. I think it is a good litmus test. Under this government's policies at the moment, if someone is looking at investing in business in Australia today, can we seriously ask ourselves: is there adequate incentive provided by the government? Is there certainty? Is there stability? Is there equity of treatment for business with other sections of the community? The answer is no.

I said it yesterday, and I will say it again today: small business in Australia is overtaxed, overregulated, underfinanced and underresourced. Until we address those four key elements of problems in that small business sector, we will not see the projected growth and the projected business investment that the government is talking about and we will not see a major change in the level of unemployment in Australia.

The honourable member for Corinella also spoke about foreign investment as a problem that was being alluded to by the Leader of the Opposition. Of course it is a problem. Australian companies want to remain and want to maintain the ownership of their industry and their business in Australian hands, and I have spoken about this in my electorate. Why do we see Australian companies forced into a situation where large multinational corporations have got to buy them? Because they cannot get adequate financing onshore in Australia. It cannot just be the particular circumstances of individual companies where the equity is not right and this is not right and that is not right. We cannot keep talking about those sorts of problems. We must address the issue of the lack of commercial capital onshore in Australia.

We have seen a downgrading of the Commonwealth Development Bank as a lender of last resort. I was in the real estate industry for about 15 years. Particularly with rural properties, if someone got knocked back because of particular lending policies of a commercial bank at the time, they could get referred to the Commonwealth Development Bank. Quite often, they could get adequate capital funding from there but it has been narrowed down and almost does not exist. That opportunity for people to invest in business is not there any more, that lender of last resort in this country. That is another area that this government should seriously be looking at.

Finally, the honourable member for McMillan was talking at length about the APM operation in his electorate. He was talking about the enterprise agreement that had been reached with the unions, which he was obviously closely involved with. He made a very true comment and I agree wholeheartedly with him. He said, `Training is a long-term investment, not a cost.'

He is exactly right; he is dead right: training is a long term investment. People who are in business—small, medium and large business—for the long term recognise that training is a long-term investment; they recognise that their employees are their greatest asset, that their business will not operate without them, that it will not improve itself and that it will not move forward without properly trained employees. He is right in saying that it should not be considered a cost. But the fact is also that it is not incumbent on any government of this country to tell people how much training they should be providing, because those people who are operating profitable businesses, who are operating productive businesses and businesses that are very successful, provide way in excess of the training that this government was trying to impose on them.

Yesterday when we were debating the Training Guarantee (Suspension) Bill, whereby the government was seeking to suspend it for only a couple of years, we moved an amendment to do away with it completely. We keep hearing about the lack of policies of the opposition. That is one part-policy that you have stolen from the opposition. We made it quite clear from the start that we were going to abolish the training guarantee levy. You have suspended it. Ultimately, you will get the message and you will abolish it because you will realise, as you will in a lot of other areas in which this government is operating, that intervention is not necessary. This is an area in which intervention by government is not necessary.

Run all your training programs through skillshare and through DEET—that is fine; but business knows the training that it must provide to its employees if it is going to remain competitive, particularly into the future. I am just going to close on that note, because it is a pet subject of mine, but I implore the government, as far as the training guarantee suspension is concerned, to go on all the way and abolish the thing.

TALKER.NAME: Mr LINDSAY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—In closing this debate, may I observe that I have been present in a wide-ranging debate on every topic except the bill for the last hour and 40 minutes. That is thanks, I am sure, to the excellent chairmanship of the Deputy Speaker and the indulgence extended to all the speakers.

PARA.TAB: The DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. J.D.M. Dobie)—Who may remind the parliamentary secretary to stick to the bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Indeed, thank you; I am pleased to see that you are so alert, Mr Deputy Speaker.
—Even awake!

—The honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman), for example, spoke about issues that have hardly any relevance to the bill whatsoever, and when he did touch on the National Standards Commission he even got that wrong. The facts are that the National Standards Commission operates under the National Measurement Act 1960. Its function is to establish and maintain a national system of units and standards of measurement of physical quantities and provide for their uniform use.

PARA.TAB: The situation is, I reiterate, that the National Standards Commission does not set standards for produce or manufacture. The amendments to the National Measurement Act 1960 are to put into effect many of the recommendations, as other members have said, arising from the program evaluation of the commission that was carried out by Dr Kevin Foley, who is well known to many members of this House, during 1991 and 1992. Indeed, the amendments are simply administrative in nature.

The honourable member for Corinella (Mr Griffin) gave an excellent speech that was very detailed—an analytical speech dealing with the amendments that are contained in the bill—and finished it, of course, with an excellent essay on the accomplishments of this government with respect to industry policy. The honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Bruce Scott) gave us a travel monologue through the electorate of Maranoa without touching the bill at all. The honourable member for Lyne (Mr Vaile) also spoke. He is, I must say, one of the most erudite speakers in the National Party, certainly streets ahead of the Leader of the National Party (Mr Tim Fischer) and the National Party frontbench. I predict that the honourable member for Lyne will, in the matter of a short time, assume leadership of the National Party.

I thank government members in particular for their contributions to this debate. This is an important bill but, I repeat, the amendments are technical in nature and are administrative in their import. Therefore, I commend the bill to the House.

That the bill be reported to the House without amendment.
