That the bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —It might suit the convenience of the chamber if I seek leave to table the government's response to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs advisory report on the Crimes (Child Sex Tourism) Amendment Bill 1994 to facilitate debate.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slipper Mr P.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously, in the four or five seconds since the Minister for Justice (Mr Kerr) presented the government's response I have not had the opportunity to read that response. However, like the honourable member for Banks (Mr Melham), I was honoured to be part of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs which received the Crimes (Child Sex Tourism) Amendment Bill for consideration. Indeed, it is part of history, because this is the first time that a House of Representatives committee has deliberated on a government bill and made certain recommendations. I must say that I think it is a credit to the minister and to the government that a very large number of those recommendations brought forward by our committee have been picked up.

PARA.TAB: During my period of membership in the parliament I have often criticised the way that the parliament has been used as a sausage machine. The precedent set by the minister at the table is a precedent which I would like to see followed more often, because an ounce of prevention is much better than a ton of cure. If bills could be referred to bipartisan committees which are able to consider those references and bring forward recommendations, then we will find quite often that the law enacted by the parliament will be of a higher standard, will have fewer mistakes and will require less remedial action than would otherwise be the case and than has been the case in the past.

This bill arose out of a growing concern in Western nations and throughout the world over the sexual abuse and exploitation of children in the child prostitution industry mainly in South-East Asian countries. Included amongst those countries are Thailand, the Philippines and Sri Lanka. However, it should be noted that this bill does refer to activities throughout the world and the actions which this bill criminalises will be actions throughout the world, not simply in the area of South-East Asia.

The child prostitution industry, unfortunately and sadly—and I believe tragically—has been supported to a significant extent by tourists, including tourists from Australia. The introduction of this bill was preceded by an increasing awareness that Australia's international reputation was being undermined by the activities of a very small number of people and that as a civilised nation we had to do something to stop our residents and our citizens from participating in this pernicious trade.

It is widely known that in many Asian countries there is a very much lower likelihood of being apprehended for activities relating to the sexual abuse of children than would be the case in this country or in other Western countries, and the penalties for sexual abuse are generally less severe than those which would apply in Australia. Often we found that tourists went abroad from Australia and participated in evil activities without any real risk of being apprehended and without any real risk of being penalised. Some Asian countries, to their credit, have now begun to crack down on child prostitution and the involvement of Australian and overseas nationals in sexual abuse and exploitation of young people.

I believe this bill is necessary, although I am one of those who have a concern about Australian parliaments enacting laws to control the activities of Australians overseas generally. I believe that first and foremost—as recognised in this bill—the laws of the country where the activities take place should take priority and should have pre-eminence. I suppose this bill is designed as a safety net measure, in effect to criminalise activities and to prosecute in Australia Australian citizens and residents, who would otherwise escape the laws of those overseas nations.

I must say, though, that I think the nature of the activities sought to be caught by this bill is so abhorrent that it is justifiable, and indeed appropriate, for this parliament to be enacting this legislation. I have major concerns, also, about this parliament tearing up the constitution of Australia by, in effect, signing conventions and treaties which then give the federal parliament legislative competence in areas which under our constitution would normally be matters for the states. I was heartened, however, by advice from the Attorney-General's Department that this legislation is not based on a treaty or a convention but rather on the external affairs power.

It is pleasing that a large number of the amendments suggested by our committee have been picked up by the government. At the heart of those amendments is the suggestion that the justice which applies to accused in this country should apply also when offences are committed overseas. What we did not want to do was to set up a kangaroo court where accused people were not given all of the protections and safeguards that under the British-Australian criminal system are normally extended to people who are accused of crimes.

The purpose of the bill is to amend the Crimes Act 1914 to insert a new part IIIA dealing with, firstly, sexual offences committed by Australian residents overseas; secondly, related offences of benefiting from or encouraging the above mentioned offences; thirdly, defences to these offences; fourthly, the provision of evidence by video link in proceedings under this part; and, fifthly, the provision of rules relating to the conduct of trials under this part.

Once enacted, this bill will, in summary, create a range of sexual offences involving children, committed by Australian citizens as residents overseas, and create offences relating to the organisation or promotion of child sex tourism. It is very important to make sure that the promoters of this kind of activity are also caught, and the government has accepted this.

The coalition raised numerous concerns about this bill in the first instance. Among them was the title of the bill. It was suggested by my colleague, the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Williams), that the bill should more properly be entitled the Crime (Overseas Exploitation of Children) Bill. I am sorry that the minister has not picked up that suggestion by the honourable member for Tangney; I think that name is a more appropriate name for the bill. The bill's title at the moment tends to be emotive, but I suppose that is a matter not of substance.

We had further concerns, relating to the inherent vagueness of the original bill. Also, we had concerns that the penalties for those who organise and encourage offences were less than the penalties for those who commit the offences. We were worried about poor drafting—for example, in defining the offence, in referring to the `offender' rather than to a `person'. The explanatory memorandum for the bill indicated that sexual offences against children overseas did not apply in situations where a child was only incidentally present during sexual activity because of, for example, cramped living conditions. However, this was not indicated in the legislation.

Further, the deeming of proof in relation to proof of age was identified as being fraught with danger, as an Australian jury would have much difficulty in determining the age of a victim. There were suggestions that, if the jury was not satisfied that the victim was, for example, under 12 years of age, they should convict of the under-16 offence; and, if not convinced the victim was under 16, they should acquit. However, it was noticed that the Victorian Crimes Act provides that the judge or jury may determine a person's age on evidence and this may involve the appearance of the person. One could argue that the capacity of an Australian jury to estimate the age of an alleged victim of Asian extraction, by video, is somewhat restricted. We had excellent evidence from Professor Bode at the committee hearings. He was a person who said that, while he could determine the degree of physical maturity of a particular child, he was not necessarily able to determine a child's chronological age.

Now the principle of this legislation has widespread support from the coalition and indeed from throughout the community. However, inherent difficulties were evident from the beginning. Those difficulties were picked up in our committee's report. The government has brought down its response to the report and we therefore see the amendments which are now before the committee.

During public hearings on the bill—and I was privileged to attend some of those—many major issues of concern were raised. I must say I was impressed with the quality of the witnesses who came before the committee. They were people without vested interests. I must say that a number of them had differing views but you would expect that on an issue such as this you would get differing views from different people who approach a subject from varying perspectives. I must say that I was impressed with the quality of the contributions, the honesty of the contributions and the way in which the people came before us without vested interests.

The concerns that particularly alerted me to the problems in the bill were concerns relating to fundamental legal principles and, indeed, the need to ensure that the system of prosecutions proposed in fact, provide justice for those people who are accused. The issues raised were considered under four broad headings. Firstly, there were social issues. The majority of Australians are outraged by the sexual abuse of children be they Australian or foreign children. Such conduct is an offence against Australian community standards and it is a criminal offence when committed in Australia. The committee supported the view that such conduct ought to be criminalised when committed by Australians overseas.

The committee, however, recognised serious problems in the drafting of the bill. For example, the bill's response to procuring evidence and prosecuting a case was to short-circuit some of the traditional safeguards afforded to accused persons in Australia. These concerns were picked up by the acting Senior Public Defender for New South Wales, Mr Martin Sides QC, who said:

SPEECH.PARA: Child sex tourism exploits children and it exploits poverty, and it is desirable that this country should play a part in bringing it to an end. Any legislation should be workable and it should be practical. It is no use passing legislation that is unworkable. In the rush to end this most hideous trade, we must not lose sight of the fundamental principles that underpin our democratic institutions; one of those is the right of the accused to a fair trial. . . The right of the accused to receive a fair trial is paramount. If that right is undermined we compromise our democratic institutions. . . It is my view that there are significant and powerful procedures that are not available to accused persons or, for that matter, the prosecution in this legislative scheme.
The committee recommended that the bill uphold the legal protection afforded to accused persons. That is at the heart of our criminal justice system.

PARA.TAB: On the issue of foreign policy the committee noted that the conduct of Australians overseas impacts on our bilateral and multilateral relations. There are also significant practical difficulties arising from the bill such as the cost of prosecuting a court case, costs of defending a case, cost of a video link, collecting evidence of the proscribed conduct, the reliability of documentary evidence on the age of a child and protection for witnesses, just to name a few.

I must say I am interested to see the minister present in the committee because I gather that he said earlier in the House that the legislation would not create any additional expense or any additional Commonwealth outlays and that the costs of prosecutions could be found from the budgets of the federal police and from other Commonwealth bodies. Well, the evidence that we had at committee hearings was that if this bill is going to be successful there will have to be a very substantial injection of funds to ensure that the federal police and the authorities and, indeed, the court systems have the capacity to process and deal with matters covered by the bill.

In relation to legal concerns raised by the bill, the principles of justice were the most important issue of concern raised by witnesses during public hearings and in submissions. Some witnesses believe that the presumption of innocence on the basis of the Australian tradition of criminal law was put at risk by the bill.

A further concern was the lack of consultation in preparing the legislation. The committee recommended that the government ensure adequate and effective consultation in the preparation of legislation. Such consultation should extend to practitioners experienced on both prosecution and defence matters, as well as to lawyers' organisations such as the bar associations and the law council and to non-legal organisations such as civil liberties groups.

In all, after extensive discussion and consultation the committee made 37 recommendations impacting on the legislation. In the conclusion to its report, the committee supported the objectives of the bill. It accepted that in the past Australians travelling to overseas destinations have been able to abuse children sexually and to escape the consequences of their behaviour on their return to Australia. The same activity would be criminal if perpetrated in Australia. The committee made particular note of the need to redraft certain clauses to overcome oversights and errors in the bill. The report reads:

SPEECH.PARA: From the beginning of the Committee's consideration of the Bill, concerns were expressed about provisions in the Bill which in the view of some witnesses contain unacceptable changes to criminal law principles and procedures. These include apparent short-cuts to assist the prosecution because of the practical difficulties of conducting a successful prosecution.
Furthermore, the committee reported:

The committee believes certain Clauses can be successfully redrafted to ensure that the Bill is effective and enforceable without abandoning the safeguards that have been traditional elements of the criminal law in Australia.

Among the major amendments recommended by the committee were collapsing into one category the existing categories of offences, under-12 and under-16, to stop defendants being acquitted because the child's age was unable to be determined, with the maximum penalty for having sex with a child set at 17 years, and the government has picked this up. Another was increasing the maximum penalty for those found guilty of organising sex tours from 10 to 17 years, and again the government has agreed to this.

PARA.TAB: The committee recommended removing a clause making it mandatory for courts to take evidence by video link where the witness's attendance would cause unreasonable expense or cause the witness psychological damage, giving discretion to the court. The government again has adopted this suggestion. I must say this was one the matters that concerned members of the committee. It is in order to have video link evidence if it reduces costs and enables the matter to be dealt with expeditiously, but one has to have very effective safeguards with video link evidence to make sure that there is a possibility to cross-examine, that one can look at the demeanour of a witness, and that justice is not only done but also seen to be done.

The committee recommended that an alteration be made to a clause under which people convicted or acquitted of child sex offences overseas cannot be tried in Australia, to ensure that there is no loophole to escape Australian justice; and also that the states bring their laws against paedophiles into line. The final recommendation of the committee reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee recommends that the Parliament pass the Crimes (Child Sex Tourism) Amendment Bill 1994 as soon as the serious problems raised in this report are considered and addressed.

The problems raised in the report were serious, but I must say the response is to the minister's credit and to the government's credit. You do not often find me coming into the parliament to give the government a lot of credit, but I believe that, where credit is due, it should be given; and I believe the minister has seriously taken on board the recommendations of our committee. He might not have implemented all of those recommendations, which is unfortunate, but we cannot expect to win in every case. I think the bill that we are now debating today in the committee is infinitely better than the bill that was debated in the main chamber earlier.

PARA.TAB: We have had a bipartisan report presented. The minister considered seriously the recommendations of that bipartisan report. The legislation that will result from this debate and the debate in the other place will be very much better legislation. It will assist to maintain Australia's reputation internationally, and it will make sure that this pernicious activity by a very small number of Australians overseas will be criminalised and that people who commit offences will receive the justice they deserve; but also it will make sure that accused people are indeed given the proper protections that one would expect in any fair and reasonable justice system.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, like other members of the committee and the parliament, welcome the opportunity to have a second bite at this. As has already been indicated by the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Slipper), the process that we have gone through—through the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs—in the consideration of this bill has been an important one. The outcome of this process, as reflected by the minister's response to the committee's report, is that we have seen quite considerable progress in the quality of consideration of legislation by the parliament. Indeed, I think this chamber adds to that process.

PARA.TAB: It is important that the committee has had the opportunity to look at the legislation in this way. It is a piece of legislation that has attracted a lot of attention in the Australian community, and I suspect it has attracted a lot of attention, of which we are not yet aware, from this industry—I think we have to call it a slavery industry—in many countries overseas.

The committee considered evidence from many people, both from a legal standpoint and from a practical standpoint. Like you, Mr Deputy Speaker, I am not terribly familiar with all of the intricacies of law. Those sorts of things are way above my head, but we do have many people, such as the Minister for Justice, and members of the committee, who have studied law and know the ins and outs of it in fine detail. They are a credit to this place, of course, and to their profession.

What concerns me, as a relatively simple fellow, are the practical difficulties, as I think they have been described in the report, regarding the implementation of this law. There have been calls for this law to be a model. I put it to this chamber and to the minister that a law is only as good as its enforcement. This law should not just be a model law but a model for action. They are two very different things.

We are going through the development of a law of this country which will apply outside Australia. That in itself is something novel and very important, particularly in respect of this issue. In many regards, we are going into somewhat uncharted territories. Whether it be issues relating to determining the age of witnesses, the means by which evidence is taken, or whatever, there are many aspects that we take for granted in Australia that will not be taken for granted in these other countries.

I think it is fair to say that in many of the countries we are talking about, life is a very cheap commodity, and children are very cheap. That is one of the reasons why millions of children across the world are still in slavery, especially sexual slavery. While this country, and most other countries, outlawed slavery many years ago it still persists. Slavery through sexual exploitation is a very big problem in the countries of Asia.

These problems arise because of the poverty that so many people, particularly in rural areas, find themselves in. Despite the best efforts of their own governments and many other agencies, there still exists poverty, and the need for parents to sell their children into slavery—a slavery that most Australians and most people in the world, particularly through the agency of the United Nations, would describe as despicable and abhorrent.

My concern is that we have a law so that, if ever a case is brought to prosecution in this country, we have to very much consider the protection of any witnesses, particularly in a case where the witness is likely to have been a victim of sexual abuse and exploitation as well as slavery. It is on that issue that we, as a government, have to focus our responsibility, and the people of Australia have to focus on their responsibility through government action.

We have a law, which I think is workable. First of all, it signals to those in the industry who develop the tourism and the sex slavery trade outside Australia that they are being put on notice, that they cannot escape the examination and opprobrium of this country by operating their trade in another country. We are putting on notice those who use those entrepreneurs, shall we say—although they are slavers—to get their satisfaction from children in another country in this way. Those Australians are clearly under the spotlight now.

It is sad that, in many countries, we do not see the same attention being paid in a practical day-to-day manner to enforce existing laws in these countries to protect people. Particularly now that we have this legislation, Australia should take this up in a bilateral manner and should seek the open and total cooperation of governments and law enforcement agencies in those countries to overcome this. There are ways in which the Australian government—through the agency and the department of the Minister for Justice (Mr Kerr), who is at the table, as well as other ministers—could do much to improve that situation.

While we generally trust the law enforcement procedures and the police forces in Australia—most Australians have a genuine regard for our justice system—part of the problem is that that is not always the case in these countries that we are talking about. Whether it be the police, the military or other forms of authority in those countries, we often find that those agencies are just as involved in protecting this industry as are others who would be acting without any authority or protection.

This brings me clearly to the point that, if we are expecting a person to come before a case to be prosecuted and to give evidence in Australia, that person needs a particular form of protection, something which we, in Australia, would take for granted. When the first case is brought before the courts under this legislation, I will have great concern for the safety and the protection of any person acting as a witness for the prosecution. We do not need to see these sorts of things on TV to recognise what is quite likely to occur—namely, that the witness or those witnesses will probably disappear and be found dead somewhere at some time in the future. That is, if anyone cares what happens.

Witnesses to the inquiry of the committee gave evidence that Catholic priests in some cases have to carry guns to protect themselves—that is, when they are involved in organisations which are setting out to give alternative support and safe haven to children in these countries who are subject to sex slavery in this way. Therefore, it should be apparent that, if Catholic priests are forced to carry guns for self-protection when protecting children from life on the street or in this trade, then any witness outside Australia who is going to be brought before a court operating in Australia is going to need very secure protection, if we are to ensure that this law does as intended, which is to stop exploitation of children.

The worst thing, and something that I do not think anyone would want, is that any witness—most probably a victim, as well—should be found to be harmed in any way by virtue of being a witness. The government has to very seriously address this matter. We cannot just rely upon the law itself; we must have, on the ground, systems for the protection of witnesses—something that is very difficult for us in Australia to manage. We do not have the authorities; we do not have the way of dealing with day-to-day life that the police and military in those countries have. I believe that the government has to pay very serious attention to this issue, which is described simply in the report under the heading of `Practical difficulties'.

If we do not attend to this matter, then the law will not be a model law and it will not achieve what it is meant to achieve and what everyone wants it to achieve. It could, I believe, end up as a death sentence. I am not being melodramatic about this. I believe that, if effective protective mechanisms are not put into place for witnesses and organisations that support witnesses, then we could be writing a death sentence for someone in that situation; and nobody wants that. So the law has to be a model for action. That means that the Minister for Justice and the minister responsible for overseas development issues and others have to focus their minds on supporting agencies and supporting witnesses who would come before the courts in any of these circumstances.

During the conduct of the inquiry, I and most other members of the committee and the rest of the parliament would have received a lot of letters during a somewhat emotional and, at times, hysterical campaign from some well-intentioned people in the community who felt that the work of the committee was a delaying tactic by some in the parliament, or that it would water down the bill and make it less effective. Judging from my involvement in the consideration of the committee's work, and judging from the response of the minister and the government, it is very clear that the legislation has been significantly improved and that, through that process, a very clear and unusually strong bipartisan approach has been developed from this parliament—an occurrence which is obviously to the credit of the parliament and to the people of Australia.

I raise that point because I think it is important that, with issues that at times are obviously emotive and that people have very strong feelings about, there needs to be a better understanding in the community of the processes of deliberation of legislation. I am glad to see that most of those people and organisations who wrote to us in such alarm, urging us to ignore these matters or to come very quickly to conclusions similar to the original legislation, have now responded with much happiness at the outcomes. That is something which is obviously welcome, and it is also indicative of the value of the process that we have gone through.

I return to my main concern in this whole issue. I know that there are many recommendations and considerations that the committee has taken notice of—as indeed there were in the minds of the minister and the department in putting this legislation before us in the first place. Many of those are very difficult, technical, legal ground-breaking considerations. I end on the point that, if we do not look beyond the actual law to the process of application of the law, and particularly to the protection of witnesses and other people that this law has been put in place to protect, then we will not only do an incredible disservice to the law, but also to those very people it should protect—and possibly at the risk of life.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, this is the first occasion I have spoken in this chamber.

PARA.TAB: The DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Hollis)—It is the first occasion I have sat here, too.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I commend you and wish you well. I trust that you will have many other occasions when you shall be able to enjoy that or other functions around this parliament. It is interesting that this system seems to allow an intimacy that does not exist elsewhere, but in speaking here there are a couple of things I would say. Firstly, I am delighted that the Minister for Justice (Mr Kerr) is here. If it is to work, it really has to involve an exchange with the minister. I know it can be a bit of a bore and there is another world out there, but if we are going to have the system actually functioning it is important that there is this opportunity of interchange. Therefore, I commend the Minister for Justice for being here, and if we can have that sort of an opportunity for dialogue then it will work a lot better than otherwise. Generally, I think that the system is worth a go. How it works out, no doubt time itself will tell.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, as others no doubt have said, this is the first time in my recollection that legislation has been sent off to a committee of the House for consideration. I think that is something that can be looked at to a greater degree, and the product proves, in this instance, that it has worked. My reservation is only that the reason it has to be sent off is that we are not allowing enough debate on legislation in the parliament itself, and I think that is a pity. While I am all in favour of a Main Committee and allowing references to committees of the parliament, I remain a champion of the parliament and I very much regret that it is necessary for us to have these sorts of occasions because the parliament fails. In a way we are not identifying ways by which we can make the parliament per se more effective. It is there and in that function I continue to have concern.

As for the legislation before us, there are a few background aspects to this consideration. The first is that I commend the minister for having accepted so many of the recommendations, in spite of his earlier reservations. The trouble is that there are not many areas in the past where we have tried to legislate for offences outside jurisdiction. It is important that in so doing we do not forget that the states do have a concern. I do commend to the minister the consultative processes which we have recommended in the committee's report because it is important that we still retain a cognisance of the extent to which, in the judicial system in Australia, the state systems are so important, particularly in the criminal law field.

It worries me that, in developing fields like this to apply outside jurisdiction, we retain a very close connection with the administration of justice within the states and the territories of our federation. I do not see that it need be against the principles that are applied, or are sought to be applied, federally but rather a way by which they can more effectively be applied. It is particularly important for the minister in this and other areas that, to the maximum degree, there be both consultation and acceptance of propositions and proposals put by the state ministers because, while they too can be a little trying at times, they are part of the federal system and it is the way by which our system has to function. Therefore, for all the difficulties that it entails, I think it is essential that there be consultation.

In the actual implementation of the changes and the amendments which I am pleased to see the minister has advanced, there are a couple of aspects that I want to address. The first is that in the area of applying an offence outside jurisdiction there are two aspects that demonstrably require attention—and I see that they have had fairly significant attention in the amendments. The first is the extent to which proper protection needs to be given to the accused. While all of us deplore the trade and all of us seek to prevent the trade, it is important that people accused be still given the proper protection of the Australian judicial system so that a person against whom an accusation is made remains innocent until the charge is proved.

This is a particularly emotive area. It is deplorable that it should exist at all. It does exist and the people need to be brought to justice but, because it is outside jurisdiction and others have different concepts of justice, it becomes more difficult sometimes to ensure that the accused person is seen as just that until the case is proven. I worry, in the application of offences outside jurisdiction, that that proper protection is allowed. That in no way means that the people should not be prosecuted. It in no way means that they should not be tried in the same way as any other offender, but it does mean that the same protections against the accused person should be maintained, not to give them undue protection but to ensure they get the proper protection of our Australian judicial system. That is even more important because I worry that in another reference before the committee whose report is here we are looking at another instance where offences occurring outside jurisdiction are to be tried.

It becomes extraordinarily difficult if you are in a position where other concepts of law intrude on our Australian judicial system and where we are to a degree derogating the concepts of Australian citizenship, Australian residency and the protections of our Australian legal system. So it is particularly important that we get the right balance. The first real aspect as far as the amendments are concerned is that they do enhance that and I think that is important.

The second is the video link taking of evidence. For a long while, through my wife and through other contacts, I have been aware that here in the ACT for some years the Chief Magistrate has pioneered and advanced the concept of video evidence of witnesses with respect to child abuse cases, and I do commend Magistrate Ron Cahill for that. He has done an excellent job in the pioneering of this form of taking evidence but it needs to be done in such a way that the evidence is taken as though it were before the court.

In the Australian instance it is done because so often the high emotion around the abuse of a child makes it hard for that child to give evidence in a dispassionate way. If they were in a more comfortable forum with people surrounding them whom they know it would be easier for them than being in the forum of a court. It concerns me, when we apply video link evidence in this field where you are taking evidence from someone overseas, that you do again take that witness into a surround where you can properly expect the evidence to be given to be true, and where, whether it is through an oath or an affirmation or some obligation imposed on the witness, you can get reasonable results because in video link for overseas witnesses it becomes even more difficult to ensure that you are actually going to get the person who is giving evidence in a climate where they understand the processes of our judicial system. If a person is falsely accused and falsely convicted, then it brings the whole of the system into disrepute.

I hope the protection that the minister has inserted—the video link—will work, but it is an area that we will need to give some attention to and perhaps as time passes we will need to see how it works. I commend the minister for developing it. I know he is committed to it and I think it will work. The one thing that we referred to in 5.4.2 on page 49 of our report, which concerns me still, states:

SPEECH.PARA: Consideration may need to be given as to whether child witnesses understand the nature and quality of any oath or affirmation that they give.

That is so true. It is particularly important that we look at the competency of witnesses and the extent to which those witnesses are affecting the guilt or innocence of the accused. It is a difficult area but it is one that has been improved by the amendments the minister has made. I therefore support them. I suspect that they are not matters which should be seen as having been written in Holy Writ, but that they are matters that need to be considered as time progresses and we see how the charges move.

PARA.TAB: Unfortunately, I was not here when the minister introduced the amendments and I have been trying to ascertain the extent to which the age question has been resolved. It is now resolved satisfactorily but I must say that it had worried me that the age of the person against whom the offence was charged was going to be a major issue of contention. I think that is now satisfactorily covered. It is important that we understand that many people do not look their age—some look older than they are. If it then becomes a reasonable excuse that the person, against whom the offence is said to have been committed, appeared and was genuinely believed to be of a legal age, then, of course, it removes the capacity for the prosecution to be successful. Therefore, it is important that age be dealt with in a reasonable way. As I read the amendments, I think that is now satisfactorily covered.

The other issue that I was interested in, and which has worried me, is that the people who conduct the sex tours and trade also need to be dealt with. Under the amended legislation, 50DA(1) and 50DB(1) certainly seem to me to satisfy the criteria. This is an offence which seems to me to be part of the trouble. Tourist agents and operators, and so on, have seen it as another way to expand the attractions, or whatever they call them, for people taking particular journeys. That should also be treated as an offence against the whole purpose. It is a barbaric trade, it needs to be prevented and I think this legislation, as now amended, should go a significant way to achieving that.

I think the legislation has been significantly improved. I commend the minister on accepting the proposals from this committee and trust that, in consultation with his state and territory colleagues, the legislation will stop a trade which all of us accept is wrong. It should not exist in the first place and it certainly needs to be prevented. I commend the minister and the amendments that he has made to the legislation and support them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —To gather some concept of the horrific nature of the trade in child abuse and the activities of paedophiles from around the world in South-East Asia, one has only to read the book The Child and the Tourist by Ron O'Grady, published for the End Child Prostitution in Asian Tourism, Australia Group. Whilst I am in no position to judge the veracity of what Ron O'Grady has written, if there is enough truth in that to warrant the publication, and enough truth in the publication to warrant the legislative approach that the government has taken, I think that all honourable members will support it, as will all Australians.

PARA.TAB: This has been a first for the House of Representatives and an opportunity to examine legislation in detail. It is regrettable that, over the last two years, the government has chosen to adopt a rather slack approach to legislation, often introducing bills and important measures with little notice and, in other instances, forcing under guillotine the most extensive and pervasive measures through the House, without adequate scrutiny by the House. That is not the case with this legislation, and the difficult nature of it and the complexity and the sensitivity of some of the measures proposed, which are unique in Australian law, have caused the government to consider the House of Representatives Committee for Legal and Constitutional Affairs a proper place for close scrutiny and examination of the bill.

I want to pay tribute to my colleague the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Williams), whom I believe, of all honourable members, was most responsible for alerting the House of the need to use its own committees. On a previous occasion, he was unsuccessful in persuading the House or the minister but, on this occasion, he initiated the interest and the Minister for Justice (Mr Kerr), who is at the table, complied, and we thank the minister for that.

Perhaps, as an aside to the minister, I might make the request that we be given a little more time in future. I am sure that we could, without setting hurdles or difficulties in the path of the government, do a more adequate job under less pressure and with less pressure on our staff. I think that everybody would work along a little more happily if we had perhaps a more considerate time frame. I trust that the minister, in his response, indicates that he is happy with the process that we have gone through.

I wish to deal with a number of matters in the legislation, but in particular I wish to deal with a matter where I had a difference of opinion with my colleagues. That was contained in an expression of concern included in the report, where I stated:

SPEECH.PARA: On balance, I find that the proposition contained in Recommendation 18(b) may allow otherwise sound prosecutions to fail. The obnoxious character of this trade leads me to conclude that defence based on belief about age must be proved on the balance of probabilities.

I believe that in this instance the onus of proof should be reversed, and I am pleased to see the government has sided with my view rather than with the committee view. I commend the government for that because, whilst the proposal that the onus of proof be reversed is not lightly entered into, I think we must be satisfied that Australians—citizens and residents—should not play any part in abuse and sexual exploitation of children under the age of 16 in the conditions that apply in Asia.

PARA.TAB: It is a different matter to apply the proper processes for occurrences in a nation where arrests and proper processes of court can take place. We are not talking about that. We are talking about acts committed outside Australia. So despite the unusual nature of this process, I want to commend the government for deciding to weigh the defence lightly with an extra difficulty, and that is that the defence must prove on the balance of probabilities that the belief on age was well founded.

Among the other areas that the legislation covers, I wish to deal with the video link evidence. That is a matter that concerned me, having looked very closely at the war crimes legislation and the difficulties that the Americans and Israelis had entered into with video link evidence. I can only caution the minister there. I have seen photographs of people under close surveillance being intimidated in their evidence on video, with the person doing the intimidating off camera. With a second camera in the room it is possible to see who is in the room and what influence they are bringing to bear on a witness.

I think the video link process needs a lot of investigation. I would be very reluctant to enter into this in any light manner. I believe it is a matter that the minister needs to follow carefully and that the House may need to review. If there is any miscarriage of justice, if there is any perjury, or if there is any false evidence given, what is the recourse the minister proposes? There is very little that can be done to rectify false statements or perjury when video evidence is taken. That is a matter that was of concern to me and to all members of the committee, and that is why we were reluctant to proceed as quickly as the government wanted to proceed in the taking of video evidence.

I notice that in the government's reply it was said that the government does not accept that its previous formulation violated traditional standards of justice. That is an extraordinary statement. It is not couched in thoughtful terms, because it does deny protection for people giving evidence that would be completely unacceptable in Australia.

In regard to consultation with the states, I would encourage the minister to proceed strongly but to carry the states with him, if at all possible, because this must be a total package if we are going to prevent tours. Tourist operators, tourist agencies and people putting together tours must, under state law, be controlled. I do not want to see, and I do not think anybody in the committee wants to see, an extraordinary extension of Commonwealth powers in this area. We would want the states to pick up their proper responsibility.

The government's response places much of the responsibility for consultation on the states, saying that state governments have an interest in a bill such as this and that it is up to their Attorneys-General to consult widely. That does not absolve the Commonwealth from consulting. The committee found, when it consulted, a wealth of opinion and some interesting views that encouraged us to come down with a report which has been basically adopted by the government.

There is little else that I want to comment on, except the consent requirement. We, as a committee, cannot understand the government's difficulty in accepting the requirement that consent should not be an element in defence. The government, in its response to the committee's report, spends some time and some effort in explaining why consent should be part of the process, but ultimately decides in favour of the committee's recommendation. It is the view of the committee that by allowing consent to be part of the process we just blow the thing sky high and make the legislation very difficult to administer. It is difficult legislation in any way, and in any manner, because the issue is how we can apply Australian law in an external capacity such as is being proposed in this legislation. It is by threat, it is by example, it is by word of mouth and it is by a cultural attitude that we hope to modify behaviour.

Whilst the committee agrees with the government that everything must be done, this legislation does have limitations. I wish the government well with the legislation. I congratulate my colleague the honourable member for Tangney with the encouragement that the chamber adopt this process. I express appreciation to the minister for his willingness for the government to adopt most of the recommendations of the committee, and point out that there needs to be ongoing attention paid to the taking of evidence by video link.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Williams Mr D.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek your indulgence.

PARA.TAB: The DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Hollis)—You actually need leave first. Is leave granted?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes. It would be my hope that we could conclude this well before one o'clock and I hope the honourable member might give me some time to reply.
—I think, Minister, it is the hope of us all. I call the honourable member for Tangney.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I think the committee realises that this bill is part of an international attack on some despicable practices, that it involves pioneering legislation and that it is likely to be seen as a model overseas for what can be done in other countries.

PARA.TAB: It is most commendable, in my view, that the members of this house have cooperated so energetically to ensure that the best possible bill has been prepared. I earnestly hope that the Minister for Justice (Mr Kerr) has a proper appreciation of the extensive work that has been done by the members of the committee, by some of the witnesses before the committee and—I mention in particular—by the secretariat of the committee that prepared the report. The committee, of course, is the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs of this house.

I commented previously on the tabling of the committee's report and I do not propose to repeat what I said then. Since then, the minister has tabled the government's response to the committee, which largely accepts the recommendations in the committee's report. Despite what I would regard as some inappropriately reluctant acceptances of some recommendations, I think the government's response is generally appropriate.

Where the recommendations of the committee to amend the original bill have not been taken up by the government, reasons have been given; and I think it is fair to say that the decisions were taken in good faith and that none of the disagreement between the committee and the government in its response is so serious or significant as to justify any further opposition, from this side at least, of the committee.

There is one recommendation of the committee I do comment on. It is, on the face of it, accepted; it is recommendation 4. In this the committee recommended that the government ensure adequate and effective consultation in the preparation of legislation and suggested that such consultation should extend to practitioners experienced in both prosecution and defence as well as to lawyers' organisations such as the bar associations and the law council and to non-legal organisations such as civil liberties groups. The government said:

SPEECH.PARA: The government is prepared to look at the issue of wider consultation in the preparation of legislation.

That appears to me to be somewhat lukewarm. The government goes on to note that the bill arose out of an initiative of the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General and gives a history of the development of the bill, which involved consultation with state and territory attorneys-general. It said in the response then:

As pointed out to the committee and also noted in its report, normally whenever there is federal legislation in which state governments have an interest, such as the bill, state attorneys-general would seek views within their jurisdiction, including the views of defence practitioners.

It seems to be stating that the Commonwealth itself had no consultations with persons practising on a day-to-day basis in the criminal courts. That seems to me to be a serious deficiency in the procedures for the development of legislation of this type, and I would urge the minister to ensure that the department develops consultation processes that do involve people involved on a day-to-day basis in the practice of the relevant area of the law.

PARA.TAB: Other speakers this morning, in particular the honourable member for Jagajaga (Mr Staples), have referred to the importance of the enforcement of the bill. It is novel in a number of ways. First, and perhaps most notable, is the use of international video links for the taking of evidence in courts in criminal trials. Secondly, perhaps notably, it creates offences where the conduct is constituted by conduct abroad that in some cases is not necessarily an offence in the place where the conduct takes place. As other speakers have urged, I add my weight to the suggestion that the legislation be carefully monitored. Its effectiveness will be carefully assessed by interest groups, who will be very quick to criticise the government if it is not effective. In that respect, it would be useful to all if there were information obtained to give some guide or yardstick by which to judge the effectiveness of the legislation. I appreciate it is difficult to obtain that sort of information but, for example, statistics on the advertising and conduct of what appear to be sex tours from Australia would be one area where a possible guideline could be identified.

Finally, I suggest to the committee that the process by which this bill has reached this stage should be seen as an appropriate model for the processing, in appropriate cases, of difficult legislation. I trust the government will recognise the benefits, as I am sure the minister does, of the use of standing committees as a means of maximising public consultation and input on complex issues.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I hand up three copies of the explanatory memorandum. It has been useful to have the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Constitutional Affairs look at the Crimes (Child Sex Tourism) Amendment Bill from a fresh perspective. The government is unable to accept the committee's general criticism that the bill as introduced departed unreasonably from traditional safeguards or throws aside 200 years of criminal justice with fairness for the accused. These extreme statements appear to be largely based on a misunderstanding of the law in Australia as it relates to sexual offences against children and the available defences. Under the law of sexual offences involving children across the Australian jurisdictions, it is for the prosecution to prove beyond reasonable doubt the elements of the offence, but a defence is allowed as to the accused's belief—reasonable belief in some jurisdictions—which is a matter for the accused to establish on the balance of probabilities. That is the case in every Australian jurisdiction.

PARA.TAB: This bill follows this approach, and I hold to my view that the general structure of offences and defences in the bill is appropriate. The government, therefore, does not adopt the committee's recommendation concerning the burden of proof as the defendant's belief about the age of a child. The proposed section is in accordance with judicial authority and equivalent legislation—for example, R v. Douglas 1985 Victorian Reports, and Heath, Indictable Offences in Victoria, and the authorities cited therein. As both the former and current presidents of the Australian Law Reform Commission pointed out to the committee, it is within normal standards to require the defence to establish belief in age on the balance of probabilities—a point also made by the law faculty of the University of New South Wales and by the Attorney-General of South Australia in their submissions to the committee.

Further, unlike its counterparts under state legislation, proposed 50CA currently only requires a subjective belief to be proven on the balance of probabilities. It would be extremely difficult for the prosecution to negate beyond reasonable doubt an assertion of what was in the mind of the accused at the time of the alleged offence, especially when that which may be asserted need not be reasonable or rational, and when intoxication can be used to assist the defence of mistaken belief. As Justice Elizabeth Evatt noted, knowledge of age—a matter peculiarly within the knowledge of the accused—is not an element of the offences which must be proved by the prosecution beyond reasonable doubt.

I note that the Senate Standing Committee on the Scrutiny of Bills also had no difficulty with the proposed section, nor was the government persuaded by the committee's recommendation that no prosecution should proceed in Australia if the actions are not criminal in the laws of the foreign country. I believe that to accept that recommendation would defeat the purposes of the bill. The policies behind the bill require an attack on the demand aspect of the problem at its source, notwithstanding the legality or otherwise of the proscribed conduct in some countries.

A defence of legality would merely encourage paedophiles to avoid the bill by targeting those countries whose laws against child sexual abuse may be inadequate or who lack the resources to combat it. Moreover, the Convention on the Rights of the Child represents an internationally agreed standard for the treatment of children and places an onus on signatories to encourage other states to review their relevant laws in the light of that standard. In any event, reforms have and are being undertaken by those countries in which the exploitation of children occurs in order to bring their laws into line with international standards. For example, Thailand is expected to introduce legislation which will, among other things, expressly make it an offence to have sex with a child prostitute.

However, a matter that also concerns the government, in legislation that is already quite complex, is the added—in my view, as a matter of principle, unjustifiable—complexity created by such a defence. The availability of a defence that a proscribed act is not criminal in the laws of the foreign country will invariably lead to the need to call expert evidence and to a contest as to what the requirements of foreign law are. As well as the substantive law, that would include proof of the content of the background, such as questions of mens rea, in legal systems that may be different from our own. The committee has stressed the need to avoid any potential confusion to juries and to simplify the issues in any trial under the legislation. To introduce such a defence would clearly run counter to that principle.

A number of the committee's recommendations which the government has adopted concerned general procedure for legislative policy development or minor drafting changes of a technical nature which are explained in the supplementary explanatory memorandum. The more significant changes to the bill as introduced are as follows. Firstly, proposed section 50FA, on the determination of a child's age, has been redrafted as agreed during the committee's hearings. The provision sets out the matters which the jury may take into account in judging a child's age in the absence of birth records. (Time expired)
The DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)—Order! The honourable member may continue.

TALK.START.PARA: —These include, but are not limited to, the appearance of the child, medical or other scientific opinions, and foreign documents or records, or copies of them. The proposed section 50FA preserves all the normal rules as to admissibility of evidence, and includes a clarifying statement that the prosecution is not relieved of its obligation to obtain the best possible evidence of age. Indeed, the prosecution has no interest in providing anything less than the best available evidence of age to the jury since age, like all other elements of the offences, must be proved to the jury beyond reasonable doubt.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, regarding the inclusion of a warning to the jury that, if evidence is treated as admissible because of subsection 50FA(1), the jury must be satisfied beyond reasonable doubt in determining the age or age range of the child. Thirdly, I refer to the inclusion of a definition of `act of indecency' in proposed section 50ABA. Although any definition of the expression `act of indecency' must necessarily be in very wide terms, the government has come to the view that even such a wide definition is useful in these circumstances in order to overcome perceived difficulties with code jurisdictions in applying the common law and to ensure uniformity of the relevant considerations regardless of where in Australia a trial takes place.

I consider that the definition proposed represents an appropriate codification of the common law for the purposes of the bill. An act of indecency is defined as an act of a sexual nature, involving the human body, or bodily actions or functions, and so unbecoming or offensive that it amounts to a gross breach of ordinary contemporary standards of decency and propriety in the Australian community.

Fourthly, the collapsing of the standard and aggravated sexual offences into a single offence against children under 16 years involves the amendment of the age of the child proposed in sections 50BA, 50BC, 50BE and 50BG to read `a person who is under 16' and the deletion of proposed sections 50BB, 50BD, 50BF and 50BH. The government agrees that a potential gap in the legislation could have arisen because of the probability that birth records in many countries where child sexual exploitation occurs may be inadequate.

As the committee is aware, the same problem arises in relation to sexual offences under state legislation, upon which the bill's provisions are partly based, but it is insignificant because of Australia's universal birth records which establish age precisely. As recommended, the minimum penalties are retained for the merged offences, and proposed section 50FE has been inserted providing that in sentencing a person convicted of an offence under the part, the court must take the age and maturity of the complainant into account. These considerations are additional to the matters which must be taken into account under section 16A(2) of the Crimes Act.

The fifth significant point is the inclusion of `intends to derive gratification' as an element of proposed offences involving acts of indecency permitted in the presence of a child, and the sixth a removal of the belief as to consent as to an element of the defences in clauses 50CA and 50CB.

With reluctance, and after much consideration, the government has agreed to remove the element of consent as an element of defences in clauses 50CA and 50CB. That requirement was included out of a concern to protect persons under the age of 16 from conduct by Australians where the perpetrator either does not believe the person is under the age of 16 or does not believe the person consents to the conduct. The absence of a consenting requirement could allow an individual to escape liability merely because he or she believed the person was over 16, irrespective of the fact that the evidence disclosed that the child had been raped or had been forced to commit indecent acts.

It was not a novel requirement. Consent is a requirement of the `reasonable mistake' defence available in respect of similar offences under state laws where the elements of the defence are consent, and mistaken belief in age, and reasonableness. However, the government has decided to give weight to the concerns expressed by the committee and to remove consent as an element for the defences. The government will monitor the operation of the provisions with a view to making appropriate amendments in the future if required.

The seventh point is that the maximum penalties in division 4, encouraging and benefiting from child sex tourism, have been increased to 17 years imprisonment; and the eighth that proposed sections 50EA and 50EB have been combined into one provision detailing when the court may make a direction that evidence be taken by video link, removing the mandatory formulation and the double negative of the `not contrary to the interests of justice' requirement.

The proposed sections were intended to overcome the costs and difficulties for both the defence and the prosecution in securing the attendance of witnesses from overseas, or using material taken from overseas in deposition form. They were also intended to reduce the trauma of the victim appearing in court. Proposed section 50EB(2) was intended to reflect a clear intention that, in the absence of compelling reasons to the contrary, the defence and the prosecution should be allowed to seek the use of video link technology where the circumstances listed in proposed paragraphs 50EB(1)(a), (b) and (c) were met. The present provision adopts the committee's recommendation by combining the sections into one provision, removing the mandatory formulation and providing that any direction for the use of technology in a particular case must be consistent in the interests of justice.
The remaining amendments are essentially minor policy or drafting matters which are described in the supplementary explanatory memorandum. I commend the amendments to the committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be very brief. The coalition does not oppose the amendments proposed. I will just briefly comment on some matters mentioned by the minister. The government has rejected criticisms referred to in paragraphs 2.2.3, 2.2.4 and 2.2.6 of the advisory report on the Crimes (Child Sex Tourism) Amendment Bill 1994 prepared by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. However, I think the Minister for Justice (Mr Kerr) will readily understand that it was a very strong unanimous view of the committee that the bill in its original form was not appropriate and did not contain ordinary safeguards for persons accused of serious crime.

PARA.TAB: In relation to the issues on which the government has chosen not to accept the committee's recommendations, as I have already said, there are differing views. In relation to the question of the onus of proof in relation to belief as to age, the minister has mentioned some authorities in the government's response. They are not the only authorities on this issue. There are differing views, and the committee's recommendation was consistent with the ordinary proposition that the prosecution should prove all elements of an offence.

TALK.START.PARA: —Every Australian jurisdiction has these provisions. There is not a single jurisdiction without them.

—There are different authorities and different opinions, and the committee's report reflects them. In relation to the treating of conduct as an offence under this bill when it is not an offence in the place where it is committed, the committee took the view, quite legitimately in my view, that the primary focus ought to be in the country where the conduct occurs. To create an offence abroad for conduct committed within a country is to send the wrong message. The primary purpose would be to ensure that the legislation in each of the relevant countries is in appropriate form. I accept that there is a different view on that which the minister has expressed and it is not proposed to take it any further.

PARA.TAB: I do not propose to comment any further on any detail, but there is one point I would mention. Prior to the sitting of this Main Committee on this bill there was circulated, albeit on a limited basis, a composite bill which incorporated the government's proposed amendments. That was a very useful document. I would commend that practice to the minister as useful. It would be even more useful if it were circulated further in advance and were more readily available.
Amendments agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.

PARA.TAB: That the bill, as amended, be reported to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 3 March 1994:

PARA.TAB: Has the Government reviewed the capital structure of the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC) in response to the recommendations of the Prices Surveillance Authority in its report on FAC charges; if so, what was the result of the review.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: The Government considered the outcome of the review of the FAC's capital structure, recently undertaken by a Steering Committee of Commonwealth officials from the Departments of Transport, Finance and Treasury. The Government also considered the recommendations arising out of other recent reports, including those by the Taskforce on Regional Development, the Prices Surveillance Authority and the Industry Commission.

As announced by the Prime Minister in the `Working Nation' statement, the Government has decided to introduce reforms to improve the FAC's investment and pricing decisions, to develop an ownership-neutral regulatory regime for airports and to conduct a scoping study into the possible sale of the Corporation's airports. The Government is proposing to sell all FAC airports over the period 1995-96 to 1997-98, subject to the outcome of the scoping study and to the necessary amendments to the Labor Party Platform.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 23 March 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Did the Federal Airport Corporation (FAC) in its submission in 1992 to the inquiry by the Public Works Committee into the stage 1 development of the airport at Badgerys Creek state that it was difficult to forecast passenger levels at the second airport with any certainty as it was almost impossible to predict the responses of airlines and passengers to severe congestion at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport and the alternative of using a second Sydney airport at Badgerys Creek.
(2) Has the FAC forecast a specific date by which demand at Badgerys Creek would warrant the construction of an international airport; if so, on what basis.
(3) Has the FAC updated its forecasting methodology and results for Badgerys Creek Airport since it made its submission to the Public Works Committee.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brereton The Hon L.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Federal Airports Corporation (FAC) has provided the following answer.

PARA.TAB: (1) In its submission to the Public Works Committee in 1992 the FAC stated:

"It is not possible to confidently predict the amount of aircraft traffic which will be attracted to a new and uncongested airport at Badgerys Creek. Components of the demand could include the following: scheduled passenger flights; charter services; instrument landing training; carriage of large or small freight items and express overnight parcel services. As stated earlier, the enhancement of capacity at Sydney Airport will mean that the market will not support the operation of Badgerys Creek as a major passenger airport before about the year 2010. However, it is anticipated that there will be a gradual increase in the number and size of aircraft using Badgerys Creek in the intervening years."

(2) No. The Corporation's view has always been that the timing of the development of Badgerys Creek would be driven by the level of demand in the Sydney Basin. According to the Environmental Impact Statement conducted for the parallel runway at Sydney, Badgerys Creek Airport would be viable in the long term when there were at least 25 million passenger movements at Sydney Airport and that by the time that Sydney Airport reached 30 million passenger movements, Badgerys Creek would have two million passenger movements. The Corporation's central forecasts, published in July 1993 show that Sydney Airport will reach 30 million passengers around 2010. This timing may change (either up or down) in subsequent forecasts depending on trends emerging in traffic growth.

(3) Forecasts, being predictions, are by their very nature imperfect. The Corporation is constantly reviewing and revising its forecasting methodology to ensure the forecasts are as accurate as forecasts can be. The Corporation updates its forecasts every year due to changes in the key economic variables affecting passenger and aircraft movements and developments in the industry. This may affect the indicative timings the Corporation originally provided to the Public Works Committee.

While the Corporation uses its forecasts for capital expenditure planning, making it important that they are not over optimistic, it is equally important for the forecasts not to be over pessimistic as this would lead to the Corporation failing to meet its primary objective of providing for Australia's airport needs.

The Corporation does compare the performance of its short term central forecasts against the actual growth in passenger movements. In general terms, the Corporation's short term central forecasts have tracked actual growth in passenger movements at all of the Corporation's airports reasonably well over the past six years. The performance of the Corporation's central forecasts in international passenger movements for 1992/93 can be seen in the following table which shows that actual growth in international passenger movements showed little variance from the forecast.

The acceptability of the Corporation's forecasts is further demonstrated by the fact that in the last two years, Cairns Airport and all the New Zealand International airports requested to join the Corporation's forecasting process.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 3 May 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) What projects has the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC) commissioned from Access Economics since 1988.
(2) What did each project cost.
(3) Which of these projects was the subject of a publicly competitive process, such as tenders or expressions of interest, before each was awarded.
(4) For projects which were not subject to a competitive process, why was the work awarded to Access Economics.
(5) Is he able to say who are the owners of Access Economics and whether any of those persons have been employees of the FAC.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: The Federal Airports Corporation (FAC) has provided the following answer.
(1) The Corporation has commissioned one project from Access Economics a study entitled Airport Demand Impact of the 2000 Summer Olympic Games—Will Sydney's Airport Capacity Cope With The Games?.

While the Corporation produces a set of passenger and aircraft movements growth forecasts on an annual basis, and the short term forecasts have tracked actual growth in international passenger movements very well over the past few years, the Corporation commissioned Access Economics to provide an independent set of passenger and aircraft movements forecasts to ensure an appropriate level of traffic was taken into account in the Corporation's planning for the year 2000 Olympic Games.
(3) None.

(4) Access Economics was commissioned directly due to their acceptance in the market place as one of Australia's leading economic forecasters. In addition, Mr Geoff Carmody, a principal of Access Economics, is recognised as one of the country's leading tourism analysts.
(5) The owners of Access Economics are Mr Geoff Carmody, Mr David Chessell and Dr Edward Shann, none of whom have been employees of the FAC.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 3 May 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has the Federal Airports Corporation employed lobbyists in 1994; if so, in each case, what was the (a) name of the lobbyist and (b) purpose and cost of the work.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Federal Airports Corporation (FAC) has provided the following answer:
The FAC has not engaged any lobbyists in 1994.

(a) In July 1993, the FAC engaged the services of Hill and Knowlton's General Manager—Canberra, Mr Col Parkes, a registered lobbyist, to monitor the Canberra scene on any issues relating to the FAC, particularly its involvement with Parliamentary committees. The terms of the on-going engagement expressly exclude lobbying activities.
(b) The cost of Hill and Knowlton's engagement has been $10,007 to date.

(2) All lobbyists must be registered in a Register of Lobbyists, which is maintained by the Department of Administrative Services. (2) Land access studies already underway are required to examine rail options to service Sydney West Airport. These will have to take into account provision for rail access to the airport terminal area.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 4 May 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Does the Minister's Department follow a "Buy Australian" program; if so, (a) when was the program introduced and (b) what sum was spent in advertising and promoting the program in (i) 1988-89, (ii) 1989-90, (iii) 1990-91, (iv) 1991-92 and (v) 1992-93.
(2) What sum was spent within the Minister's Department on Australian made and overseas produced goods in (a) 1988-89, (b) 1989-90, (c) 1990-91, (d) 1991/92 and (e) 1992/93.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Department does not have a "Buy Australian" program in relation to the purchase of goods. The Department follows the policies outlined in the Department of Administrative Services Commonwealth Procurement Guideline No 12, Australian and New Zealand Supplies. The Department also uses contracts arranged by the Department of Administrative Services for common use items such as computing equipment.

(2) The Department's recording systems do not record where goods are manufactured either Australian made or goods produced overseas. To collect and assemble such information would be a major task and I am not prepared to authorise the resources and effort involved in assembling such information.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Justice, upon notice, on 31 May 1994:

PARA.TAB: Has the Australian Protective Service in Victoria bought any playground equipment; if so, (a) why, (b) what items were bought, (c) from whom were they bought and (d) what was the cost.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: No. However, the Australian Protective Service, in its role in managing the day-to day operations of the Immigration Detention Centre in Maribyrnong on behalf of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has facilitated the purchase by that Department of some recreational and related equipment for use by detainees.
(a) not applicable
(b) not applicable
(c) not applicable
(d) not applicable

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 1 June 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) How many post-doctoral fellowships were offered through the Australian Research Council in (a) 1993 and (b) 1994.
(2) How many applicants were there in (a) 1993 and (b) 1994 for the fellowships referred to in part (1).

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: There are four categories of fellowships offered through the Australian Research Council:
Australian Postdoctoral Research Fellowship
Australian Research Fellowship
Queen Elizabeth II Fellowship
Senior Research Fellowship
(1) There were 50 Australian Postdoctoral Research Fellowships offered in 1993 and 50 in 1994.
(2) There were 516 applicants in 1993 and 529 in 1994.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 7 June 1994:

PARA.TAB: What are the (a) cost of corporate services, (b) running costs and (c) percentage of corporate services costs to running costs for 1994-95 in each agency for which the Minister has portfolio responsibility.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (a) The Department's estimated running costs expenditure for corporate services (sub-programs 6.1 and 6.2) in 1994-95 is $137,170,000.

(b) The total estimated running costs for the portfolio for 1994-95 is $1,201,709,000. This figure includes $5,788,000 estimated to be deemed to be appropriated. Deemed appropriations are attributed to sub-program 6.1 and have been included in the totals in (a) above.
(c) The percentage of corporate services running costs to total portfolio running costs is 11.4%.
